fields.title: First Entry
fields.text: Well, this is my first entry in this little web project of mine. I hope to add to this list of entries every couple days or so. The few of you who will frequent this site (that means you, mom and dad!) will be able to have a little window into my life. Fortunately for me, the window you will be looking through will be tinted with the exact color that I wish, since I will be creating them. You will just have to deal with that, and just in case you are a little short on time, you can just read the boldface type and get the gist of what I am trying to say. So everyone have a nice day, be sure to give your elders respect, be frugal with your money, and look to the future. That's it for me, ta ta for now.

fields.title: The Feast of the Hunter
fields.text:
Well, this past weekend was the annual Feast of the Hunter's Moon festival at Fort Ouiatenon, West Lafayette. The Feast is an annual event that recreates a 18th century French-Indian trading post that was in this area. Many many people (something like 45,000 this year) come to the festival from all over the country to see interesting things and sample interesting foods. Many of the people come dressed up in period clothing, dressed as 18th century traders and voyageurs (look it up). Since I was here at Purdue (just down the Tippecanoe river from Fort Ouiatenon), I went to the Feast with my family.

I have gone to the Feast for several years now, and the same sort of thing always seems to happen to me. Once I get over the initial shock of seeing so many weird people wearing weird things all at once, and I stop trying to look cool, I begin to see just how little there is to do. The whole event is spread out over an area about the size of two football fields, and most of it is devoted to campers who go to stay the entire weekend. About half way through the thing, however, I realize that it's not about doing stuff and seeing stuff, but it is actually just about simply being. It's just about being part of the whole experience. I don't care where I go or what I do, because I feel like part of a community, like I grew up and live with all of the weird people everywhere. Eventually I can ignore all of the stroller pushing suburban families who do nothing but complain and get in the way (their children all have fake wooden swords and rifles).

Everywhere you go the whole weekend, there may not be anything to do, but something is happening. People are singing, or cooking something, or doing some sort of presentation. We heard a great song about the various amputational sacrifices that one must make to become a pirate. We had delicious handmade apple dumplings. We saw some Irriquois presenting an example of their native dance. It was a chance to escape the homework and ego bashing that is College, and go to a different time and place. At least for a while.

I had a great time with my parents, too.

fields.title: Games, Delayed
fields.text:
I just got word that Half Life 2, possibly the most advanced game ever, is finally finished, and will be coming out on November 1st. I am extermely excited about it, but I am also a little worried. The game was originally scheduled for release on September 30th, 2003. That's a long time to wait for a game, not knowing just when it will come out. The real problem is that this is not a rare case. Most games are delayed, and most of those are delayed by an incredible ammount. Duke Nukem Forever, the proposed next game in the Duke Nukem series (extremely intellectual games), was supposed to be released some time in 1997. DNF is still not out yet, and the developers have no idea when it will be released.

Other games, like Daikatana had similar fates. However, when they finally did come out, they were horrible games, destroyed by the hype that came up because of the delay. Whenever a huge game is delayed, the game is surrounded with so much hype that it could not possibly live up to expectations.

I have two comments to give about this. First is what will happen to Half Life 2? I have no question about it's success (it is the sequel to the game that most people consider to be the greatest game of all time, and it looks simply breathtaking, so there is no question that it will sell), but will it be a good game? I have preordered my copy already, and I have watched the E3 videos on a regular basis. Am I getting too pumped for this game? Movies can have the same effect happen, too. Just look at Star Wars: Episode 1 (hey, I loved it, but a lot of people didn't). Am I destined to be dissapointed by Half Life? Only time will tell.

My other comment is this: how can they justify a delay of this magnitude? When was the last time the creators of a movie decided to delay the release an entire year, just a week before it is scheduled to be released? You don't see commercials on Fox for a new show, only to learn that it won't be on till the season after next (well, maybe that was a bad example). Should the game industry be allowed to hold the carrot in front of our noses for so long? For the most part, the games themselves are really the only things that get hurt, so one would think that developers would care enough to wait a little while before announcing a game.

Maybe I am jumping the gun a little bit. PC Gamer has reviewed Half Life 2, and gave the game the highest score to date: 98%. Perhaps it's not that bad after all, hype or no hype.

fields.title: Four More Years?
fields.text:
The guys next door to me have a mock Time Magazine cover on there door that has a picture of George Bush, and the phrase 'We're F**ked' underneath it (with the asteriks). That about sums up my opinion.

I voted in my first presidential election two days ago, and I must say that it one of the funniest ordeals in my life (and not in the good way). I will express my disgust and rage at the government here, where all can enjoy and be enraged by it. I will go ahead and throw my oppinions and frustrations into the fray with the hundreds of other web complaints out there. Bush must not surf the internet much.

I will try to stay away from just saying what everyone else has been saying for four years now. All that stuff about Bush lying, cheating, and stealing his way through the United States. Oh, well I guess I did say it. That's not my point, though. I have a series of ideas (read: crazy schemes) that I think would make this country a better place to live in. But first, I will tell my story.

I woke up on Tuesday refreshed and ready for a day's hard work, coding my next web project (read: computer games). I sat down in my desk chair, and remembered that it was Election Day. Whoopie!! For the first time in my life, I finally had a voice. I could finally express what I felt for all these years with a simple hanging chad. I hurredly got on my bicycle and rode off to Cary (Ironic? perhaps) Quadrangle, the local (read: only) polling place on the Purdue Campus. I left in such a hurry that I forgot to take my registration card, or a book to read (you'll see why that was a problem later in my epic story).

So I get to Cary (I still think that's a little weird), and follow the My Man Mitch signs to the small door that leads to the small room in the basement where an entire college campus was to vote. You may be starting to see my problem. I crammed myself inside, squeazing past the pseudo-line to get shelter from the drizzling rain that had gotten my bike seat all wet during the night. I figured that it wouldn't be too long, judging from past election days and the primaries that I have witnessed. I figured that voting was a smooth, quick process that only takes a few moments per person, so although the line was long, it would move fast.

I couldn't have been more wrong.

I heard rumors up and down the line of the 15 minute wait. The 30 minute wait. THE 45 MINUTE WAIT. And, with a hushed voice, the horrible, legendary monster: the hour long wait!!!! **gasp**

Damn, I thought, I should have brought my book to read in line. Oh, well, I can just strike up a conversation with this really attractive (read: hot) girl in front of me.

I didn't strike up a conversation with the hot girl in front of me. She was studying, and I - um - didn't want to - uh - bother her. Yeah, that's it.

Anyway, that hour long wait would have been nice. We waited and waited, the hot girl and I, and it seemed like my whole adult life was going to be spent standing in line. It didn't really seem that bad (I went to the Star Wars Celebration 2, where I actually did spend most of the time in line). It was annoying, however, because I just wanted to throw my vote away and get out of there.

As we got closer to the little doorway of hope, we could see that people were spending up to ten minutes voting. 'What, did they add an essay question this year? What's taking so long?' I said in the best smart-ass college student attitude I could muster. The students around me, who are used to essay tests, all laughed. We started chatting.

As it turns out, the board of elections only sent three voting booths to Purdue University. Three booths were to support an entire campus of hyped up, hip, voting college students. What were they thinking? The guy in charge said that they didn't expect many voters, with the small turn out at the primaries. Okay, am I the only one who finds that stupid? First of all, the primaries are really worth nothing, at least this year. Secondly, didn't he see Purdue's own newspaper, which has reported record numbers of registered students this year? How could anyone in their right mind possibly think that three booths are enough for a giant campus of unruly students?

My only consolation is that they gave us stickers when we voted. Yes, that makes it all worth it: a sticker that says 'I voted.' Joy. The guy behind me was annoyed because he got a pin four years ago. 'They must have spent all of their money on voting booths' I said with a chuckle. Everyone laughed again. I wish someone important heard that. Or the hot girl.

So after two of those monsterous hour long waits, I finally got to vote. I was a little worried that without my registration card I wouldn't be able to vote, and all that wasted time would be - well - wasted. Actally it was not a problem. All I needed was my expired learner's permit (yep), and I was able to fully waste my vote by writing in 'RALPH NADER.' Indiana has voted Republican since God knows when, so it wouldn't matter just who I voted for. A vote for NADER is a vote for BUSH as far as Indiana is concerned.

I didn't even get to vote for the gay marriage issue.

So, yeah. The United States voting system has some serious problems. I heard that later in the day students were waiting upwards of five hours to vote. CNN had already colored Indiana in with red before some of my friends were even able to cast their vote. That's just not right.

So just to make my opinion really heard, I am going to list my ideas for how to make the US electoral system better. Here they are, in no paticular order:

  • No person's vote should go uncounted. Why should we continue to work with a system that was invented for a nation of ignorant illiterates. I don't want some 'electoral college' voting for me. I want my vote counted. The popular vote means absolutely nothing when you get right down to it. Somebody has to agree with me on that one.
  • More voting booths Wouldn't too many voting booths be better than too few? Honestly. I would even forgoe my sticker, if it means that I don't have to wait for two hours.
  • We need another party Simple as that. We need another party. I am sick of the Republocrats running everything. Somebody needs to step up. Libertarians? Greens? Hell, even the Communist party would be a refreshing change of pace.
  • The parties that exhist need better candidates Well, that's probably not going to happen, but I think that the Democrats could have done better than Kerry. The Republicans could probably have done better than Bush, too. When your candidate can't even explain his point clearly, you have a problem. When your candidate can't even express a thought clearly, you have a problem also. Try somebody else. Al Sharpton? I wish.
  • Have more faith in the system At the very least, have faith in the system. My problem is that I was told that they didn't expect many voters, so they didn't plan for a large croud. 'We didn't think that we would have many voters.' Not with that attitude, you won't!
  • A new voting system When America's Idol gets ten times more voters than the Presidential election, that's a problem. I know, I know. America's Idol is very different than the Presidential election, but we could still learn from it. How about a show where all of the presidential candidates (all of them. Dean, Kerry, Al Sharpton, Bush, Nader, everyone) live together in a house, and every week the American people vote one off until only one remains? I would tune in to see that. It could be on Fox! Imagine the possibilities! It would be better than 'Amish in the City' at least.
  • No multible terms How can Bush be allowed to spend half of his term campaining for the next one? If Presidents are allowed only one term at a time, they would get a lot more work done, and be much more willing to give a crap. Maybe.

    • All I know is that the Government ows me 2 hours. I don't know how I want them paid back to me yet, but I will think of something. Also, that internship that I was pondering at Relic entertainment (in Canada) is look more inviting every day. Both people I have told that to asked me the same smart-assed question: 'So you don't care about the high taxes?' No. I don't, thank you. If if means that I can go about my life without Big Brother looking over my shoulder, then no I don't mind the taxes. Jesus. Whatever. I am not going to go on about the mess that this country is in (that's what the other web complaints are for), just the electoral system.

    There are probably more things to add to that list, but my rant is getting really long as it is, and I have homework to do. I would love to hear some feedback on some of this, but since I have no audience, it may not happen too soon.

fields.title: Metaphor
fields.text:
Things can change very quickly. I'm not really talking about anything in paticular, just things. Complicated things. Like, for example, when you are being chased by a bear. A big bear, maybe a grizzly. It just keeps chasing you relentlessly knocking over everything in its path. Whenever you think that you are away from the beast, it breaks through the brush behind you, ready to maul you completely. You run and you run, trying to escape the bear. You didn't do anything to it; it found you. Okay, so maybe you gave it a steak, which has given it the taste for blood, and now it wants to try something a little more gamey. You cast off everything that might lure the bear. The beef jerky in your pocket that you were saving for later. The bottle of bear pharamones that you used to lure the bear in the first place. You even give up your bear skin hat, thinking that perhaps the bear was wanting revenge. You turn to face the bear, thinking that you might be able to scare it away. I just keeps lumbering down upon you, and your fear makes you run. You get very tired. You think that you can't go on any more, and the bear will surely catch you and maul you at any moment. You just want to be rid of the bear forever; you just want to have peace. With your last ounce of strength, you climb a tree. You pull yourself up into the tree with all of your might. The stray branches cut your skin, and the action strains your muscles, but you keep climbing without caring about the pain. Finally, you think you are safe. You relax, and then you look down. The bear begins to climb the tree after you. There is no escape now. You jump down, climb out of the tree, and await your doom. The bear looks into your eyes, you feel its breath against your face. It reaches up its paw and leaps at you. With a great force, you fall to the ground, the bear on top of you. This is it, you think. The bear has you. You hope it kills you quickly. The bear's head gets closer. It opens its mouth. It licks your face. It just wanted to thank you. You now have a new friend.

See? Things can change very quickly. First you think that the bear is going to kill you, but then it turns out to be your friend after all. Metaphor.

I feel really Taoist right now. I think I will change my quote.

fields.title: New Year
fields.text:
And another thing:

I think that I got my housing situation planned out for next year. I will be living in one of the larger rooms here at Meredith Hall. They are pretty nice: private bathroom, a comfortable ammount of space, high speed internet, everything a guy like me needs. I hope to room with my current next door neibor, Barry Schatz. Or maybe Chris Fancher (he's looking over my shoulder right now). He always jingles his keys from a lanyard, which is getting a little tattered. Anyway, I think that it will be pretty good for Scott and I to take a break from constantly seeing each other. We really catalyze many of each other's problems. Don't get me wrong, he's awesome, and I love him, but we have our flaws, just like every relationship in the universe.

I have spent the entire weekend working on my second web project for CGT 141. This web site is about Tron, and it will probably never see the light of day. It's okay, nobody cares about Tron. You can check my projects page if you really care that much. I may put it up locally, but only if I get at least 20 e-mails from fans recommending that I do so. Ha. Take that.

I love the movie Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind. It's great how it doesn't just show relationships as perfect. They, like everything else in the universe, have flaws. It's not just a perfect love story. The music is great, too. I - um - bought the soundtrack, and it makes me cry every time. I can't listen to it; it's too much. No, I actually just had something in my eye. Yeah, that's it. right.

CLEMENTINE: I wish you'd stayed.
JOEL: Me too. I wish I had done a lot of things. I wish I'd. . . I wish I'd stayed.

I wish I'd stayed, too. I'm sorry.

fields.title: You know what sucks?
fields.text:
You know what sucks?

Crashing on your bike. Landing on your face, and your hand. Your writing hand. On concrete. Wearing a heavy backpack (which does crash into the back of your head). Yeah. That sucks big time. I am wincing as I type this, because I have lost some skin on my left hand, and I will soon have a massive bruise on my elbow. I broke my front reflector on my bike, scraped up the front of my handlebars, and almost broke my watch. Yeah, that sucks. I have a freaking scratch on my chin. I can only hope that people think that it's acne. Yeah, that sucks. Damn curb.

Oh, well. I am still alive, and no bones are broken (I think). I get to play Half Life 2 tonight, so everything should turn out okay.

When it happened, I just wanted to lay there for a while. Let my head stop swimming. Let the pain catch up to me. It turns out that you can't do that when you fall down. If you don't get immediately up and ride off, people think you're dead. That might end up being a problem. Therefore, it's best to just hop back on that bike, and ride off. As I rode off, I thought about that Neosporin commercial (the one where the kid crashes on her bike, and her mother gives her some neosporin). That kid had a big cut on her chin (much bigger than mine, so it could be worse). It really made me think about neosporin commercials, though. They always show comparisons of cuts with neosporin and without, and they are identical cuts. How the hell do they do that? Do they pay people to get scarred for life, or is it makeup? I don't know which is worse.

Just makes you think. . .

fields.title: Half Life 2
fields.text: I suppose that I should comment on Half Life 2. I have spent a good amout of time on the game, and I can tell you that it is one of the greatest games ever made. It makes Doom 3 look pointless. It plays like a feature film, and grips you like nothing I have ever seen, books, TV, movies, and theatre included. It is probably the first game that actually convinces me that I am in a different place. The graphics are so amazing, that I feel the world that I am in. The story is extremely engaging, and the facial animations of the characters really makes me believe that they have their own emotions and feelings. It is an amazing spectacle. Half Life 2 is the dawning of a new age of computer games. It gives you a glimpse at the limitless possibilities that computer games have. Instead of simple diversions, games could be glorious works of art, comperable to any movie, and much more engaging. It's a testament to the power that computers have. Now, if you will excuse me, I will get back to my game.

fields.title: Giving Thanks
fields.text:
Okay, so Thanksgiving was great. Here's the scoop:

Check out the rest of my site, too, because I made a bunch of little tweaks, changes, and I have hidden lots of cool suprises.

I remember the drawn out Thanksgiving hype that I was forced to engage in in elementary school. I remember the story (probably mostly untrue) about the 'Pilgrims' having a feast with the 'Indians'. I remember the story of the Mayflower and her uneventful voyage to religious freedom. The weird thing about this Thanksgiving is that I live on a college campus, and I live here with several foreign students. I think that most Americans take for granted the fact that we are the only group who celebrates the holiday. One of my foreign friends asked me what Thanksgiving was all about. It made me think about kindergarten. I was suprised that I was telling someone the story, instead of someone telling it to me. Yet a vast majority of humans don't even know it exists.

Then I went home

THE DOG My parents got this new dog. It's a mix between a rotweiler and a groundhog. No, actually it's rotweiler/german shepherd, but it does look like a groundhog. It likes to chew. It especially likes to chew on people. Hopefully it will get past that and realize that it really hurts when a dog chews on you. His name is Theadore Edward Bear, or Ted E. Bear for short. Or Tedward, for really short.

THE FAMILY The four of us went up to Lafayette for thanksgiving day. My mom's mom lives there, so we weren't just going to Purdue for thanksgiving. We ate at this huge Thanksgiving banquet that some place has every year. It was really good food, and I wish that I could have eaten more, but I have just had less and less appetite lately. It really made me mad that I wasn't able to eat as much as I wanted. Oh well, that's a different story. After we left Grandma's house at about 4 PM, we headed to my Dad's brother's house for the other half of Thanksgiving.

On the way there, we almost got in a huge crash with a car that was running a stoplight (we had a green light). They looked at us like they were extremely mad at us, and when we drove around them, they turned across several lanes of traffic and started tailing us! They were about six inches from our back bumper, and if it wasn't for my father's excellent action movie quality driving skills, they would have probably pulled out various assault rifles and shot us to pieces. It was a very weird experience for a Thanksgiving evening.

We finally got to Uncle Dan's house, and everyone had already finished eating. We were really late because we were at my other Grandma's house all day. My uncle flew in from California, and my other uncle drove in from Denver, so everyone was there. All seven siblings of the McGill family, their spouses, and children. It was a wild several hours. I talked to some of my relatives, but unfortunaltely I wasn't able to really talk to most of them. The space was limited, and so are my slowly-developing social skills right now. Most of the time was spent playing wild and crazy games of improvosation with all of my cousins (there are many). It was a lot of fun. I hadn't seen my cousins from California in about six years, and I hardly recognized them; I also hadn't seen my cousins from Denver in a while. I went to Denver a couple summers ago, and I had a great time with Sean and Lake, my cousins. It was great just goofing around with everyone.

A couple days earlier, I was watching Oprah and Jim Carrey was on. He is one of my idols, and for a while I wanted to be just like him when I grow up. I find it so amazing that he can do funny things just non-stop. As I watched the show, I wished that I could be that funny all the time. While we were goofing around at Dan's house, I realized that I was that funny with them. To my cousins (who are all younger than me by quite a bit), I am Jim Carrey. Whenever I feel bummed out, like nobody likes me, all I have to do is remember that with that group of people, I am a celebrity. From all of my cousins looking up to me (well, they literally do, I am 6'8' after all), to all of my uncles and aunts interrested in my computer animation work, I feel so wanted. Everybody needs something like that. I can't wait till Christmas so I can see all of them again.

People were at our house from Wednesday night, all the way to Saturday night. It was nonstop action. It was one of the greatest weekends ever.

THE INCREDIBLES I also got a chance to watch The Incredibles, the new movie from Pixar. As somebody who does computer animation, paticularly skeletal character animation, I can tell you that it is the most amazing movie ever made. Pixar was able to capture every nuance, every little detail about each character. The animation was the greatest piece of work that I have ever seen. The graphical detail was also superb. The hair was amazing, the shadows an lighting was perfect, the models were spot-on, the voice acting was excellent, etc. etc. It really is quite Incredible. Now my parents are going to drag me to the Polar Express, which looks stupid. It just looks like the creators wanted to show how cool computer graphics are. In every clip I have seen about that movie, somebody's doing a backflip. They need a decent story before they can create a good movie. Plus they cheated.

All of my relatives watched the movie with me, and after it was over, they started asking me all sorts of questions about how it was done. Being a freshman in Computer Graphics I didn't really know, but I was able to make up enough stuff that sounded right! I also want to mention that every time the HP commercial comes on where the guy has picture frames and they magically have pictures of him in them, my relatives ask me how they did that. I think I know, but I can't really explain it too well. It gets a litle annoying after a while.

THE RETURNWhen I finally got back to school, I wished that I could just stay home, where every one loves me, and I have a great time all the time. The problem is that life isn't always like that. Usually, life consists of being made fun of and always trying way too hard to keep your dignity. For me anyway. I constantly have to have an argument like 'No, the GeForce 6800 isn't as good as the x800 XT!' or 'yeah, that nForce 4 is going to rock' or whatever. Everything is a posturing battle of pontification. Maybe the problem is that I don't really have any friends outside the dorm, or maybe the problem is that I don't have a girlfriend. I don't know. fields.title: I feel like crap
fields.text:
I feel like crap

I just played my first game of Wallyball (volleyball in a raquetball court). It was awesome. I don't know if it was the cold outside, or the physical excersize, or the fact that I have a slight cold, or the fact that I haven't gotten enough sleep lately, or a mixture of all of them, but I really felt bad when I got back from the game. I wanted to lie down, but I couldn't because my bed is too hard to climb into (when you feel really bad). I was walking to the bathroom, and I started to loose my grip on reality. I shut my eyes.

Like a dream, I heard something collapse on the floor. As I layed there in the middle of the hall, the world swimming around me, I just wondered what was going to happen next. First, I had to find out why I was on the floor, which was easy when I coupled the collapsing noise with the fact that I was, in fact, collapsed. Then I had to start thinking about moving somewhere else. I didn't want to get up, but as I have said in earlier posts, you absolutely cannot stay on the ground when you fall down, otherwise people will think that you are dead. The thing is, though, that I was actually in physical duress, and I might have needed actual help. At what point is it okay to stay collapsed? When I am actually dead? At any rate, I was able to acheive enough cohesion to realize that someone opened the door at the end of the hall, so I looked up at them, and sort of wiggled to the side. You know, like it was completely normal that I was laying in the hallway. This might be a problem for me. Even when I am collapsed in the hallway, I still have to worry about my environment. I knew that no matter what, I had to go somewhere else. Luckily I was recomposed enough to say that my room was too warm, and it was more comfortable in the hallway. I was able to climb into my bed, and lie down. I am fine now. Fine enough, anyway. It was really wierd, though. Now I have to get ready to talk to my parents, who will undoubtedly freak out when they read this.

The Saturday night movie tonight is Master of Disguise (one of the worst/greatest movies ever). That will cheer me up.

I saw Garden State today. It is a really great movie. It shows Natalie Portman's amazing talents well. She is one of the most beautiful women in Hollywood. She is an amazing actress, she was in Star Wars, and she goes to an Ivy League school. That is really attractive. Anyway, the movie really made me rethink a lot of things about my life. The new plans are still forming in my mind (perhaps their complexity caused my mind to lock up earlier), perhaps the future will show new outlooks on life.

time for sleep now

fields.title: The Best Games of 2004
fields.text:
The year is up, and what a year it was for PC gaming. Two legends finally came out, and some interresting beauties came, starting new legends. To wrap things up, I will run down my pick for the year's best games (PC only). I also rant about Vampire: Bloodlines.

See the List here

First, the categorized list of genre toppers, assuming that one title can't take them all (because one pretty much could. . .):

Best Game
Half Life 2
Best Action Game
Doom 3
Multiplayer Game
Joint Operations: Typhoon Rising
and (tie)
Unreal Tournament: 2004
Strategy Game
Rome: Total War
Roleplaying Game
Sid Meier's: Pirates

Yeah, Half Life 2 could have swept the board. While thinking about it, I realized that there really weren't any good roleplaying games this year. That suprized me a little, considering that we usually get a couple D&D games at least.

And another thing, Vampire: The Masquerade: Bloodlines is a great game, except for the fact that it is full of bugs. It is the second game to have Half Life 2's source engine, and it shows just how much work went into polishing Half Life 2. Even the opening cutscene of Bloodlines was so full of bugs that all we can do is laugh at it. There are so many bugs, glitches, half-assed work, bsp holes, and annoyances that it turns a terrific game and terrific engine into a merely noteworthy B-level game. I almost hear Marlin Brandow saying 'I could'a been somebody, I could'a been a contender.' This game really could have been an amazing achievement. With the most powerful engine, very well developed gameplay, and an intriguing and twisting storyline, this really could have been a good game. If only they had taken an extra year to smooth out all the bugs. It's a shame, but also a good motivational example for games to come.

fields.title: Cars
fields.text:
Sometimes, I like to go to car dealerships and look at the Porsches, even though I will probably never have one. I will look around, find one I really connect with, and sit in it. I like to pretend that it's my Porsche, and I am driving down some back country road and enjoy the scenery. It makes me feel more driven, more motivated in life, like I have this Porsche that I need to worry about and make paments for. I pretend that I am driving around and showing off my nice car to all of my friends who don't have cars. I like to do all that, even though I will probably never have one.

A very major chapter of my life has closed. Several years ago, I wanted nothing but to be a professional actor. I gave that up, but I still loved performing. I actually promised people that I would get into the theatre department here at Purdue. I wish I hadn't now. I see what professional theatre is like. It's distilled, taken down to it's root elements. It's examined, picked apart, and looked at with a mathematical eye. It is no longer an art, it is a science. I can't deal with that. It sucks. Would we take a Davinci apart like that? Someone probably has. I don't understand it. For me, theatre is a chance for me to have a place in society. It gives me a purpose. All too often in my life, I feel lost because I don't know what to say, or I don't feel like myself. When I perform, I know exactly what to say, and exactly who to be. Sometimes I feel like it's the only thing I do really well, but I can't do it, and will likely never again do it. I made a choice. I chose computer graphics over theatre. That was my decision, and it will turn out okay in the long run. Everyone has to leave the hundred-achre wood at some point. I now have to decide if I should drop the theatre minor, because it is totally not going to help me like I thought it would. Pain in the ass.

Then, suddenly again, Christopher Robin, who was still looking at the world, with his chin in his hands, called out 'Pooh!'

'Yes?' said Pooh.

'When I'm - when - Pooh!'

'yes, Christopher Robin?'

'I'm not going to do Nothing any more.'

'Never again?'

'Well, not so much. They don't let you.'

Pooh waited for him to go on, but he was silent again.

'Yes, Christopher Robin?' said Pooh helpfully.

'Pooh, when I'm - you know - when I'm not doing Nothing, will you come up here sometimes?'

'Just Me?'

'Yes, Pooh.'

'Will you be there, too?'

'Yes, Pooh, I will be, really. I promise I will be, Pooh.'

'That's good,' said Pooh.

'Pooh, promise you won't forget about me, ever. Not even when I'm a hundred.'

Pooh Thought for a little.

'How old shall I be then?'

'Ninety-nine.'

'I promise,' he said.

Still with his eyes on the world Christopher Robin put out a hand and felt for Pooh's paw.

'Pooh,' said Christopher Robin earnestly, 'if I - if I'm not quite - ' he stopped and tried again - 'Pooh, whatever happens, you will understand, won't you?'

'Understand what?'

'Oh, nothing.' He laughed and jumped to his feet. 'Come on!'

'Where?' said Pooh.

'Anywhere,' said Christopher Robin.



I wish someone would read this

fields.title: Sex can wait, Rasturbate!
fields.text:
I came across a really cool web site. It's called the 'rasturbator.' Before you start coming up with gross things that 'rasturbater' could mean, I will tell you. The site allows you to upload any picture of your choice, and it will blow it up, rasterize it (turn it into hundreds of little dots), and format it for print on a bunch of letter sized paper. We found a nice picture of Keira Knightley, and 'rasturbated' it (we had a lot of fun telling random people that we were rasturbating). I have some great pictures, if you will just

click here . . .

Ok, so there's this web site. It's called the Rasturbator, and it is totally cool. Any web site that lets my friends and I yell sexual innuendo that isn't really innuendo is an awesome web site. We needed something to liven up the hallway, because we were getting sick of the drab white walls, also the smell was getting pretty bad. 'Lets get some hot chicks and put them up on the walls,' we said. What we meant, of course, was 'Some artful posters would be a nice contrast to the shades of grey present in this environment.' We're always so concious of good design. 'Yeah, let's rasterbate (giggle) all over the wall (giggle).' Come on, we're 18 year old college guys, what do you expect us to say? We wanted to eventually have rasturbations (giggle) all up and down the hall, covering the entire hallway. How totally awesome would that be? Seriously. So we did a google image search for a good picture of Keira Knightley, who we all adore so much. Here's the image we selected:

Now, if this picture is offensive to anyone, please let me know. I didn't think it would be a problem, which is why I selected Keira for this thing in the first place. I didn't think anyone would be offended by pure un-flawed beauty, but, you know, it takes all kinds. I though anyone who had a problem with this picture had problems of their own, because beauty this pure should not cause that response. Anyway, we uploaded the image to the site, and made the measurements to come up with the size of the full image. The final rasturbation (giggle) ended up using 72 sheets of standard letter sized paper. We went on down to the computer lab (yes, you read that right) to print off the 72 sheets of pointillistic beauty. We got the whole thing to print, giggling at the lab assistant the whole time. Eventually our RA (we have a new RA named Zawar) came in and asked us what the hell we were doing, but we just giggled at him. We were a little freaked out when we realized that each sheet of paper was not printed to the edge (of course), so we would need to hand-cut every single sheet to get them all to the right size.

At this point, we had a pretty big group of people watching us, because it was a pretty cool thing, after all. We gathered up the bundle, and started taping it to the wall, right outside my room. Among the group of bystanders was a bunch of people from our hall, a few random girls, and Zawar himself (clear proof to us that we wouldn't get in trouble for it). The final measurement came out to 7'7' tall by about 4'6' wide. That's really big, by the way. Everyone who saw it thought it was awesome. People would walk though the hall, and right when they finished saying 'this hall smells like crap' they would see the poster, and then they would say 'wow, this hall is awesome.' Mission: accomplished? Unfortunately, not quite.

IMAGE BONANZA!!!!

Ok, so now the bad news. Zawar told us that as long as Jason (the head RA) is okay with it, it will stay. We all figured that it would be okay, because we made it through an entire day with no removal-order. Then at about 5 oclock, we get the bad news. Zawar told us that we need to remove it, but that we could talk to Jason about it. So we decided to talk to Jason about it. It was a lot of work and awesomeness to just tear down. Jason was an absolute asshole, though. He just flat out told us, 'it's coming down, no question, you're taking it down.' We guessed that he was in a hurry, and we decided to talk to him on Monday (it was Friday at the time). Later we get the order that it has to come down by Friday night. Mission: Failed. damn. First the men's sign, then the giant poster. What was his reasoning? It was a fire hazard, and could be offensive to someone. Right. As if. I ended up having to take it down, and I put it on my ceiling, over my bed (the only place large enough for it). So now I look like some kind of weirdo with this huge picture right over my bed, but whatever. It was fun, and it gave us something to do for a while. Immediately after I took it down, someone was walking through the hall, and wondered where it went. He doesn't even live here, but he was still mad that it came down.

fields.title: Make your own Dream
fields.text:
The cafeteria in Earhart hall serves a desert that they call 'make your own dream.' They have these lousy cheescake things, with an assortment of toppings. I looked at those toppings today, and I looked at that little sign they have. 'Make your own dream' is what it says. It belongs in one of those futile motivational books. The ones which only work because whoever is reading them decides to stop being an asshole and just live like a human is supposed to. 'Make your own dream' sounds like some tagline from a bad Britni Spears song. One of those purely commercial songs who's only purpose is to promote some new product. In the video, Britni would wear some skimpy outfit and be one of those assholes who needs a motivational book. 'Make your own dream' sounds like a slogan from an overused armed forces commercial. 'Make your own dream in the US Naval Marine Guard. Fight for fredom clearing beaches of empty beer cans and used condoms.' Why is it that people try to be motivational with stupid taglines like that, when the only useful application for it is a mediocre dessert. Of all the times anyone has ever said 'Make your own dream,' it has only made sense when it was delivered with canned strawberry-topping and crunched up heath bars. I made my own dream today with the toppings I chose, although I mostly just wanted plain cheesecake. I wish life were that easy. I wish that every time something crappy happens to someone, they can just sprinkle M&M's or canned strawberry-topping on it and make it their dream. Maybe the world would be a little stickier, but would that be so bad? How I wish life were that easy. I am in desperate need of a dream, like that one where Natalie Portman was in my kitchen at home. I would love for that to happen, just for the pure value of being able to meet Natalie Portman. Dreams come and go. They sneak up on me and confuse me. They excite me and they get my hopes up. They never come true. My dreams never come true. I can make all the dreams I want, but they will always just be dreams. Everytime I think a dream has finally happened for me, it ends up being lousy cheesecake covered with canned strawberry-topping.

Don't sue me, Britni

I am a blade of grass, wind cannot hurt me, I will only bend with it. The rain only strengthens my roots. The gardener cannot kill me, and in fact he helps me grow. fields.title: Hometown Politics
fields.text:
When I graduated from high school, I vowed that I would never return to that awful place. Don't get me wrong, Mt Vernon High School isn't the worst place in the world, it's just that high school wasn't my paticular cup of tea. I was so quick to forget high school, that I didn't even attend my own commencement, a fact that I doubt I will ever regret. The last thing I want is something that will make me start to worry about the trappings and chore of a high school student once again.

Imagine my suprise, then, when I found myself doing exactly that.

There's a hubbub going on in my hometown. It's a hubbub that threatens to consume the enire population in an epic stuggle, the likes of which haven't been seen since -- well, since the Bush administration came into office.

What could it be? Click here if you dare.

All of the schools in the east-central Indiana area are balooning up more than a Thanksgiving day Parade. These gigantic high schools are cropping up everywhere. It's insane, the amount of students that are moving to the area. Not to be outdone, Mt. Vernon school corporation has done some expansion of its own in the last couple years. To kick things off, Mt Vernon was proud to announce their new, multi-milion dollar football statium two years ago. They also just built a huge 'intermediate school' for just the 5th and 6th graders, further increasing the age seggregation of modern public schools. Currently under construction, the McCordsville elementary will add to the sepparation of students along town borders. Indeed, it would seem that the Superintendant, Dr. William Riggs will not stop until he has divided every student into a sepparate school, and sucked every last penny of tax money from the parents.

Oh, how I wish I was kidding.

It would seem that 'raising academic achievement for all students' includes the construction of multi-million dollar buildings. The administration announced late last year their plans for their capricious new additions for the 'old 'n busted' high school and existing elementaries. Included in this plan is a $60 million addition to the high school, a $27 million dollar addition to the two elementary schools, $16 million for a new gym, pool, and auditorium for the high school, a technology center, and a new bus garage. First off, the school system has an auditorium, a pool, a bus garage, and a whopping 7 gyms at its disposal already. I'm sorry if all of this seems a little redundant to me. The grand total for the whole project, according to the administration (and keep in mind that prices are very often not met, projects usually go over budget), is 136 million dollars. That does not include the two schools recently built, or the football stadium. Just to keep things in perspective, Conseco Fieldhouse, which is a multi-purpose arena for a professional basketball team, cost 174 million dollars (a difference of. . . 38 million dollars). Mt. Vernon school corp. services about 3,191 students, which is one of the smallest corporations in the area, whereas the Fieldhouse can seat 18,345. Maybe those two things don't really compare, but it's worth noting.

Big deal, you say. So what, you might scoff. A school is entitled to spend some money on 'raising academic achievement for all students' if it wants to. If you find yourself saying those things, you might just want to listen to this. The proposed addition, all told, will increase property taxes of everyone in the area an estimated 60 - 85 percent from current levels over the next six years. What are your property taxes, I ask. Say you owe about $1,100 every year (that's when you don't count that storage shed as another structure). If you happened to be living in the Vernon township area over the next six years, and this whole deal goes through, you could be owing another $935. That's almost a thousand dollars more that you will have to pay each year just for living in the Vernon township area. What if you have a hundred acres of farmland? What if you can't afford that? What if you don't have any children, and you couldn't care less about paying for Dr. Riggs's new gym?

According to Dr. Riggs himself: Tough Noogies.

Okay, that's not a direct quote, but it would be easier for him to just say that. If you live in that northern Hancock county area that is Vernon Township, you will have to pay those taxes, without question. The expansion plans went through the school board with a vote of 3-1 in favor, without even questioning the taxpayers opinion. Tough noogies, indeed. Dr. Riggs was so convinced that the plan would go through without problem that he didn't even make the effort to ask anyone their opinion. The plan was given with the voice of someone who has no uncertainty, no question about whether or not taxpayers will be willing to pay for it or not. What's worse is that it worked. The football stadium was getting boring, the intermediate school was already collecting dust. Riggs was bored, and wanted some new project to think about.

And what of those sad residents of Vernon Township who will have to pay for his new diversion? The residents, of which my parents are proud members, will be forced to deal with this plan. Or will they? A small band of residents, a Rebel Alliance if you will, has risen up and declared a remonstrance on the evil Mt. Vernon Empire. A petition has gone around collecting signatures of people who don't want to pay an additional 85% in property taxes. The petition has a very good chance of getting enough signatures. Two distinct factions have formed. The members of the remonstrance, and their blue forms are facing off against the proponents of the plan, and their yellow forms. It is an epic struggle between the 'blue forms' and the 'yellow forms.' Needless to say, the blue formers have a lot of strong information backing up their position. Like the Rebel Alliance of a long time ago, the blue formers just might win this war. I really hope that Riggs is shaking in his 'academic achievement' boots, because he's next. I hope he doesn't drop his beloved golden cross on his way out.

Why am I so up at arms about this? After all, I did promise myself that I wouldn't concern myself with that place any more. I don't go there anymore, and don't pay any property taxes. So what's the problem? My parents, though they have no more students to drag throught the gauntlet, still have to pay for the construction. That is money that they could be giving me! Seriously, though, this goes so much farther than Fortville, Indiana. Mt. Vernon's construction plan brings a whole new moral dilema to the game. Far more important than whether or not to allow the Ten Commandments in the classroom, far more important than capital punishment, is the concept of the business of public education. No longer does Mt. Vernon care about preparing students for the world, not that I really think they ever did. No, Riggs is far more concerned with 'raising personal wealth achievement for himself.' That is why I care, and why you should, too. If this plan goes through, how many more schools will follow this example?

I know I'm bitter. I know I went through Hell to fill Riggses' wallet. I know that with the proper application of adjectives, a web logger can make any subject look bad. Still, $1000 dollars a year for life is a large price to pay for a gratuitous gym. You can't argue with that.

For more information on the remonsterance, visit mvtaxpayers.org

fields.title: Life is good
fields.text:
Life is good.

It's really refreshing to have people -- well, peers -- who really care about me. Where I grew up, in school if you showed any sort of emotion at all, you were quickly tought that 'people do not behave like that.' Well, I am free from that, and I now have friends who truly care about me. Friends I truly care about. When I'm in an unhappy mood now, someone will actually talk to me about what's bothering me. My whole life, I always thought to myself, 'college is going to be so awesome,' etc. First semester, I wouldn't have agreed with it, but now I sure do. This past couple months has been the best couple months of my life. The only thing that could make this any better would be if Star Wars was coming out on my birthday again. OH WAIT, IT IS!!!!! Yeah, that totally r0xx0rz.

Seriously, though, the one real downside to this year is pretty blaringly obvious. I really miss my parents. They were always there for me. I could have intelligent conversations with them, without fear of them bashing my ego against the wall. I feel so bad about the fact that I haven't called them as much as I could have. I think the reason I haven't been thinking about them very much is that if I started thinking about it, I would really begin to realize how much I really do miss them. I miss eating breakfast with my Dad. I miss talking to my Mom about school. I miss playing 'trucks' with my Dad. I miss having Mom read books to me before I went to sleep. I miss my Dad's infinite and artistic craftiness. I miss my Mom's ability to write the perfect thing at any time. Now I'm starting to cry, see?

Well, I will have to look forward to this summer, because I will be working with my Dad and his amazing artistic skills, and I will be able to have intelligent conversations with my Mom again. Before I left, my Mom told me that I would be missing fresh eggs. I do, Mom. I do miss your chickens' eggs. I miss having eggs with every meal. Even though at the time I was annoyed with your writings and your various schemes, I would give anything to be able to hear what you are working on right now. Being away has really shown me how amazingly inteligent and wise you guys are.

I guess I'm at a junction in my life. I am starting to become more of a college student, a purely social individual. At the same time, I am feeling pain from being torn from my parents and my childhood.

What's my point? It's actually pretty simple.

I love my wonderful new friends. More importantly, I love my Mom and Dad.

You can check out some information about some of my friends (paticularly the ones in my hall) at Lord Ontario's web site. It's an irrelevant link. (on the left hand side of the screen)

fields.title: Robots Outmoded itself
fields.text:
My family and I went to see Robots last night. It was really a lousy movie, if you must know. I don't know why Newsweek would hail, 'the funniest movie of the year,' because it really wasn't that funny. Maybe it's just me, because I have a weird sense of humor. I never laugh at the show Family Guy, even when my friends around me are always cracking up. Even still, comedy does not make a movie, not by any means. I'm going to compare this movie to the Incredibles, which I don't agree with at all, but they started it (in their commercial), so they deserve it. I don't think that they are in the same league, so it's hard to compare them. Robots is not anywhere near the nuance or pure creativity of the Incredibles. The Incredibles is without at doubt the greatest animated movie of all time, in my opinion. It just barely edges out Monsters, Inc. I even consider it to be one of the greatest movies ever made, since it hardly feels like an animation. Robots, on the other hand, although their commercial would say otherwise, is not a decent movie at all. Why is that? What makes the Incredibles so much better than Robots? Absolutely everything.

Robots has a lousy, predictable script, stupid character development, and just bad planning. While watching it, I felt like it was more of a series of short animations than a whole movie. They threw in too many gags to have any sort of consistency in the characters. Also, where Pixar somehow seems to succeed in every movie they have made, Robots just seems way too cluttered. Pixar movies have a certain level of detail in every shot, but yet it never seems cluttered or overly complicated.

Unfortunately for Robots, one of its biggest strengths is also what makes it a bad movie. The animators went to great lengths to make it look spectacular, and indeed it does. Every scene has outstanding technology, from the huge scale transportation system to the extremely detailed domino sequence. The problem is that it just seems like the animators were showcasing the capabilities of whatever animation package they were using. This is the computer animator in me coming out, and I could go on about this movie for a while. I felt like I was at an expo, and some software company was showcasing their new physics system. Each scene of the movie felt like a sepparate short animation showcasing a different capability. The animators did things just because they could, not because it really helped the movie's plot at all (not that there was a plot to help).

I must say, though, that the design work, like the character models and the environments were extremely detailed and well done. The voice acting was also top notch, but that's what you would expect when a company spends more on the actors and design then they spend on the script.

As bad as Robots was, I will say that it was so much better than Shark Tale, or even Shrek, in my opinion. I thought both of those movies were terrible.

One important thing to say is this: before Robots, the theatre showed the new trailor for Episode 3. It's worth going just for that. George Lucas has taken a lot of space-flak for his prequels, and I feel terrible about that. I loved both Episode 1 and 2, and I'm sure 3 will blow my socks off (along with my feet). I am going to need to make a post about the prequels, because something needs to be said. Stay tuned.

fields.title: Lately by Aengus Finnan
fields.text:
I find myself lost. Just absolutely lost.

I can only try to regain control of my life.

Here I am, just a man, one of oh so many.
With coin in hand at this old wishing well.
And I don't know if I believe in making wishes, but something has me saying, only time will tell.
So I wish I was a breeze in summer. I'd wrap around you; I'd dance in your hair. And if for a moment you should chance to breathe me, I'd carry your voice till it filled the air.

Lately skies have me thinking about you.
On open roads I hear your voice, I have to turn, 'cause not one face or story, not one single song of glory has ever won back my heart from you.

I would I were a splinter of moonlight.
I'd come so softly, to fall on your bed.
I would bring you a map of dreamland, and I'd stay all night to watch o're your head.

And if in dreams I was a ship in the water I would be sturdy, I would be sound.
And I'd sail over any sea or ocean to the harbour of your love where I would lay my anchor down.

Lately skies have me thinking about you.
On open roads I hear your voice, I have to turn, 'cause not one face or story, not one single song of glory has ever won back my heart from you.

Well, here I am, just a man, one of oh so many.
With empty hands, dreams in my eyes.
And I'm not sure, if dreams get answered, but until then, there's open roads and open skies.

To tell the truth, no face or story, not one single song of glory has ever won back my heart from you.

This song sums up everything pretty well.

I know you won't probably ever see this. Still, it would be nice if you did. I know you think that I'm just a foolish kid, blinded by my false impressions of you. I just don't understand what you think I have wrong. I have a million reasons why I love you, most of which I don't even know or understand. I went there hoping to find something that would allow me let go, but I only found the opposite. I lost track of what I want to do with myself. I lost all purpose in my life. Maybe things will settle down and I will be fine in a little bit, but as I walk along these open roads, not one single thing will ever make me forget what an amazing person you are, and no one will ever win my heart from you. I don't feel like I was able to really tell you how I feel. I have all these thoughts that I wanted to express, but I couldn't express them. I wanted to tell you everything, but I couldn't put it to words. I must have told you 'like' or 'you know' like 500 times, you know? For a year, I would have given anything to be able to see you. Now, all I want is just to be able to never see you again. As it is, I will have to find my way down there again to get another few minutes to try. Another few minutes to try and express myself.

I don't know why I feel like this. I don't know what to do. Why do I always get the feeling like nobody really wants me around? I wish I could spend the rest of my life in her arms. Not because I love her, but because when she hugs me, for that moment, I stop feeling un-wanted. Any time I am with people, a part of me constantly tells me that they don't want me there. I wish I could spend the rest of my life hugging her.

She was the one who told me that when I go to college I won't have a real home anymore. Like everything she told me, it is profoundly true. I'm home for spring break, and I just feel like I am in the way. I feel like I am breaking up everyone's routine. Yet, I can't really call Purdue my home, especially now that I am having second thoughts about enrolling there.

I need to stop second guessing myself all the time. I need to stop thinking that I am so inferior to everyone else. I need to forget about her and move on. Right?

If you want to know why I love you so much, all you have to do is just give me a call. You can't ever do that, though, can you? I can't even be mad at you, because I understand and respect why you do everything you do. I need to just stop thinking.

I want the old days back, when I saw you every day and you laughed at my jokes even when you didn't immediately get them.

fields.title: I am NOT every student!
fields.text:
The other day, I was walking back from a class, and I noticed a sign on the sidewalk that said 'everystudent.com.' It was just an orange laser jet printing with white text, taped to the sidewalk with ordinary masking tape. I thought nothing of it. A lot of people tape signs to sidewalks on campus, and nobody pays much attention to them. Students just walk on them, and eventually those poor signs are ripped apart by the repeated stress of the students' unforgiving shoes. I occasionally see groundskeepers working frantically to scrape the tape off of the sidewalk, a futile gesture because more signs always come to replace their torn and trampled brothers. It's interesting that a major marketing scheme at Purdue relies on the knowledge that most students keep their heads down while they walk. The basic bowed head is commonplace, it seems. Anyway, that's a different matter. I saw this sign a couple days ago, and I wondered what 'everystudent.com' actually is. I assumed that it was some sort of student organization, to give students something to do besides drink and make out with each other. In my head, I saw students spending every second of free time surfing this 'everystudent.com' for some social fix that would keep them going another couple minutes. I immediately ignored the sign, like I do with most items of that nature. I have found that if I just ignore those types of people, they will ignore me. They will keep their heads down, and go on with their lives like they hadn't just seen a guy who actually has a different colored sock on each foot. It turns out that I wasn't completely wrong about 'everystudent.com,' but I did underestimate it by a grand margin.

Turns out, it's a cult.

I should warn you all that what I'm about to say will definitely offend a lot of you, so consider yourself warned. I don't want to get into any arguments about this, and I will not talk to anyone who just wants to tell me how wrong I am. So there.

Christianity is an interesting religion. It's one of the only religions to actually lead followers to kill people who don't believe in it. Nothing is more blunt than the Crusades. You can't deny that. A lot of people would say that the whole 9/11 thing is a result of religion, but it really isn't. People from another religion kill us, and so we immediately figure that it was because of that religion. Islam is not a violent thing. Christians were the ones who formed armies and went to the Middle East to slaughter anyone who gets in their way. That's pretty violent. The whole mentality still exists. When word got out that I am not a Christian in High School, people freaked out. I had people constantly trying to convert me. My Christian friends actually have a hard time being friends with someone who doesn't believe exactly what they do. I just don't understand that.

One of the most popular student committees here at Purdue is a group called 'Campus Crusade.' Yes, they are die-hard Christians, and no they don't slaughter people who stand in their way. At least we've gotten more civilized than that. These people, although I have lived with them mostly peacefully for my entire life, really scare me. The word 'cult' comes to mind. Here's where a lot of people are going to frantically run to their email providers and hit the 'caps-lock' key. I am entitled to my opinion, especially on the internet, so deal with it.

Today at dinner, everyone had a red t-shirt with the words 'everystudent.com' printed on the front.

Ok, so not everyone, but honestly a majority of the people in the dining hall had one of these shirts. My friends and I were just wondering what they meant. We started noticing more and more red shirts. At one point, I turned and a girl was walking past, so I was looking right at one of these shirts. I honestly screamed. I think it scared her, but I couldn't help it. It was really scary. Only a couple days ago I just heard of this thing, and now almost everyone has a t-shirt proclaiming that they are 'every student.' What the Hell does that even mean?

Well, I have since found out that these shirts are the workings of the campus crusade. That did not help abate my fears. I had a feeling all along that the crusade had their hand in this somewhere, and it turns out that they do. A glance at the web site doesn't help my fears, either.

Christianity seems to be the only religion that tries to stuff their ideals down non-believers' throats. One of the first things on their site is a link that says, 'Is There a God?' Their list of six 'straight forward' reasons to believe in God is all very ridiculous, in my opinion. What is their primary reason to believe in God? Throughout history, in all cultures of the world, people have been convinced there is a God. Basically, you should believe in God because everyone else does. I'm not an Atheist. I do believe in God, so I'm not discounting His existence. I am, however, refusing to believe in their reasons. Their reason to believe in God is like saying 'I believe in Darth Vader because the special effects in Star Wars are so good.' They say that God exists because the Bible says so. Whatever. I don't care.

They are entitled to believe what they believe, just like I am. However, I am not proclaiming my beliefs to be those of 'every student.' That is what offends me about this. I do not, and I will not, believe what they believe. Therefore, it cannot possibly be 'every student.' What about the high population of Muslims, Jews, and Hindus who go to Purdue? They are obviously a part of the pronoun 'every student.' They aren't Christian, though, so the entire thought that this is 'every student' is ridiculous. I really hope that Hillel (the Jewish student group) speaks up about this. Someone needs to speak up about this. Instead of worrying about the smoking ban (which will come into effect next year), we should worry about the Christianity problem. Freedom of religion, anyone? And for all of you people ready to click 'send' on your all-caps email, how about a little freedom of speech? I don't want to have to make t-shirts that say 'church = cult' or 'don't drink the koolade' but I will.

There are schools for Christian students, so you all can go to one of those if you want every student to believe exactly what you do.

fields.title: At Least I Still Have My Desire to Rant
fields.text:
I have been in the market for some nice general purpose. If anyone out there has some that they could give or sell me, please contact me and we can work something out. Any kind of purpose would do, really. Maybe you have some of your old childhood dreams that you don't mind parting with, I'll take those off your hands for you. Some nice purpose would really be great right now . . .

At Least I Still Have My Desire to Rant

Ok, so there really isn't much to say about my life right now. However, I do have a serious point that needs to be made. (I'll try not to cuss too terribly much)

Shut up about Star Wars.

Oh, I'm not even kidding about this one, people. I am getting so incredibly sick and tired of all this ridiculous negativity toward the prequels. I happen to love the new movies, thank you. I find nothing wrong with Hayden Christensen. George Lucas is making the movies the way that he wants to make them, whether you like it or not. I swear, the next time someone complains about Hayden Christensen, I am really going to have to try hard to NOT punch them in the face. This just really calls for a big heaping bowl of STFU. I'm really sick of these stuck up assholes who happen to be experts on absolutely every single little thing in the world making ridiculous complaints about everything. You know what? I'm pretty sure we all have opinions, so you aren't really that special just because you happen to have one. We have to live with the way George Lucas makes his movies. If you think they should be made differently, you can just go ahead and make your own movies. There's the real problem with your arguments. You can say all the bullshit you want, but I can shoot it all down at once simply by saying well, make your own movies, then. If you would just take a look at how much work has gone into a film series like Star Wars, you might just realize that you could never create anything with the creative power or storytelling mastery that George Lucas has. I can't wait for Episode 3, but I am really dreading all of the nonsense that everyone is going to spout just because it didn't live up to their outrageous expectations. Let's just end it with this: I love the entire Star Wars series; not because they are particularly amazing works of film, but simply because they are the expression of the creative energies of so many people. I have no expectations for Episode 3 because it will be what it is, and there is nothing I can do about it. Get some goddamn acting training, and THEN you can tell me how horrible all of the acting is in the prequels. Guess what: The original movies weren't exactly powerhouse acting performances, either, you know. End of Rant.

fields.title: Lively Fiction
fields.text:
It seems that my life might be changing. Turns out, it was there all along, and I was just blind to it. That's the way, I guess. I hate to be a jackass and talk about how great I am, but hey, we're all great. I am special. Everyone is special. I don't care how I feel tomorrow, because for this moment, I love life again. I know I will go down again, but I don't care. For this moment, my apathy is paying off.

Friends are really important. They really come in handy when you need someone to pull you out of quicksand. My eyes had just passed the waterline, and I felt the stick touch my outstreached fingers. I hadn't seen her standing there, so I didn't know she was trying to save me. I could feel the cold sand filling my nostrils. The black grip of unconciousness was slowly rolling over me.

I felt the stick touch my outstreached fingers, and I ran my hand along the fragile bark. The tree branch felt like a dream, like my mind was wishfully imagining the sensation of being saved. There was no bottom to the sand. I reached with my feet, trying to find a piece of hard ground to balance my weight on. With every movement, I just sank deeper and deeper into my watery grave, my desperate feet killing me in their attempt to save me.

I felt the stick touch my outstreached fingers, and I could feel the cold touch of the old wood. It was an old stick, one that had broken off of a tree long ago. The branch was discarded as dead weight, cast aside to allow the tree to grow. The branch was dead. It was still a sturdy branch, strong enough to pull someone out of a pit of quicksand. I was handed the broken end of the branch, and I could feel the severed joint where once stood the trunk of a great tree. The slightly rotted wood was somewhat soft to the touch, and bits of the fragile bark crumbled off at my grip.

I felt the stick touch my outstreached fingers, and in an instant I clenched my fist around the discarded branch of a tree. I felt it pull, but my body was too entrenched in the sand to be moved. A second pull, this time much more forcefully that the first, and I began to feel the pressure of being pulled against the force of gravity. She leaned back, and put her entire weight against the stick. I hadn't seen her standing there; I didn't know anyone was there to save me. I felt my head break the surface of the sand, and I could feel the cool spring air against my wet skin. My eyes came to the water line once again, and I opened them. The bright morning sun burst through the canopy of the forest. My eyes squinted under the rays of light being cast through the bare branches of the trees. I didn't think I would ever use my eyes again, so the renewed sensation was shocking at first. Once my eyes adjusted, I could see the canopy more clearly. I was able to notice that the branches weren't entirely bare. Tiny green buds were beginning to grow on the grey wood, and I could already see life beginning to course through the old growth once again.

I felt the stick touch my outstreached fingers. This branch was not alive. It had no green buds growing on its surface, and life was not coursing through it's dark, rotting wood. This dead thing, the most lifeless thing in the forest, was renewing my existence. Soon, as if green buds were growing on my skin, life would be once again coursing through my body. I would be able to live once again, and all because of this dead, rotting wood. I was saved by a dead branch, and, of course, the girl.

I hadn't seen her standing there, so I didn't know someone was there to save me. My eyes ran along the length of the stick to her soft hands, and then up to the most enchanting pair of eyes I have ever seen. This perfect angelic woman was standing there, straining with the stick in her soft hands, saving my life. This perfect angelic woman, with skin like the softest most pure silk, was giving me the chance to live again. This perfect angelic woman, with golden hair that fell on her cheeks in the most gentle caring manner, saved me at the last possible moment. My arm reached out, and I felt the hard surface of the forest floor. I pulled my body onto firm ground. She crouched over my body, the most amazing example of caring and compassion the universe has ever seen. She brushed the sand away from my face, and I realized that I was covered head to toe in millions of grains of moist sand. Touching my chin, she lifted my face to line up with hers. At this moment, I knew the extent of the universe. At this moment, I saw how vast our universe really is. I saw every nuance and detail just by gazing at the reflection of the forest in her pale blue eyes. We sat there for an eternety, staring at the extents of the universe. Her face was youthful, its slender curves forming together into the most beautifully gentle thing I have ever seen. I have seen her face before. I have seen her face in my dreams, when I dream of angels. I have seen her face in dreams, when I dream of heaven. I suddenly feared that I had died in the sand, and this woman was a lovely creature come to welcome me to my afterlife. 'Are you ok?' Her voice echoed through my head. I told her I was, and then she kissed me gently on the cheek. Truly, I know what it is to be a flower in summer, with a soft beautiful butterfly resting peacefully on its petals. Truly, I know what it is to be a fresh ripe peach, with a drop of morning dew resting peacefully on its skin. Her kiss was like a butterfly, her lips were like drops of dew, resting peacefully on my cheek. Her embrace was the wind itself wrapping around me, protecting and loving me. She saved my life, and simultaneously allowed me to live a lifetime of happiness in a single moment.

I felt the stick touch my outstreached fingers. My life and breath, renewed.

fields.title: Fountain Run
fields.text:
I am somewhat scared by change. Monumental things, like moving away from my parents, whom I had never left for more than 3 days, and going to a completely foreign world. Those things scare me, sure. Those things scare everyone. More so, the small things scare me, too. Small things, like going from a state of warm comfort to a shivering wet mess. Those things scare me, too. Today Neal, Chris, and I went for a 'fountain run' where we went to the fountain by Beering hall and ran through it. At first, Chris and I stood there looking at the gushing water, thinking that maybe it wasn't a good idea. Neal, soking wet from head to toe (except for the freak strip of dryness down his left leg) tried to push us into the spray. The sun glared down, but it somehow felt less warm, the breeze was cold, as if to say, don't do it. We watched the children run around the fountain, and I admired their ability to throw their cares to that nagging wind. You can't explain what it is like to run through the liberal arts fountain at Purdue University. It is an amazing sensation. Jets of water are bombarding you from every possible angle, and you are instantly soaking wet. Once I took that first step, the fears were gone, and I was concentrating more on not letting my bare feet slip on the slick wet stones. Once I left the fountain, at the other side, the Sun mocked me. Clouds covered her, and the wind blew harder. I was freezing, but it was one of the funnest things I did all weekend. My only regret was wearing my thin white pants, which immediately became see-through when they were soaking wet.

A little boy was having a wonderful time at the fountain today. He borrowed one of our little squirt guns and uselessly squirted our wet shirts. He called Neal 'big boy.' We all laughed and shivered in the Sun.

I need to realize that a lot of things are just like running through the liberal arts fountain at Purdue University. I may be somewhat scared about what state I am in afterwords, but once I take that first step I will just forget them all. A lot of things are just like that. I am thinking about those things tonight, like writing a huge research paper, approaching and talking to the most beautiful girl I have ever seen, kissing said gorgeous girl. I can't help but think about how much better I am as a person since I experienced the fountain run. I can't help but wonder how my life would be different if I had just talked to that girl. Life is full of little changes, little opportunities, and little jobs. Some of them leave you dripping and shivering. Some of them leave you with an awesome new knickname and a great post for your web log.

Siobhan, listen: This is a message from yourself. Never miss an opportunity again. Never again.
