fields.title: Shoelaces
fields.text:
This semester is it. In the next several months, my path will be set. It may not be from any direct decision from myself, but by the natural course of events. Whatever the case, the end of this semester could very possibly be the dawning of a completely new direction.

The term 'new direction' might be a bit misleading. That almost infers that I had a direction before. I currently have no direction for myself. Everything I once felt like I wanted has changed. Every dream I thought I had is - well it isn't destroyed, just shaken. The once perfect dream that I once had - the dream that I can't even seem to describe anymore - is clouded and obscured by a series of seemingly insurmountable obstacles.

I currently have a full fledged war inside my head. It is not a simple army vs. army war. When is internal conflict ever like that? This is a cold war. My brain is at war with itsself, and neither side seems to know that it is at war with the other. It's like I am leading several sepparate lives, each with it's own friends and goals and even dreams. I suppose this isn't extremely odd, but it's not making my life at all managable. I seriously need a purpose, and nothing I can think of is working.

My shoes never stay tied.

I was walking home from the first rehearsal for the play I've been swept up into. I felt a soft pressure against my left lower leg, just above the ankle. In between strides, I glanced down at my feet pressing against the sidewalk in a tedius alternating pattern. My right shoelace, a long blue string weaving through my shoe in curious geometric patterns, was loosened, and the ends were stretched out. The ends of the shoelace were chaotically flying around my leg with each step. I'm always intrigued by the pattern the shoelace tips make as they swirl around my ankle in mid stride. When in a certain rhythm, they alternate back and forth, wrapping first around my ankle crossing each other, and then flying back wrapping around the other way with each time my foot moves forward. This time, walking along the sidewalk on the south side of State Street, the shoelace was not in the proper rhythm. Then ends of the very loosly tied string were dangling randomly around their anchors, occasionally applying a soft pressure against my left lower leg, just above the ankle.

I am always tying these shoes. The once perfect, pristine finish of blue and white is now dulled, stained by dirt, time, and the millions of hazards a shoe encounters on a daily basis. They were once perfect white. They were once covered by a nice interlocking pattern of perfect blue suade. Now, like the shoes they replaced, they are losing that perfect appearance. For some reason, these shoes refuse to stay tied. My left shoe, currently obediently staying within the parameters laid down for it when it was made, remained tied only because on the way to rehearsal when it was loose, I tied it with a double knot.

Knots are things that I have never been able to understand. Somehow, looping a string around itself provides enough force to stop almost anything from moving. Knots have always been a metaphore for marriage. I can't managed to keep my shoelaces to maintain their knots.

Shoelaces have one purpose. They prevent shoes from falling off. I wish my life were that easy. Is life that easy? What is my purpose?

Theatre has always been easy for me. It serves a very specific and important purpose in my life. It gives me a purpose. I don't mean that it gives me a purpose to be alive or a reason to exist. Theatre provides a momentary escape from the uncertainty of my life. When I am assuming a role, for that tiny instant I have a purpose. Whether it be to deliver a certain line, to perform a certain action (or let someone perform a certain action on me), or to simply walk across a stage, for that moment in time I have a purpose. I don't care about the audience. I don't care about anything else in the entire world. For that moment, I am a person with a distinct and universally important purpose. For that moment, I have a shoe to tie down. I'm so uncomfortable with social situations. I have always been uncomfortable dealing with most people I have to deal with. I never know what to say. I never know what to do. When I have a script, though, I know exactly what to say, and exactly what to do.

The problem is, once the purpose is fulfilled, once the performance is over, once I return to my conciousness, I am again lost. Once the purpose is gone, I am untied, to dangle randomly around, occasionally applying a soft pressure against the universe's left lower leg, just above the ankle.

Is this what I have come to? Comparing myself to shoelaces?

fields.title: My physics professor
fields.text:
Let me explain just how terrible my physics professor is. I'm currently sitting in my physics class, and since I can't stand to listen to him talk, I decided to do something productive and post something on my website about him. He is without a doubt the worst teacher I've ever had. He talks like the comedian Ben Stein, except that he does it naturally and it's even less funny. He really has one of the most deeply boring personalities on the face of the planet. I often think of him sitting at family gatherings, prattling on about random confusing things, boring the crap out of all of the children who were dragged to the thing. His family members (probably his adult grandchildren) would all look at each other and feel extremely sorry for his students.

I am one of those poor unfortunate students. I can sit here listening to him ramble, and I learn absolutely nothing. We have these electronic response pads, and he randomly gives us multiple choice questions to answer with them. We usually get them wrong (by 'we' I mean the entire lecture hall full of students) and he chuckles to himself and explains why we are all incompetant. The problem is that he doesn't seem to feel the need to teach us the material covered in the question. He doesn't seem to understand that this is the physics class for students who didn't take any physics in high school. We don't know what he is talking about most of the time. He might as well give us the final on the first day of class, and then spend the rest of the semester explaining to us all why we were wrong.

I'm lucky that I have Chris around to help me with the homework. He keeps telling me that the class is easy, but I am not quite as physically inclined as he is. This is going to be a hard semester.

fields.text:
Chapter 1, Part 1

Read

A tear landed on the cold metal floor. The floor shook with the force of the shuttle's engines. Transport Lieutenant Mark Soren paced from the fore of the passenger compartment to the rear. His uniform boots were loudly knocking against the metal floor panels as he walked. His hands were wrapped behind his back, his back was straight, his strides even. In the front of the shuttle, the 'In Transit' light was on, accompanied by the constant warning beep which is standard for the fleet's transport craft. In nearby seats, some petty officers were loudly debating football scores. Outside Shuttle 15-23, the SDS Vigor slowly drifted along, awaiting her shuttle back. Behind the cruiser, Morsus was slowly rotating about Beta Centauri. Behind Beta Centauri hovered an infinite universe of infinite discoveries. A tear slid down my cheek and landed on the cold metal floor. It was the only sound I heard. It was the only thing I saw.

I am Lieutenant Tristan Marcus, command Lieutenant for the Solan Defense Fleet. I graduated with honors from the SDF academy on Earth. My first position was as an Ensign on a small frigate. I was one of 8 officers on the ship. Earth apparently decided that my paticular talents would be best suited on a larger, more active ship, so I was transferred to the Vigor.

As the shuttle carying Leutenant Soren and I left the point defence perimeter of the Vigor, the last 4 years were swirling around in my head. As shuttle 15-23 set a course for the surface of planet Morsus, I thought about all of the things that I would be losing. I was leaving the ship to be court-martialed. I had to wait on Morsus for the next SDF ship that would be headed to Earth. The Solan schedules listed no ship going from Morsus to Earth for at least 5 local days, so I was stuck there with nothing but my remorse. I didn't mind leaving the fleet. I wasn't afraid of having to deal with a dishonorable discharge. I didn’t really care at all. I had friends on that ship, though. I felt like I had a family on that ship. I made the terrible mistake of falling in love with a lieutenant named Carys Patrick. A court-martial meant that I would never see her - or any of my other friends in the fleet - ever again.

Morsus worried me, as well. I had never met a Terran before, and I wasn’t excited to be one of the only humans on this planet. At the time, I assumed that I deserved it. I was being court-martialed after all. I felt like I didn’t deserve to live. I didn’t want to live. Not without her. I joined the academy so many years ago because I had nothing better to do with my life. I don’t have any particularly useful skills, and there isn’t much that I enjoy doing. As I watched Lieutenant Soren’s feet pass by me, I would have given anything to go back and live my life over again. I wished that I had never joined the academy. I had no idea what I had ahead of me.

The shuttle hit the Morsus atmosphere and I watched patterns of the ships shields dance around the window. We still had 20 minutes before the shuttle would reach the garrison, so I closed my eyes. I had a dream that I was stranded alone in the middle of a vast desert. I walked and walked, but I got nowhere. I was clutching something in my hand, but I couldn't tell what it was. Then everything dissappeared and all I could see was Carys's face. She looked sad.

Leutenant Soren woke me up when we landed.

For what it's worth, I fixed the discussion page. You can now make your own comments. I didn't make a new topic this week because I don't think there's much point. I have apparently lost about 90% of my audience, so there isn't much point to spending too much on the site.

So for anyone who cares anymore (Mom and Dad), I am thinking about leaving Purdue. I'm thinking about it more and more every day. The problem is that once I think that I have to decide what I'm going to do instead, and so far the answer to that question has eluded me. I want to leave this lousy computer graphics department and do something that I can 1, do, and 2, actually care about. I want to go into writing or anything with less manual art. I can't draw, and I never could. That's why I wanted to go into computer graphics, because I can animate things very well, but I can't draw them at all. I didn't think that I would have to draw at all in order to animate, but I guess I was wrong. Maybe I'll just CODO into computer science and get a degree in that, just for something to do. I have a feeling that I won't actually use a degree for the information it teaches me. I just need something to say that I graduated and I am competant, and I need to do something that will give me enough free time to work on independant projects like this site. Independant projects are the things that will get me jobs, not degrees or grades. Those are the the thoughts swirling around in my head right now.

I hope that I can be accepted a little more into the play, because I really need some friends.

fields.title: Found
fields.text:
Cameron Marston sometimes makes me very upset. He has a very abrasive nature to him which can become infuriating if you don't know him. It's just his way, and I wouldn't have it any other way. Everyone has their annoying faults. I have recently been tested in my patience to keep him around. He comes in my room (there is a history of annoyance with him and my room, after all) and uses my couch, my television, Mike's Xbox, and our bathroom. Then he makes very asinine comments about us and the things that we love.

This is not a Cameron bashing post, so stick with me.

He has recently reminded me just why I am friends with him in the first place, and why we all put up with his asinine nature. He sent me an email in response to my last post. He didn't want to leave it as a comment because he was afraid of being cut off by the 2000 character limit. I told him that I would upload it, and now I've decided to do it as a full post. I hope whoever randomly stumbled upon this site is entertained by my incessant descriptions of how I am finding myself.

And just to stay on topic here . . . I am still the only person who doesn't use a tray in the residence dining halls. Using trays is so conformist.

Cameron's Email

Shauvon,

For what it's worth. I'm thinking about leaving CGT too. Personally I don't think CS is right for you though, especially if you are looking for more free time to work on independent projects. CGT has one of the lowest workloads of any major I've seen at this school, it may be stupid work, but at least there typically isn't that much of it. 211 is an exception of course, but you'll have that occasionally and you won't ever have Maicher again, so if you make it through this you're done with him. Also CS has a lot of lab science requirements and I don't think you'd care for that very much.

Honestly what I think you should do is stay in CGT, do just enough to get by, and work the next couple of years on your modeling portfolio. You are a better modeler than almost anyone I've seen in CGT and that includes upperclassmen.

Most of the coursework isn't going to help you, so say fuck it and do the work that you want to do. It's unfortunate that few people would hire you without a bachelor's degree, but that's the nature of the beast. You've still got a lot of modeling stuff that you could learn and I'd be surprised if you didn't get hired to do that kind of work out of school even with the portfolio you have now.

There are many things that upset me about this post, one being that you claim to not have any friends, which hurts me because I didn't see any sign of this self-induced solitude coming. We may be assholes, but we do care about you and you need to tell us that you need us rather than posting angsty, vague messages meant to guilt us into expressing concern over you.

The thing that really annoys me about these rants of yours is that you claim that the CGT coursework is wasting your time and not teaching you anything. You claim that you want more time for independent projects, but when you do have that time you sit around for 12 hours in a weekend playing Fable or one of the umpteen other games that you have or buy on a fairly regular basis. Maybe if you actually spent some time working on your projects, like the Half- Life mod or adding the Imperial Guard to the Warhammer game, we'd take your complaints a little more seriously. It seems to me that the person causing you the most harm here is you. You bitch incessantly, but you never do anything to fix your situation. I am more than willing to help you in any capacity that I can, but you never talk to me about your problems and you seem to do very little to help yourself. In the end I am your friend and am willing to help you out in whatever way I can, whether that be morale support or contributing to one of your projects or just bitching at you to keep you working, but there is nothing I can do if you don't feel like motivating yourself.

You are in full control of your life and nobody else can make your decisions for you. I know I may come off as a little harsh in here, but I'm only trying to be perfectly honest with you. I think you are capable of great deal. You're a much more talented artist than I am, whether you choose to believe that or not. You're also a much better modeler than I will probably ever be a web designer. I'd hate to see you squandor all of your promise because of self- imposed angst and outright laziness.

I was going to post this to your journal, but I figured you might not want it to be on public record. It's probably vastly over 2000 characters anyway as I have a tendency to ramble. Also, don't let a lack of web traffic discourage you, I hardly get any hits unless the webcams are up. I do check your journal every day though, so you have at least one viewer. Whoever posted that other, rather eloquent, response clearly reads your journal often too, so that's something.

Just remember, I'm here if you need me, but I can't help you if you won't talk to me.

Cameron

fields.title: Another Cryptic Post
fields.text:
I know exactly why I came along. She was talking to her friends whom she hadn't seen for months, and she kept saying things to them, but directed at me. She kept smiling at me, like I knew what she was talking about. I stood there the entire time, only saying my name when one of her friends asked me who I was. I didn't come along to be a part of the conversation. Her hands were playing with one of the store shelves, clicking it into place and lowering it back down again. She smiled again, her blue eyes shooting towards me through black eyelashes. She smiled again, her round cheeks glowed under the florescent lights. She told me how different things seemed to her after being away for five months. I told her she looked gorgeous. she told me she didn't know what she wanted to do with her life.

She drove, and I was folded next to her. She turned the radio up. Her round cheeks glowed under the sunlight. That's why I came along. Sunlight came through the car's windows and danced across her skin. The rays of sunlight could not have chosen a more beautiful subject to illuminate. There are fields of roses, ancient forests, miles of calm ocean, and fresh snow covered mountains which are lit every single day by lucky rays of sunlight. Those rays, the ones that light the beautiful things on this planet, are jealous of the ones that come to Earth to light her face. It is for those rays of light that I came along. If all I get is two hours every five months to be able to see those rays of sunlight carry out their journey, I am still eternally greatful.

Shauvon, Just tell her that, and the rest will fall into place. And go eat something.

Everyone say hello to the new audience. Several members of the Road cast have told me that they have gone to this site. I am working on a Road website. It is a sort of online playbill. fields.title: 2 bits
fields.text:
So yesterday I lost my bike, I lost my soap, I lost quite a bit of my self esteem, and I lost quite a bit of my hope. Then I had to lose something else. Mom, you'll really enjoy this. For the play I'm in, I had to have my hair cut. A great deal of my hair was removed, and with it went a great deal of my sense of originality. I sat in the chair, a beautiful young girl stood behind me wearing several shirts. (She had like 5 shirts on, and they didn't seem to be able to do the job of one. I'm not complaining) First went the clippers, then the scissors, then the clippers again. Handfulls of hair fell on my lap; clumps of curly red hair bounced on my shoulders. In one lock of hair was my pride, my sense of accomplishment. Another one contained my faith in the future, my ability to have hope that things will maintain some sort of continuity. She methodically removed my hair from my head. She removed my confusion, my lack of perception. Down fell my constant nagging sense of failure. The buzz of the cippers removed my fear.

I would like to say that the haircut cleansed my soul, and now I am returned to a neutral state, ready to take on life. I really want to say that, but I won't. I am still the same insecure and lonely person I was before. The only difference is that now I can see my ears in the mirror. A haircut causes a great deal of excitement for only about five minutes. I went to practice, put my stuff down, and realized that everyone was looking at me. They all said their version of 'it looks really good' and went on their way. Nothing more needs to be said.

I have apparently broken my mp3 player now, as well. It fell about 3 feet from my chair, and now the hard drive is damaged and it won't play. I didn't just have 1700 songs on it, but I also used it to back up my computer. Those things are all permanently gone. I can't blame this one on thievery. Only one person is to blame. It really makes me wonder what else I am going to lose.

At night I sort through my day. I feel a great warmth in the distance. A bright light is calling me, but I don't know how to get to it. A vast hope is just out of reach. I don't know how to reach it. I can't reach it. Then it disappears, and I go to sleep.

fields.title: Road is great for me
fields.text:
This play is definitely one of the best things to happen to me in a long time. I almost forgot what the sound of people uproariously laughing together sounded like. I've spent 4 hours a night, every day for a month with these people, and I don't think I have heard a single insulting remark the entire time. No obnoxiously critical declarations, no references to obvious weaknesses, no putdowns have been thrown. I think television has infected society with an unhealthy need to insult each other. I now remember why I love to do theatre.

Reason number 368: The absolute hilarity of the dressing rooms.
Reason number 1,427: The complete and total teamwork.
Reason number 456: The unadulterated love that is shared between absolutely everyone.
Reason number 138: The complete acceptance of everyone by everyone.
etc. etc. etc.

The best thing about it is that I get twice as much of it as I'm used to with high school. Also, this is the first time I've ever done any group activity where every single person gets along so well. There is no hatred at all between anyone in the cast or crew. Tonight we had a 10 minute break after dress rehearsal, and everyone was in such a goofy mood. It was without a doubt the best 10 minutes of my recent memory. If you're in the Lafayette area, definitely check out Road between October 20th and October 30th. It is going to be one hell of a show.

I'm pretty close to being broke. I'm going to have to get some sort of job. My problem is that I spend far too much money on other people. Nice guys definitely finish last. Maybe I just do it so I can use that as an excuse. I don't have to make a proper effort because if I fail, I can just blame it all on my being nice. I'll have to get over that.

Tomorrow will probably be pretty emotional. We'll have fun, though. I don't know what I'm going to do on Monday.

I think I might rasturbate a picture of Meryl Streep. Keira Knightley has nothing on her.

fields.text:
You're not serious. You're not even a joke. You're just like all the rest of them. Frightened to sniff the wind for fear it'll blow your brain upside down and then you'll 'have to do something different.' Wasting your whole life. Work, work, work, work, work. Small wages, small wages, small wages. Getting by with a smile. Getting by without a smile. Work, work, work, work. Small wages. Then death with the big 'D'. Not even a smell left over from it all. If you're lucky, a see-through memory, slowly desolving like Steradent.

Shit happens.

For fuck's sake, is that all I can say?

fields.title: Chapter 1, Part 2
fields.text:
Read Chapter 1, Part 1


Chapter 1, Part 2

Read

'Lieutenant Marcus, I am Ensign Green of the Morsus Garrison. It's a pleasure to--'

I cut him off and disgregarded his weak salute. I was sick of the military charade. 'Who is in command here? Please tell me they put someone higher than an Ensign in charge.'

'Uh, well, the--'

I cut him off again. 'Just take me to him, Ensign.' The poor officer probably nearly failed in the academy, so they sent him to this terrible post. His wrinkled pants and crooked hat showed how incompetant he was. Competant ensigns almost never let their uniforms go to such a state.

'Y-yes sir.' He sloppily saluted one more time, and then he turned to lead me into the garrison. Lieutenant Soren and his petty officers would see to it that my belongings would get off the shuttle. They worked quickly. The shuttle began leaving almost before we entered the garrison. With a blast of its engines, my life as I knew it ended.

The landing pad was about 50 meters from the actual garrison. The place wasn't designed with asthetics in mind. A simple box sat above ground, with a 10 meter tower prjecting from the center. Most of the complex was underground. The entire thing was surrounded by a rather tall concrete wall, which blocked my view of the rest of the planet. From what I could tell, it was pretty much like Earth.

Ensign Green led me down to the main office. The plaque outside read 'Jonathan Ward, Lieutenant Junior Grade.' I outranked him.

'Sir, welcome to Morsus.'

I nodded, and shook his outstreached hand.

'Would you like a tour of our facilities?' He must not have had many visiters.

'Maybe later,' I said.

He was visibly dissappointed. 'Maybe some other time, then.'

'Maybe. Can you show me to my quarters?' I was hoping that a tiny garrison would have the space to give me a room.

'Of course. Ensign Green will show you.'

Perfect. I could have ordered him to take me himself, but I didn't really care. I was very tired, and I was looking forward to being able to sleep for more than four hours at once. The poor young ensign took me to a tiny room in the basement of the building. It was obviously Ward's quarters. As his superior, he was required to give me the largest room in the facility. I really hope that it didn't mean that he had to share a room with Ensign Green. My small chest of everything I owned was already in the room, waiting for me. I didn't even bother with it. I took my jacket off and went right for the bed. It was painfully uncomfortable, but I didn't notice at the time.

Sometimes dreams can just be random, and sometimes they don't make any sense. Sometimes dreams can be pretty prophetic, though. If only I could tell at the time.

I had a dream that I was alone in the middle of a vast desert. I was holding something in my hand, but I couldn't tell what it was. A SDF shuttle was hovering in front of me. I could see Carys standing in the shuttle. She had her back to me. Then the shuttle flew into the distance and dissappeared. The shuttle disappeared and I was alone.

fields.title: The 211 Group project
fields.text:
I just thought I would give a little update about the group project that I was in for CGT211. My good friend Extra Cameron, the Happy Canadian was also in the group. The project was to create pre-production materials for a movie / video / whatever of our choice. Extra Cameron, in a stroke of genius, decided that we should design a video for the Death Cab For Cutie song, What Sarah Said, from their new album. The song is hella depressing, so I won't go into huge detail about it. Just click the link below to get all the scoopage on said project.

Yes, this link right here.

What is pre-production, you ask? Well, we were to design all of the aspects of the video, which according to Kellen Maicher, the godlike professor, boils down to Characters, Environments, and Props. Extra Cameron designed a couple characters, the amazing Tyler Kupferer did another couple characters, Samantha the Senior designed the props and things, and Slick Stephen worked on one of the main environments. (I just made those knick names up) The song centers around a hospital (in that the entire thing takes place there). Therefore, the environment was a hospital, the characters were patients and nurses, and the extra things were stuff like exit signs, coke machines, coffee cups, etcetera.

My part of the project was to do a couple of the environments. For the last 4 summers, I've been working at an architecture firm previsualizing environments, so I figured it would be pretty easy for me to do a couple hospital renderings. The requirements of the project stated that we had to create a raster image. There were many requirements about what the images was supposed to be like, but it didn't say anything about what program was to be used to create the image. It's theoretically an Adobe Photoshop class, but I thought it was rediculous to render an environment in Photoshop, so I used 3d Studio Max. Yeah, I cheated a little bit. It's a raster image that fits every requirement for the project, so there is nothing wrong with it. I'm just like Captain Kirk. 'I don't like to lose.'

Anyway, here are my images:

First, I had do do one of the hallways of the hospital, complete with rooms (albeit empty). Several people have thought that the first one is a photograph.

The sign at the end of the hallway points in the various directions for the Cardiology, Pulminology, Out Patient, ICU, and CGT 211 Student wards.


Another section that I had to do was the waiting room. I went ahead and did the area outside of the waiting room, too, because I love that reflective floor. I designed those light fixtures because I saw them somewhere and I thought they looked cool. I wanted to have as many harsh shadows as possible, to heighten the tension and depressing . . . ness of it all. I think I saw those lights in a mexican restaurant somewhere. Strange choice for mexican restaurant, but excellent choice for depressing waiting room.

There is nothing behind the curtains.


And finally, I was in charge of the outside of the hospital, which meant that I had to design an entire hospital complex, parking garage and all. (don't let me fool you, I really enjoyed it) You may notice several things. It is raining. There are no windows on the actual hospital (this is because the shot in the video is from above, zooming away from the guy sitting on the ground, so you never see the hospital walls). The parking garage only has lights on the first row of columns (it already took about 10 minutes to render one frame, I didn't want to make it take any longer by doubling the lights). Finally, you might notice the z-buffer error on the large windows of the diagonal wall in the image named 'ground0005.png' (some of the windows don't display because they are so close to the surface of the wall, and I was too lazy to fix it).

The ambulance is just two white boxes with the word 'Wambulance' printed all over it.


Now for the technical info. Let me just get this out of the way, so I can feel special for knowing so many big words. You can skip to the next paragraph if you don't want to read the mumbo jumbo. Stick with me, though, because the ending is really good.

The two scenes were rendered in 3d studio max 7, using radiosity calculations and photometric lights. The hallway scene and the waiting room are connected together. All of the textures were created from scratch in Adobe Photoshop, with the sole exception being the magazine covers in the waiting room. The floor reflection was achieved using a raytraced material. All of the objects were modeled with simple primitives. The outdoor scene contains a total of 144 lights, and the hallway / waiting room contains 39. I think that about does it.

Although I was afraid that I would get in trouble for not using photoshop to render the scenes, they didn't seem to care at all. We turned in our project and awaited the presentations. This week, on Monday and Tuesday, every group had 5 minutes to present their work, which included at least two pieces per group member, and around 100 storyboards. Five minutes was undoubtedly not enough time. Anyway, our group, which was called Team Steel Blue, by the way, decided that we should make a video for our presentation, instead of making some stupid powerpoint presentation or something. Good old Tyler worked up a five minute video a la VH1's Behind the Music. Neeless to say, we owned everyone.

We all got an email from Professor Maicher yesterday, which explains how awesome we are. Apparently he sent a copy to several other professors, who all thought it was great. Although Maicher wants to teach us about the real professional world, he doesn't seem to have any problem with distributing our creative property. It's no big deal, because it's definitely awesome enough to want to show everyone.

Only one group in the class will earn an A on this project, whith everyone else geting a B or lower. I'll be sure to post the grade that we got, but judging from the other presentations, I don't think there's much competition.

I'm happy to say that I have a copy of the video for your viewing pleasure. Feel free to distribute it all you want, but it would be nice if you give me an email so I can give Tyler an email asking to use it. The credit for all the filming and editing goes to Tyler, who is definitely one of the greatest minds of our generation. We all worked really hard on this project, so everyone take a look at 211: Behind the Project. It's in Windows Media format, and for that I appologize.

fields.title: Last Night's adventures
fields.text:
I'm pretty much just making sure that my new image upload system works correctly. I'm going to be home most of next week for Thanksgiving, so I want to be able to make posts and upload images from home, which I should be able to do. I think the images work pretty well. If you want, I'll tell you what we did last night.

'Ok, Shauvon, tell me about last night.'

I spent all day yesterday working on a little side project I have going. I've been wanting to render a space scene for a while now, so I started playing around with 3d Studio on Friday. I re-developed my intimate relationship with 3ds while working on the 211 project. I quickly worked up a nice planet + ring scene, and I started modelling a space fighter. I made both of them up as I went, and they are turning out pretty well. I still have to skin the fighter, and insert a couple of them into the planet. I'm hoping I'll have some free time at home next week to work on that some more.

Anyway, all day yesterday I was switching between working on the space fighter and playing Quake 4, which really redeems itsself well in the later levels. Neal, Cameron, and Chris came back pretty late in the day (around 7) because they went to Bloomington for the football game.

I was surfing the internet for information about building a media center PC (I really want to build one), and Neal came in to the room with a big jug of orange juice. He locked the door, and went into the other room. I was confused about what they were doing in there, but I was more interested in AMD Turion 64 processors, so I didn't really think about it too much.

My fingers slid across the computer, pressing 'flag' and 'L' to lock my computer, so nobody finds my collection of Star Trek fan fiction. I journeyed over into the other room, and found the four guys (Mike Davis had joined them at this point) sitting around drinking orange juice. They had apparently aquired some sort of special tonic which they were mixing with the juice. It seems that they didn't want anyone else asking to have some of their orange juice, so Neal locked the door to keep the juice-hounds out. By the time I came into the room, half of the 1.75 litre bottle of tonic was finished. They must have been worried about someone finding out about something, because the bottle had quite a bit of proof in it. I don't like anything without Tang or Dr. Pepper in it, so I didn't try any of their orange juice.

Chris took what was left of our koolaide and mixed it with his juice. I know the picture is of Neal, but it was Chris who made the drink.

Everyone started discussing various topics. One main point of discussion was the trip to Bloomington, in which they found Chris's brother's girlfriend to be somewhat unsavory. Chris mentioned that he thought his brother's girlfriend was a 'chief example of someone who needs to continue to develop her social skills and ability to deal with guests.'

He was very firm and coherant in his arguments.

Neal found it necessary to reiterate how much orange juice he drank, explaining how many 'friends' he had inside him. Chris ate his steak sandwich that he purchased in Bloomington.

Meanwhile, Cameron and Mike Davis were having a discussion. Cameron likes to discuss all sorts of things sometimes.

Cameron wanted to make sure that I understood what he was saying.
Neal's Adventure

Neal decided to call his sister, who has been living in the Ukraine for the past couple years. He sure talked to her for quite a while. I couldn't hear what she was saying, but I'm sure she was very interested to hear about how many friends Neal had ingested. Neal explained to her that I was taking pictures of him. She must have been telling him a really funny joke, because he couldn't seem to stop laughing.

Neal was somewhat alarmed that I had a picture of the Blue Man Group on the front of my shirt. He made several comments about the blue men on my chest.

I don't know what his sister was talking to him about, but he kept telling her that he was focused.

Neal was apparently annoyed with me taking pictures of him, and he expressed his feelings by biting my camera. I'm not sure what his sister thought about that.

Since the camera didn't satiate his appetite, he looked around for more food. Chris's sandwich came with several sweet pickles, which Neal was quite partial to.

Of course, the pickles made his hands dirty, so he had to wash them off. He found the toilet more than adequate for the task.

Stomach full and hands clean, he was able to go back to talking to his Sister.

When he finished talking to his sister, Neal turned to the other residents of our hall for topics of discussion. Neal's neighbor was wearing an orange hat, which must have reminded Neal of one of his least favorite football teams. Neal told him that orange was one of his least favorite colors. I think Neal expressed his arguments pretty well, and the other guy had a hard time working up any sort of response.

He obviously couldn't come up with any response for Neal's well thought out arguments.

Neal was getting pretty worked up, though, and I was afraid that he was going to start a fight. He repeatedly expressed his wishes to damage the poor guy's various bones.

Fortunately Neal decided not to pursue the matter any further.

Cameron and Barry were discussing something now, I believe this time Cameron was discussing some kind of music. Cameron had just returned from the third floor, where he was hanging out with some random people who he ran into. Cameron decided that he was going to bring the rest of us up to the third floor to meet his new friends. This brought about some more discussion. Chris mentioned that one of the girls they had seen was rather attractive. Cameron was able to persuade us to go up to the third floor with him.

Cameron was never able to find his friend's room. Meredith is very hard to navigate, so it's no suprise that we couldn't find our way around the labyrinth. Cameron finally entered a room. We asked him if these were the people he met earlier, and he said no. They were nice anyway, and they talked with Cameron for a while.

Neal turned to me and mentioned something about how nice these people were. It was cerainly nice of them to let us hang out in their room.

Then he made another phone call.

Next we decided to go visit Scott, who also lives on the third floor of Meredith. It was a long walk down the hall to his room. Neal had to stop in the shower room on the way there and ask everyone what there names were. Cameron had to lay down and rest.

Eventually we made it to Scott's room.

Scott was very happy to see us. He never actually said that, but I'm pretty sure it was understood. His room is very small. Realtors call it cozy.

Cameron tried his hand at one of Scott's computer games,

Chris was very suprized by something,

and Neal made another phone call.

Chris told Scott all about his brother's girlfriend and her indadequate social skills. Scott was very sympathetic.

We said goodbye to Scott and went on our way. Scott was concerned that we were making too much noise, and he told us that we should be quieter. Good old Scott is always helping out. It was very nice of him.

All this journeying around Meredith was pretty hard for all of us.

Both Cameron and Neal had a hard time getting back to my room.

Cameron almost went to the wrong floor. I live on the first floor, and the second floor is all girls. He would have been very embarrassed if we hadn't stopped him.
Cameron's Adventure

Cameron and I were both pretty tired from all of our journeys around the building.

Cameron was very interested in a poker game that was going on in the study room. The poker players weren't as enthusiastic about him as he was about them. I finally peeled him away from the glass.

He saw some people outside in front of the lobby, so he wanted to investigate.

It turns out that it was a group of young Purdue students from India. Cameron introduced himself, and started to discuss lots of important issues with them.

He made it clear that he is actually from Canada, and he hates Americans. He also made it clear that he hates George Bush. He learned everyone's name, and how to pronounce them correctly. It was clearly a long day for Cameron, because he was having trouble pronouncing their names.

They all sat on the sidewalk, and became more culturally aware. Cameron showed everyone how to sit 'Indian style.'

Cameron learned a lot about his new friends and their culture. Look how much more culturally aware he looks in this picture.

He also made a lot of friends.

Cameron talked to his new friends for a long time.

I was getting pretty cold outside in the wind, so I told Cameron that I was going back to my room. He stayed and hung out with his new friends for a while.

There are 55 pictures here, and this is the only one I am in.

Well, I would say that the image uploading system is working pretty well.

I sure am glad that I go to college, because I get to have such interesting and enlightening nights like last night. I get to hang around with friends discussing various intellectual topics in a distinguished and scholarly manor.

fields.title: Rules of development
fields.text:
The Matrix: The Path of Neo is one of the worst games I have ever played. How in the world could someone have played that game and decided that it's ready to be released. There are graphical glitches every 5 seconds (not even exaggerating), and animation glitches every single time you do anything. It brings several interesting points to mind.

I'm starting a list. Let this be not the definitive, but the ever adapting list of rules for game development. They aren't mandatory or anything, it's just things you should do if you want to make a good game. Go ahead and follow Shiny's plan of releasing whatever filth you come up with just to milk the cash cow. However, if you don't want 50 million suicides on your hands, you might want to think about making a decent game.

Shauvon's simple rules of game development.

1.

Do not release a game with obvious bugs.

Okay, if it occasionally crashes on certain video cards with a paticular driver, it's fine. If some random side NPC has a weird animation bug, don't worry about it. If you're way over budget already, just relase it.

If all of your dynamic lights cause bizarre texture corruption, or every other animation screws up and ends up looking terrible, or characters often randomly disappear from the screen in the middle of a cutscene, or the graphics will completely and totally die (absolutely nothing works correctly) on certain systems when turned all the way up, or the terrible hit collision system causes walls that the player hasn't touched to explode on the other side of a room, or the camera just decides to go through a wall and make everything impossible, or character models have various polygons sticking out of them, or LOD changes occur and random times right in front of the camera, or bullets shoot backwards when you point the gun at a certain angle, you should do something about it. Any one of those glitches could ruin a perfectly good game. Path of Neo happens to exibit all of them, and many more. They all happen frequently enough to make it obvious in the first several minutes of play, too.

For the love of God, just play through the game ONCE before you release it. This is what Beta testing is for. Patches are fine, but a game shouldn't have this many problems when it comes out.

I had to laugh at one point in Path of Neo. After failing a jumping puzzle for the 10th time, Neo reappears at the beginning and says 'This is getting old.' No kiding. They even aknowlege that the game has problems, but they aren't willing to address them.
2.

Extra useless levels need to be removed.

You may think that you are doing gamers a favor by including more levels, but really you're destroying a good game. For example, after defeating agent Smith in the subway station (an infuriating and stupid battle, by the way), Neo gets stuck in a different subway station which has been corrupted by bad code. He has to jump around a badly modeled train car and hit the brake to get out of an infinite loop. Then he goes and fights Smith again in another station. How was that important to the story? It wasn't in the movie. If they did write or even shoot the scene, they cut it out because it would have ruined the movie. Why can't developers go through a game and cut out scenes and levels that aren't important? Movie makers have been doing it for years now.

Side quests are perfectly acceptable, but not for a first person shooter. Bonus missions are great, but make them bonus missions instead of forcing the player to wade through piles of crap just to get back with the storyline.

I would rather play a short game than a shit game.
3.

If you are going to make some gimic a key element of the game, make it something that the Player ejoys having.

Max Payne has bullet time. Aliens vs. Predator has the ability to be the Alien. Dead to Rights has bullet time. Messiah has taking over people's bodies. Enter the Matrix has bullet time. Brother's in Arms has the ability to order your squad around. FEAR has bullet time. Half Life 2 has the gravity gun. The Path of Neo has bullet time.

Bullet time is almost a new genre, it's used so much. This rule should just be 'If you are going to use bullet time in a game, play Max Payne first.' For some reason, the original Max Payne is still the only game to do it well. The only exception to that is FEAR which is one of the most amazing games ever made. In Path of Neo, the 'focus' button feels more like the 'make everything impossible to control and see' button. Gun combat in PoN is the single worst thing I have ever had the misfortune to experience. The only game that even comes close is Enter the Matrix. When you try to dive in any direction in PoN, Neo flys twenty feet in the air, making it impossible to hit anything. It shouldn't be so hard to do what Max Payne did so brilliantly.

Please, if you are going to use a gimic in a game, make it a blessing like Half Life 2's Gravity Gun, not an eye-gouging annoyance like PoN's 'focus.'
4.

Just because you use DirectX 9, it doesn't mean you need to layer on every vertex and pixel effect possible.

Just 5 minutes with Path of Neo and you'll start to hate bump mapping. You'll hate it almost as much as ID software loves it. They bump map everything, just because they can. The difference is that ID uses normal maps to improve the detail in their levels (Doom 3, Quake 4), whereas in PoN, they use bump mapping to make his suit look wrinkly, but it just ends up looking like Neo has been severely stabbed repeatedly in random places.

Anachronox used the Quake 2 engine, and it still manages to tell a story infinitely better than Path of Neo, even without all of the vertex processing and pixel shaders.

Keep it simple, and it will stay entertaining. Good graphics can do a lot to improve a game, but lousy graphics can do so much more to ruin it. As soon as you see Neo's terrible suit, you are taken out of the game.
5.

Don't shoot yourself in the foot by butchering your storyline.

Peter Jackson can tell us all about butchering stories, but he isn't here. Peter is a good example, though. I don't think we will ever know just why he felt it necessary to completely rewrite the Lord of the Rings, but it ruined the movies. The Wachowski brothers (they made The Matrix, and they're also famous for being really creepy and scary), did the same thing with Path of Neo. They added stupid scenes, rearranged things, and changed important lines. There is absolutely no reason for them to do any of that. Playing the game, you can just see the Wachowskis wandering around the development studio, claiming to be 'gamers' and telling the poor developers to put a bunch of stupid ideas into the game, like the end boss battle where Neo has to fight a giant agent Smith made of buildings.

Dear Wachowski brothers,

If you sit around all day watching anime and playing Playstation, you aren't a gamer. If you think jumping puzzles are important to throw into every game ever made, you aren't a gamer. If you think that the Playstation is the best gaming platform on the planet, you aren't a gamer.

I would tell you to stick to making movies, but you have proven your inadequacies there, too. Just crawl back into the hole you came from, and stop torturing people.
6.

Games fail as movies, and movies fail as games.

I would really love for someone to prove me wrong here, but the truth is you can't. The point of games is that they give the player the ability to choose his fate. Movies are a completely different form of entertainment. I wish they would stop trying.

It's worse knowing that the following games will become movies: Half Life, Dungeon Seige, Duke Nukem, American McGee's Alice, Splinter Cell, and Deus Ex. Some of those have a chance of being good, but so did Doom, for crying out loud.

One more thing, I'm sick of these stupid movie games that just let you play every battle in the game. Star Wars: Revenge of the Sith, and every Lord of the Rings game, for example. I'm not playing another game like that again, not that I did to begin with. Enter the Matrix and Path of Neo are pretty much the same thing, just with guns and 'make everything impossible to control and see' buttons. Look, we can make a game look and feel just like a movie, except we'll throw in a bunch of extra levels that make no sense and don't contribute to the story at all. Fine, now make an actual game.
7.

Improve your voice acting.

Movies suck when they have bad actors in them, even if they are written and directed well. Look at any Keanu Reeves movie. Why would games be immune to bad acting?

If people are just going to skip every cut scene to avoid the terrible voice work, just leave them out all together.

The annoying thing is that the voice actor's union is fighting to get more money. They must not be able to get payed much because they have such a hard time expressing their wishes. They must have a hard time expressing anything, for that matter.

It's also depressing to see bad screen actors turning into bad voice actors. Keanu Reeves makes Path of Neo worse and worse every time he opens his unarticulated and semi-retarded mouth.
8.

Leave big decisions up to the Player.

It's what computer games are all about. Games have far bigger emotional impact than movies because the Player is actually involved in the decisions. Games today feel more like Pac Man, just weaving through tight corridors with only two ways to go, forward and backward. We need more Deus Ex and Grand Theft Auto, and less Medal of Honor.

9.

Bad controls + terrible gameplay = waste of time and money.

'IF NEO PUNCHES IN THE WRONG DIRECTION ONE MORE TIME I SWEAR TO GOD . . . ' is something that shouldn't have to be said during a game.

The gun combat in PoN makes me want to shoot myself because the controls are so terrible. Neo never shoots in the direction he is pointing, or in the direction the cursor is aiming. You would think that he would shoot in one of those two directions. The camera is in such an akward place, and the perspective is so bad that it just makes it worse. I can never tell what's going on, so I just randomly hit buttons and move around until the combat is over. When you get moves off on enemies, like jumping on them or whatever, it's only satisfying because you finally got the paticular combination of keys correct. The only reason I haven't shot myself yet is because I'm afraid that using a gun is actually like that.

WASD + Mouse is a good standard. Considering how often games come out that have half decent controls, it's so suprising that games still come out that are impossible to control. Sticking to standards like that leads me to the last one. . .
10.

Develop standards, while avoiding standards.

This is a tough one, but not really that tough if you play games on a semi regular basis. Things like WASD and the general layout of the HUD is pretty standard now. There is no reason why control response or the user interface are as terrible as they are in some games. Standards can help you get past simple things, so that you can move on to develop the more important things, like the 'make everything impossible to control and see' button. There is no reason to reinvent the wheel.

However, standards can really ruin a game. Quake 4 was so extremely boring because I've played that game hundreds of times already. Certain standards like 'enter room, spawn enemies, destroy enemies, give health / ammo, repeat' need to end. When games like The Sims or Black and White come out that completely redefine everything, they are applauded and succeed. That sort of innovation needs to continue. I'm all for denying conformity, after all. But keep in mind that games like Enter the Matrix and Daikatana are hated because they refuse to follow the simple pattern that gamers are used to, like playability.

It's a fine line, but it shouldn't be that hard for computer science and math experts.

That's just what I think. As always, I'm open to your comments / additions / criticism.

fields.title: T-Day
fields.text:
December 15th, 0800 hours.

T-Day.

Three tests, one day, hours of studying. So far things are going great. I knew my CPT 267 test was going to be easy, but then I saw the first question,

1.) What is the value of 'x' after the following code:

x = 17 % 9

A. 9
B. 1
C. 8
D. 10

I almost fell out of my chair. It only got easier from there. My favorite was:

15.) What header file should you include to have access to the string class?

A. <fstream>
B. <string>
C. <iostream>
D. 'math.h'

hmmmmmmmm, what could it be . . . . ?

The only confusing thing about the test was when I realized that there were two #42's, one of several stupid mistakes on the test. I love it when I could have taken my final a year ago and still gotten an A on it.

I'm not looking forward to the other two tests today. If another person tells me that I could have rescheduled them, I'll go insane. I am completely aware that if you have more than 2 tests on a single day you can reschedule one of them. I just didn't want to, because I don't really care. I like being able to take care of all of my tests in a big chunk. I'll be sure to post after The Economics and the Raster Imaging tests to let you all know how T-Day turned out.

One bonus of having to get up so early for the stupid test: being albe to blast my music at 9 in the morning and hoping that all of the morons in my hall are really annoyed by it. It's revenge for everyone who was yelling and screaming last night when I was trying to sleep, or for everyone who was yelling and screaming while I was trying to study, or for everyone who was yelling and screaming while I was trying to sit here without people yelling and screaming. There is far too much yelling and screaming in this hall.

For anyone who didn't find those two questions quite as easy as I did, it's fine. They are both just really easy programming questions. The first one is dealing with modulus (%) which takes two numbers and returns the remainder after deviding them. It's one of the simplest concepts in programming, and it basically means that a lot of the test was just simple elementary school math. The second question is slightly more complicated, but it's still insanely easy.

fields.title: My Normal Day I
fields.text:
Ok, so the ACTF is the American College Theatre Festival. This thing I'm at is the regional competition. A representitive comes to each show at each school in the country and they pick the best actor or actress to go to this competition. Everyone who is selected picks a partner (it can be anyone) and then picks two scenes to do with that person and then a monologue. After round one (which happened bright and early this morning), the more than 350 teams is thinned down to 35. Those 35 then do their scenes again, and one of them is selected to go to the national competition. The winner of that competition wins a nice $2,500 scholarship. Last year, the lovely and talented Amanda Folena (from right here at Purdue) went all the way and won the national scholarship. So remember that next time you think Purdue's theatre department doesn't exist. Here are those nominated from Purdue:

  • Caley Milliken, from A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.
  • Joe Quadres, from A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum.
  • Andrew Carlson, from Arms and the Man
  • Stacie Hadgikosti, from Arms and the Man
  • Annelise Dickinson, from His Occupation
  • Alexander Floyd, from His Occupation
  • Lauren Sivak, from Marisol
  • Matthew Erickson, from Metamorphoses
  • Suzanne Miller, from Metamorphoses
  • Lauren Briggeman, from Road (for those of you who saw Road, she was the angry Daughter who gave the speach near the end about everything being dirty)
  • Peter Kremidas, from Road (again, for those of you who saw Road, he was the guy who starved himself)

An Impressive list, to be sure. Five of them are grad students (the ones in bold), and the others are undergrad. I have the honor of being the lovely and talented Matthew Erickson's partner. It's a real honor to be chosen by him, because I've seen him in several shows and I really look up to him. We performed this morning, at about 11:40 (Normal time; 12:40 Lafayette time). As it turns out, you can only do one scene of the two you selected for the first run, because there are so many groups. Matthew and I did a scene from Beggars in the House of Plenty by John Patrick Shanley. It went pretty well. I was also able to see the lovely and talented Andrew Carlson's scene, the lovely and talented Annelise Dickinson's scene, and the lovely and talented Caley Milliken's scene. I'll report on how everything went later. Stay tuned.

In case you haven't noticed, I refer to everyone in theatre as 'lovely and talented.'

fields.title: No creativity
fields.text:
I'm starting to see just how dark this world is. More and more, I'm realizing that there is no real creativity anymore. Any attempt to produce any creative thought is immediatly and painfully shot down. I can see where the games industry is leading, and it's heading down a road that I can't follow. I can't work in a world where the only definition for success is profit. I can't play by their rules.

Things I've seen about Path of Neo haunt me. PC Gamer gave it a 67 percent, which they call 'above average.' They admit that it's not a great game, but they call it above average because it's all they get. How can everyone just roll over and accept that filth? As my friend Scott Shultz put it, '[Path of Neo] had lots of bugs and the gameplay was pretty bad, also the gun fighting was not to my satisfaction. But when I installed the game the only thing I was really looking for was some descent hand to hand combat and it following the movie fairly well. I got that and so I was happy enough to get past the bugs and gameplay(which by the way the combat is really not that bad once you get used to it).'

Scott's statement sums up the entire game industry. Here is what he is saying:

'It's pretty painful to play, but I want to play a(n) [insert genre] game, and it is the only possible option. The human body can endure quite a bit of pain, anyway.'

Why do we have to settle? Why are we forced to pay for the EA Games-fueled plague of lazyness and apathy among developers?

This is only the beginning. What will be left in 5 years when I might be ready to make any sort of difference? What will be left worth fighting for?

fields.text:
I found out last night that I can't move back into the same dorm room again next year. They(the Morons In Charge)'re changing this wing of Meredith to be all girl next year. I'm very much not wanting to get another dorm room if I can't have this one. Any other room that would be similar to this one would be quite a bit more expensive.

So I need one of two things to happen:

  • Either someone who is moving out of an apartment or has room there so I can move in
  • Or someone who knows a way that I can fight the MIC about this.

So if you have room in your apartment, you're moving out at the end of this year, or you know someone who will have room next year, please contact me and we'll discuss it. Also, if you're interested in bureaucracy and you think I might be able to get the MIC to leave this hall alone, contact me. Simmilarly, if you think I'm awesome and you want to tell me, contact me. One more thing, if you have a lot of money, and you think I should have some of it, contact me.

fields.text:
The audition for the Monkeys was last night. I think I did alright. My scene work was pretty good. My real weakness is the games where we stand in a line and make jokes about something. Last night we played b movie, in which we say 'I saw a bad movie about _ last night' then everyone else says 'how bad was it?' and we say 'it was so bad, _.' I pretty much bombed that one. I've never been good with being on the spot, which is why I don't think I should really do improv, but it especially hurts in a game like b movie or worlds worst. I've always wanted to have a quick wit like my uncle Mike, up near Detroit. He makes jokes all the time, and I think he would be perfect at improv games like that. I try to make puns like that, but I usually can't think of anything. Anyway, I don't really know how well it went. This is pretty much my one chance to work with Peter before he leaves Purdue, and I would like to get in for that reason alone. They said they would call in the next couple days if I made it. I'm not holding my breath.

In other News, I've made some small changes to the site. You might have noticed that the menus have changed. This is something new that I'm trying, and I'm going to see what more I can do with javascript effects. If the buttons don't seem to work correctly, you should try to refresh the page, and it might work better. I kinda' like this way, but Cameron said that it overlaps content, which isn't good. I might switch back to the old way, but we'll see. I've also tweaked the updates ticker on top of the screen, so it includes the News Quotetm changes now, and you can look at past quotes if you click the ticker when it has something about the quote on it. As always, you can click on the ticker and it will take you to whatever it is referencing. I'm working on the page that lists all of the updates in a big list, but it isn't working yet.

fields.title: He's 50!
fields.text:
I just felt I needed to make some sort of update. I'm at home for the weekend, for my Dad's 50th birthday. It's somewhat odd to think that my Dad is 50. It's worse thinking that I'm going to be 20 this year.

Anyway, I'm home for a couple days to hang out with dad. We played a game of the Star Trek card game, and looked at some renderings. Then I showed my parents The Aristocrats, which was a nice experience. We also played with Dad's new camera. It's an amazing single lense reflex from Nikon. I'm in love.

See some pictures.

I took these pictures with the new camera. Dad went into the garage to check out the job that my Mom and sister had done. They cleaned it up nicely. That's Scott on the right (he's 19). Dad's on the left (he's 50).

He also got this new cordless drill.

Scott helped me out with a nice perspective shot. I now realize that Aili should have been standing about a foot to the left. Dad also got this new vacuum cleaner. It seems that most of his presents were things that he could use to do things for mom.

This picture shows how amazing the camera is. You can't really see at this size, but it's perfectly in focus and it has perfect color and light. Trust me. This picture doesn't really show anything that my Dad got for his birthday.

I'm not sure what's going on in this one.

But then came the dog.

Theadore hadn't seen 'the tall guy' in a couple weeks, so he was pretty excited to see me. He barked quite a bit.

For anyone who is wondering, Ted E. always looks like this. It's not a lense trick or photoshop effect. He's just always this blurry.

The D50 is the only camera with a fast enough shutter speed to capture Mr. Bear.

Ted barked a lot. Notice that Scott has been backing away slowly through the last several pictures.

This is why. Tedward found 'the guy who smells like food' and was pretty excited to see him, too.

Scott finally subdued Theadore, though.

But only for a moment. Edward had to come see what I was doing.

Then he said hi to Aili.

There they are, the ultimate creators of this website.

And here's Dad working on something. I'll give five dollars if someone (besides my Dad) can guess what program he's working with. Click the picture to see a larger version.

fields.title: A simple guide to enjoy Garfield
fields.text:
Jim Davis is a comic genius. His strip, Garfield isn't really very funny anymore. To the untrained eye! He obvously knew that to branch off into more cerebral comedy would kill his strip, so he kept it somewhat normal. However, if you simply remove all of Garfield's thought bubbles, it becomes one of the funniest comic strips to ever grace the newspaper. Find out for yourself.

Click Here

Here's a handy guide that will hopefully help you enjoy Garfield even more. Simply removing Garfield's thought bubbles really changes the whole dynamic of the comic up.

Garfield's owner, Jon, seems like such a weirdo. Maybe no women want to date him because he talks to his cat so much.

Sometimes Jon just looks completely insane.

Occassionally, you have to do more than just erase dialogue. Sometimes removing Garfield all together works.

Try removing or tweaking a frame.

Here's my personal favorite. It's comic genius, I tell you.

Well, there you go. I hope you will enjoy Garfield as much as I do, and I hope that it gets to run for another 27 years!

fields.text: Well, I'm home right now for Spring Break. There are now two big dogs here, and they get along well enough to help each other bother us to no end. The animal hair and dust is really getting to me, and I am starting to agree with the otolaringologist that I am allergic to cats and dogs. fields.title: Daylight: Saved
fields.text:
I just went through a time warp. The Crazy Monkeys went to Champaign, Illinois for an Improv show Saturday night. They are an hour behind Indiana. We went and the guys had a great show. Then, at 2 AM (3 AM Indiana time), the clocks rolled up an hour, for daylight savings time. This year, Indiana decided to participate in this rediculous waste of time (literally), so everybody rolled up an hour. I hadn't changed my watch back to Illinois time, so in the end I didn't have to because the time zone changed itself to my watch. All I had to do was roll my watch up an hour when we got back to Indiana. The problem is that at some point in there, I lost an hour. I never rolled my watch back an hour, but I rolled it forward. I hate time.

I thought up two things after this adventure through time.

1.) Some day, I will attempt to go around the world backwards, and see if it's possible to stay between 12:00 and 1:00 for an entire day. I'll make a TV show about it.

2.) Next year, I'm going to Cincinnatti for the Daylight Savings switch. Theoretically, I'll get my hour back. Hell, I might as well go all the way to the next time zone after that, and I'll make my hour back plus interest.

fields.title: Rediculous things
fields.text:
There are some pretty rediculous things going on right now. Here is one.

John Deely is a bastard.
We had our first dress rehearsal for The Winter's Tale on Monday, but unfortunately I also had an exam for my Stat class. No worries, I thought, I'll just go in before the exam and ask when the makeup session is. Every exam I've been to here at Purdue has had a makeup session, so that people in my position can take the test later when it is more convenient. The Winter's Tale is an academic function, so it definitely has precedence over an exam, and I am allowed to take any conflicting exam later. John Deely didn't think so. John Deely is the 'professor' of my Stat class. When I went in to tell him that I couldn't take the test (after having just walked from my room to Lynn hall and then to Matthews just to find the guy), he took me into the hallway and gave me a very well practiced and loud speech. It would have been intimidating and a maybe even a little scary if he wasn't straining to look up so he could yell at my face. He asked me if I thought this was High School. He said that he thought we were more mature than that. He apparently had something against me telling him that I couldn't take the test at the last minute. I had every reason to turn it right back at him and chew him out for being an asshole, but I stroked the little man's ego, just to humor him. I shut up and stared down at his bald spot (honestly, you can't intimidate a guy who's a good two feet taller than you, John). I just went ahead and took the test, since it wasn't really necessary for me to be at the dress rehearsal right away anyway.

Thanks to the glories of modern internet, I can tell the world what I wished I had said to John Deely. Here's what I really wanted to say to him:

Ok, listen up, buddy. (take step forward, really emphasising the height) You have absolutely no right to talk to me like that. Quite a bit of money exchanged hands so that I could go here, so I'm not doing this for your benefit. I pay you, pal. The money you spend on your comeover comes straight from my tuition, little man, so you better respect me. I came in here with every bit of respect for you, and I respectfully asked you to make up the test, and you think you have the right to yell at my face? I can't take this test because I have an academic function which I am contractually obliged to attend. You're going to let me make up this test tomorrow, or I'm going to get the dean in here to explain it to you further. You talk to me about maturity? You think your class is so much more than high school? Look, pal, you're teaching a bunch of Liberal Arts majors at an engineering school. This test that people are taking is open book, and open note. You're questioning my maturity, and you're teaching a class that has all open book exams? You're absolutely right, pal, this is nothing like high school. I never had anything this easy in high school. I know you get off on yelling at students, and I'm terribly sorry that I'm not going to just bend over and let you go nuts, but nobody - especially nobody who's paid with my money - talks to me like that. I'll see you tomorrow. (Put badass sunglasses on and walk out)

I had every right to say that to him, but I'm kinda glad I didn't. I just took the test and got it out of the way.

fields.title: Antisocial
fields.text:
The show went really well. I had fun, and I think everyone else did, too. It really is a breathtaking spectacle, and everyone who can should see it. After the show tonight there was this reception for everyone. They had some cookies and punch out and everyone gathered to discuss the show. The audience was mostly older people tonight, but there were some younger folks as well. Richard Rand saw the show tonight, and he really enjoyed it. Rich directed Road, which I was in last semester, and he's an amazing director to work with. I felt really akward, though. For some reason I feel like I'm in a different show than everyone else. I sit backstage and watch the show through the closed-circuit television, and then I go on for a couple minutes to say my lines. Of course the only things people said to me tonight were mentioning how tall I looked in my costume. That's really my only function. My sole purpose is to look impressive. I don't have to act. I just have to be tall. I can't really say that I'm not excited to be able to use my only strong physical characteristic. To be honest, I have been training for this my entire life. I just feel sepparated from the rest of the cast for some reason. It must just be me, because I felt this way about Road, too. I do have fun, and I enjoy goofing around with everyone backstage. I can't help but feel like the only reason I'm there is because I am abnormally and freakishly tall, and they are exploiting the fact that people like to stare at me. Other people talk about their lives, like what they've done recently, or movies they like. People only talk to me about how tall I am. It's ok, though, beacause my life is pretty boring, so I wouldn't really have anything else to talk about anyway.

It's just really hard to describe how I am feeling. Maybe I should write a movie about it.

fields.title: Champion
fields.text:
Tuesday evening, at 5:30 PM, the cast of The Winter's Tale played the first official games for the Purdue Theatre Basketball League (PTBL). We had 14 people show up, so we set up 3 teams. Two of the teams had five people, and one had 4. We commenced a four on four on four tournament. I was on the four person team, with my Li'l Chum and Stevie Chaddock. We also had a guy who was a friend of one of the cast. I don't know where this guy came from, but I sure was glad he was on our team. Even though we had one less player than the rest of the teams, we still held our own. The first game we played we lost, but then after recouperating and watching our two competitors play, we performed much better. We beat both teams, and then beat the first one again for the hell of it. We are therefore the ultimate PTBL champions. It feels very good to be on top, even though many of my muscles don't. The next game is next Tuesday at 5:30, so we'll have to defend our title then. I don't think it will be very hard, considering we are champions.

Also, I made my first slam dunk on Tuesday, which is pretty exciting. Ok, so it was more of a lay-up where I touched the rim, but it went in. I'll keep working, and soon I'll be a slam dunk champion, too. I sure have more dunks on my record than anyone else in the PTBL. I'm starting to see why people always wonder if I play basketball. I am pretty awesome.
