fields.title: Joey Marburger: Idiot
fields.text:
There are some pretty rediculous things going on right now. Here's another one.

I found an idiot. It's really not that hard to find an idiot around here, but I'm pretty proud of this one. He's a really stupid one. His name is Joey Marburger, and he is the assistant features editor for the Purdue Exponent. This man (boy) is one of the primary reasons why the Purdue student newspaper is knicknamed the 'Excrement' by most of the students. Here is Joey's column from Thursday, April 20th, entitled

Excise proves freedom isn't free

Excise proves 'freedom isn't free'

I've got a problem. It runs in packs, costs hundreds of dollars and makes me sick. Yes, I'm talking about excise police.

With the sexiest party day of the year upon us, these bounty hunters of the underage drinker will be out in full force to make sure you might not have a good time. Now hold on, before this gets too intense, I must say that I respect local police and their efforts to provide security and make students safe. But excise police just don't do it for me.

I guess you can get a rush out of busting parties to which you weren't invited, writing tickets ruining someone's social life for quite some time, and making personal money off another's misery. But is the safety for underage drinkers really the issue? What if all minors quit drinking and there weren't any tickets to hand out anymore? Well, poop. I suppose excise would be out of a job and the crap ton of money they, and the fine state of Indiana, make.

Really the issue is Indiana spends money on these guys to crawl around and bust kids while murderers and rapists roam the streets. You know why? Because busting hardcore criminals doesn't pay good money. So please excise, if you care about people's safety, try being a real cop and make a difference.

Oh, if you get on the Indiana Excise Police Web site (link) you might notice the third purpose in their mission statement is 'to provide for the raising of revenue.' That 'revenue' might go to education, or something beneficial for the state, but I'm sure a good bit of it goes right to excise officers' pockets.

And for those who wish to party this weekend just remember from the fine creators of 'Team America World Police,' freedom isn't free. It costs about $500 after court services.

Joey Marburber is a junior in the College of Liberal Arts. He believes he will be singled out for a P.I. this weekend due to this column. He can be reached at features@purdueexponent.org.



That is exactly how the article appeared in the Excrement. I don't know if I should even say anything about the article. It really speaks for itself. Joey Marburger is an idiot. I wish I could get the picture he has next to this, because it is another good argument for his idiocy. He has one of those emo haircuts, with hair covering his right eye. He has a black shirt and a red striped tie. His right arm is stretched forward, his thumb akwardly jutting upward at a strange angle. The picture looks like it was taken a half second early, that he was in the middle of smiling and giving us all a 'thumbs-up.' The picture looks like the camera man took it just a bit early, so poor Joey's smile hadn't really formed yet, and his thumb was stuck at that weird pergatory somewhere between the presidential thumb's up gesture and the thing a painter does to measure his subject. The picture looks like it was captured at an akward time, but I bet Joey's just one of those people who always look like that. His writing seems like it was taken just a bit too early, too, and if he had just let those thoughts develop a little bit more, he would have realized that it was such a terrible idea.

I suppose I should at least elaborate on some of the things he's talking about. The 'sexiest party day of the year' is referring to the fact that it is Grand Prix week, which is just a rediculous excuse for everyone on campus to be completely drunk all weekend. Considering how much underaged drinking happens on a regular basis on campus, this week is most definitely a good time to bolster the police force. As much as he hates the excise police, I can almost gaurantee that they won't to the job anywhere near well enough to curb the amount of alcohol abuse here. Oh, and that link that he lists in his column (the link above is exactly what he listed) is not about excise police, it's just the Indiana State Alcohol and Tobacco Commision. Providing for the raising of revenue is just talking about the fact that they give licenses to people to sell alcohol. It has nothing to do with excise police at all.

Boy I hope he gets arrested this weekend.

Some day, this website will have a list of idiots who are drags on society and rediculous excuses for human beings. John Deely and Joey Marburger will top that list.

fields.title: Aili's new house
fields.text:
My sister, Aili (who readers of this site have met already) has made several proud accomplishments. She recently accomplished one. My sister is a homeowner.



So here's the new house (new to her). It obviously needs some work, but that's what she's looking for. The transaction completed last week. My mother and I arrived at about noon o'clock today to help out with the early stages of fixing this place up.

Aili and her dog, Lucy had already arived. Lucy was already bored, but was interested in mom's feet for a while.

Dad works just down the road from Aili's house, so he showed up to help out with the deadbolt. I'm not sure what Aili was talking about. Aili said something about a task that she thought was important. She was worried about the necessary equipment or materials that would be needed for said task.

Mom expressed her disagreement that said task was as necessary as Aili thought. Mom then went on to convey her lack of faith in the entire project and her annoyance at something either Aili the dog or myself was doing.

My task was to put some nails into the ceiling. I had to make sure that I looked cool while I did it, so I wore my sunglasses. I eventually covered one of those holes full of electrical danglies with a smoke detector.

Then I put some nails into the floor. The blood rushed to my head and I got a little loopy for a while after this. At least I still looked cool. It's annoying that the floor had some electrical danglies, too. That's more smoke detectors than a room needs, in my opinion.

Aili told me to get some pictures of the house. I didn't feel like her paticular usage of the words 'goofball' and 'weirdo' was really necessary.

So, ok, here's the rest of the house. Namely the stairs going up.

The upstairs bedroom.

The upstairs bathroom with flanking shower heads.

The unfinished upstairs back room. Text reads: 'Temp Wall' 'Do not screw with'

A closeup of the AC plug. It is not plugged in, and as a result the outlet is asleep.

Here is a shot of the nice view from the rear window. Speedway!

Here's the other room upstairs. It's a nice little office. There are a handful of network plugs under the desk there. I know they're connected, because I tested them, but I can't for the life of me figure out where the hub is.

Going back downstairs. Financial status should be based on how many turns are in your stairs. Aili has two. How many turns are in your stairs?

The nice lady across the street noticed that the house needed a new tire. This one was flat.

Lucy had some 'splaining to do.

Dad and I got to work.

Mom helped.

The jack needed to be positioned right under those little notches.

No time for that! You can just call me jack from now on.

Now it's time for lunch. Mom and I piled into the truck, and Aili drove her car to the tire place to get the flat one patched. Dad went back to his office.

There isn't a whole lot of room in Mom's truck.

And you really have to watch out for hop-ons. This guy jumped into the back of the truck, and he seemed pretty crazy. On closer inspection, though, his shirt shows that he was an architect, so he was definitely crazy.

Anyway, back to the house. This is the kitchen. It doesn't look too bad. There were some crazy box things nailed to the bottom of the cabinets which were quickly removed. That's one of the largest microwave ovens I've ever seen. The kitchen sink was pretty dirty and pretty bland. The kitchen ladder was in good shape, though.

Here's the room behind the kitchen. It's in pretty bad shape. The roof is breaking, the walls are falling apart, the door is screwed shut, the floor needs to be rebuilt, there's a hole in the back wall, the wall to the left is not even really there, and the lightbulb was dead. Once it's completed, though, it will be a pretty awesome room, I think. To the left is the stairs going down to the basement and the circuit box.

This guy showed up at about 3:30, when the school bus came by. His name is R.J. He was pretty creepy, and a little too familiar with the house. We think there was some bad business between him and the previous owner. He helped out with some stuff, but he mostly just stood around and said random things. I believe in this picture he was counting something in the downstairs bathroom. Or maybe he was playing checkers on the wall. That's enough of him.

This is the exterior of the house.

The yard is getting to pretty jungle-level proportions. R.J. offered to mow the lawn for a couple bucks a week.

When we got back home, Lucy was pretty tired.

Well, that's all of the pictures I got. If you were wanting more, you're just getting greedy. Stay tuned for tomorrow, for the scoop on election day: Pointless '06.

fields.title: Pointless 06
fields.text:
I wish I could make an extended post mocking the lame news coverage of voting, but I don't have the time. The 2006 Primaries were this past Tuesday, if some of you didn't notice. I can understand if you weren't extremely excited about who your county commissioner, prosecutor, or sheriff is. I'm sure you're even less interested about who could possibly be running for those positions in the fall. That's the really pointless thing about these primaries. You're not voting for anything (with one exception, which I'll get to), you're just voting for who you want to vote for in November. Plus, you have to pick a party and just vote for them, and in Hancock county (where I'm from), only one party exists. Hancock has voted Republican in every election since Lincoln. That's a legacy we're not soon to give up. As a result, you're stupid if you vote for any other party (I say that like it's a big choice, there's only one other party) in the primaries, because they will lose, without fail. So, yes, I am sorry to say that I am currently classified as a Republican.

The one important thing (and the only reason I went home during finals), was the school board race. People might remember my long post about Dr. Riggs and his crazy construction plan (go ahead and click anywhere between these parentheses to read that post). His crazy construction plan was turned down by the public, thankfully, but we need people in the board to tell him that he's an idiot and stop him before he does anything else really stupid. My mom was the campaign manager for a candidate who promises to do just that. These two guys, David Bush and Shelton Oakes ran for school board with the local taxpayers in mind. The board needed two new members. Shelton Oakes was elected, but David Bush unfortunately came in third place. A lady (the only woman running) got the first seat. I will avoid getting into the politics of it all, but needless to say we're somewhat upset that Bush didn't get elected. We're almost as upset as when that other Bush was elected.

Anyway, I stood with my Mom outside one of the voting places to hand out buttons and tell everyone that David Bush and Shelton Oakes would appreciate their vote. I believe that's called Electioneering. In total, about 250 people showed up at the Fortville Boys and Girl's club to vote. That's out of about 1200 registered voters who were supposed to go there, and that's about of about twice that many eligible adults in that part of Fortville. That makes it about a 10% turn out.

I voted at my old high school (going back to that place was a very tramatic experience). I was number 194, and I voted at about 1:30. The poles were open at 6:00.

It just really gets me that so few people care.

Some pictures

This sign sat outside the door of the Boy's and Girl's Club. Fifty feet was judged to be about the doorway, so as long as we stayed outside the building we were fine. It's crazy that it is a felony to electioneer. Imagine being convicted, and never being able to vote again, just for the two or so people who were ever in the place at one time.

They don't like Electioneering. Subterranean Homesick Alien, and Karma Police are fine.

Budd Gray showed up and hung out for a while. The guy on the phone and the guy with the sunglasses are a couple of cronies who showed up with him. Budd is running for Sheriff. The whole thing had a huge mafia vibe, with the two muscles following him around. Budd got by far the most votes (because he had by far the most money, that's how democracy works), so he will be sheriff in the fall. I say he will be sheriff, even though he's just the Republican candidate, because nobody is going to vote for the Democrat.

The judge came out a couple times to make sure we were playing the right Radiohead songs.

Budd Gray is a pretty big guy. He'll probably make a good sheriff, just because nobody is going to mess with him. I'm taller, though, so he's just a little guy to me.

'David Bush and Shelton Oakes would appreciate your vote for School Board.' If Mom had said that one foot further, she could have been arrested. If she had just gone inside wearing all of the 'Bush Oakes' buttons that she had on, she could have been arrested. Awesome.

This guy, Kim Dailey, is currently on the school board, and he was running for reelection. He didn't win.

Here I am voting, right where they told me to.

Peter Kremidas has written the first Deny Conformity guest column. Here it is for your viewing pleasure.

This column was written by Peter Kremidas, and is his intellectual property.

Guest Column


by Peter Kremidas

I have to write my thoughts down by hand, with a pen and paper. It slows me down, let’s the ideas form themselves and become concrete. I’m sitting in village coffee shop, about 4 hours before the second to last exam I will ever take. There is a ceiling fan right below a ceiling light, so the light is pulsing like kitten’s quickly beating heart on my paper. There is bad music in the background. It sounds like sad John Mayer. So it must be John Mayer, or Coldplay.

Conversations about people’s problems and upcoming tests appear and disappear at random, fading in and out with the ‘Ts’ and ‘Ss’ cutting the short silences with the most clarity. The words don’t even register in my mind. These are only sounds humans make; it’s best not to try and make sense of them.

The occasional clinking of silverware, turn of a paper, and other various clicks, movements, and sounds of friction come in and out and complete the message that there is life here.

All these people are just like me. We have our whole lives ahead of us, and we don’t even know it. We can’t know it. When I think about how much my current decisions really effect the rest of my life, my handwriting suddenly gets small and nervous, and I don’t want to do anything so that I can stay safe and mistake-less. It’s a pressure that nobody isn’t aware of, but everybody ignores. Maybe that explains the escapism. Maybe early twenty-somethings drink as much as they do in order to make that pressure go away. If not drink, we all have our own brand of escapism. Video games, TV, movies, the internet, art, masturbation on an epic scale, whatever dips your proverbial chip.

Imagine going through every day fully realizing just what the fuck you’re doing with your life here. It’s no wonder that we periodically act as if our actions had no consequences. After all, we’re on the edge here, right between childhood and adulthood. It’s no wonder that college is one part cerebral boot camp, and another part playground for big kids. Most of us just aren’t grown up enough yet to live in a world full of consequences.

I was…well, still am among those lacking the strength to completely accept the world as it is. And it’s high time I learned. My mode of escapism was the same as most people’s. I drank, I did drugs. But, unlike others, I picked another poison as well. I picked comedy. I was picked by the crazy monkeys. And now I’m graduating and it’s time to go on to what my dad calls “bigger and better things.”

Being as analytical as I am, I can’t help but think about this supposed “bigger and better” world. I think about it, and I have had by far the best times of my life here. I have laughed the hardest, loved the most, danced the hardest, accomplished the things I am most proud of, made my best friends, learned the most, and done it all more here than anywhere else. Ever.

But there was another side to this. My worst times happened here, too. There were many times when I didn’t think I would ever get better, that I would never be happy again. There were times I cried so hard that I left stains in cold pavement. I hurt more here than anywhere else, and I’ve got the scars to prove it. And by the way, if you think all that was over one woman, you’re giving her way too much credit.

And all through it all, I stood on a stage with some “Crazy Monkeys,” with all these life long friends that have come and gone through the years.

And we laughed.

We laughed no matter what.

And so, when my dad talks about things getting “bigger” and “better” for me, I think he’s right. I think things will get bigger for me. I really do. But I don’t think they’ll ever get any better than this.

Thanks so much, and goodbye.

I’d better get back to studying.

-Peter Kremidas, May 5th, 2006.



Peter Kremidas is a graduating senior at Purdue University. He is planning on pursuing a career in comedy and life. I guess I shouldn't say that he's planning. He isn't really planning on doing anything, and that's what makes him special.

fields.title: Inconvenient
fields.text:
Everyone needs to see this movie. I urge you all, as citizens of Earth (and probably the United States), to learn about the current crisis we are faced with. It isn't war. It isn't oil. It isn't the current administration. It isn't rising gas prices. It isn't the corporations taking over. It isn't Apple. It isn't Microsoft. It isn't nuclear war.

This crisis is global warming. I know, I know, global warming has been about as much of a concern as a plague of locusts, and nobody really cares. I'm telling you, though, it's important, and you need to see just how much.

It is my opinion that Al Gore would have been the igreatest president of all time, were he elected in 2000 (or had the republicans not stolen the election, however the case might be). He has an extremely important message. It's very disappointing that people today are so controlled by politics that they refuse to see his message. Please, for your own sake, look past your blind devotion for just 100 minutes and listen to what he has to say. If you don't, there is a very good chance that hundreds of millions of people will die.

The film is An Inconvenient Truth, out now in theatres across the country. You can see a list of the theatres the film is playing at here.

Visit www.climatecrisis.net for more information about how you can save the world.

Feel free to tell me why I might be wrong here. I would love to discuss it.

fields.title: Sign Adventures in Louisville
fields.text:
I recently spent some time in the Louisville area, working on my aunt's yard with my cousin, Pat. I was really interested in the signs that populated the area.

Click here to see them.

Street Signs

Here's a delightful little sign. It was just down the street from my aunt's house. An interesting thing about this area is that many of the signs are lacking the cross street, like this one. If someone was driving along Hawley Gibson Road, and they came to this street, how do they know what it is called? Well, the name of the street pictured here is actually...


...Old Floydsburg Road, which is not to be confused with...


. . . Regular Floydsburg Road. Floydsburg and Old Floydsburg actually intersect, but unfortunately there are no road signs at the intersection. It really makes you wonder, though. Which came first, Floydsburg or Old Floydsburg? Did they make a street called Old Floydsburg before they made a street called Floydsburg? Another interesting pair of streets are


OLD LAGRANGE


and Regular LaGrange road. These two pictures are actually of the same intersection. It goes in LaGrange, and comes out OLD LAGRANGE.


This is the street my aunt lives on. Kavanaugh lane.


But just down the street is Kavanaugh road. These two roads are completely unrelated and unconnected.


State Road 1447.


Chamberlain Lane. Seems a little redundant.


I'll meet you at the corner of Old Floydsburg Road and 329-BY-PASS Road.


The end of the pavement there is the end of Woodcreek Crossing Way. It isn't wooded, it isn't anywhere near a creek, and it crosses nothing. This isn't a road. It's a driveway.


Misc Signs

The truck in that sign is very angry.


Oh boy. Beef Brisket, Pork Butt, and Amish Chickens. Who buys Amish Chickens??


The Rug Man 2: Captain Carpet's Revenge


Somebody needs to turn those 't's into 'f's.


This is a great sign.


Up and down are apparently both down now.


It's a good thing Bob Evans has plenty of Dino Toobs. You wouldn't want to run out of Toobed Dino.


These roadwork warning signs are absolutely everywhere. Five hundred feet down this road, there is another sign saying 'Road Work 500 Feet.' Four hundred feet from that sign is a sign that says 'Road Work 100 Feet.' And then one hundred feet from that sign is nothing. Roadwork signs clutter the streets, but there no actual road work happening anywhere. I wish I could have gotten a picture looking down a hill where you can see roadwork signs every hundred feet. Almost as frequent as these signs are signs that say 'end roadwork.' They seem more like a political campaign than a road construction warning. Judging from how much road work is actually happening on these roads, the campaign seems to have been a success.


Interstate Signs

Gene Snyder Freeway Ends In Kentucky.


NO, not Zorn! His evil plot to take over the world can not succeed!


I need more time to prepare my hyper plasma quantum molecular partical accelerator beams. I must defeat the evil Zorn!


CURSE YOU, ZORN!!!

fields.title: First test
fields.text:
The first Wednesday of the semester is a student's first test of the semester. Students are challenged to remember where all of the classes they had on Monday are. Here's a list of classes that I'm taking this semester.

Ethics
One night, you go to sleep. When when you wake up, you see that you are in a hospital room, with a bunch of tubes connecting you to someone in the bed next to you. You learn that the champion orchestral troupe has kidnapped you because their star violinist has taken ill and you are the only person who can keep him from riding the bullet train to deadsville. Are you morally obligated to stay until the violinist gets better, or are you ethically justified in giving them all a big 'screw you' and leaving? Welcome to Ethics 101.
Voice for the actor
The most attractive of the Purdue theatre grad students teaches me how to properly use my voice(s). At the end of last year, she and a few other grad students mentioned that I have a really good voice, so I quickly signed on for this course. I now see that it was just a ploy to help her meet her quota.
Stage Combat
Richard Stockton Rand, the professor I am creating a web site for, is a pretty amazing little man. In this class, I learn how to beat the crap out of someone without actually touching them. Later, I will learn how to swordfight, and perhaps eventually broadswordfight. Rich is teaching me mental and physical discipline, which right now translates to extreme muscle fatigue. I am sore in places I didn't know I had muscles. Perks: a really gorgeous, over-six-foot-tall volleyball player named Alex. Cons: always being paired up with her and realizing that she is quite a bit more physically fit than I am.
Acting Workshop III
The heroes from Acting Workshop II: Curse of the Meisner-Monster meet up once again, but this time, it's personal. The evil Zorn Avenue is going to destroy the world, and only the performance of classic American and European realism will stop it. Zorn's weakness is Henrik Ibsen, as it turns out.
Intro to Lighting technology
We all have to sign up to work on lights for a paticular show taking place this semester. I signed up for the winter dance show, hoping to get a chance to hang out with some scantily clad dancers, and impress them with my mental and physical discipline. It probably won't happen, but a guy can dream.

It's a pretty light schedule, but I also have a job this semester (don't ask me what it is; I have no idea, to be honest). I'm somewhat glad I don't have more, because after just the third day, I'm exhausted. If that Stage Combat class doesn't have me toned and fit by the end of the semester, it can't be done.

In other news, I finished my first draft of my screenplay. Now all I have to do is pick up everything and move to LA. I've sent a few copies to a few of my peers, and the initial reactions seem to be positive. Stay tuned to see how this works out.

My first Crazy Monkeys show will be Friday, September 8, at 8:00. It will be at the Village Coffee house, and it will be free. Come see me be nervous and terrified.

fields.title: Shauron's Name Adventures
fields.text:
I'm a man of many names. Well, perhaps I'm not a man, but I do have many names. I will recount my misnamed misadventures here, so that everyone can find entertainment in other people's confusion.

Part I, In which Shauvon glazes over twelve whole years of his life

According to my mother, she who named me, my name means 'Night Hawk' in Gaelic. When she was very pregnant with me (I was 12.5 pounds when I was born, so she was very pregnant), she had a dream. In my mother's dream, she was standing outside at night. A hawk appeared, flew toward her, landed in her arms, and turned into a baby. That baby was me. Anyway, that's how I got my crazy name. The name that would haunt so many teachers. My mom told me recently that it's a combination of Shawn and Steven, and she's correct.

The most commonly used name I receive is 'Shuvon,' with the emphasis on the second syllable. Shove on is not the correct way to pronounce my name. It's the correct way to move one large thing so that it is on top of something else. I actually met a girl at Purdue last year whose name is Shavonne. Her name is pronounced 'Shuv-ON.'

One time I got a detention slip with the name 'Shavin' on it.

When I was in seventh grade, my gym teacher insisted on calling me shove on. One time, when I was bored in his 'health class,' he called shove on to get a worksheet back. I was sick of telling him that it's Shauvon, so I yelled 'IT'S SHAUVON' and quickly grabbed the worksheet out of his hand. He made me do ten pushups.

Only one teacher, in my entire 12 years of public school, was able to pronounce it correctly on the first try (that I remember). I will name him for you now. Mr. Chef, my fifth grade teacher, had just returned from vacation in Ireland, so he was familiar with Gaelic pronunciations. I tip my hat to you, Mr. Chef.

I guess I should be happy that my high school diploma had my correct name on it. It wouldn't suprise me at all, though, if those idiots at Mt. Vernon Community School Corporation had misspelled it. Considering they did almost every single time they tried in the twelve years I was a student there.

I hope you enjoy reading the stories of my name misadventures as much as I enjoyed living them. Well, I actually hope you don't enjoy it as much as I did. I didn't enjoy it very much at all.

Continue to Part II of Shauron's Name Adventures

fields.title: Name adventures: Part II
fields.text:
In which Shauvon is accepted to college, and visits a pulmonologist.

In 2004, I was accepted to Purdue University. It was a pretty exciting moment in my life. Well, not that exciting, I suppose, considering they accept somewhere around 50,000 new students every year. That was before I realized I didn't really want to get a degree in Computer Graphics Technology, so I was getting a degree in Computer Graphics Technology. I will always remember opening my acceptance letter. They came one day when I was at school. I say 'they' because there was, in fact, two letters addressed to my house. One of them was for me, Shauvon G. McGill.

The other was addressed for Sauvon G. McGill

That was a new one. I've had letters missing, changed, repeated, and mangled in my name before, but I'd never had the 'h' missing. Of all the phonemes in the name Shauvon, the voiceless palato-alveolar fricative ('sh' as in 'wash' or 'fish') is the easiest to remember.

The two acceptance letters were stapled together and taped to my bedroom door for quite some time.

A year later, the summer before my sophomore year of college, I had some lung problems, so I went to see a pulminologist. That was still before I realized I didn't really want to get a degree in Computer Graphics Technology, so I was still getting a degree in Computer Graphics Technology. That meant that I sat around all day working with computer graphics. I was out of shape, and as a result, my lungs weren't too excited about me jumping on my bike after lazing around all summer. If I had known that I would be relieved of my bike in just a few months, I wouldn't have worried about it. Anyway, the pulminologist had his receptionist set up appointments for several outpatient tests. The receptionist was a rather, well, dull woman.

'Ok, what's his name.' She talked to my mom, like I was 9, and not 19, years old.

'Shauvon,' my Mom said. It's a combination of Shawn and Steven, she would tell me later that day.

The receptionist called in the first of the appointments. 'I need an echocardiogram for a 'Savron.'' She missed the voiceless palato-alveolar fricative.

'No, it's 'Shauvon.' 'SHo-VIN''

'Sha. . . SHA-VON' That would have to do. She called in the next one. 'I need a pulmonary function test for a 'Shalvo''

After a moment in which my mom and I both tried not to laugh at this poor mentally challenged woman, we corrected her. 'It's Shauvon. SHo-VIN!'

'I need an appointment with a heart specialist for a 'Shalvron''

It went on like this for a while.

Later, after my Mom re-scheduled all of the appointments because nobody had the right name, I was able to have several specialists tell me that there was nothing wrong with me.

A few days later, we found out that the insurance company wasn't going to cover any of the tests. They mentioned something about a Sauvon McGill not being on our plan.

They forgot the voiceless palato-alveolar fricative.

fields.title: Raw rules
fields.text:
I recently upgraded to a digital SLR camera, the Canon EOS 350D (her friends call her Digital Rebel XT). It is definitely a sweet piece of technology. One of the greatest things about digital SLR cameras is the ability to record images as a digital negative, or Camera Raw format. Basically, it stores as much data as possible, so that you can tweak almost everything later on a computer. White balance, exposure, contrast, saturation, shadows and many more settings can all be manipulated later on. It allows the photographer to worry more about the shot, and less about all of the technical nitty gritty. Of course, you still have to deal with shutter speeds and aperture values, but that's what photography is. I'll show you just how powerful Camera Raw format can be. Also, I'll show off some sweet pictures I took with my new tripod. They are some awesome shots.

You're an awesome shot.

Shot one: Long exposure street.
Here it is as I shot it, with generic white balance and exposure. It looks ok. I set up the tripod next to State Street and shot off a 20 second shutter speed.

Here is the shot, after I tweaked it in Photoshop using the camera raw plugin. This isn't photoshopped, though, all I did to it was tweak the raw settings built into the image.



Shot two: horizon glow.
This is a shot of the halo eminating from Battleground, I believe (a town just north of Lafayette). This shot was taken from the footbridge crossing the Wabash.

Now after tweaking. Primarily, all I did was adjust the white balance.



Shot three: under the bridge.
The Wabash is running really low right now, so I could walk out onto the bank and get some nice shots of the State Street bridge.

Again, the only major change was the white balance.



Shot four: under the bridge II.
I didn't get many good shots of the State Street bridge from the footbridge, but I got a few nice onces from the ground below.

Again again, the only major change was the white balance. I had a huge 'holy crap' moment when the sky popped out like this.



Shot five: under the bridge III.
I don't have enough shots with me in them, so I turned on the timer and ran out to be in this one.

I really like how the sky looks on these.



Shot six: State Street's crotch.
This is the point where State street changes from two roads to one.

Our world is very yellow, it seems. I prefer blue.

fields.text:
I need to buy my own food this semester. I know that doesn't sound like much, but I've never had to do it before. In order to afford all of the Tang and pizza rolls, I've gotten a job. What does this mean to you?

Entertainment

I'm working for the ECN (Engineering Computer Network). They have a website (https://engineering.purdue.edu/ECN/). Part of this website is a 'Wall of Fame' (https://engineering.purdue.edu/ECE/Alumni/WallOfFame), where they list all of the past graduates from Electrical and Computer Engineering. It's essentially just a huge database of names and pictures. I'm working on that database. Actually, the database is already made, I'm just - well - I don't really know what I'm supposed to be doing. All I know is I come here quietly for two hours every day, and they quietly put $150 or so into my checking account every other week.

I am working, though, so it's not like I just come here and do nothing (it's almost nothing). On my first day, my boss told me that I would have to figure out how to work with the database. She didn't mention that I would also have to figure out what exactly I'm supposed to do. At this point, I still don't know what I was hired for. On one of my first days, I was just exploring around the site, seeing what it was all about (I'll save you some time and tell you it's not really about anything). I noticed as I looked through the listings that the lists of graduates (broken up by year) that show up on the website are different than the actual lists in the database. Many, and some times many many people are missing from the list. That's a problem, and it probably results from the fact that nobody who does anything actually knows what they're doing. The upshot is that it creates a new industry of people who's purpose is to redo everything everyone does. This of course applies to anybody anywhere in the world, not just people who create extremely faulty databases for extremely seldom-visited websites. Maybe my job falls into the second category, maybe it falls into the first.

I found out that all I have to do to fix the database is go to each offending record (the people who don't show up), and click 'update.' That's right. For the last several weeks, I've been going to hundreds if not thousands of pages to edit individual graduates and clicking a single button. Early years were easy, because only a handful of people graduated from Purdue those years. However, the 90's had hundreds of graduates each year. For the later years, I have to look at the list on the website with the list in the database and find each and every guy who is in one but not the other, and then click a button. How exciting my job is!

The list of graduates from the year 1900.


The list of graduates from the year 1990.

This is pretty mindless, as I'm sure you can guess. I usually occupy myself with episodes of Curb Your Enthusiasm on my Creative Zen Vision:M. One time I watched Blade 2 while I clicked that little 'update' button several hundred times. Sometimes I only work for an hour, but I write two onto my time card. I don't think I even need to go in on Fridays at all, because nobody else does. I really feel like George from that one episode of Seinfeld, where he never does any work, but just makes it look like he is always really busy. I think most of the episodes of Seinfeld were about George not working, now that I think about it.

My boss is an interesting character, and I'm still trying to decide if she creeps me out or if she's just eccentric. I'm leaning toward the latter, frankly. I don't think she cares that I don't really have anything to do, it's not her money that's being quietly deposited in my account every other week. She has to know that this website gets maybe five hits a year, and that it's such a huge piece of junk it needs to be completely rebuilt. All I know is that she wears some pretty rediculous outfits, things that I could never hope to put into words.

Long story short, I have no attachment to this job whatsoever. If I was fired (because they realize that I'm completely unecessary), I could get a hundred more little bean counter jobs like this one in a week. I therefore have no qualms about being one of the worst employees this world has ever seen. Take right now, for instance. My boss told me that she wasn't going to be here all week. That gives me an interesting challenge. The challenge is to do as little work as possible, while still making it look like I'm not just watching Curb your Enthusiasm for two hours. Right now, for example, I'm making a long post to my website about it. If it wasn't for the random people who occasionally walk by and can verify that I didn't show up, I probably wouldn't even come in at all.

I'm getting very close to the end of the database. I'm almost out of years to fix. I don't want to get there, because it means I have to find something else to do. That, my friends, is not an easy task. I think my boss mentioned something about pictures . . . ?

Ok, so now we get to the upshot for you, tonight's loyal fans. As I go through each and every student who got an Electrical Engineering degree at Purdue, I run across some semi-interesting names. For example,

This one isn't so great, I just think it's an interesting name. Plus, I have to love the name Tang.


Eric is a lame and unworthy name for a Schwinghammer.


Oh Yoshimi, they don't believe me, but you won't let those robots defeat me.


I don't care what James Michael told you, because James Michael Lies!


Are you Charles? Hardley.


I hope these guys were really good friends, and that everyone called them 'french fries.'


This guy should have been a surgeon. 'This guy needs surgery, fast!' 'Make way for Dr. Thrash!'


What's the history of a name like that?


'Hello, Roberts.' 'We're on a first name basis here, call me Robert.'


And now, my favorite. For some time, I've been searching for a stage name to go by in play programs and things like that. I have found it. I will be

He definitely looks like a Fankboner.


Well, that's all, mainly because it's 5:30 and time for me to go home. One perk about my job is that there's a webcam pointed directly at the place I park my bike. So if you're really bored you can take a look and see if I'm here pretending to work. If you see the giant blue and sliver bike, it's probably mine. If you're lucky (and watching at half past the hour), you might just see me!

Click here, and then click on the big picture to see the live footage.

fields.title: A list of autobiographies
fields.text:
I'm in Purdue's production of Richard III, and I need to submit a bio for the program or whatever. If anyone out there isn't familiar with bios, they're stupid and pointless little paragraphs that people write about themselves. I despise them for several reasons. They always feel like I'm showing off, I don't like writing something so mundane, and I never know what to say. I'm supposed to turn a bio in today, so I'm going to see what I can do. Humor me, if you will, and I will try a few things out here.

First, the classic, boring, stupid, meaningless, informative bio.

Shauvon McGill is a Junior majoring in theatre. This is his second semester in the department, and his third production at Purdue. Shauvon came to Purdue to study computer graphics technology, but he switched to theatre because he prefers the security of modern professional theatre. Shauvon wants to thank his parents, his friend Scott, his role model Rob Cockerham, and of course, Ina Garten.

Boring. Let's spice it up a little bit.

Shauvon McGill is and always has been composed entirely of a new type of spatial plasma which has yet to be discovered by the scientific community. Many years ago, several stars collided in deep space. The mass of the two stars collected together, creating this new substance and launching it at the planet Earth. The mass landed on the surface of the planet and cooled to form the body of Shauvon McGill. A reclusive mad scientist found the lifeless body and took it to his lab to study. A few years later, the mad scientist was working on an experiment when something went terribly wrong. The scientist was killed, but his mind was mysteriously transported to the plasma body. He gave up his scientific career and decided to study theatre at Purdue University. This is his third show.

Much more interesting, no? A couple weeks ago, I wrote a bio for Andrew Preston (I'm much more comfortable writing bios about someone besides me) for the Crazy Monkeys website. It turned out pretty sweet. I could just steal that back and change his name to mine.

Many years ago, for a brief moment in time, the universe was perfectly aligned to a particular position that only occurs once every two hundred million billion years. Scientists call this event the cosmic rocking, and it is a phenomena that most humans were completely unaware of. In fact, only a select few even know that the cosmic event exists. However, that cosmic event is the most important thing that will ever happen. At that precise moment, almost twenty five years ago, at the instantaneous event when every single body in the entire universe was perfectly aligned, a baby was born on a small planet in the Milky Way Galaxy. That planet was Earth. Some believe that the baby was imbued with the energies of the entire universe, and some say that it was an emissary sent from the gods to teach us to be at peace with one another. Whatever the case, everyone knew that this child was special. The child soon found powers beyond those of any normal human. Soon, the child advanced beyond every other child, every teacher, and even those considered to be superior human beings. Scientists from all over the planet came to study this being, and discover what gave it these amazing powers. Not a single human being could discover what caused this creature to be so superior. All of the knowledge, the documentation, and the studies meant nothing. All of human logic was useless. The being's powers were beyond even human imagination, which was always thought to be infinite in its abilities. This being could rock. It rocked hard, and it rocked fast. The being could rock harder and faster than anything that ever existed in the history of the universe. The world was stunned, for the universe had created the ultimate being. This being is the pinnacle of existence. This being is Shauvon McGill.

They probably won't let me submit that, though. It's too 'out there' for them. What a bunch of prudes.

But what if I submit a bio that is written about the future instead of the past?

Shauvon McGill will graduate from Purdue University in three years. After failing to do anything with his theatre degree, he will spend six years living in his parent's house, playing computer games and completing freelance web design projects to pay for more computer games. At the age of 29, Shauvon will finally meet the girl of his dreams, and move out of his parents house. Shauvon will spend the next six years moving around the world with his girlfriend, who is a competitive pole-vaulter. Shauvon will then be contacted by an old friend of his who needs a writer for a sketch comedy show. Shauvon will spend the next twenty seven years writing sketch comedy and eventually comedic films. Shauvon wants to thank his parents, his friend Scott, and of course, Ina Garten.

I'm just not feeling very attached to any of these. Here is what I am going to do. The other night, my friend Lauren Sivak had a dream that she submitted her bio, and the department changed it to 'Cast, beer, friends, life.' She was upset, because she doesn't even drink beer. The graduate students told her that they can change her bio however they want, and she can't do anything about it. Finally, she saw me. I was upset about my bio, as well. The department simply changed mine to:

Rivargo . . . ?

It's short, it's sweet, it's mysterious. There's no way they will let me use it, but it's worth a shot. It will make my year if they put that in the program.

Wish me luck.

fields.title: The curse of the gypsy's organ
fields.text:
or, Shauvon and Andrew get taken by an old crippled lady.

'Do you want to go to Goodwill?' Andrew Monkey said.

'That's the second time someone has asked me that today.' I responded. 'And the first time I will say 'yes.''

Off we went, to the Goodwill store on the other side of town. Little did we know that this trip would

CHANGE OUR LIVES FOREVER!!!

'So, why do you have a coffin in the back of your car?' I asked Andrew, wondering why he had a coffin in the back of his car. Andrew did, in fact, have a coffin in the back of his car, which confused me a little bit. He just said, 'I don't know,' and we climbed in and went off to Goodwill.

A few minutes later, our conversation about robots came to a close and my thoughts returned once again to the coffin in the back of Andrew's car. It was a large wooden crate, about four feet wide and six feet tall. It was predominantly plywood, and a few marks on the sides let us know which was was up. Although the ability to quickly find up is a good thing to have when driving in your car, the presence of a large plywood coffin is not. 'So, why do you have a coffin in your car?' I asked again. I'm pretty sure the emphasis on the word 'do' worked exactly the way I hoped, because it let Andrew know that I meant business. He told me what happened. I don't think he was lying, because if he was, he would have come up with a much better story.

He had apparently been driving home from work and noticed this large wooden crate sitting in the alley behind the coffee shop where he works, quietly letting passers by know which way was up. He didn't even think twice about it because when you see a wooden crate in an alley behind the coffee shop where you work you can't waste any time thinking about what you would do with it just pick it up and come up with something later. A simmilar thing happened to us when we saw a 'One Way' sign laying in the grass behind Jimmy Johns. Andrew didn't have his car at the time, and we didn't want to walk down State Street holding a 'One Way' sign. I wish we had gotten it, because then we could start a collection of things that point out other things.

Later, Andrew would use the box to stand in.

For those of you wondering when we would get to the gypsy's organ, your time has come at last. Three fourths of the way to the Goodwill store, we had to stop at a stoplight behind a few other vehicles. Act of fate A: if we had been just a few minutes earlier or later, we wouldn't have been stopped where we were, and the following would not have happened. I looked to my right, and I saw a house. The sign in front said, 'ESP Readings: Open.'

'Do you want to get an ESP reading?' I asked Andrew.

'What?' He responded, confused.

'Do you want a sweet organ?' I asked Andrew.

'What?' He responded, amazed.

For you see, in front of the ESP lady's house sat a sweet organ. It was big, it was made of wood, and it had two rows of keys.

'Look at that sweet organ.' I suggested.

'Woah, that is a sweet organ.' He confirmed. His emphasis of the word 'is' showed that he meant business.

The traffic moved ahead of us, and we had to leave the organ behind, for the moment. We discussed the possibilities of purchasing the organ, and we debated the reason for the organ's exterior home.

'The fact that it's sitting outside shows that it's for sale, right?'

'You would think so, but there was no sign.'

'Well, the fact that there is no sign could mean that it's free.'

'I hate it when people say that. Just because there is no sign doesn't mean that it's free.'

'I wasn't saying that, I was honestly wondering.'

'I don't know, maybe it's just sitting there. It was back away from the sidewalk, so it might just live there.'

'Well, it wouldn't hurt to go in and inquire.'

'I don't even know how to play keyboard instruments.'

'This is a perfect opportunity to learn.'

We had arrived at Goodwill. Shopping at Goodwill is always a suprise. You never know what you're going to get. I ended up finding a weird felt clock, a new swiss army knife to keep in my pocket, and two Lego sets (I know the risks involved with buying used Lego sets, but I thought it was worth it). Andrew got a couple spatulas, an ice cream scoop, and two crazy lightbulbs. This next part is pretty good.

Andrew checked out ahead of me. As he walked up to the counter, the very cute girl standing behind the register commented on Andrew's shirt (it was a Velvet Underground tshirt). The connection was made. Andrew looked at me and gave me a less than subtle wink. It turns out that the girl was a senior in high school, which quickly scared Andrew away. He promptly toned down the flirting. We thought about buying a wheelchair, but when they told us it wasn't for sale, we decided against it.

That's when Andrew got some balls. They were made of brass.

We went out to Andrew's car. Andrew wrote his phone number on the back of a savings deposit slip. He went back inside the store for a few minutes. I used the time to look at the pamphlet that came with my new pocket knife explaining all of the features my knife doesn't have.

Andrew told me later that the girl said, 'were you talking about the Big Lebowski earlier?'

I forgot to mention that we were talking about the Big Lebowski earlier.

'yeah, we're having a Big Lebowski party tomorrow night if you wanted to come . . .'

Allow me to bold the words which paticularly stabbed Andrew in the heart.

'I don't know. I'm working here all weekend and it's my one year anniversary with my boyfriend.'

At least he tried.

We set out to explore the Goodwill store on the other-other side of town. We were talking about the girl we met at the first Goodwill store so much that we almost forgot about the organ.

'Did you forget about the organ?' I asked. If Andrew could have done a screeching U-turn right then and there, he would have. He may have failed at getting a girl, but he would succeed at getting an organ. Off we sped to the gypsy lady's house. Act of fate B: If I hadn't remembered about it, we would never have gotten it.

We inspected the device, just to make sure it was something we really wanted. The problem is that this was never a thing we really wanted. We overcame that problem and went inside to inquire. Inquire we did.

The gypsy lady was sitting in a chair, apparently somewhat crippled, with various medical supplies scattered around her. She had a cast on her leg. I wonder if she saw that injury coming.

'The asking price is fourty dollars.' We had a hard time hearing her, because she had a few obnoxious dogs that kept barking. 'Everything works perfectly.' Usually when people say 'everything works perfectly' something probably doesn't work perfectly. That was something I learned on this adventure. We couldn't get it immediately, because Andrew didn't have fourty dollars cash, and his car was full of coffin.

Unfortunately, I had to go, so I wasn't with Andrew when he made the purchase. Simmilarly, I have to go now, so I'll continue the story in a little bit.

fields.title: The curse of the gypsy's organ pt. II
fields.text:
or, Why you should live on the first floor.

Read part one

'Do you want to help me unload an organ from my car?' Andrew Monkey said to me at about 11 Saturday morning.

'That's the second time someone has asked me to unload an organ today.' I responded. 'And the first time involving a car.'

After I left him the night before, Andrew unloaded his coffin, got some cash and went back to the gypsy's house. He only had fifties, so he asked for ten dollars back. If you remember, the gypsy said, 'the asking price is fourty dollars.' Well, when Andrew asked for the ten dollars in change, the gypsy said, 'the asking price is fifty dollars.'

'Eh, whatever.' Andrew said. Fifty dollars is still a pretty great price for an organ in which 'everything works perfectly.' The gypsy's mexican helper helped Andrew load the organ into his car. They didn't know which way was up, but they did the best they could.

Now we're back to 11 on Saturday morning. 'Ok, well, I'm downstairs, so I'm coming up to your apartment for pizza rolls.' Andrew told me. I put some pants on and started some pizza rolls. The pizza rolls were good, and the pants too short. I took a look at those lego sets I bought the day before. That leads me to:

CONSEQUENCE NUMBER 1: MISSING LEGO PIECES

I expected to have some pieces missing. After all, I bought a lego set at Goodwill. I expected to get passed the second step of the instructions, though. When I was missing such a crucial piece, I knew my future looked grim. The Lego set was not just missing a few pieces, it was unbuildable. That was dissappointing. Little did we know that it was only a small symptom of a larger problem. We just blindly went off to his place to unload his new organ.

Andrew lives on the third floor of his building. The organ weighed about 200 pounds. Maybe some of you have lifted 200 pounds up two flights of stairs, and maybe you haven't. If you ever get the chance to do it, avoid it at all costs. We took 15 minutes pushing and pulling that thing up the stairs.

We took a break half way through to plug it in and see if it worked. We figured we should see if it did actually work before we lugged it all the way up the stairs. If the gypsy lied to us, then all the work we did would be for nothing. The building had a few outlets outside by the stairs, probably for just such an occurance, in case someone needed to test an organ before they take it upstairs. Andrew tentatively plugged the cord into the outlet. No explosion (good sign). The power light came on (good sign). Andrew tentatively pushed one of the keys. No sounds (bad sign). I pushed a lever, and the organ started playing a simple beat. We smiled at each other, and took it the rest of the way up the stairs. 'It's probably just something I have to figure out.' Andrew said.

The organ is a Lowrey Mardi Gras. It has:

  1. Levers to control the lower key volume, the beat volume, the bass volume, and the beat tempo.
  2. A row of switches to select a beat pattern (two per switch!).
  3. A row of switches to select the upper key instrument.
  4. Switches to toggle the 'genie bass', 'magic swing bass', and 'magic chord system.'
  5. Switches to select the lower key instrument.
  6. Switches to select the presets (we don't know what these do).
  7. Levers to control the sustain, swing piano volume, and vibrato.
  8. Buttons to toggle vibra trem flutes and flute celeste (whatever those are).
  9. Thirteen foot pedals to control the bass.
  10. A master volume pedal.
  11. Two rows of piano keys.
  12. A power switch.

Of all of those things, most of the piano keys don't work, and as a result, some of the switches don't seem to do anything. The piano keys work some times, and sometimes they don't work. The one exception to this is the mid-range 'B' on the lower keyboard. That baby works perfectly. This leads me to think that it's fixable, and all it will take is an electrical engineering major (Scott) to get in there and solve the problem. The keys that do work are pretty amazing, so if this thing is going at full capacity, it would be devastatingly awesome.

The only downside is the whole curse thing.

We removed the back panel, to see what the organ's organs looked like. 'You know, we did buy this from a gypsy.' I mused. 'There's a pretty good chance that it could be cursed.'

At any rate, the organ's presence brought about many delicious organ related puns, such as:

  • 'We just wanted to organize the place a little bit.
  • 'We should move it into your room, taking it along the organ trail.'

After a few hours playing around with it, it was adorned with all sorts of labels and stickers. (actually, only two sorts: three labels and one sticker) None of these things were on the organ when we got it. Andrew had that weird egyptian sticker for a while, and he never knew what it meant. We just knew it had to go on the organ.



The most exciting part hasn't even come yet. We've already seen one effect of the curse, and many examples of fate's shadowy hand in these events. Stay tuned for more shocking tales in The Curse of the Gypsy's Organ!!!

fields.text:
or Every Abortion of Critical Thinking has Consequences

Read part one
and part two

'Do you want to go to this Halloween party?' Andrew asked me on Saturday evening.

'That's the first time someone has asked me to go to a Halloween party,' I replied, 'and the second time I'll say yes.'

We had to wait for Andrew to get off work. I went home to put a lousy costume together. What our costumes were is not important, because as it turns out

WE WOULDN'T NEED THEM!

On my way back to where Andrew works (the coffee shop in front of the alley where he found the coffin), a group of partially inebriated men stopped me and asked me where Chances Are was. Chances Are is a show club on the far side of Lafayette, just past the Gypsy's house Andrew and I went to the day before. I told the gentlemen that they were in very-much-the-wrong place, and they kindly asked me if I could take them there. If I had held out a little longer, I probably could have gotten them to pay me. Act of Fate C: if I had shown the gentlemen where Chances Are was, perhaps the fateful events of Saturday night would not have happened quite the same way. Luckily (or unluckily), Andrew called me when the gentlemen were discussing this matter with me, so I had an easy excuse to get rid of them. They went off down Chauncy hill, presumably walking to Chances Are. I doubt they made it, because it's about fifteen minutes away from Chauncy Hill by car. On slightly inebriated feet, I'm sure it's a much longer journey.

Andrew called me and told me to meet him at the coffee shop. We were going to meet at his car, but he forgot some things (like his wallet), so he had to go back for them. Act of Fate D: if Andrew hadn't forgotten his wallet, we would have been just a few minutes earlier, and perhaps the fateful events of Saturday night would not have happened quite the same way.

Andrew got his things and we left. Some crazy guy was saying something about a missing box that he keeps in the alley. I don't know what that was all about. Eventually, Andrew and I got to his car. Andrew drives a Subaru Outback station wagon. It's a nice car. It has enough room for a rather large coffin, or an average-sized Gypsy's organ, or five comfortable Crazy Monkeys. It has cup-holders, an FM radio, power windows, and

A SEVERE DESIGN FLAW

We were driving out on 200 North. Friends call it Lindberg Road. That is the road that leads to Andrew's apartment. It is also the road the leads to my Grandma's house. Look it up on Google Maps on your own time. We had just passed the Celery Bog, and I was about to note that the road was getting bumpier. There is a particular stretch of Lindberg Road that goes over the Celery Bog which gets particularly bumpy (corrugated cardboard style). They have rebuilt the road several times, but each time it just gets bumpy again (corrugated cardboard style). We had just passed that particular stretch of Lindberg Road, and I was about to note that the road was getting bumpy yet again. I made it through the following words before Andrew's window exploded: hey, this, road, is, and getti. 'Getti' isn't actually a word. I was trying to say 'getting,' but I was cut short when Andrew's window exploded. I usually mention something about that particular stretch of Lindberg Road whenever I ride on it, because it seems like every time I do, it gets bumpier and bumpier (corrugated cardboard style). However, at this particular moment, certain events were slightly more important. Right as I was about to speak the voiced velar nasal sound at the end of the word 'getting', Andrew's car made it's own voiced velar nasal. Granted, Andrew's car lacks several key points of anatomy to properly emit a true voiced velar nasal, but it did what it could with what it had.

There was a loud bang, followed by a loud pop, followed by the sound of millions of glass shards falling all over the back seat of Andrew's car, followed by the sound of Andrew and me experiencing simultaneous 'brown alerts.' By a show of hands, who here has been in a car when a window exploded? Sometimes I forget that the internet isn't a lecture hall. If you have experienced the spontaneous explosion of a car window, you know the horrible fear that consumes everyone in the car when such an event occurs.

There was a short period during which various expletives were said.

'That means someone is shooting at us, right?' Andrew asked.

The answer is, of course, 'no, don't be ridiculous.' However, the surging levels of adrenaline in my body caused me to say some form of the expression 'shit, I don't know, man, but I think so.' We made it to Andrew's apartment, both of us ducking below the level of the dashboard, and we got out to survey the damage. I had my camera, and took some pictures of the car.

Here is where I'll put the bold text saying,

CONSEQUENCE NUMBER 2: THE EXPLODING WINDOW

This doesn't do justice to how much broken glass was everywhere. The door is actually full of it, so every time we closed it, it rattled in a rather comical way.

Car glass is coated with a poly-bunka-junka-chloro-mega-hydro-floxy-stuff, which prevents it from shattering into horrible flying shards of death, like regular glass. As a result, car glass breaks into these nice, neat chunks. Except for the bits that don't, they just turn into millions of tiny pieces.

Although these glass chunks might look like a delicious new rock candy confection, they are not actually very delicious at all and very harmful if swallowed apparently. However tempting it might be, please refrain from eating the glass chunks.

Andrew took his car to the police to report the damage, just in case someone was shooting at us. The police apparently told him the correct response to that question. I stayed at his apartment, sorting things out with the organ. Mainly I just turn on the auto rythm, auto bass, and magic chord systems, and hold down the one key that works while I dance around it for hours at a time. It never gets old. Someone was saying something about wanting to destroy something. I don't know what that was about.

Andrew returned with beer. We had made a non-verbal agreement not to go to the Halloween party, and hide in his Apartment instead. Madness quickly set in.

CONSEQUENCE NUMBER 3: VARIOUS MADNESSES

Gen had the ocean madness, Pat had the space madness, I had the label madness, and Andrew caught a rare case of the Australian Digeridoo madness.

Dear. God. RUN!

I also like this image, but it didn't really look very good in the animated Gif above.

The window was a little terrifying, and the madness was as well, but as curses go, this one was pretty entertaining. I've already forgotten about the missing lego pieces, as I'm sure you have as well. Cut to the next day, however, and we get the worst curse of all!

CONSEQUENCE NUMBER 4: DIET COLA

'Dayna, can I have a drink of your Coke?'
'Sure.'

'Oh God, it's Diet! Blork!'

Haunting.

Andrew took his car in to get the window fixed, and the mechanic said that it was a specific defect in that particular car. Apparently when you transport cursed organs in certain Subaru Outback station wagons, the rear driver side window explodes. That's important to know.

Well, I think I've just about said all there is to say about this adventure. If anyone has anything to add, that's what I made the comment system for. I hope everyone enjoyed reading about the Gypsy's organ about as much as we enjoyed being cursed by it.

fields.title: Name Adventures, Part III
fields.text:
Part I
Part II

I have been working for the Engineering Computer Network for several months now. That job is another story. However, the name adventure that I had at my job is not another story. I worked there for about a month. Everything was going perfectly fine. One day, however, I was unable to log into the database to work on anything. I inquired about the problem. We looked into the list of users allowed into the database. There I was:

shauvon.g.mc.gill

The extra dot after 'mc' makes the G in my last name capitalized. We didn't understand why I wasn't allowed into the database. Finally, the guy in charge of whatever opened a command prompt program and looked me up. There I was:

shauron.g.mcgill

'Wait, what?

There was absolutely no reason why it would have switched. I hadn't sent in any forms or anything recently. I hadn't done anything that would have caused them to change my name. However, there it was:

shauron.g.mcgill

'Hold on. What?' It's not every day that a computer starts mis-pronouncing your name.

'I'll go ahead and put you in the list, and you'll have to send an email to the ITAP (information technology at Purdue) helpdesk and request that they fix it,' the guy in charge of whatever said.

Someone, somewhere saw my name written on something and decided that Purdue's student information, the information that we painstakingly registered two years ago when I signed up to go to Purdue, was wrong. Someone somewhere saw my name scribbled on a piece of paper and trusted that over Purdue's officially registered student information.

'This letter looks a little like an 'R.' I'll just go ahead and fix it in the computer.' The person probably thought.

'This student will be so happy that the information in the computer is finally corrected after two years of being wrong.'

Anyway, I sent off an email to ITAP asking them to change it back to shauvon.g.mc.gill. I like it that way. It has all the dots in the right places, not an 'r' to be found, and it's actually spelled right. Those are all good features. Here's the email I got back:



Hello Shauron G Mcgill,

You contacted the ITaP Customer Service Center 49-44000 itap@purdue.edu Stewart Center G65 about:

Incorrect name change

Your case is HD0000000108910. Please make sure this number is in the subject line of all correspondence regarding this case.

Thank you,

ITaP Customer Service Center 49-44000 itap@purdue.edu Stewart Center G65

Ok, great. I'll let Shauron know when I see him. A few days later, I got this email:



Hello Shauron G Mcgill,

Information for the directory comes from Personnel or the Registrar. It appears that your student information has the correct name, but your employee data superceded that with the incorrect name. You will need to contact the business office in your department to have this fixed in the employee information.

Please make sure your case number is in the subject line of all correspondence regarding this issue.

Thank you,

ITaP Mailhub Team

Attachment1 : Attachment3 : Attachment2 : Attachment4 :

'Your information comes from people or other people. However, we don't feel like doing anything about it, so go talk to someone else.' Great, thanks. Anyway, for some reason, my name was fixed, sort of. It became:

shauvon.g.mcgill

Whatever, it's missing the extra dot that makes my last name correct, but it's not a big deal. I was just glad to be Shauvon again. I got this message:



Hello Shauron G Mcgill,

We believe that your issue, Case # HD0000000108910 , about Incorrect name change, has been resolved or escalated to an external support partner.

If you agree that this issue has been resolved or escalated externally, please reply to this message, adding the word 'closed' to the body of the email.

If you feel this issue is not complete, please reply to this message, adding the word 'reopen' to the body of the email and explaining why and we will re-open your case.

If you choose to do neither, then this case will automatically close in 15 days.

Thank you,

ITaP Mailhub Team

It's like they don't even read their own emails. I didn't want to confuse them by giving them another problem to redirect to someone else, so I just left it at that. A week or so later, I got this email:



Hello Shauron G Mcgill,

You are important to us!

Please click on the link below to complete our survey. This information will help us evaluate our service for continued improvement. Your Purdue Career Account login and password will give you access to the survey.

(link to the survey)

Thank you, ITaP Mailhub Team

Here's their survey, with the answers that I submitted:

fields.title: The Great Tang Fiasco
fields.text:
A terrible thing has happened to me recently. Those of you who know me well will understand what a blow this is. Kraft foods has repackaged and re-formulated Tang. Yes, everyone's favorite astronaut drink has been changed. It is no longer the tang I used to know and love. It is different, and it is disgusting. I am hereby beginning a full boycot on Kraft Foods, to end only when they give me back my Tang.

Food companies repackage their products all the time. Usually this is a harmless attempt to look cooler or better than the competition. The change in packaging has no effect on the contents. Usually this is the case. When such a change occurs, the package will be labeled with phrases such as 'new package, same great product.' Food companies have very specific recipes for their products, and consumers need to be reassured that those recipes are unchanged.

Let's discuss for a moment why a company would choose to repackage a product. Perhaps a competitor has repackaged their product, and the company wants to keep up. Perhaps a new competitor has appeared on the scene, and the company needs to compete. Neither of these situations apply to tang. Sure, Koolaide has a very large market, but there is no product that matches the, well, tanginess of Tang. Let me repeat: There is no proper substitute for Tang. With no competition, it should be Kraft's prerogative to keep Tang the way it is, so as to avoid customer confusion. As soon as Tang lovers think Tang is no longer the same, they will flee into the waiting arms of the Koolaide man. This is precisely what is happening with me. Wait, Kraft also owns Koolaide. Great.

Tang has a very long and illustrious history. Tang was invented in 1957 by William A. Mitchell. Mitchell also invented Pop Rocks, Jell-O, and Cool Whip, so Tang comes from a very powerful family. Tang didn't find success until 1965, when it was used by NASA in Gemini flights. Tang caught on, and it has been associated with astronauts since then. Tang has gone unchanged for fifty years (yes, this year is the fiftieth anniversary of Tang). Tang has been unchanged, until now.

In November, 1985, General Foods (the company responsible for Tang) was acquired by Philip Morris Companies (the company responsible for tobacco in America). General Foods had made some acquisitions of their own. General Foods owned several companies, such as Oscar Mayer, Burger Chef, and Perkins Products Company (the maker of Koolaide). When Philip Morris bought General Foods, it was the largest non-oil acquisition ever. Shortly later, Philip bought Kraft Foods, and merged the two companies together. Little did they know that Kraft would screw it all up in twelve years.

According to Wikipedia, Lyndon Johnson, Jimmy Carter, Ronald Reagan, and Bill Clinton all loved Tang when they were in office. They loved it before Kraft destroyed it.

For a very long time, Tang was served in big plastic containers that held enough Tang for either six quarts or nine quarts. You did not need to add sugar. This is what separated it from Koolaide. Koolaide needs to be mixed with sugar in order for it to work. Tang was specifically formulated to mix directly with water and drink. The nutrition facts can be seen to the right. Those were taken directly from the Kraft website. Look at that. Nothing but sugar. I liked it that way. I don't need anything else. Sugar and flavors. That's all I want. Kraft doesn't care.

A few weeks ago, I went to Wal-Mart with my friend Andrew Monkey. I needed to buy some more tang and pizza rolls (I'm almost 21, but I eat like a 10 year old). Wal-Mart had no tang. A gaping hole was left in both the powdered drink mix aisle, and also my heart. A couple weeks later, I returned ot Wal-Mart to try again. They had Tang, but it was not the same Tang.

I had a very bad feeling about this. First of all, the new container is a really weird size. It's about a third the size of the old six quart container. The new one makes eight quarts, too. How can it be smaller, but make more? It does tell me that it 'makes 33% more than 6 quart Tang.' It is also pretty open about its low sugar content. That's a bad sign. The worst harbinger of doom is the fact that nowhere on the new package does it say 'new package, same great product.' Instead, it has some new 'Fruitrition' logo. I was wary. 'Fruitrition' shares an awful lot of syllables with 'Nutrition,' and that's not something I drink Tang for. I decided to give them the benefit of the doubt, and buy the new Tang. I had no choice, anyway, because as was stated earlier, there is no proper substitute for Tang.

Wikipedia acknowledges the new packaging. The new containers are smaller because they contain a more concentrated formula. That makes sense, really. Our technology has advanced quite a bit since 1957. Why can't our Tangology have advanced as well? It must be that Tangologists have merely made a breakthrough in Tanguistics, and now they are able to make the Tang powder more efficiently. They have also apparently made some breakthroughs in Fruitrition, a complex science reserved for only the top scientific minds. Technological advancements are good. However, Tangological advancements are not.

A look at the back of the package shows that the concentration is not the only thing that has changed. The new Tang contains only 9 grams of sugar, as opposed to Olde Tang's 24. Further examination shows the following ingredients in the Ingredient List: Maltodextrin; Sucralose, Acesulfame Potassium, and Neotame (sweeteners). Why would Tang need sweeteners?

Interestingly enough, I happened to glance at an empty Splenda packet that my roomate left on the counter. I immediately recognized the ingredients Sucralose and Maltodextrin. New Tang is made with Splenda.

It is apparently important to Kraft for Tang to have less sugar than juice. That is why they have redesigned it. They haven't made any breakthroughs in Tanguistics. They're just picking a fight. They're taking on juice as Tang's competitor. That is a strange choice. Kraft has a hundred other drink products that they could put in this 'better than juice' bracket. Why do they need to ruin my the drink I have had my entire life?

New Tang is not the same product as Olde Tang. I can taste a difference. You may not notice anything different, but that is just because you do not have the same skills in Tanguistics that I have. My claims are supported by the fact that the ingredients and Nutrition Facts are different. New Tang contains Splenda. It has the distinct artificial sweetener after-taste that Olde Tang did not have.

We all grew up with Tang. Tang hasn't changed significantly in half a century. If you are like me and you believe that Kraft should not be changing a classic product on its fiftieth aniversary, please voice your opinions directly to them.

Kraft Foods Global, INC.
Northfield, IL 60093

1-800-431-1002

Click here to send a comment to Kraft

Kraft is a large corporation owned by an even larger corporation. Chances are our voices will not be heard. However, as consumers we have the greatest power of all over them. We control whether or not they make money. I hereby announce that from this moment on I am in a full boycot of Kraft products (and their parent company Philip Morris) until they give Tang back to us. I invite you all to join me in this. Tell your friends. Denyconformity.com is now officially denying Kraft Foods.

fields.title: CAPTCHA
fields.text:
The spammers have taken their next move, so now I am forced to implement a system I was hoping I wouldn't have to implement. An easy system has been around for a long time to prevent spammers, by proving that the entity attempting to access a page is truly human. I will soon be implementing a Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart, or CAPTCHA. These devices have been around for some time, and I'm sure most of you have seen one in one form or another. Usually, they are used on account setup pages to keep automated bots away. In most CAPTCHAs, you are required to look at an image, and type out a handfull of letters or numbers that appear in the image. I will try to make my CAPTCHA as easy to use and unobtrusive as possible, while still requiring just enough logic to prove that you are human.

It will have something to do with the following code, so you can go ahead and start memorizing it now.

09-F9-11-02-9D-74-E3-5B-D8-41-56-C5-63-56-88-C0

Okay, so I am not going to make you all memorize that code. Still, it's a good code to remember.
