fields.title: The Return of Tang
fields.text:
Tang. I found it. First, before you continue, make sure you've read the following:

The first article, which started this whole fiasco.

The first update, with a not-so successful replacement.

Another update.

Andrew Monkey. He's almost on his way to Spain, and could be there when you read this. He loves him some mixed mithai. He's also my hero.

Why? Because he brought this into my life:

The lid labels never survive on these things, but you get the idea.

Before I continue, I'll just quiet your suspicions right now. I'm sure, if you read the previous articles about Tang, that you're wondering, 'could it be?'

Yes, it could.

I'm getting ahead of myself, as I am want to do. Let me explain where this came from. Andrew was in his hometown of New Albany, Indiana, and he went to an Hispanic Grocery Store. That store was selling a brand of Tang, presumably sold in Hispanic countries, which looked awfully familiar and 'fruitrition-less.' It has the classic shape and size, before they made the formula more 'concentrated.' Let's take a look at the ingredients, just to see what it's got under the hood.

Kraft Foods Puerto Rico knows how to do their job.

Sugar. Check. Citric Acid for tartness. Check. Less than 2% of flavor. Check. No sign of sucralose. Double Check. This definitely looks like it could be good. Let's have a look at the product itself.

Oh boy.
Orange gold.

It looks like Olde Tang. It smells like - well, it smells like Real Sugar Orange Fanta, which isn't far off from Olde Tang.

Made with real sugar, not corn syrup. Delicious, if not for the price tag.

How does it taste?

My finger-test proved quite successful.
Andrew took a more direct approach.
We mixed a pitcher up to give it a proper tasting.
I don't get many pictures of myself on this site.
I'm kind of a goofy looking dude.

Ok, so it tasted good. It tasted really good. But did it really taste like Olde Tang? We couldn't be sure. Not without a taste test, that is! I prepared a sample of the Puerto Rican Tang, to scientifically measured proportions.

In a scientific flamingo cup.

Then I went into the super-secure locked up archive Tang that I've been saving inside a mountain in case I really needed some.

Probably three years old.

I carefully prepared the two identical glasses (to make sure neither of us were at all biased).

Andrew waited patiently.

I chipped off a few chunks of the Olde Tang (once it hits a couple months old, it kind of hardens into a sort of prehistoric, petrified Tang rock), and ground it back into a powder.

Not as pretty as the new-comer, but looks aren't everything.

Ready to go, the two cups were pretty much identical.

Which is more delicious?

As scientifically as possible, I tasted each one.

I no longer have that goatee.

Here's what Andrew and I agreed on. First off, there were differences between the two drinks. That could certainly have been attributed to the archive Olde Tang losing a bit with age, for sure. They were both good, but one was pretty clearly better. One of them was a little grittier, which I figured was the Olde Tang not mixing particularly well, but after thoroughly re-mixing it, it tasted better than the other one. It would seem that the newcomer was not quite as good as Olde Tang, but it was definitely good enough. Andrew wanted to verify which was which, but I couldn't. I had to make it completely untraceable, or my overly-critical mind would be immediately tainted by knowing which was which. He was frustrated that we wouldn't be able to know for sure which was better (although I was pretty sure that the difficulty of mixing the one proved which it was).

I remembered that knife he was sharpening earlier, and decided to make an effort to find out.

Then I remembered that we had been taking pictures the whole time. Duh. I looked at the two cups, and sure enough, one of them - the one which tasted better, in fact - had considerably more worn flamingos than the other one. I checked the footage and compared the flamingo wear patterns to the cups.

Olde Tang. Intact Flamingos.
Newcomer. Faded Flamingos.

'Andrew . . .' I said. 'The faded flamingos were on the New Tang . . .'

A Jump Ten was all that could express our excitement. Nobody was around to take a picture of it, unfortunately, but rest assured it was awesome.

The New New Tang was the one we liked better. My life is finally complete.

So, as a guiding light for the rest of the world, more than a year after this whole fiasco started, I give you the solution (for now, until Puerto Rico gets wise). A couple weeks later, a giant box arrived in the mail. Andrew had ordered an entire case of the New New Tang from the same store he bought the first one from. Opening that box of twelve wonderful canisters was one of the highlights of my life.

Tang is back.

As a side note, with this boon of Tang, we've explored new possible applications for the delicious no-longer-just-breakfast drink. John, whom you might remember from our Mixed Mithai adventure, is a fan of high-class, expensive alcohol, particularly Gin. Late one night, while I was getting a midnight snack of a glass of Tang, and John was getting a midnight snack of a glass of Boodles British Gin, we accidentally ran into each other, mixing the two.

'Hey, you got Boodles in my Tang!'

'Hey, you got Tang in my Boodles!'

'Heyyyy!'

The Crazy Monkey was born.

Boodles and Tang: The Crazy Monkey

Yes, I've tried it, and yes it's pretty delicious.

One more side-note: someone who happened upon my Tang article emailed me a few days ago. He was a big fan of the Tang-ish drink Sunny Delight, and he said that it has recently gone the 'fruitrition' route, following Tang where consumers are unable to follow. What are drink-makers thinking?

And people wonder why the economy is a complete mess.

fields.title: ENTR 200
fields.text:
I'm in the Entrepreneurship class, and I have to write a paper about the project we had for our mid-term. It was a group project, and we had to find an Entrepreneur and interview him about his business, videotape it, and edit the video into a seven minute showcase video.

So we had to go to the Indianapolis Airport and talk to this guy who fixes up corporate jets. It turned out well, so whatever. Here's the description of the paper I have to write (which is due tomorrow). This is directly copied from the assignment description.

Each of you will write a paper on your personal impressions and what you learned from the interview itself and the entire process of completing it. This is not to be a recap or summary of the interview. It is a write up of what you learned from the whole process. Questions to help give you direction:

  • What went well?
  • What did not go so well?
  • What would you do differently the next time you have a complex group project such as this?
  • What did you take away from the comments and experiences of the entrepreneur?

Someone always asks: 'How long should this paper be?' The real answer is simply, long enough to thoroughly cover the topics. As guidance I will add this -an amazingly good writer could not capture all of this in less than three full pages. On the other hand, a reasonably good writer, one who edits well, who is concise yet comprehensive, can do a very good job in six or seven pages. It is due on October 21 at the beginning of class (turn in a printed copy).

Here's the video, in case you care.

fields.title: To Andrew
fields.text:
Dear Andrew,

How are you? I am fine. You've been in Europe for about a month now. I know you know that, I'm just recapping what the situation is so you know I have reserved brain space for remembering what happens to you. Anyway, you've been in Europe for like a month or whatever. Or maybe you were in England for some of that, I don't know. I hope you're having fun. I hope you're having tons of stupid fun with your big, stupid face.

I decided to write you this letter to show you how much awesome fun we're all having here now that you've finally put an entire ocean between you and us. Yeah, we're having tons of funs all over the place like a billion, and most of it is in regards to you getting the H out. We're always like, 'here's a toast to that guy Andrew and his no longer being here!' Then everybody gets really quiet for a few minutes, and I try to think about dinosaurs because that's what I used to do when I was a kid and I was trying not to cry.

Ol' number 3 is still doing well. That weird secondary light in the bathroom has gone out, and we can't figure out how to take it apart to replace it. We're going to tell Jonny Bash about it and have him send that skinny dude to fix it, but they're really busy right now with leasing season. Also, Bash'm just got elected to the County Council, so I kinda don't want to approach him until that blows over a little bit, because I'm sure he's got a lot to say about the whole situation. John renewed his lease for next year, which means we don't have to worry about cleaning up all those labels and marker on the walls and stuff.

I finally bought peanut butter the other day. After over a year since I moved out of my old apartment, I'm out of the stockpile I collected as part of the Meisner Collection. That leaves the footrests and that coffee table thing in my room as the only remaining items that I stole from Dan (well, except for the frying pan, the Foreman grill, that jacket that doesn't fit me, and that one spoon).

Oh, Harland Fankboner has a new Fresh Idea card. That's new. Remember that time we went to the store and I bought a whole box of Sweet Tarts Ropes? I haven't eaten any Sweet Tarts Ropes in like three months. Isn't that about when you left town? Just look how much healthier I am now that I don't have your big ol' stanky ass holding me down.

The Monkeys are going to do a show at IU again this year. I'm really excited for it, even though the email invitation we got and all the documents are made out to Tim Franklin. We've got a show with the Ship of Fools on November 22, too. It's another charity show, this time just for Habitat for Humanity. Joe has been in contact with the charity, and I told him to tell them that if they don't send some of their people to the show this year, then I'll just keep all the money for myself. I have to redo the combined logo for the flier for this show, since the Crazy Monkeys have a new logo. We still haven't cashed that check yet (you know the one I mean). Sorry about that. We've had a lot of other stuff to think about, and we're also pretty lazy.

I don't think Joe actually told the Habitat people that.

Just so you know, I got a catalog today from Things Remembered, that place that engraves people's names into metal junk. So you and your little friend Andy Briston have gotten me onto somebody's mailing list. I hope you're both happy. I'll probably get these catalogs for the rest of my lonely, sweet-tarts-rope-free life. Just so you know, I could totally snatch a sterling silver heart dangle for $65 with like four whole words engraved on it. I'm going to buy one that says 'Andy Briston died this year.' There's only a few more weeks in 2008, you know.

The bottlecap bucket is pretty much level to the rim, so it's time to either do something with these or find a larger bucket. I bet we could have found one at Goodwill, but John never wants to go there. Remember that time we got cursed by a gypsy and then you fled the continent, sticking me with it? That gypsy has moved across town into a way nicer house in a way nicer neighborhood (or at least her 'ESP Readings' sign has). She's doing way better now that she's gotten rid of the curse. Maybe in Europe you can find some sort of ancient temple that does curse clensings and you can have them do something about it. Maybe you could dig up a cardinal's bones and perform some sort of ritual or something. You should dig up a cardinal's bones anyway. It couldn't hurt.

I made a video for my sister a couple weeks ago. You remember when you used to sit on the couch playing Half Life while I was working on projects and stuff? John just sits in his room playing Half Life. It's not the same. Anyway, I put the video online so you (or any joker who's reading my totally private letter to you) can see it. It's pretty hilarious, plus it has Justice in it. If it ever finishes rendering, I'll put a link up on this website or something.

Well, that's about all I have tonight. Good ol' Friday night. . . Remember when I would be like, 'hey, it's Friday, let's go to a bar!' and then you would give me that look like you think I'm a moron, and I would totally play it off like I was kidding and laugh awkwardly for too long, then we'd go back to playing Team Fortress 2? John actually listens to me all the time, and we keep getting stuck at a bar because I didn't realize that I was just kidding.

That new Zombie Team Fortress game is almost out, and I played the demo. It's pretty sweet, but I probably won't get it since I don't have any friends here anymore who'll play it with me. John just sits at his computer looking up wikipedia stuff in Linux drinking Cosmopolitans.

Ok. Have tons of funs on Europe. Party till you puke and all that. Let me know when you do that thing I asked you to do (not digging up a cardinal; the other thing).

Sincerely,

Shauvon

fields.title: Why
fields.text:
I had a thought. Actually I had a few thoughts. If you want to know why I've been really out of it lately, or you didn't know I was out of it and just wanted to know what was going through my mind, here's your answer.

Of course, you'll have to forgive me for answering your question with a question.

Why am I here?

Why am I here?

That's the question that occupies most of my mind lately. I don't mean it on a cosmic, meaning of life sort of level. Just, 'what for?' Why am I working here? Why am I at Purdue? Why am I getting out of bed? I've been really struggling with the 'what for' of everything. (bear with me, this does go somewhere)

The way I see it, life is a series of horrible events, strung together by periods of relative calm. Something terrible happens, either to me or the world around me. I deal with it, and it blows over ('events always have a way of working out'). I feel bad about the terrible thing that happened for a while (or I am otherwise affected by it). Time pushes those memories back, and they ultimately slip away. I calm down; I forget. Life moves on, and I'm left to wait for the next crisis.

It would be fine if those crisis points were balanced out, if every once in a while something really awesome happened to me. I don't have good things. I don't catch a break. All I get is neutral - periods of relative calm with which to catch my breath.

Here is an example. A couple weeks ago, I came down with a nasty stomach flu. I don't know what it was, and I don't care. All I care about is the fact that it made me throw up all night. If you know me at all, you should know that I have a pathological hatred of vomit. I hate talking about it. I hate hearing about it. There is absolutely nothing that I consider worse. I would rather lose a limb. I would rather die.

Melodrama aside, the event crippled me. I was ready to come back to school (it was right at the end of the semester break), and have a great last semester. Instead, now I'm just living in fear of the next crisis. Every time I wake up in a cold sweat, because I heard my roommate go to the bathroom in the middle of the night, every time my stomach feels upset, every time I eat anything, I can't help but wonder if the time has come again. Did John catch something? Did I catch it, too? Will this bite be the one that makes me sick? It could happen any day, at absolutely any point, and there is absolutely nothing I can do to stop it. Worse still is the knowledge that it will happen again. It is inevitable.

Is that all I have to live for?

Some day, maybe soon, I will calm down. The memories won't be so fresh, and I'll be able to close my eyes without thinking about it. Some day I'll be able to go to sleep without wondering how soon I'll be woken up by nausea. On that day, when I finally forget, is when it will happen again.

Is that all I have to live for?

See, I don't know if I'll ever actually produce my pilot (in fact, I really doubt it). I don't think I'll ever fall in love. I don't know if I'll ever be able to build a computer that doesn't constantly crash. I don't know what kind of job I will be getting in a couple months when I graduate. I have no idea when, or if anything good will ever happen to me, but I do know that something bad will. It may not be vomiting. It could be my computer completely failing (or crashing while I'm working on something really important). It could be yet another person breaking my heart. It could be a Crazy Monkey show that I work hard on that turns out terribly. It could be one of a billion things that I couldn't possibly imagine. I don't know what bad thing will happen to me, but I do know that it will happen.

Is that all I have to live for?

If all I care about is just not vomiting (or whatever), why should I do anything? The more I'm in contact with people, the more I put myself at risk of catching something (or having my heart broken). If I don't care about getting a job (I'm really not sure that I am), when why do it? If I know all I will get out of class today is boredom, why should I go? If I don't think my pilot will ever be made, and I'm sure nobody will ever care (including myself), why should I work on it? Why not just sit around all day working on Stupid, Useless Crap.

Here's you: 'You dwell on the negative, Shauvon.' That's the point I'm trying to make. When a crisis happens, we all dwell on the negative. We have to look at what's going wrong so we can do something to fix it. Then, when things are back to a status quo, we can forget it. We can fall back into our ignorance, and ignore how horrible the universe is. I can't do that. I refuse to ignore what's wrong. I refuse because I need to know what's wrong. I need to know why.

I could return to my life of contented ignorance, silently waiting for the next life- altering crisis. I could work on my pilot. I could do my homework. I could, but then I would lose everything. I can't let go, because I need an answer.

Why am I here?

There has to be an answer to that question, because I am here. I'm out of bed. I went to class. I'm still thinking about ideas for my pilot. I ate something. I almost said something to a cute girl who sat next to me. Something is driving me, and I can't - I can't let go until I figure out what that is. I can't let go of this screaming desperation, this raging fear, until I have an answer. I can't embrace the ignorance again until I know why.

Ask yourselves, now. Why are you here? Put your hands down, that's rhetorical. I'm just saying, it's something you should know. Why do you get out of bed? Why do you risk getting sick every single moment of your lives? Maybe you don't need one (probably because you haven't had any crises lately). Maybe I'm the only person who needs a reason.

Why am I here?

Why not?

I'll leave you with the lyrics to a Nine Inch Nails song, Getting Smaller (because nobody understands an existential crisis like Trent Reznor). The song came up on my headphones, and it inspired me to come up with this whole diatribe.

Getting a little erratic here
And I don't know who to trust
I guess they got a way of reading my mind
I guess I gotta adjust
Got my arms they flip flop flip flop flip

Well I thought I got you on my side
I haven't got fucking anything

And for what it is worth
I really used to believe
That maybe there's some great thing

And now I cant tell the difference

And what appears to be real

fields.title: 10 Reasons why you wish you were me
fields.text:
So that last thing might make you glad you aren't me, but we both know that isn't the case. You still wish you were me. Let me give you ten reasons why.

  1. Two Classes
    One of which is a 200 level course. I don't think I really have to explain this one.
  2. Height
    Face it. You wish you were six eight.
  3. Free shit.
    I won't tell you what or how, just in case somebody wants to arrest me (probably from jealousy), but I Can get a lot of really expenSive things 4 free.
  4. Web development is like play
    I really enjoy putting an application together, which is why I do it on average for 6 hours a day. Since I consider it more like playing a video game than doing work, I really only do like 2 hours of work a day, and most of that is going to or from class. Oh, also I get paid to do it.
  5. No obligations to man or machine
    I have a part time job, a few modest bills every month, and two pretty easy classes (see #1). Those are the only minor obligations I have. I ask myself why I should get out of bed every morning because I don't have to get out of bed. I ask 'why am I here?' because I don't have to be here.
  6. Social Detachment
    I feel alienated and isolated from everyone around me, but I prefer it this way. It really sucks sometimes, sure, but you have no idea how freeing it is to be completely detached from everyone around you. I don't have to follow anybody's rules (except the government, with the exception of #3).
  7. The soundtrack rocks
    Listen to what I listen to almost constantly, as loudly as I listen to it, and you'll be ready to punch cars out of your way and smash down walls.
  8. Healthy and chemically pure
    Except for the lung thing (which is really only enough of a problem to be a conversation piece), and the obvious psychological hurdles, I've never had a serious health problem. Also, barely any drugs ever enter my system, and the ones that do aren't any more powerful than anti-histamines.
  9. Tim, John, Mike, Tom, Logan, Joe, Eli, Kelsey, Lauren, Matt
    I know, you have cool friends, too. Well fuck you and your friends. Mine are better. I sincerely believe that. Last Friday evening, a room full of people all decided that they would rather watch me and my friends than you and yours (unless you're one of those people I listed, in which case you are one of my friends (and yes, I realize that there were other shows and things going on that night that had audiences, but whatever)). I get to watch the Crazy Monkeys perform pretty much every day.
  10. My computer(s)
    Sure, my desktop crashes occasionally, but it's a quad core machine with 8 gigabytes of ram and DirectX 10.1 capability and a TERRORbyte of hard drive space. Plus it has Vista on it, which is better than anything you might be using. Also, my Eee is better than your laptop.

There you go, the top ten reasons you wish you were me. I'm just saying this to make sure that we're clear. I might have trouble motivating myself and understanding what my place is, but there is nobody I would rather be.

I guess I should also mention that I was inspired to do this by one of those disgusting Facebook chain letter things.

fields.title: What if 1
fields.text:
What if you had a day with no consequences? You're going to die the next day, so you have 24 hours to do whatever you want. What would you do? Who would you talk to?

What would you listen to if you knew it would be the last song you ever heard?

What would you say to someone if you knew it was your last conversation?

What would you eat? What would you touch? What laws would you break?

Really think about it. Don't just think about thinking about it, just to humor me. I'm just text on a screen, so you don't have to make me feel better. I'm doing this for you. It's important that you think of something now, before I corrupt your brain with the point I'm trying to make. Did you think of something? Good.

Now, what if you weren't dying tomorrow (hopefully this is actually the case). Which of those things would you still do? Any of them? Why wouldn't you do a thing you specifically want to do before you die just because you don't know you are yet? Is consequence worse than death?

Do one of those things, anyway. Right now.

fields.title: Summer '09
fields.text:
So here's a thing about me. My life is ending on May 9th, 2009.

That's when my last class happens, a final for Physics.

On may 11th (the 10th is a Sunday), I begin the 'rest of my life.' Working every single day, all day, until I die. I might take a break on my birthday.

After May 9th, 2009, everything I know will change. Well, okay, so my lease will continue through August, and my job will remain indefinitely, but the point is that my life as I know it will be done. Yes, I will miss it, but judging from how generally unhappy I am most of the time, I shouldn't mourn for long.

Speaking of which, I've been especially unhappy lately. It's (that's 'it was') my last Spring Break ever, and I failed my goal of seeing at least one boob. My pilot hit a wall (in my head), and I completely lost interest in producing it. I've lost touch with reason. I feel like I have no point. I can't say anything that hasn't already been said. I can't do anything that hasn't already been done. Plus, you know, my life is going to end in a couple months.

My problem is that I can't think of a single thing that I really want to do. There are things I'm mildly interested in, a lot of stuff I like to do to kill time, but nothing I would want to do every day from now until the end of time. That's been really bumming me out. Especially since five months from now I'll be homeless, and jobless, on top of being directionless and careless. That's terrifying on top of depressing.

I feel better now, though. I feel better because I've pushed the 'end of life as I know it' back a bit. I found something that I want to do. Instead of fear the 'end of my life' I'm going to bring it on. I'm going to just let it all go. I'm going to say goodbye to my life, and I'm going to leave. I will walk straight into the abyss, and I won't be coming back. I mean, this me won't be coming back.

I've never done anything particularly hard. I've never done anything particularly interesting, frankly. Before I get a real job and spend the rest of my life building websites or whatever else I'll be stuck doing, I'm going to have one real adventure.

I'm going to Burning Man.

fields.title: New Facebook
fields.text:
or, People are Morons

Facebook has a new layout. I figured I would mention that in case you're my parents or you live under a rock.

Of course, by 'new layout' I mean that they slightly re-designed the home page, which is just a center for pertinent information. Who befriended whom, who says what about which, and et cetera. They redesign it once or twice a year. Every single time they do, the new layout is met with such a barrage of negative criticism, you'd think a Republican was just elected president again. Of course, by 'negative criticism' I mean mostly cursing in all caps.

Somebody decided to start a vote this time around to see who liked the new layout. As of now, the application has 80,505 votes for the new layout and 1,234,926 votes against. (or as I like to say it, 80,505 intelligent people and 1,234,926 morons). People are still voting because they think it will make a difference. Facebook neither made the application nor do they care what the outcome of the vote is.

The other thing that people are still doing is commenting on the voting application's message board. Here are some highlights of those comments, along with my reasons why they're morons.

So the second, third, or fourth layouts are fine? I think the first layout wasn't great, either, but who can remember six years ago? Also, who doesn't like black text on a white background? You probably shouldn't read any books. You're right, though, Myspace is totally better.
What a valid argument. Or maybe this is just an act of self-censorship.
I'm not sure you get the message behind that book you're quoting there, Paul.
Oh, old people. Your desperate attempts to stay with the times are so futile.
I'm waiting. What happened yesterday? Do you want to talk about it? YOU TALK ME NOW
. . . what?
First off, the friends system hasn't changed at all, only the home page has been changed. For that matter, photos haven't changed at all, either, except that they now have rounded corners. Ok, so the higher emphasis on 'fan' pages probably just signifies Facebook's true desire to serve as the world's greatest advertising platform, but I'm sure that's what you were getting at. As for why your friends are gone, well maybe it's because you're a barely coherent moron.
Maybe you should sit down for a moment and take a deep breath. You should probably see a doctor about that internet-triggered vertigo.
The thing I find interesting about these posts is that they would have all had to be typed at exactly the same moment. Also, all five of these people (well, four people and one shoe) thought that just voting 'I do not like the layout' just didn't quite say 'I do not like the layout' enough for them. Essentially 85% of the comments were something to the effect of 'I do not like the layout.' Thanks, that's really helpful, shoe.
I am not subject to change!! You aren't allowed to bring it into my life! SO THERE
It seems like some of the people were so enraged by the new layout that they couldn't even type properly.
This guy probably saw it and hated it, but thought, 'I hate it, but maybe if I look at it again in a little while.' Then he looked at it again. 'I STILL HATE IT'
Some day I will have my revenge against those insolent dogs! They will feel my wrath . . . as soon as I move out of my parents' house. Man, when I get to college I'm going to be all, 'dOwN wItH fAcEbOoK!!!1' If only there was something we could do to protest their actions and also remove all of their power . . . I mean, without having to delete my account, because otherwise I wouldn't be able to make any friends.
Oh, come on, the difference is right . . . oh, wait. I think she's on to something here.
To be fair, English probably isn't her primary language. Wait, that doesn't mean she wouldn't know how to use capitalization. I'm not sure where to begin on this one.
It sure does, Mariel. It sure does.
This is actually a long-used web design term.
This one isn't really that bad, I just needed to include it to make sense of the next one. Ok, so Lukas doesn't know the difference between 'you're' and 'your' but at least he's not a complete moron. Like this guy:
EIGHT MORE YEARS OF NEW FACEBOOK
Not like those keyboard keys, they're right at your fingertips, aren't they? You; can't miss that shift key.

Facebook is actually a sovereign nation, now, so business isn't even what they do anymore, FYI.

Messages, etc. are all in the exact same place they always were.
See those little buttons in the upper-left corner? They've been there for years, and that last one takes you right to your messages. now
I CAN. The only reason we've EVER been on Facebook is for communication. 'I joined Facebook to . . . uh . . .' I can't even think of a joke to finish that thought because there's absolutely nothing you could join Facebook for that isn't some form of communication.

This was just a casual perusal of the first 20 pages or so of comments. The joke's really on me, though, because there's no way I'm wading through this:

. . . just to make fun of people.

fields.title: Physics Girls
fields.text:
There are these two girls in my Physics Lab. They sit in the middle of the room, and their desk faces my desk. As you can probably imagine, I'm pretty bored a lot in Physics Lab, so I spend a lot of time watching them. I just drift off while my lab partner calculates all of the gratuitous calculations, and they happen to be the best thing in the room to look at. Is that creepy? I'm just going to continue as if it's not.

The thing is, they could be sitting in a room full of actors from the OC (don't call it that), and they would still be the best thing in the room to look at. They could be sitting in an art gallery, and they would still be . . . anyway you get the idea.

They're gorgeous.

Of course I don't know anything about them, except that they're friends, not physics majors, and perfect. Sure, I'm embellishing a little, just don't tell them that. Maybe it's just the content of the class, or the bimbo management students who sit at the next table over from me. Maybe it's the way the blonde's golden hair shines in the midday sun, or the brunette's curt and gentle smile. Maybe it's just the fact that they are consistently dressed so well for a pointless, 200 level class. Maybe it's just my nature to fall deeply in like with whomever sits on the other side of the room.

Maybe I'm just a creep.

It occurred to me today, as I watched the blonde walk across the room to get something from the printer, that these will be the last girls I will admire from across a classroom. I've done it constantly since I was six, since even before I started wearing two different colored socks every day. I always see a beautiful woman on the other side of the room, think something poetic and sad about how I'll never meet them, and then move on to the next class. Sometimes I've talked to them, usually I do nothing.

I don't think it's really worth talking to people. Of course, here, I'm referring to people in general. They're never what I hope they are. They can't live up to the expectations I unconsciously place on them based only on appearances. At best, they'll give me something to do for a while, and at worst they'll cause me a considerable amount of pain and hatred. Ninety-nine out of a hundred people you meet will do nothing but frustrate and annoy you (that's one of Shauvon McGill's patent-pending laws of life). I don't like having to talk to people, but since I am a human being, I have to. It turns out that's ok.

One out of those hundred times, they'll change your life. Somehow that justifies everything.

Anyway, I've been doing a lot of 'looking back' at the last five years, thinking about what I should take from it all. Since I am an entirely different person than I was five years ago, I guess the answer is everything. Still, I wonder if these two girls represent my last classroom crush, or my last chance to do the only thing I ever really wanted to do in college. Do I risk ruining the former for the minuscule chance at the latter?

Of course, since there are two of them, it's only a 1 in 50 chance that they'll break my heart . . . As if there's any chance at all that I'll actually talk to them.

Here's looking at you, cute Physics Lab girls. You may not be the last girls I admire from the other side of a room, but you'll be the last girls I admire from the other side of a classroom. Thank you for giving me a reason to go to class.

That made me think, that WLFI weather girl is really cute, and also, what other jobs could I do?

I decided to quantify my prospects with the following handy chart:

It's all theoretical, at this point, and it's all just based on things I made up as I was making it, but I think it sums up the job scene pretty well. There is no scientific or mathematical basis for this graph in any way, but there isn't really in the job world, either, unless you're a scientist or mathemagician (I should add those to the graph!). I might continue to edit it as time goes on.

What jobs are in your 'fun zone?' What jobs would you consider high on the 'Gain' axis? Where would you say the job you have now fits in to the graph? Are you above or below the 'line of qualification?'

I suppose if you have a job for a few years, your qualifications will pretty quickly adapt to include that job.

Just something to think about (for me, anyway).

Being goofy gets you weird stuff.

The Crazy Monkeys are getting t-shirts, so we need a big fat wad of cash to pay for them. We have plenty of money (too much money!) in our BOSO (Business Office for Student Organizations) account, so I went to Schleman hall to get it. It's our money, right? Apparently, it isn't. Then I went to Greyhouse to get a cup of hot cocoa because I'm annoyed and I have work to do (which I'm putting off to write this). When I ordered it, the beautiful girl (everyone who works at Greyhouse is freaking gorgeous) behind the register asked if I wanted all of the bits that go on top (some sort of marshmallow fluff and chocolate crumbles). Wanting to be hilarious, I said, 'of course, that's the only reason I'm getting this. If I could just get a cup full of that stuff, that's all I would get.' I don't actually want a cup full of that stuff. I ordered a hot cocoa because I wanted a hot cocoa. I only said that because it's my responsibility as a local celebrity to be hilarious.

Anyway, here I am, drinking my cup which is only half full of cocoa, and half full of marshmallow stuff and hundreds of chocolate crumbles. Also I know more about good accounting practice.

fields.title: Old
fields.text:
I'm getting old.

I realized over the weekend that I'm turning 23 in three weeks. That's old. 23 is when ages stop mattering so much. What's the difference between 22 and 23? It's nowhere near as much as the difference between 20 and 21. Furthermore, I'm noticing myself doing 'adult' things more. I've found a passing interest in connoisseur beer (if just to humor a couple of my friends). I can no longer drink soda or eat candy before I go to bed, because it will keep me up all night. Foods I had no problem eating before (particularly frozen foods) are disgusting, now.

I went to Lafayette Brewing Company (a bar) with John and Tom the other day, and we weren't carded. I don't know if that's so much a result of me being old or if they just weren't doing their job, but it was still weird.

I'm not ready to be old, yet. There are too many things I haven't experienced.

fields.title: Three years of Monkey Fliers
fields.text:
I will soon be leaving the Crazy Monkeys. It's been a long, fun ride. Along with retiring my leadership and my comedy, I will be retiring my role as Dude-who-designs-most-of-the-fliers. After three years in the group, I've designed 19 different fliers. Let's take a look back, and see where we've gone over the years.

Click on any (almost) of the images to see a much larger version, to see the sweet detail in all of these promotional materials.

January, 2007: The first flier I ever made. I did it because we just needed something to go up in the coffee house, so we would only print like two of them. I remember somebody mentioning how terrible this flier was, which made me decide to actually make some good fliers, which started this whole saga.

January, 2007 (auditions): This time, I wanted to make something flashy, colorful, and dynamic. This is the flier that got John, Tim, Sarah, Tom, and Kaz into the group, so I think it was a successful flier.

April, 2007: An interesting typographical layout. One of my earliest memories of John was him walking into practice with a few dirty words circled on one of the handbills based on this flier. Can you spot them?

August, 2007: This was the first show of the year, and I wanted to start up a graffiti-esque advertising scheme. This flier pretty much became the only outcome. The text and the graphic are too separate.

November, 2007 (charity show): This turned out to be one of our best shows. Sure, it was too long, but we raised like $250 for Habitat for Humanity and the Timmy Foundation. I really like how the dual logo turned out, but the flier ended up way too busy and cluttered.

December, 2007 (Big Dog Eat Child): I was in a class about persuasion in advertising, and they said that motion goes a long way to catch the eye. I found a picture that I took which had a lot of motion in it (and also a big dog, to signify the sketch group we did the show with). I think it turned out pretty well.

January, 2008: On a Saturday Morning, in my lucid, half asleep state I saw this flier. Note that this is the first appearance of Myriad Pro, and an early iteration of the new logo text. I don't know why the underscore was there, I guess I thought it looked cool at the time. I've always wanted a poster-size version of this one.

January, 2008 (auditions): I couldn't decide which picture best suited the slogan I chose for the '08 auditions, so I picked three (they only really count as one flier, though). We ended up using the first and the third one, putting both up all over campus. This flier got Joe and Logan (or Jogan) into the group. Note that the new logo text is fully realized now. I still think that these are very sharp and visually interesting.

February, 2008: Another abstract modern art whatever for the Village. I think these only went up in the coffee house, so not many of them were printed. I think I joked at the time that this flier (and the rainbow one before it) made me gay. I think this was the last show we ever did at the Village Coffee House.

April, 2008: For my best friend Andrew Monkey's last show, I wanted to honor him with this vectorized, 11x17 flier. I used the Scanner Darkly poster next to my desk as inspiration. We printed a full-size poster version of this one, and everyone signed it. Joe's Mom won it at the show.

August, 2008: The first show of the year, and we couldn't get Matthews Hall. We were stuck in Armstrong (the new building), and it was not great. I decided to go ahead and do what everybody else seems to be obsessed with, and use a grunge theme with lots of paint splatters. Notice that the wall shifts from red to blue to enhance the perspective.

October, 2008 (auditions): We needed girls in the group, so I wanted to use a flowery, girly graphic to attract some. I made a certificate at work which they ended up not using (lame), but I didn't want it to go to waste so I turned it into this flier (sweet). The picture is from my parents' new woods. Notice the reference to Harland Fankboner and Lookit the Tiny Monkey. This flier got Kelsey, Lauren, Matt, and Eli in to the group, so it was partially successful at getting girls (actually, it tripled the number of girls in the group, so that's a big win).

At this point, I officially released the new Crazy Monkey logo. I made a new logo for the group for a few reasons. First, I wanted to make an impact and make sure that they never forget me (until someone else re-designs it). Second, and more important, I wanted a logo that was less phallic, arthritic, and hard to draw. The new logo can easily be sketched on a chalkboard or sidewalk. Also, I think it's neat that the new logo has the letters 'C' and 'M' in it.


Do you see them?

Anyway, with the new logo, I threw together some promotional materials for it. Let's take a break from the fliers for a moment to see some of these graphics.


The first teaser graphic, which I think was the picture on our facebook page for a while.




A series of images I made and didn't use in any way. I wished that there was a big media buzz over the new logo, but nobody really cared. I guess these images can stand as a memorial to October, 2008, which wasn't bad. I did the first three in Photoshop, and the last one in Maya. The middle one was from a photoshoot we did to finally get a group photo which was immediately invalidated by getting a bunch of new members. Devotees might recognize the alley shot from my photo series I made a while back.

October, 2008: This is the first flier to have the new logo. I don't really count it as a flier, though, because it's the same as the one I had for the first show of the year, just with the new logo 'spray painted' over it. We wanted to actually spray the new logo over the banner we have of the old logo, but we've never been able to because that thing's huge.

Anyway, once all the buzz over the new logo died down, we got back to doing hilarious improv shows.

November, 2008: Another 11x17 flier, because we really wanted to promote the charity show. I really like how this flier turned out, but I was not very impressed with how well the audience turned out. The Ship of Fools told us that they wanted pajamas made out of a material with this pattern on it. I'm inclined to agree with them.

December, 2008: For Sara's last show, I wanted to do something somber. It didn't really turn out that way, and I'm not really a fan of what I ended up with. This was right in the middle of a pretty serious lull in my photography (which I'm only just getting out of now), so I didn't have much material to work with. I think it was an interesting idea, but it didn't really work too well. Vienna isn't a great place to do a show, FYI.

January, 2009: Then I came back hard. I love this one, and I turned it into a great desktop wallpaper, too (most of these fliers can be downloaded as wallpapers from the monkey website, in the archives). I wanted to prove that I could do shiny gradients and other web 2.0 stuff, and I did just that. This was when I started to realize that the new logo is pretty spindly, though, which I'm not a fan of. I wish the outer border was heavier. By the way, every show we've done at Greyhouse has been amazing. The energy in that place is fantastic.

March, 2009: I had the idea that we should try a show at Hot Box pizza, since we were unable to get Matthews all semester, and Greyhouse books all semester in advance. This show turned out okay, and we absolutely packed the place. This flier has the first actual appearance of the full text + graphic logo. I wish I made the cardboard thing actually look like a pizza box, and not just a weird piece of cardboard. Also, I hope Hot Box doesn't sue us for stealing their style.

April, 2009: I had the idea a while ago to do a super-show which would take an entire evening, and feature groups doing shows in venues all over town. We only ended up getting one other group, and toned the plan down from five groups in five hours to three groups in three hours. Then I had the idea that if we did a longform show we would have one of every style of live comedy. This was the best comedy show I will probably ever be a part of. This was also the best weekend of my life.

April, 2009: We finally got Big Dog down to do another show, so I made another dog-themed flier. I wish I had made it look like stacks of paper instead of cut out of paper, because using red in the background threw off the illusion. Big Dog is probably the coolest group of dudes ever. Our logo kind of looks like crap on the blue background. I wish I had just used a black and white logo.

May, 2009: The last flier I will make for the last official show I will do with the Crazy Monkeys. Like Andrew's flier last year, I made an homage to this year's graduates. I don't know about Tim or Mike, but the symbolism here for me is that I'm walking to Burning Man. My friend Stephanie helped me tweak the layout a little bit, mainly in the placement of the date, time, and location text. This one's in vector, so it could be blown up as big as you want and it would still look sweet. Poster?

So there you have it, all of the fliers I made during my time with the greatest comedy group outside of Chicago.

I hope you're happy. I'm crying, now.

fields.title: CGT 456 Group 3 Report
fields.text:
If you have talked to me in the last two weeks (or looked at my twitter feed), you'll know that I just finished up a big group project which didn't quite go so well. I was stuck with idiots who didn't do any work. Anyway, I had to write a report explaining how much work we all did and what it was like. I just sent mine to the professor, and hopefully it doesn't get me in trouble. I'll show it to you. I know, I kind of rip the two dudes a few new ones. I'm only stating fact, and future potential employers might want to know things like 'is completely incompetent' or 'incapable of understanding ASP.NET' about a potential hire, and those things don't usually make it onto resumes.

To whom it may concern:

I am reasonably convinced that my group, group 3, did the absolute worst project in this class. I have looked at a few of the other groups' work. They're dynamic, flashy, and interesting. Ours looks terrible, is full of bugs, and in many places doesn't work at all. That isn't a great way to start a group project report. I just want to preface the whole process with this disclaimer. It's unfair, you see, to compare our project to the other groups. It's unfair because the other groups were actually groups. Group 3 was really only one man.

I did almost all of the work on this project. I say 'almost' because there were a few things the other two group members did which I had to completely redo to make it work right. Who put together the entire class structure? I did that. Who made all of the database interaction? I did that, too. Who built the system for displaying a list of questions, showing the answers, and all of the code to add new questions and answers (which essentially was the entire project)? I did all of it. Who wrote the code to generate a tag cloud and dynamically display it on the page? I wrote that code. Who built all of the ASP.NET panels and wrote the code behind file to sort through them all? You guessed it, it was me. In fact, I feel particularly confident that I was the only member of my group who actually knew how to use ASP.NET or C# in any productive way. I'm not sure why I trusted my group members to handle just turning it in. I was out of town that weekend, so I had no choice. The only way I even knew the other two guys existed was because they were ridiculously annoying and incompetent.

Did the group work well together? We absolutely did not. We didn't work together at all. I did all the work, and the other two guys sat staring at their screens scratching their heads. Did I have any problems with any members of my group? Absolutely I did. They were morons and they didn't understand anything. If they had told me afterword that they were, in fact, 15, I would not have been surprised in the least.

I'm not sure how to divide the work load. I would say between the two of them, they did maybe 5% of the overall project (if you don't count the stuff I had to redo because it didn't work). Considering the site doesn't even really work, that's essentially 5% of nothing.

Gabe did the beautiful design. Actually, he just came up with the header; the sidebar was my idea, since we needed a place for, you know, content. He immediately volunteered to design the site, which is something I am still puzzled over. He was preparing his 411 presentation at the time, so obviously he couldn't actually work on the design for this website until that was over, when all we had time for was the complete pile of trash he came up with.

David dealt with the database structure; of course I use the term 'dealt with' very loosely. As far as I know, he just had a friend of his do all the work. Even with a supposed expert SQL Server guru backing us, I still found things missing from the database structure on a daily basis. David also insisted we work on his personal server, instead of the space provided to us by the class. To say this was an inconvenience would be like saying David himself was merely lazy. I had to use the world's worst FTP software to manually upload every file I changed, and I had absolutely no access to the SQL Server database to find all of the things that were missing from it. Ultimately I had to make my own page that just dumped out all of the data because I had no other way to view it. The process was slow, annoying, and unnecessary. The biggest frustration came when David decided that we should go ahead and move everything over to the class server anyway (but I could go ahead and keep working on his if I wanted to). At least he thanked me for all of my work almost constantly.

I worked on this project pretty much straight through for about six days in a row (plus off and on for the two weeks before then). I definitely did more work on this than I did for the first two projects. Unfortunately, it was just too much for one man to finish. I told them I wasn't going to be able to work on it on Friday evening or Saturday morning, figuring that they could debug anything that wasn't quite working yet. Of course, that was assuming they knew how ASP.NET worked. I have since checked the site, and of course it's broken. It worked fine when I stopped working on it on Friday morning, so obviously one of the geniuses thought they could sneak into the garage and start playing around with daddy's tools. I would be insulted that they even want to keep their names on the thing, but that wouldn't be fair to them. Sure, I'm responsible for the stuff we got working, but they're responsible for all the stuff that doesn't work at all. I guess that entitles them to have equal credit.

We're supposed to say what grade we would give ourselves if we were grading this project. I would give us a 'D,' but only because I still want to pass. My diploma is riding on this a little bit, so it would suck to not graduate just because I was stuck with some idiots. I know one thing for certain, though. David Auble and Gabe Masters-Jackson should not pass this class. They don't know the first thing about ASP.NET, and they should not be allowed to think that they do (or make employers think they do, for crying out loud). I'm not trying to throw them under the bus to save my own skin. It's just that I obviously know what I'm doing, and they obviously don't. That means they should fail, and I should not.

It should mean that, anyway.

I hope it means that.

Well, cry 'havoc' and let slip the dogs of grading. I can only apologize for the terrible site that you're forced to wade through to grade it. I'm not making any excuses for anything we didn't get done. I'm just letting you know that it was a miracle we got anything done at all.

For what it's worth, you're by far my favorite professor in CGT. I'm not just saying that. You're the reason I'm pursuing a career in web development. Thank you, and good luck with the new class you're teaching next semester. It sounds awesome, and I really wish I could have taken it.

Sincerely,
Shauvon McGill
smcgill@purdue.edu

Let this stand as proof that if I posted it on here I probably meant every single word, because I did, and I do.

So I wasn't sure if I was going to pass my Physics class or not. I didn't go a lot, and I skipped a lot of stuff. Yeah, that's not a good plan, but the whole class was so pointless, and I've had so much else to worry about over the last few months. Obviously if I didn't, I would have to retake the class, probably over this summer.

Grades were supposedly going up on Wednesday (tomorrow), but I thought I would go see if they were up yet tonight. I wanted to know if this was going to be a pretty bad summer or the worst one ever. As it happens, the grades were posted, and as it happens, I did get the D, after all. You might not be aware, but 'D' stands for 'Degree.'

I am a college graduate.

If only I weren't so lonely and unmotivated.

If you were wondering, I got a 'B' in my other class, the one I wrote the scathing email to my professor about. I had an A before that project, so it definitely brought me down, but it didn't hurt me too badly, apparently. I keep running into one of the dudes from my 'team' around town, and it's pretty super awkward.

fields.title: Introducing Carus
fields.text:
or Shauvon Should Not be Allowed to Have Money (part 1)

I have a new camera. This shouldn't be news to you.

It's a Canon 50D, with a Tamron 18 - 270 mm lens. I have a 4 gigabyte Compact Flash card, and a Canon 430EX speedlight (but the speedlight isn't new). It's probably the most awesome thing I've ever owned (except maybe that limited-edition signed copy of Ara that I have around here somewhere). The new camera, which I call Carus (a Latin word for 'expensive'), has 15 megapixels. It shoots Canon Raw files that are around 25 megabytes a file. My old camera, a Canon 350D (apparently lower numbers mean better cameras), had 8 megapixels and created files that were about 7 megabytes each. I can take just over 200 pictures on a 2 gigabyte CF card with my old camera. With Carus, using a 4 gig card, I can take about 150 pictures. That's how much bigger 15 megapixels are.

The pictures my old camera took were plenty big. With 8 megapixels, you can easily print poster-sized versions of photographs, create desktop backgrounds that span two widescreen monitors, and quickly fill hard drives with pictures. Carus takes photographs with almost twice the resolution and over three times the size of my old camera. I can substantially crop photographs taken by Carus, and they will still be larger than anything my old camera took. That gives me a great deal of power as a photographer. A 15 megapixel file is 4752 pixels wide by 3168 pixels tall.

You can see just how big that is by looking at this 6.51 megabyte JPEG file.

Carus is Heavy (its full name is 'Gravis, Ergo Carus' or 'Heavy, therefore Expensive'). When I hold my old camera, it feels like a child's toy compared to this beast. Aside from making me feel like a real man, Carus's weight makes it a little difficult to carry around all the time.

I've taken a lot of pictures with Carus. You don't really have to try hard to get pictures substantially better than pictures you would take with a 'sans-carus' camera.

Would you like to see some of them?



My new, powerful lens allows me to capture small, easily scared things from a distance. Do you see it?





This is the alleyway I photographed a year and a half ago. The graphiti has been painted over (poorly).


This is one of my new favorites, and my old camera could never have done it.



Another bird. Can you see this one?

I call this one, 'West Lafayette'

I was lying on a median on State Street for a few minutes taking pictures of these flowers juxtaposed against the stoplights and traffic behind them. I feel that the larger, more serious camera allows me to be more bizarre and intrusive with my photography. People won't question me as much because my camera tells them that I mean business.

These photographs are a sign of things to come. 2009 will be a good year for DenyConformity.com.

One of my best friends, Tim, and another one of my best friends, Mary, had their wedding on Saturday. I will always remember it as one of the high points of my life.

It is not often that one gets the opportunity to witness perfection. On Saturday, I did. I could not be happier for the couple, and I feel so honored that they allowed me to share just a tiny piece of their perfection. Tim absolutely adores Mary, and Mary absolutely adores Tim. Their relationship is one of the most beautiful things I will ever see; of that I am certain. To wish them happiness feels futile. It is obvious that they will know nothing but happiness. They will know nothing but perfection.

Here's to perfection.

fields.text:
Terrified.

Terrified.

That's the primary component of my mood the last week (and day). You see, I've moved to Chicago. I've moved to Chicago, I'm in way over my head, I'm alone, I'm out of my element, and I'm terrified. I've done this thing, this 'grand adventure' that is becoming an adult. I don't want to do it, and I don't know why I did. There are 2.8 million people here.

2.8 Million people. (I Googled '2.8 million' to see just how much that is, and interestingly that's the number of homes that weren't ready for the DTV switch. I bet those people don't have TV anymore and they're terrified).

What am I doing? What am I doing? What am I doing? I feel so out of place. I'm a 20 minute train ride from Downtown Chicago. I can ride my bike to the Sears Tower. I saw these comedy people tonight, these girls who do improv (friends of my roommate). They're funny, sophisticated, and interesting, and I'm just some fucking hayseed from the middle of nowhere. I don't know how to behave. I don't know where to go. I don't even know what I'm terrified of.

You know sometimes when you fart and for a split second you think you might have done more than just fart? That's how I feel, except it's all the time. I'm constantly did-I-just-poop-my-pants terrified. It's not going anywhere, and neither are the 2.8 million people living right outside my bedroom.

God damn it, what am I going to do?

 

Maybe what terrifies me so much is the fact that I'm actually doing alright here.

fields.title: Whole Foods Market
fields.text:
I live in Chicago, now.

Something I'm getting used to is having the comic book store considerably farther away. It means I make much less impulse purchasing of cool comics, or I at least have to coordinate them around my once-a-week trip to that part of the neighborhood.

One of the other difficult things about being a person with only two arms and zero cars in a big city is buying groceries. Of course, the big city does mean I have a few options (although I'm still looking for a great little greek-owned food mart somewhere).

Very recently, a Jewel Osco (the chain of Supermarket here) closed right around the corner from my place while they build a new one. A shiny new Jewel will be opening in the fall of 2010, but that does me little good now. The nearest Jewel is now about seven tenths of a mile away.

Also about seven tenths of a mile away is a cool supermarket called Trader Joe's. Joe runs a pretty trendy little mart, with lots of organic food and other hipster gear. Hipsters don't like brand names, so Joe's got his own. You're not going to find Nabisco, Kellog's, or Kraft here (well, you might, but it isn't as prevalent). Yes, it's a store without Kraft Foods. My boycott just got a lot easier. Joe's got a whole aisle of this super trendy stuff called 'wine.' He may call himself a trader, but he primarily just trades wine for cash. I doubt they would accept an old pair of pants for a box of cereal, or this old hard drive I have laying around for a watermelon. Joe is, in fact, a poor trader.

Closer, at four tenths of a mile, is the nearest CVS pharmacy. I know it's a pharmacy and not a food-mart-cy, but they have essentials like ice cream, cereal, candy, and more of that 'wine' stuff (plus plenty of drugs). Also, they have brand names, which means Oreo cookies. My boycott once again meets challenge.

Closer still, at three tenths of a mile, is a store called Whole Foods Market. I think they're implying that other stores only sell you like eight-tenths of an apple or cheese with extra holes or something. At least they're upfront about what kind of store they are. Namely, a store kind of store. I'm less tempted to try to barter with them.

By the way, in case you were wondering, the distance from ol' 248 S. Chauncey #3 (my old apartment) to the Purdue Union was only three tenths of a mile. From 248 S. Chauncey #3 to La Village food mart was only one tenth of a mile. I am now farther from food and other trendy hipster amenities than I used to be.

Being the closest superfoodorium, I went to Whole Foods today to see what it was all about.

It was all about the Benjamins.

Read More

or Shauvon no longer has any money.

I'm sorry about the poor image quality in these photographs. I only had my cell phone with me. I just noticed the Range Rover in the foreground of that picture.

The first thing you notice about Whole Foods is how overwhelmingly full of itself it is. Connoisseur beer piled right inside the front door? Aisles of organic groceries piled on wooden shelves? Antipasto bar? Accessories like two-bottle rubber wine caddies hanging at the end of aisles? General aroma of fine cheese? This place has it all.

Really, though, once you get used to it, Whole foods is just like any Marsh or Kroger that I'm used to (those are what they call supermarkets back where I'm from, in the middle of nowhere). Just replace the Connoisseur beer with Bud Light, the organic groceries with moth-infested processed corporate human chow, the wooden shelves with monolithic, cold steel, mile-long shelves, the antipasto with cheese wiz, the wine caddies with NFL branded beer cozies, and the fine cheese smell with a mixture of rotting produce and fat sweat, and you've got yourself a Kroger.

Obviously I'm exaggerating a little. Sometimes they have Miller High Life.

Seriously, though, I'm much more comfortable at a place like Kroger or Marsh. Probably, I suppose, because I'm used to places like that. The Whole Foods was very new, and like most things I encounter here, wholly terrifying. At one point I realized I was actually lost inside the store. I was lost and scared in a maze of wooden shelves and bland, beige food packages when I began to realize that Whole Foods was an entirely different sort of store. Whole Foods is not a Supermarket. It is, in fact, a Market, and it makes you wonder just what is so super about a Supermarket. They don't just have an antipasto bar, they have a place where you can sit, relax, and eat your antipasto (or presumably anything else you bought) right there in the store.

The produce and fresh meat selection was extraordinary. Truly, Kroger does not sell ground Bison.

They had cups of fresh berries which looked absolutely unforgettable (in fact, between going there and writing this, I purchased and ate most of one of them, and I can assure you that it was fantastic).

Plus, where else can you buy cheese the size of a case of beer?

And just look at the deli section. Everything looked way better than the generic 'slop salad' you'd find at any Kroger or Marsh deli.

Also, and I didn't get a picture of this, they have Almond Milk. Yes, it's pretty much what it sounds like.

Whole Foods certainly seems like the sort of place that is far healthier for you to shop than other, more 'super' markets. Sure, Organic food is pretentious (just look at how I have to capitalize it!), but you can't deny that it at least seems healthier than all that corporate human-chow. Ultimately, that's the real point, though. Whole Foods certainly seems like it is a much better place for you to shop. Perhaps it is, but there is definitely a cost for that sense of 'super'-iority.

You see, you're paying a premium for the sort of place that Whole Foods Market is. When you walk into a place as pretentious as Whole Foods, in your mind you slowly begin to replace the word 'pretentious' with 'goddamned expensive.' Ultimately, those two things are synonyms. Just how much were those berries? Ten dollars a pound (and each cup was about a pound). Ground Bison is $5.99 a pound. A very small box of (non-Kellog's) cereal is $3.69. A half-gallon of 2% is $2.39 (some prices aren't terrible, but you're not going to find any deals). The Almond Milk is two 30 ounce boxes for $4 (It comes in a juice box thing, and it doesn't require refrigeration. I'm so intrigued I might have to go back and buy some). A box with two small frozen pizzas is $4.99.

A woman finally asked me why I was taking pictures and notes on my cell phone, so I started to feel bad about not buying anything. I told her I was just interested in the place and wanted to tell my mom about it, so if you aren't my mom, don't read this. You hear me? This article is only for my mom.

Anyway, I went ahead and got a few things that I needed (like milk, bread, frozen pizzas, gluten-free waffles, and fresh fruit). I just got one basket, which turned out to be only one paper grocery bag full of food.

Just one bagful of pretentious, gluten free, organic, delicious, and admittedly cool, food. Any guesses how much the total was?

$48.11

Almost $50 for just one bag full of odds and sods (I've been watching a lot of British TV). How much food can you buy at Kroger for $50? How much is one basketful of food at Marsh? Certainly not $50. I used to feel bad when a basket of food at La Village (only one tenth of a mile from my home) came to $25. Is the quality of life that Whole Foods allows you worth the added cost? These are not necessarily rhetorical questions.

The other day, I was walking down the alley behind my apartment and was passed by one of my neighbors parking his Audi A6 in his garage next to his Maserati. I suppose he (or the guy with the Range Rover in the picture up above) doesn't mind spending that much for food (he probably feeds ground Bison to his dog). I don't know if I'm cool with it, though. I'd rather just buy comic books.

fields.title: Four years
fields.text:
Denyconformity.com is now four years old. Four years ago, I started this website to complain about my boring life. I don't like keeping a 'blog' because I don't think people really care about my personal problems. I want this site to be an interesting exploration of human culture and a place for me to explore my viewpoint on life. Hopefully my unique perspective is entertaining and insightful to somebody. That is my ultimate goal for this site, to provide something interesting for somebody to read. If I can help someone avoid a bad decision, or brighten someone's day with my mis-adventures, then I believe this site will be a success.

With moving to Chicago, I think my life has become considerably more interesting to an outside observer. Every time I told someone I was moving here, they seemed to be somewhat jealous of me and my exploits. Of course, all I felt was extreme fear, but that's another story. The thing is, I'm not sure what adventures I should try to get in to up here. Therefore, for the next year of my life, and by extension the next year of DenyConformity.com, I want to commission your help. Help me make this site as good as it can be. Let me do the things you've always wanted to do, and tell you what it's like.

I'll get interesting stories to tell on my website, and you can live vicariously through me, maybe learning a little about adventures you've always dreamt of.

So feel free to comment on this post with any ideas, dreams, or goals that you want me to do for you in the next year. No idea is too small, and no adventure is too obscure. I can't guarantee that I'll do everything you ask me to (obviously), but I can guarantee that if it won't get me in too much trouble, I'll tell you all about it here (with plenty of pictures). Think of it like a to-do list for DenyConformity.com, and for me, Shauvon McGill.

Is there a part of Chicago you've always wanted to see? Is there something you've always wanted to do but you've never quite had the money/time/patience/guts/stamina/desire to do it? Is there something that you think I should do because of who/where I am, or just because you think I should? Perhaps there's something you want a picture of, or a thing you've always heard of that you'd like to know more about. I can help make any of those things happen.

I'm a young man with a sweet life but no goals and no drive. Now you have a chance to get a glimpse of this sweet life, and help me have a reason to get up in the morning. This is also your chance to have a voice in the future of DenyConformity.com.

Thoughts?

fields.title: Willie Thunderstorm
fields.text:
I'm currently trying to get a chance to see a thunderstorm from the top of the building formerly known as the Sears Tower. Someone recently asked me to try to do this. I've made a little progress, and I thought I'd let you know what I've discovered so far. I wanted to update you all as soon as possible to let you know that I will, in fact, actually try to do things that you ask me to do.

Read more

Is it possible to see a thunderstorm from the top of the Sears Tower?

To start with, I thought I'd give a little history on the Sears Tower. Of course, you could just go to Wikipedia (which I am doing) and read all you want, but I'll give you the highlights. The Sears Tower is 108 stories or 1,450 feet tall. It is the tallest building in the United States (and was the tallest in the world for a while). It is currently the fifth tallest phalli - er - structure in the world. Sears actually lost their naming rights in 2003, but it continued to be called the Sears tower until recently, when some company called Willis something or other bought a bunch of the building and demanded to change the name.

There are so many groups on Facebook angry about the name change that people have started making groups angry about all the groups angry about the name change. That's how angry the internet is about the name change. How angry are you?

Personally, I think it's great. I mean, it's always been a giant willie, so now we can actually call it that.

Anyway, I think it's interesting that Sears never actually fully utilized the building, leaving it mostly vacant until the mid 90's, when it was sold it to somebody else. 'They're' also planning on painting it silver, which I suppose would make it much easier to keep cool.

The observation, or 'Sky-' deck opened in 1974, and it's on the 103rd floor of the building. I don't know who's office is in the 108th floor, but he's probably one of the coolest people in the world (let's face it, it's almost certainly not a woman). On a clear day, you can see Indiana from the Skydeck. The observation deck in the John Hancock building (which used to be the most phallic name for a building) is 323 feet lower. In January, 'they' opened up a few glass bottomed balconies which extend out of the Willis Tower, and give you the sensation that you're floating 103 stories up. They sound pretty awesome, and I will try to get some pictures of them in the next week or so.

It costs $14.95 for a regular adult ticket to the Skydeck. The deck is open every day from 9 AM to 10 PM. They probably start kicking people out at 9:50, because they're tired and want to go home. I presume that working at the top of Big Willie would diminish most of the novelty of the thing. I went to the Skydeck once with a school trip at night. It was pretty neat, but I bet on a clear day it would be even more neat.

But what about during a thunderstorm?

I've seen Big Willie completely cloaked in clouds before, and I'm sure when cloud cover is relatively low (in altitude, not quantity) the view isn't so great. It's probably still pretty interesting, but you probably can't even see the ground, let alone Indiana. If atmospheric conditions are just right, though, it certainly would be spectacular to see a thunderstorm from one of those little glass balconies. It seems like it would be quite a show, but it also seems like the sort of thing 'they' wouldn't let you do, for safety reasons.

My good friend Lili emailed one of 'them' and asked if the Skydeck was open during thunderstorms. Mirian Vasquez of Skydeck Chicago responded by saying, 'Thank you for your interest in the Skydeck. Guests are definitely allowed on the Skydeck during thunderstorms. The view might not be so great though, since storms bring thick, dark, clouds. I hope this answers your questions!'

Well, thank you, Mirian, that certainly does answer some questions. Apparently it is possible to see a thunderstorm from the top of the Sears Tower, with a few caveats. First, you can't go to the top of the tower, because the Skydeck is on the 103rd floor. Second, you might not actually see anything, because the tower could be engulfed in clouds. Third, you'll have to pay $15, and the thunderstorm will have to be before 10PM. Finally, you technically can't actually see a thunderstorm from the Sears Tower, because it has been renamed the Willis Tower.

Hopefully that sheds some light on the whole idea, and gives you some insight into what it might actually be like. Only time will tell for sure how well it will actually work out, though. I'll have to keep my eyes on the forecast. The skies are clear tonight, and for the near future, so we'll just have to wait for the next big storm . . .
