fields.title: An open letter to Visa and Chase Bank
fields.text:
Dear Visa and Chase Bank,

I recently made a purchase from a website called Newegg.com. You probably aren't really aware they exist, but they probably receive hundreds if not thousands of charges (from Visa cards) every day for sweet electronic and computer bits. I tried to be one of those lucky people this morning.

You see, I moved recently, and so I have a new computer desk. The keyboard shelf I am now using is slightly smaller than I would like. Because I have too much money as it is, I decided to go ahead and buy a new, shorter keyboard to give my mouse more room to move about on my desk. Newegg.com, being the best place to buy computer bits, was the perfect place to shop for a keyboard.

The internet is supposed to be a magical world where anything is possible, and anything you could possibly dream of can be right at 'your' fingertips (I put 'your' in quotes because I realize that I'm currently speaking to a corporate entity with no real individual identity, plus 'you' probably don't really have much desire for things like keyboards). As a young man in my early twenties, I have made hundreds, if not thousands, of purchases online for everything from sweet computer bits to train tickets to tonight's dinner. In fact, I have spent almost $8,000 on Newegg.com alone since June, 2004. I feel, as a young man in my early twenties, that the internet truly is 'my oyster' and there is nothing I cannot accomplish using this glorious series of tubes. In short, I am highly competent with exactly this sort of task.

At least, that's what I thought until I got a Visa Debit card from Chase Bank.

I realize that the presence of nefarious ne'er-do-wells presents the necessity for increased security and 'digital paranoia' (I just made that term up and I think it's pretty great). I acknowledge the concept that paying my bills online will forever be a painfully frustrating and bizarrely complicated process (I really don't care that much if someone wants to hack into my electricity account and pay my bill for me, but whatever). Paying bills is complicated, but it isn't impossible. I have to repeatedly check my email to recover passwords I only use once a month (at best), and answer security questions that I usually make fake answers to anyway. Eventually, the process is done, and my electricity remains on for another few weeks. Still, this process pales in comparison to the 'Verified by Visa' process that you subject your customers to.

Upon placing my order today (on a website upon which I have placed many orders in the past without problem), I was directed to a page with a little box on it.

I've seen the 'Verified by Visa' process before, so my heart sank as I realized this order wasn't going to be as easy as I was hoping (or as easy as the bike helmet I just bought from Amazon (hopefully you've heard of them) with the exact same card, which simply required me to pick a billing and shipping address). I tried a few passwords, trying to remember the one I would have created for myself on that mysterious day that I supposedly created a 'Verified by Visa' account. None of them worked. After a few failed attempts, you decided to stop letting me try.

It might be worth noting at this point that I have, as a matter of fact, never actually created a 'Verified by Visa' account. I know this because you eventually told me so. This makes it difficult to remember my password.

The (seemingly) handy link implying that I could generate a new password for myself served only to tell me that I didn't have an account, so I couldn't generate a new password. This is not the most helpful thing to read. It is, in fact, the type of thing that upon reading causes one's mind to turn quite quickly to thoughts of murder-suicide (preferably involving as many members of the Visa brain-trust as possible).

At this point, I knew that my only recourse was to call the phone number that was presented to me. All I wanted was my goddamn keyboard. I was not stealing anybody's identity, nor has anybody ever stolen mine, but I still had to be punished for it. Thank you, Visa, for having so much faith in your own system.

The automated compu-lady that greeted me on the phone offered no option to 'just order my goddamn keyboard' so I picked a few choices that sounded like they would get me to a human being as quickly as possible. I had to enter the last four digits of my card number, so I entered the last four digits of the debit card I was trying to place the order on (the card that sparked this whole debacle in the first place). Compu-lady explained that I was incorrect (she obviously knew more about the card I was looking at than I did). I guess she didn't care about my card anymore, because she asked for my zip code. I gave her the zip code for my address here in Chicago (the address I promptly changed all of my banking information to). Again, I was wrong. This electro-broad obviously knew much more about me than I did. I tried my old, Lafayette, zip code, and it appeared to satisfy the compu-lady's (misinformed) obsession with me. She then asked me for the last four digits of my social security number, which I entered without problem. We had finally agreed on something. Mechano-girl put me on hold.

I was, of course, repeatedly assured that the call would be monitored. I realize this is supposed to make me feel better, but it definitely does not. Why am I waiting for someone to pick up my call when you repeatedly tell me that someone else is already listening to me? I ended up on hold for over ten minutes, until someone (else) finally picked up.

'Welcome to Card Services, can I have your name, please?' the man asked.

'Shauvon McGill,' I replied. Asking my name is a simple identity verification. Nobody else could possibly know that information.

'Okay, Mr. McGill, how can I help you today?'

'I am trying to make an online purchase and I guess I don't know my password,' I told him.

'Okay, let me forward you to someone with online services.'.

I was placed back on hold. At this point, if anybody was, in fact, monitoring my call, they were subjected to a slurry of foul language. I am deeply sorry for any trouble I caused to your spy department having to listen to my uncontrollable, raging frustration. I regret that it was generally un-creative, too, so it wouldn't even have been that interesting to listen to.

Finally, a woman picked up.

'Welcome to Card Services, can I have your name, please?' the woman asked. Note that absolutely nothing was different between the first and second agents, other than the fact that the second one was a woman and the first was a man. Apparently one could help me and the other could not (although it turns out that neither could actually help me).

'Shauvon McGill,' I replied.

'Okay, Mr. McGill, how can I help you today?'

'I am trying to make an online purchase and I guess I don't know my password,' I told her, through gritted teeth.

'Okay, I can help you with that. Let me just pull up your information.' This surprised me. Up to this point, the only information she would have had was the (wrong) zip code that compu-lady got from me, the last four digits of my social security number, and my name, which I'm sure they would not be able to spell without thorough coaching.

'Is this for the card ending in XXXX?' She asked. It was not, actually.

'It's not, actually,' I replied. Perhaps we had reached the source of the problem.

'Are you trying to use your Chase Visa Credit Card?' she asked.

'It's my Chase Visa Debit Card.'

It turns out that I was talking to the 'Credit Card Services' department, and that it was the entirely wrong department to talk to about my debit card. I told her that this was silly (which was not exactly the word I used, to be honest), because this was the number I was directed to call after using this very debit card. I would have to use my Chase Visa Credit Card to set up a 'Verified by Visa' account, and the human-lady directed me to 'verifiedbyvisa.com' where I could set up a new account (by the way, this would have been a great piece of advice to give me from the very beginning, instead of a 'generate new password' link which didn't actually do anything). For some reason, the Verified by Visa website wouldn't open, because nothing ever works right when I try to use it, so I couldn't set up a new account. The human-lady offered to redirect me to technical support, and I told her I just wanted my goddamn keyboard.

I was so frustrated at this point that I told the agent I was just going to forget the whole thing and do something else (such as buy a keyboard from Amazon). I apologized for the language I used and acknowledged that none of this was her fault, and then I hung up. I clicked the 'cancel' link on the 'Verified by Visa' password box, and I was redirected back to Newegg.com's checkout process. Then I was rather surprised.

I was surprised, you see, because I was looking at an order confirmation. I had to check my order history to be sure, and make sure I had gotten a confirmation email from Newegg, but it was true. My order was completed successfully. In spite of not being 'Verified by Visa,' it was successfully charged anyway. 'Oh,' I thought, 'well, whatever.' I had finally ordered my goddamn keyboard.

I hope at this point you have noticed some glaring problems with your entire process, but just to be clear, let's go over a few points. First, you sent me on a perilous quest to have control of my own money based on a credit card that I wasn't even using. You see, I wanted to just order this goddamn keyboard with the money in my checking account, which is curiously why I decided to use my debit card instead of my credit card. You decided that I was using my credit card anyway. This is why I didn't actually have an account, and I was therefore unable to actually 'verify by Visa.' I would hope, as one of the most powerful money laundering corporations in the world, you understand the difference between 'credit' and 'debit.' Perhaps you should take a look at an economics textbook (which, incidentally, Amazon recommends that I buy because I bought one once).

Second, the phone number you told me to call was just a general account information number, not in any way designed to assist me with 'Verified by Visa.' I was forced to have someone manually redirect me to where I needed to go (which was not actually where I needed to go). Perhaps if you had electro-broad simply explain that anyone having difficulty with 'Verified by Visa' was probably best off just placing their order through paypal (or switching to Master Card), you could alleviate much of your call congestion.

Third, even though you seem to be in pretty serious 'cahoots' with Chase bank, you don't seem to have gotten the memo that I have changed my billing address zip code. Secure systems don't work if you don't actually update them when I change my information. It isn't identity theft if I know more about my life than you do, Visa.

Finally, probably the biggest problem with this system is the fact that after I failed to log in and was locked out of my (non-existent) 'verified by Visa' account, the order still went through without a problem. If I were, in fact, some nefarious ne'er-do-well who had stolen some poor dude's debit (not credit) card so that I could buy keyboards on the internet, I would have easily accomplished that goal, and I wouldn't even have needed to verify My Own Name to do so.

Visa and Chase Bank, you obviously are trying to ensure my safety online. I understand that. I appreciate your efforts, but I also laugh at them. You are, frankly, doing a terrible job. I suspect that this is part of a larger conspiracy to convince people to continue to shop in real stores instead of buying goods online, and that idea scares me. I feel more secure with my Facebook account than I do with my debit card. This is simply a travesty, and it is so much a travesty that I felt the necessity to write this open letter to you immediately. Put simply, you are ruining the world. Please make an effort to allow me to control where my own money goes, and don't punish me for trying to do so. I assure you, I know what I'm doing, and if I can't figure it out, someone who isn't between the ages of 18 and 25 will never have a chance. After this, I completely understand how our economy has gotten to where it is. Visa and Chase Bank, you are to blame. I wish I didn't despise the way our society works just a little bit more each and every time I make a purchase.

I just wanted a goddamn keyboard.

Sincerely,

Shauvon G. (I know my middle initial, too!) McGill, Consumer

fields.title: Lost Job
fields.text:
Dear friends and family of DenyConformity.com,

I found out today that the company I work for, Tiger Team Solutions, is being shut down. The state of the Economy has finally made its way into the digital realm, and there simply aren't enough clients around to sustain a company, even one with as little overhead as Tiger Team. I feel deeply, truly sorry for my boss, John Powers, because I'm sure this is an extremely stressful and difficult situation for him. I hope that your thoughts, and your prayers (if you are so inclined) will go out to him and his wife in the coming months.

This also, as you have probably assumed, puts me out of a job. I am trying to see this as an opportunity, not a curse. I will have some time to finish my latest project, a screenplay about a new college graduate who is looking for a job in Chicago (it's a creative stretch, I know). I am hoping that I can find a new job in the next two weeks.

I have often wondered what I would do if I lost my job. I think it's an interesting thing to think about sometimes, like what you would do if you were mugged, or how you would survive a zombie invasion, or what you would say if you were the guest on an episode of Top Gear. I know how much money I need to have each month to survive, so I can estimate how long I can last without an income before I am completely 'brokd.' I feel I can last a little while under my current situation (although my current situation is not without turmoil, which I will be sure to explain when it all blows over). This will, at the very least, help me understand what it is to be an adult.

How long could you last if you lost your job? How much money would you have to save to extend that? These are questions you might want to consider, in case you end up in a situation similar to mine. I will be sure to keep you all updated on my progress, and let you know what the job scene is like in the big 'shy-town.'

In the mean time, if anybody out there knows of any freelance web design, photography, music production, graphic design, programming, videography, video post-production, or writing jobs out there, let me know. I've got some time on my hands.

And if you see me, remind me that life is actually worth it some times.

Thanks, everybody, for your support (that I'm assuming you're going to give me).

-Shauvon McGill

fields.title: Overwhelmed
fields.text:
'When Marco Polo came at last to Cathay, seven hundred years ago, did he not feel - and did his heart not falter as he realized - that this great and splendid capital of an empire had had its being all the years of his life and far longer, and that he had been ignorant of it? That it was in need of nothing from him, from Venice, from Europe? That it was full of wonders beyond his understanding? That his arrival was a matter of no importance whatever? We know that he felt these things, and so has any a traveler in foreign parts who did not know what he was going to find. There is nothing that cuts you down to size like coming to some strange and marvelous place where no one even stops to notice that you stare about you.'

-Watership Down

fields.title: New Decade
fields.text:
People are throwing around the idea that 2010 is an entirely new decade. This is justifiable. The number 10 has an extra digit, which means it's not the same as 9. However, another (smaller) group of people claim that 2010 is not the first year of a new decade, but actually the last year of the last (current) one. They claim that there was no 'Year Zero' so the decade starts with one instead of zero.

Those people are wrong.

For a time I agreed that 10 is the last number of the 'ones,' and not the first number of the 'teens.' This is true, because you don't start counting with zero. However, time doesn't work that way. There was, in fact, a year zero.

Consider the following example: when you were born, how old were you? You were not one, you were zero. You had completed zero years of life. On your first birthday, you turn one, which means that you have completed one year of life. However, you are not in the first year of your life, are you? You are in the second year of your life. When you turn ten, you are not entering your tenth year, you are entering your eleventh. When you turn ten, you've entered the second decade of your life.

So the debate becomes not what year this is, but when we started counting. Did year one start at the beginning of time, or at the end of the first year of the modern calendar?

Theoretically, the calendar is based on the birth of Jesus Christ (who's birthday was about a week ago). If that is the case, year one should coincide with Jesus' first birthday, which marks not the beginning of the first year, but the end of the first year. That would make this the end of the 2010th year, and the beginning of the 2011th, or the beginning of the next decade.

One major problem is that the people who invented the modern 12-month, 365-day (give or take) calendar, were morons. They didn't understand the concept of zero, so the first year of the calendar is 1, and the year before that was 1 B.C (or negative-one).

We currently use the Gregorian Calendar, which was an improvement of the Julian Calendar, which was just thought up by some dudes who were bored because nobody had invented video games yet. The problem is that these calendars mainly just describe what a year is, when leap-years are, how many months there are, and other things important to your bank and electric company. However, they kind of gloss over when it all starts.

You can't just go from Year Negative-One to Year One. That's stupid. If the negative years are in fact 'Before Christ' there would have to be a year that was Zero Years Before Christ. From the day before He was born to 365 days before He was born, no years had passed. Those 365 days were 0 B.C. Nobody stopped to think about that, though, because in the 1500's when the Gregorian Calendar was thought up, they were too busy going on Crusades, dying of the Plague, and other things that killed off anybody who questioned the Pope.

Astronomers, on the other hand, do recognize a year zero. In case you were wondering, astronomers are scientists who spend their entire lives studying the motions and natures of the entire goddamn universe. I'm somewhat inclined to believe scientists over old dudes who sit around all day telling ghost stories. We don't need to get into a theological debate, however, because that's neither here nor there. Years have to start somewhere, so why not make it an arbitrary dude's birth way back a long time ago?

That's where it gets muddy. You see, it's not really based on anything, when you get down to it. Yes, this is 2010, which is two-thousand ten years from something, presumably something that happened two-thousand ten years ago. But the thing is that that something was two-thousand ten years from something else, which was also probably pretty interesting, involving cavemen riding dinosaurs and Brad Pitt beating the crap out of Eric Bana or something. It's all arbitrary and ultimately completely meaningless. The current year certainly hasn't measured the entire course of human history, which I think would be a much better scale. What if we could say that it was exactly 12,010 years since Grugg first picked up a big piece of wood, bashed it against Brugg, and then stole his wife, thereby setting a benchmark for all Human Progress from then on? That would be much cooler. Imagine how much we've done since that fateful day in Mr. and Mrs. Brugg's cave? It means as much as anything else.

It's only 2010 because that's what we call it. It's only 1459 in the Armenian calendar. It's 2960 in the Berber calendar, which sounds way cooler than boring ol' Twenty-Ten. The Byzantine calendar puts us in years 7518 and 7519. These are all just numbers. Random numbers that groups of people have been counting ever since the point that they . . . started counting.

The point is that this is the start of a new decade, because it has been ten years from something. Who cares if it's one or zero, or two-thousand ten, or seven thousand five hundred eighteen? We have so few opportunities to celebrate something that marks our progress and achievement as a species that doesn't involve having murdered someone or coming up with a great new way to sell advertising space. Let's just take this one, because it is a big deal. It's a chance to move on from the (myriad) mistakes of the last ten years, and start with a proverbial 'clean slate.' We need that every once in a while. In fact, if you celebrated the new Millennium in 2000 (like a normal person), then it has been exactly ten years, so for you it is a whole new decade, no matter what anybody says.

And another thing: people who talk about how this isn't a new decade and who still argue that the new Millennium started in 2001 are a bunch of dwonks. They're mostly the same people who use 'win' as a noun (the wrong way) and think cats with zany captions are the greatest thing they've seen since their mom reupholstered their basement/bedroom. Don't listen to them. They just want you to join their World of Warcraft guild or trade some Pokeman cards with them or something.

So wear your head high, noble human. You're living in a whole new year, a whole new decade, and a whole new life! You have nothing but opportunities ahead of you, a brand new pair of socks or whatever type of clothing your parents got you for Christmas. You may have made some mistakes in the last decade, started a few wars, messed up your economy (which for that matter is also just a bunch of numbers you made up), and gave way too much attention to Paris Hilton, but none of that matters now! You're a new man (or hu-man), a fresh canvas. Sure, you've got that weird rash and a cirrhotic liver, but who cares! Life is your oyster!

Celebrate the new decade with pride, noble human, and next time someone tries to tell you you're wrong, just remind them that we're not in 2010 at all, we're actually somewhere between 1,262,304,000 and 1,293,839,999 (the Unix time codes spanning the next 365 days). After all, that's the only time that will really matter when the machines take over.

Oh, and that's not even getting into all that Mayan calendar malarky that my Mom has repeatedly gone on long rants about. Talk about complicated . . .

fields.title: Antivirus
fields.text:
I don't make many posts on here about computer stuff, and I feel like I should have more. I've spent a great deal of time thinking about computers, I have tons of experience working on computers, and I have two computers of my very own. I think I probably have a lot to say that would at the least give you something to think or talk about, and might even improve your life.

Well, this is a post about computer stuff.

I use Windows on my computers, for numerous reasons which would be the subject of an entirely different post (or several). Although Windows became more secure all the time as we went through the last decade, and I have always been a very safe and responsible computer user, it is still a good idea to use additional security on my system. Apple Computer Company wants you to think that by just turning on a Windows computer without an antivirus program you will soon die of H1N1. This is not remotely true. Especially with Windows 7 (possibly the greatest computer operating system ever made), you can safely connect your computer to the internet (through a firewall-equipped router, of course) without an antivirus and you will be fine. Just don't be a knucklehead about it. Don't go to shady websites, do use Firefox with Adblock Plus, don't install anything (anything) unless it's from a trusted source and you know exactly what it is, and do be careful with spam emails. Do these things, and you can live virus and spyware free (most likely, anyway).

Should you get that handy registry-fixer program you found on download.com? No. How about Super PC Cleaner 2.0? Absolutely not! If you're not sure what it is, don't install it. Really, if you're not a 'power user' and it isn't the Firefox installer (downloaded directly from Mozilla.com), don't download it. You don't need special utilities to keep Windows running properly, especially if you have Vista or 7. You don't need that zany screensaver. You don't need that goofy theme that makes the mouse cursor into a little dancing penguin. Just don't do it.

What you do need is an antivirus program. Ok, so you don't really need one, sure, but if you're not a genius like me, it's probably a good idea. The problem is that companies like Symantec and McAfee want you to pay them tons of money (rather frequently, if they have their way) to use their products. You shouldn't have to spend tons of money for something you shouldn't ever need. Luckily, you don't have to, because free options are available.

I've used free antiviruses off and on for years. Purdue offered a free version of McAfee to Purdue students, and I used it some. McAfee sucks, though. You could try a program called AVG Antivirus, which is offered in a stripped-down free version. It works ok, but it gets rather obnoxious about telling you that you can give them money for a copy of the program you're already using. Another option is Avast! Antivirus, which wins the prize for most exciting name for what is ultimately an extremely boring product. I've noticed that Avast! uses an unnecessary amount of system resources and frankly does too much. For spyware protection, you have programs like AdAware, which only runs when you ask it to. Having a scanner like that 'on call' is good and bad, but it still isn't really an antivirus so whatever. There just isn't a good solution, anymore. I began to think that perhaps the ship had sailed, and just like the dream of being able to say things on Twitter and Facebook without my parents seeing it, the dream of a free antivirus was dead.

Then I found the solution, and - here's the kicker - it was made by Microsoft.

Welcome back. I hope you didn't hit your head when you passed out. Yes, I know it's crazy news to hear that not only has Microsoft (a multi-billion dollar corporation) made an operating system that works fine without having to install any free utilities advertised by banner ads on your favorite porn websites, but they have also created a pretty good antivirus for it. You see, Microsoft is not the same Microsoft that we all loved to hate last decade. They actually asked people how Windows 7 was before they released it, and now they're actually protecting it from all those viruses Apple wants you to think are out there. That's what a company does that actually cares.

It's called Microsoft Security Essentials, and it's available for XP, Vista, and 7, in both 32 and 64 bit versions. You can download it on this page. Before you install it, you should (this is important) shut down and remove all antiviri and anti-spyware programs currently installed on your computer (including stuff like Adaware). Then you can install MSE, and be prepared to let it download an update and run a scan as soon as it's done installing. The whole process is pretty quick, as antivirussies go. Like other antivirals, it will run in the background, but unlike most antivirucities, it doesn't take up a lot of your precious RAM.

The problem with Antiviroose is that while they're running, they take up so many resources they cause problems for everything else you're trying to do. You're supposed to turn them off when you install anything, they can cause problems in games and other intensive applications, and there are tons of compatibility issues with other programs. The cure is as bad as the disease. With MSE, however, you don't really have to worry about it as much. It's light, so it won't slow your computer down. I haven't noticed any problems with other applications, and it's getting good marks online. It's still pretty new, so compatibility issues and other problems could crop up, so don't expect it to be perfect right away. Since it's made by Microsoft, it should run pretty nicely with Windows, though. All in all, it's a great piece of kit, and the best part is that it's free.

Now, I don't know if I would recommend that you dump your current antivirus at your business and dive right in to MSE. It's still new, so you never know what problems might crop up. It might not quite be ready for full-scale deployment to systems that are important for your small business. It's no problem for your home computer, though, so I do recommend that you get it running as soon as possible. On the web page linked above is a link to the new Forefront Client Security, which is some kind of antivirus solution for business computers. It's essentially the same thing as MSE, but it can be run and managed on networked computers from a central location, like a server, which makes it great for businesses. It seems to still be in Beta, though, which means it's not necessarily finished yet. Consider it 'use at your own risk.'

The real question here is why they didn't include Security Essentials as part of Windows 7 in the first place. Maybe they did; I'm still using the Release Candidate because I'm too lazy to install the actual product (I do have it, though). If that's the case, then it's super awesome. However, I don't think that's the case, and I have a theory as to why. It probably wasn't ready to be deployed yet, so they didn't want to include an unfinished antivirus in Windows 7. More importantly, however, I don't think it would be taken seriously if it were. Most of the point of an antivirus, frankly, is to make you less afraid of all of the viruses Apple keeps telling you about. Since people seem to be very weary of utilities included in Windows, it could be that nobody would trust an antivirus that they didn't install themselves. People need to go through the process of installing an antivirus, to feel like they're really doing something about that damn techno-flu. That's why, I think, Microsoft won't just include an antivirus as part of Windows for a long time.

Believe it or not, computers need placebos, too.

fields.title: Ikea
fields.text:
I went to the Ikea store a while ago. It was right after I lost my job. It was kind of a wonderland of expensive things I couldn't afford. It's truly a bizarre place that you must see to believe. You should go to one, because it's a crazy experience.

Anyway, I took some pictures with my cellphone telephone way back then and just found them. I'll show them to you now.

See the pictures

Three giant cork board things were left overs from the Meisner collection (where I used to live before where I used to live), and they served as giant coasters at Party Central (where I used to live). I never knew what they were, but at the Ikea store I found out. They're Heat Trivets.

This midieval torture machine was constantly pushing into the chair, proving how durable that Swedish particle board is. I wonder how they test the durability of the durability testing robot.

They have all kinds of different shelves at Ikea, but I couldn't find the price tag for the shelves the shelves were on.

I love KILBY, but I'm not in love with KILBY. Not like that BILLY; that's one quality bookshelf.

Cardboard VCR replicas are not as obsolete as their plastic and silicon counterparts. It's good to know the Swedish take VCRs into account when they design their shelves.

Yup. Just sitting there. It was real.

Somebody took a bite out of my spoon - I mean DELIKAT.

I've irresponsibly driven a lot of carts around stores, but never have I irresponsibly driven one as awesome as this one. It was so smooth and balanced, and the back wheels swiveled instead of the front ones, so you could do super sweet powerslides between the aisles.

Well that's all. Go there and see what crazy things you can find.

fields.title: Avatar
fields.text:
I've been unemployed now for a couple months, and I'm starting to get bored. I figured I would take some time talk about Avatar, the big blockbuster from James Cameron. If you haven't heard about this film, then you probably have much more important things to worry about, like whatever creatures are trying to also live in your cave with you, or when the Child Fund is going to give you today's cup of coffee so you can go to school or whatever. If you don't live in a cave or in some third world country, then you've probably heard a lot about this film, and maybe even more about how bad it might be. Allow me to give a counter point.

Now, asking you to care what I think is as wrong as blindly agreeing with what everybody else has to say. You should still read my argument, though, because I think it's important in this world.

Read my thoughts.

Avatar followed the regular lifestyle of a major, supposedly game changing, blockbuster film. It took much longer to make than a normal film, had an army of designers large enough to invade Poland, and cost more money than God. The hype was insurmountable in the weeks before it came out, it made more money than any other movie that came out in the same year (even though it came out only a few weeks before the year ended), and then after about a week everybody started talking about how bad it was. This is the standard path of a major motion picture.

So here we are, long enough after the movie's release that everybody's either seen it or doesn't want to (or lives for less than a cup of coffee a day). People are starting to talk about how bad it was, saying it was just like Pocahontas or whatever. The plot was cliche, the characters flat and predictable, or the special effects were mediocre. The hyper-critical public internet opinion machine has said its piece, and that's all anybody needs to know.

Perhaps it's just because I'm insane (or my 'Deny Conformity' nature), but the more I hear people talk about how bad it was, the more I want to like it. Before I saw it I was fully prepared to be incredibly annoyed by Avatar when I went to see it. I wasn't even that interested in seeing it. It seemed to me like a totally cliche and predictable futuristic Black Hawk Down. Still, when you hear things like 'changes film forever' you kind of have to see what they mean. So I saw it.

I was wrong, and so are you, if you say it was bad.

At some point in the film, I realized why I was annoyed by it. It occurred to me that Avatar isn't a film at all. It's a masterpiece. I'm not saying that like, 'it wasn't good . . . it was great!' I just mean that it was a feat beyond a normal film. It was an achievement that we've never seen before, and will never see again.

Cameron first wrote a treatment for Avatar in 1994. That was fifteen years ago. He originally thought up the basic elements of what became Avatar's alien race in a film he wrote in 1976, over thirty years ago. He pretty much made Titanic so he could work on this movie. He invented technology to make movies in 3d for this movie. He waited for fifteen years for technology to be able to do what he wanted it to do. Did you notice how he never really did anything since Titanic came out in 1997? That's because he was working on this goddamn movie. I think that much devotion and determination from the highest grossing director ever deserves at least a little respect.

I want you to put the plot and the characters and even the special effects aside for a moment. Think about what was done for Avatar. They invented an entire language just for this movie. That's never been done before. They developed an entire culture and society based around an entire made-up planet full of thousands of made-up species of plant and animal life. This isn't just regular sci-fi design where some artists sit around and say, 'hey, this looks cool.' A team of designers and actual, factual scientists discussed the biology of the entire planet. They designed things based on how animals would have evolved there. They spent years developing not just some cool looking creatures, but the entire ecosystem that supports them. The virtual designs and assets for Pandora filled over a petabyte of storage. That's one million gigabytes! All that is on top of the usual futuristic human spaceships, weapons, and other technology that you'd find in a sci-fi movie. They invented an entire goddamn planet from scratch, and you're complaining that the characters are a little flat?

Now, how about the technical achievements in Avatar? You know how a bunch of movies have been coming out in 3D lately? That's pretty much James Cameron's doing. He made the first modern polarized 3D film in 2003, and he didn't do it just to play around with new technology. He did it for Avatar. He let it soak in, and waited for the novelty to wear off, so we were used to it and comfortable with it before he made his opus. He waited for us to get over that whole 'hey look it's 3D' bullshit where stuff flies right at the screen just to freak people out. You'll find none of that in Avatar. Like everything else, 3D is just part of the world, not a gimmick. It is part of the world, too. I thought it was a little weird that the photographs on a wall at one point were in 3D with everything else, until I realized that it's the future, and they simply have 3D photographs.

They also invented a new way to do motion capture for this thing. I've dabbled in animation enough to know that the animation for the completely computer generated alien creatures was phenomenal. Cameron strapped cameras to the actors' faces so that the animators could capture every single nuance in the actors' expressions. Really, the amount of work that went into just the animation on every single frame of this movie is staggering. It challenges everything ever animated before, honestly.

Just look at the number of people involved with this movie. Pictured to the right is a comparison of the 'visual effects by' lists on IMDB of Transformers (on the left) and Avatar (on the right). Transformers was no slouch when it came to visual effects, and it certainly busted a few blocks back in its day, but just look at the difference. The number of people under 'visual effects by' on IMDB for Avatar is almost three times the number of people listed for Transformers. That's ridiculous.

Just think about this: for the first time (and maybe only time) ever, both Weta Digital (Lord of the Rings and District 9) and ILM (Star Wars, Transformers, and Pirates of the Caribbean) worked on the same film. That's how complicated Avatar was to make. The two largest special effects houses on the planet were both required to pull it off.

Most of this movie, predictably, was shot on a sound stage entirely painted green. As most people know, special effects shots are done in front of a green screen, because they can easily cut out the green background and replace it with whatever they want to replace it with. Normally this means that while shooting the movie everybody just has to imagine what's going on around them, since all they can actually see is green walls and some camera equipment. That was not the case with Avatar. Cameron had a system where he could actually see everything he wanted to see in the shot, as they were shooting it, like a giant (planet sized) video game level. He could move around in the world as easily as he could walk around a real set, and do whatever he wanted with shots on the fly. That's a big deal, especially for actors who are sick of pretending that giant green cylinders are some kind of monster thing so much that they're developing an irrational hatred for the color. Of anything developed for Avatar, this is most likely to change the way movies are made from now on, and it's the kind of innovation that most of the base plebeians on the internet (the kind who say that this is still last decade) will never know or care about.

Just think about how much work went into Avatar, especially compared to other films. A regular film, especially one with a lot of special effects, is a monumental undertaking. I've made movies that are only seven minutes long and they've almost killed me. The work required for a feature-length film is insane, for hundreds, if not thousands, of people. Avatar was at least three times that much effort, and took at least ten times as long. You're willing to just shrug that off because the plot was a little cliche?

But yes, how about that plot, then? Yes, you're all right, it does seem to draw heavily on Disney's Pocahontas. The thing is, do you know what other movie drew heavily from the story of Pocahontas? Disney's goddamn Pocahontas. It's not like they wrote the story. It's a classic tale from American mythology. Plenty of movies take inspiration from mythology, and they're lauded. Avatar does it and it's a rip off? That's not fair.

Discrediting a film because its plot is cliche is like discrediting Picasso for using paint brushes. There are only so many ways you can tell a story. That's just the truth. You can go buy one of a hundred books listing the thirty six dramatic situations you can use in a story. You probably shouldn't, though, because you're going to see a lot of stuff that's been done in movies before. After the ten billion or so movies people have made, it's very hard to make one that doesn't have something somebody else already thought of. So why not embrace that? Cameron, I think, uses cliche. He uses it like an artists uses any of his tools. Why waste time going out of your way to explain something when you can just make it something we're already familiar with, and move on?

Face it, you didn't go to see that movie expecting goddamn Shakespeare. You weren't hoping for a brilliant plot or the most amazing character development you've ever seen. You went there wanting to watch some giant blue aliens fight big ass robots in 3D, and that's the truth. Cameron wanted to show us this world he created. He wasn't trying to create some sort of high literature. He just wanted to show us some giant blue aliens fighting big ass robots. Why do you expect more than that?

Does anybody hate on Terminator because the Terminator's character isn't developed that well? No, Terminator was awesome because it was about a sweet killer robot, and that's what it delivered.

If you look past the cliche and simplicity of the central plot (you could even call it 'elegant simplicity'), you might actually see some interesting themes. Cameron does a lot of exploration of duality, and I think the idea of someone needing an 'avatar' to find their place in a world is none too relevant in this increasingly internet-centered society. He delivers an poignant message about humanity's increasingly destructive path on its obsession for 'unobtanium,' a blatant symbol for our out-of-control desire for things that we can't have, and that part of us that can never be satisfied. Having that simple, basic concept of 'unobtanium' is a perfect example. It's perhaps cliche and unrealistic, but you immediately understand the point. It's the perfect, irresistible prize that's just on the other side of the line between good and evil.

The plot of Avatar is hardly the point at all. In a way, the done-before and cliche nature of the plot is in itself an example of one of the film's most important themes, the dangers of insatiable desire, and finding peace in simplicity.

Still, I truly believe that it is inconsequential whether or not the movie is good. Avatar's quality is irrelevant. What matters is that Avatar stands as a monument of what a human being is capable of. It is the ultimate work of James Cameron's life, and it is his opus. Avatar is Beethoven's 9th symphony. It is Michelangelo's David. It is Cameron's masterpiece, and that just doesn't happen anymore. In a world where all we care about is how much money we can make (the ultimate unobtanium), it seems like nobody cares anymore about what we can actually do.

That's why you should watch Avatar, and why it deserves your respect.

As with all major, supposedly game changing, blockbuster films, Avatar will eventually find its place in the annals of history. Eventually I think people will, at least subconscious, think of it as a benchmark for all films to come. I think Avatar might even get the consideration it deserves, long from now, when seen with the calm, malevolent eyes of hindsight. I wonder if anybody said that the Mona Lisa was a little simple and boring when it was first made.


On the other hand, all of the subtitles (and the movie posters) are in Papyrus, the second worst font on the planet. So yeah, screw that movie.

fields.title: My Colossal Job
fields.text:
I got a job last week.

It's pretty cool, too. I'm working for a medium-sized web design company called Colossal Squid. Its a really dynamic and hard-working team, and I'm both excited and terrified (good terrified) to be working there. This is the first time I've worked with a team of dudes who are really awesome and who know exactly what I do and what they need me for. My last few positions have been more general, less hardcore, and I am nervous about the fact that this team is going to want my absolute best. I think I might just be up for the task.

Today was my first day. Of course, I didn't have much actual work to do today, and what they gave me to do was pretty basic. Today I had to create an e-mail newsletter from a Photoshop mock-up. If you know anything about web design, you probably know that e-mail clients can't really support any major styling, so you have to make them with a bunch of images and tables (as opposed to using more modern CSS with background images). If you know anything about web design, you know that making entire web pages with HTML tables is a terrible thing for all parties. However, it is what must be done, and if this is what they need me to do, I will do it.

This is my first real job, if you want to get down to it. My actual first full time job out of college was working from home, so that doesn't really count. After working from home for about six months, and then being unemployed for another three, I'm not used to a normal job. For Colossal Squid, I will actually have to put on pants, take a bus to an office building (in the west loop), sit at a desk for nine hours a day, and interact with real human beings. I hope I haven't forgotten how to do all of those things. I am most worried about my roommate's cat, Alice. Without me around all day, she will have nobody to beg for her dinner for the hour or so before Sarah gets home.

Strangely, the idea of spending most of my days at work is very liberating. When I had all of my time to myself, I felt so useless if I didn't spend every single moment working on a screenplay, or this website, or writing something, or doing photography, or working on music, or looking for a job, or whatever. Now that I have something I have to do all the time, it's no longer my fault that I don't get all these crazy schemes done. I might keep some of these ideas on the backburner, though. I mean, a pizza place that specializes in double-decker pizzas? How can that fail?!

A half-hour commute means an extra hour every day that I have to just sit quietly and do nothing. I will have to think of interesting ways to occupy myself (like how I'm doing right now, because I'm writing this on my way home from work). Maybe I will take up knitting, or I will practice being a DJ on the bus, or take up live-blogging, or solicit, or buy a car.

Getting a job is like getting a girlfriend. For a while, you spend a few months sitting on the couch in your underwear, eating ice cream and watching reruns of old TV shows, thinking that you're totally useless and you'll never find another one like the one you just lost. Then you slowly get over yourself, and you start to go out a little, talking to some people and getting your name out there. You give out your resume (or your phone number) to hundreds of people, and you may even hear back from one or two. You can always try to go online, which could theoretically save you a lot of time and effort, but you'll mainly only hear from weirdos and creeps who want you to do some kind of porn.

Once you find somebody you really like, the courtship begins. You'll meet up, maybe for lunch or drinks, and get to know each other a little bit. You put on your best tie and present yourself as best you can (even throwing out some smart-sounding buzz words from your field or profession), so that they think you're totally classy and intelligent all the time. If you're really lucky, they'll ask to see you again. Maybe they will show you some of their friends, so you'll see the people you'll have to hang out with if it all goes well. Of course, if it does go well, you can count on losing most of your free time because they're going to want you around pretty much all the time.

There's a bit of a learning curve, as you figure out just how they like to do things. They might make it seem like you're free to do your own thing, but you just keep your head down and do what they tell you. Let's face it, you're really only in it for that big event every couple weeks (you know, the paycheck).

I would keep this whole analogy going, but frankly I haven't really gotten that serious with a girl or a job, so I would only be making stuff up.

It's going to take some time to get used to the whole 'being employed' thing, but hopefully it will be as easy as what I've been used to, which is 'being a loser.'

fields.title: Web server 1
fields.text:
For the past few years, summer has always brought with it a bit of a windfall for me. My expenses stayed the same as the semester ended, but I suddenly had much more time to work, resulting in my income going up substantially. The sudden influx of cash always left as quickly as it came, as I used it not to invest or save (as a reasonable person would do) but to fuel one of my favorite hobbies, rebuilding my computer.

The months of April and May usually see me exploring the virtual aisles of Newegg.com, which most people would recognize as the best place for people who consider pictures of motherboards almost like pornography. Again and again I would check various components, judging which would be the best option for my new super-machine. Each year the shiny new bits would come usually on the same day, and usually in one big, glorious box. My former roommate John and I would come to call these events 'Mini-Christmas.' My credit card company would come to call them 'flag for potential identity theft.'

It would seem that this year the trend continues, as I find myself pouring over Newegg shopping carts once again. This year is different, though. My computer bits just aren't old enough yet to justify dropping a bunch of cash to upgrade. This year I'm building something that will actually be useful and might actually improve my life.

This year, I'm building a web server.

I have simply had it with my current host (Startlogic) and their continual outages, bouts of slowness, and their inexplicable need to constantly change my ftp address. The time has come to throw off the shackles of my web host and take my tiny little media empire into my own hands.

This certainly won't be easy, mind you. I'll have to negotiate with my ISP, RCN (this series is going to have a lot of acronyms) about the increased throughput on my connection, and about giving me my own static IP address. I will need to get Linux up and running on the new machine, complete with Apache, numerous MySQL databases and an email server. I will need to reconfigure my various domains to point to the new server. On top of all of this, I need to finally finish that sweet new design for DenyConformity.com.

Will I succeed? Will my obsession with using Gentoo Linux melt my waxen wings? Will RCN even allow me to run a web server from home without charging me ridiculous amounts of money? Will a home-built, entry-level PC suffice for the virtually ones of hits I receive every day? What other unforseen difficulties will pop up, threatening to ruin the entire project? Will I ever get around to doing it, or am I just going to keep talking about it all the time?

The answers to these (and more) questions will come in the next few months. Stay tuned for the continuing adventures of . . .

fields.title: Web server pt. 2
fields.text:
I've been working a lot, and Left 4 Dead 2 has burned through what little free time I've had, so I haven't had much time to make any progress on this summer's project,

So, step 1 of the process is to get things cleared with my internet provider, RCN. As far as I know, RCN stands for Really . . . Crappy . . . well, yeah I have no idea what RCN stands for. I do know that they have pretty poor customer service, though. I'm currently installing Microsoft Visual Studio for a project at work which is on a .NET environment, so I had a few hours to kill. I decided to give RCN a ring. After navigating a maze of 'push X for X' options, I finally got a human (supposedly) voice. She, of course, had no idea what a web server was, so I decided to make things easier and just ask for a static IP address.

Ok, so here's your first lesson about the internets. As we all know, the internet is supposedly this vast series of tubes connecting billions of perverts with each other around the world. Actually, though, the internet is more like a vast card catalog, arranged not by some sort of Dewey Decimal or category, but by address. Since the internet operates on a specific protocol (called the Internet Protocol), every single computer (or computer network) has its own unique IP address. Yes, you, right now, looking at this website, have an IP address, even if you're connected via Cellphone Telephone, Dial-up (hi Mom), or the world's fastest fiber optic connection. That IP address is sort of like your computer's phone number, or to put it in a much more literal way, your computer's address.

Websites are just cards in this giant card catalog, and all you have to do to access them is call up that IP address. Websites are stored on computers all over the world (even giant mega-servers are just computers), and those computers (or Web Servers) have a specific IP address that applies only to them. So, to access a web server and load the website contained within, all you have to do is navigate to that server's IP address over the HyperText Transfer Protocol (that's what that little HTTP:// means). We don't need to get into specifics about what the HTTP actually is, but basically it just tells your computer how to communicate properly with the IP address it is accessing.

Here's an example (just a little sample). Google is a pretty popular website. If you don't know what Google is, then I urge you to spend a little more time acclimating yourself with our time period before you dive into the ins and outs of the internet. Also, I would like to borrow your time machine. Anyway, Google runs on a computer, just like the computer you're staring at right now. Sure, Google's servers have storage and computational ability lightyears beyond the computer you're looking at (probably), but in essence they are the same. Primarily, Google's server connects to the same internet you're connected to, and they have an IP address just like you. Google's IP address is 209.85.135.104. Just four simple numbers. Instead of typing 'www.google.com' into your browser's address bar, you can type 'http://209.85.135.104/' and you'll get the exact same thing. Kind of neat.

So why don't we see more IP addresses in our daily, internet drenched lives? It is because of another nifty little acronym, DNS. DNS stands for 'Domain Name System' and it is a universal system for providing shortcuts to the cards in that giant card catalog. Just check out the Wikipedia page for DNS if you're really interested. Basically, when you type in a domain name (google.com, for instance), your computer accesses a special server called a Name Server, which tells your computer what IP address is associated with that domain name. Your browser then figures out the IP address and usually a subdirectory (sometimes a single server can host multiple websites, so one IP address will have several domains associated with it) and then it calls up that address. All that happens before your computer even accesses the server (the process of client-server communication is also fascinating, but totally another story). It's certainly quite complicated, but if you can think of a better way to have a distributed network of completely independent machines all communicating with each other in a vast worldwide network, you're certainly wasting your time here.

Okay, so computers have IP addresses, but the problem with internet service providers like RCN is that they are constantly randomizing those addresses. Your home network will be assigned a new IP every once in a while, through a process called Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP). There are many reasons for this, mainly that it would be a pain in the ass to manually assign an IP address to hundreds of thousands of internet customers. What does this mean for someone wanting to build a web server at home? Well, if your IP address changes all the time, then where do you point the domain name?

Let's go back to that card catalog metaphor. Say you're looking for a book, perhaps a copy of Montgumery Rood, by A Chicken (yes, I'm referencing my own podcast). Well, it's easy, right? You just open up the 'A' drawer in the card catalog . . .

They don't even use card catalogs anymore, do they? That's a stupid metaphor.

Okay, say you're doing a crossword puzzle. Yeah, this is good. You're doing a crossword puzzle, and you look at the clue for 23 across. It says 'Invented the apple, colleague of Borrison' (yes, another podcast reference). Well, obviously the answer is 'Smith,' so you look up at the puzzle for the horizontal row of boxes marked with a little '23.' Simple, now you know that 'Smith' goes in those little boxes. That's not entirely dissimilar to how the internets work. Typing in 'google.com' is like saying '23 across.' Your browser figures out what 23 across points to, and fills in the little boxes with the proper IP address.

But when a server is assigned addresses with DHCP, it's like that crossword puzzle is constantly shifting around. It would be impossible for you to solve.

So what you need to do is get your internet provider to give you a static IP address, so that your little row of boxes never changes. You have to pay a little extra to your ISP, but you can always connect to your server.

So okay, back to my phone call with RCN. As an ISP (Internet Service Provider), they know what a static IP address is, and it should be easy to get them to give me one. After I was transferred to the Internet Support division and we figured out which account we were dealing with (it's under my roommate Sarah's name), I told the person-on-the-phone what I needed and asked if it was possible and how much it would cost.

'Okay, one moment, we will add a Static IP to this account.' She said, jumping to all sorts of conclusions.

'Uh, well, how much will it be?' I responded, hoping to stop her from charging an account which doesn't even have my name on it.

'A Static IP is 19.95'

' . . . per month?' (our internet plan is only $30 per month, so that seemed a little much to me)

'Yes, 19.95 per month, plus a $25 set up fee.'

'Wait . . . ' I was about to try to get her to justify why typing four numbers into a router justified a $25 setup fee, but then I realized that was a stupid thing to argue. What was a far better thing to argue, I decided, was the fact that the RCN website advertises static IP services for only 9.95 / month.

Unless I'm seeing it wrong . . .

We both took turns walking each other through the RCN website to find the price for Static IP, which I assured her said '9.95' which is not, in fact, '19.95.'

'9.95,' I said, 'would be something I would be willing to pay. I would not be willing to pay 19.95.'

'So you don't want to add Static IP to your account?' She asked.

'No, in fact, I never did want to add it to my account, I was just trying to figure out how much it will cost, and I wasn't really able to do that, so I guess I'll have to call again later.'

Meanwhile, it has become increasingly difficult to connect to my website via FTP (so I can upload files to it and stuff), and I am constantly receiving notifications that DenyConformity.com is down. So it would seem that the DenyConformity.com webserver has reach a bit of a predicament. I don't want to spend an additional $20 a month, but I can't stand sticking with Startlogic any longer. Maybe I'll just bite the bullet and get the static IP address.

Unless there's a better way.

fields.title: An Open Letter to the President of Earth
fields.text:
I have been finding myself complaining about the world more and more lately. War. Famine. Oil spills. Everything is a mess. I've decided to take it upon myself, as a person on the internet, to send my complaints to the person I think could to the most to fix it, the President of Earth. I don't know why nobody has thought of that before. There's no need to thank me, the benefit of having a better world is reward enough.

Well, I guess if you want to send me gifts and stuff, you can.

Read the entire letter

Dear President of Earth,

How are you? I am just fine. I hope everything is going well for you there in your high chambers or whatever you call it. I'm sure you've heard enough of this, but I would still like to congratulate you on your appointment to the highest position of respect and power in what is probably the greatest planet the Human Race has ever known (except, you know, wherever the pyramids came from). I'm sure it's no small order to take the mantle of Leader of the Entire World, and you have a great deal of things to take care of. However, it's certainly a great achievement, and I hope you take a moment to step back and acknowledge what a thing you've done there. I don't think I could get myself elected (or crowned, I'm not sure how that works) President of an entire planet, even if I really tried hard for a few months. If your parents aren't proud of you by now, they probably never will be so you can stop trying to win their attention. I mean, just being able to introduce yourself as 'President of Earth' has to make up for all the hard work and stress you have to deal with. You probably live in Babeland, USA. Actually, you probably live in Dubai, because that's totally where I would go if I were president of Earth. Wherever you are, I'm sure you're knee deep in all the hot chicks you can stand (or stand on, which I would probably do if I were President of Earth).

I would love to do nothing but admire Your great, all-encompassing power and grace, Your Majesty (do I call You that?), but I do have some important issues to bring to Your attention instead. I realize that you probably have millions of things to think about at any given moment (many of them in Spanish, even), but I really think that the following issues are critical to the continued success of Human Beings as a unified species, and they are therefor of utmost importance to you.

My first, and arguably most important complaint has to do with the fact that you don't exist. I'm sure you can see what a hindrance this is to your ability to lead Earth into a time of continued prosperity. I can't tell you what a disappointment it is every time I wake up and realize that even though everybody in the world can talk to one another and pretty much everybody lives together in one society, we don't actually have any kind of unifying government to do anything to make the world a better place for everybody (and we all know the U.N. doesn't really count). I am tempted to include the word 'yet' when saying you don't exist, but, sadly, I am not sure if you will ever exist at all. Call me cynical, but considering how blasé and, quite frankly, incompetent your administration has been so far, I would not be surprised if they continue to not exist for the foreseeable future. I think I speak for pretty much everybody when I say that this isn't really that great. I would ask, therefore, that you address this issue as soon as you possibly can. With power as seemingly limitless and mighty as yours, I'm sure one could easily pull the necessary strings and jump through all of the proper 'hoops' to create oneself. I look forward to your first speech when you explain exactly how you pulled that off.

My second complaint came to me the other day when I was in the bath. It suddenly occurred to me that Humans, as awesome and mighty as we are, still only have the one planet. That is simply appalling to me. What is the point in living in the future if we cannot yet explore the cosmos and live among the stars? I understand that with all of the problems and pitfalls of running one planet you would be wary about taking on another, but you could easily appoint a governor or viceroy to watch over the new world. Hell, you could even name it after yourself! I would think that it would be a relief to you to know that out there is another world of humans that will continue the species even if you really screw things up here. I know that would take the edge off for me. Plus, it would be fun if we find a world inhabited by an equal or lesser species, because it would give us a chance to have a little War. You know how much we love War, and we don't get to do it that much anymore now that we're starting to realize how stupid it is to kill each other. If we found a nice, hostile planet, we could send everybody who wants to do War over there. That would sure make Earth seem nice and peaceful, wouldn't it? Who was the last world leader who could claim that he sent all War to an entirely different planet? Nobody, that's who.

Are the limitless bounds of the cosmos a bit daunting for you? Don't worry, there are great works you can do for us here on home soil, too. You're probably already looking into this one, but I was at the movies the other day and I saw that movie about the iron man. There were two of them in the movie, and I thought it would be great if I had one of those, too. Then I could just fly to work and I could pick up cars and stuff. I know the movie wasn't real, but that's where you come in. You should tell somebody to make an iron man, and make sure that they make one big enough to fit a taller gentleman, like myself. In fact – this is another point entirely, actually – there's a lot you could do for tall people. For example, people never trim trees quite tall enough and I always end up bumping my head into branches and I get scratches on my face. Also the seats on planes are too small. Anyway, yeah, we should have iron mans. We could use them in our wars with other planets. When those stupid alien things see an army of flying metal dudes coming at them, they'd totally poop their pants, if they could poop . . . or had pants. Shouldn't every human being be entitled to life, liberty, and the ability to be an Iron Man?

Another thing: have you ever tried to park anywhere lately? Here in Chicago, they have these boxes where you pay to park, and you get a little sticker that you put in your window. While it works great, in theory, people don't know where the different parking spaces are, because each box applies to the whole block instead of each space separately. Now people just park wherever they feel like, leaving huge gaps in between each other, so all the spots run out of space, even for Smart Cars. It's a lot like communism, really. You're President of Earth; can't you do something about this? It would be better if you could do something rather soon, too, because I don't know how much longer this friend of mine can keep driving around the block looking for a space.

You know, cars are pretty silly, if you get right down to it. I mean, we should just have tubes that go everywhere like in that show Futurama (there was even a President of Earth in Futurama, so you should be all over that). It would be just like at the bank. I think we should probably keep the 'no coins' rule, too, because I don't want to get hit in the butt with a quarter when I'm trying to go somewhere. Anyway, my Mom is way more obsessed about Tube Technology, and I'm sure you've probably gotten tons of letters from her already about that.

Oh yeah, that was another complaint. Can't you get the Internet for my Parents yet? They're still stuck with just dial up access, and you probably don't need me to tell you that dial up blows. Granted, they live in the middle of Nowhere, but Nowhere is still on Earth, isn't it? Last time I checked, you were President of There. Please tell somebody to get off their ass and run some wires out there or something. It's the future, for crying out loud. If we had iron mans, you could send out an iron man and he could just fly there with his rocket boots and a . . . bunch of . . . internets.

Also, why does everybody in the world still use physical money? Can't we all just get some sort of credit card? Sure, it would be a shock to the system, and a few industries would be affected, but we (humans) are pretty smart, so we'll probably figure it out. I think that the removal of physical currency would probably most impact the vagrancy industry. It would be hard for bums on the street to ask for spare change if spare change only existed as fractions in someone's digital bank account. I can see how that could be a problem. If all those bums were unable to panhandle, there would be a lot of people out of out of work, and then they'll get kicked out of out of their homes. Still, they'll probably learn to adapt, I'm sure. You could issue credit card readers to the various tech-savy tramps roaming the streets. The others could finally get what they really want anyway, and just ask for booze; either that or - you know - get a job. You could always issue iron man suits to all the bums in the world. That would at least be really interesting to watch.

Okay, these concerns seem daunting. I understand that. I mean, there you are, suddenly the most powerful human being on the planet, with a billion things to worry about (many of them in Spanish), and some random dude starts throwing his stupid problems at you? I mean, you're still struggling with the fact that you don't exist; how could you be expected to solve the lousy parking situation in Chicago, Illinois? I think, though, that as you look out of your two hundredth floor window at the developing Dubai skyline - a menagerie of cranes, bizarre structures and exposed girders - that the Human Race needs to pick itself up. We, as a species, need to get our Shit together.

Imagine, if you will, that you had a son (or if you have a son, picture a second son). Let's call him Gerald. Gerald just went off to college. He's living on his own, now, for the first time. You are happy for Gerald, and you know that he will do just fine. Gerald is a good kid; he's smart, full of vim (whatever that is), and ready to take on the world. However, you begin to receive complaints from Gerald's counselor or RA or whatever that he's starting to slip. Gerald is self-destructive, violent toward other students, greedy, irresponsible, ignoring his homework, and just a general asshole to the other students. Gerald has been trashing his dorm room and nobody can find his roommate, Passenger Pigeon (yeah, I went there). All Gerald does anymore is sit around drinking and playing video games. What would you do about that?

You would tell Gerald to get his Shit together (or perhaps a variation on that theme). To any outside observer, Gerald is a menace to the world around him. He desperately needs to be contained. He desperately needs a parental figure to tell him to shape up, and to let him know what will happen if he doesn't (either the world explodes or Dean of Students Global Climate Change will come down and murder him). I'm simply asking you, as Leader of All of Us, to be that parental figure, and tell All of Us to shape up. Stick your head out that two hundredth floor window and yell, 'listen up everybody, we're not going to be like Gerald anymore.' Get on that special red phone connected directly to Humanity and say, 'it's time to stop being a bunch of assholes, all seven billion of you.' Tell your Secretary of Manning-up to get off his nonexistent ass and get to work. Open your eyes, bring yourself into existence, grab this planet by its giant blue marbles, and make it a better place.

Don't just do it for me. Don't do it for the children. Do it because if you don't do it people are going to call you a 'lame duck' or a 'socialist' or a 'made-up.' Do it because if you don't we're all going to kill ourselves (I don't mean we're all going to commit suicide, I mean we're going to destroy ourselves by being assholes) if you don't. Do it because I really want an iron man suit.

In conclusion, I really just want an iron man suit. Thank you in advance for making that happen.

Sincerely,

Shauvon McGill

fields.title: McGill family farm journal
fields.text:
My parents have been doing some research into my family's history, recently. They uncovered some interesting things, as well as a genealogical line stretching all the way back to when people had names like GRONGNARD. One of the more interesting things they found, though, was a journal detailing one of my ancestor's trials as they moved west to start a new life, during, presumably, the Great Depression. I found it fascinating, especially during this time of great economic turmoil. I urge you to read ahead, and get a glimpse at a bit of history. It's actually somewhat well written, too.

Week one.

The sun set slowly over the modest parcel of land that held far too much of my family's future as we arrived this week to start our new life here. I looked across this small farmland which was recently handed to me, and I felt an all to familiar twinge of fear rise in the pit of my stomach. How could my family and I survive on this meager patch of dirt and the few simple crops that were planted here before my arrival? I decided to waste no time, or perhaps decided that there simply was no time to waste. In the fading evening sun, as my wife and children settled themselves in our new house - it still seemed far too small for our four children - I set out to survey what little we had.

I was given a paltry few instructions to aid me. I could only guess what most of my tools were for. Thankfully, a small patch of vegetables was already growing, and I decided that what little I could discover from them could be invaluable when I need to plant more. I only hope the small bit of coin I can get for harvesting these plants will be enough to keep my children fed over the coming weeks.

My wife and I have been married for almost fifteen years. We met when I was still working for the Bank, back East. It was a simpler time then, and we were blissfully happy, slowly raising a family on my Generous Banker's Salary. Then, as the economy began taking its toll on us all, the warm burn in the pit of my stomach first showed itself. My wife often found me at the window, gazing off at the skyline. She always had the same nervous look on her face, and I knew she was only mirroring my own. I have a tendency to stop blinking when I'm worried, and she knew it. She would stare into my big, pale-blue eyes, and know that something was wrong. Neither of us could have guessed just how bad things were going to become.

It has, in more recent days, become cruelly apparent that I know nothing about raising a farm. I tried several times to replant the small patches of land that I had recently harvested, before I finally felt confident in my work. My oldest son, Jeffery, proved to be invaluable to me by heading to the nearest town, where a market provides me and other local farmers with the resources we need. Unfortunately, he was only able to find soybeans, and we had to spend an unfortunate amount of money to re-plant them. I looked on with great trepidation, hoping to whatever omniscient beings watching over us that these soybeans - our only option - would prove valuable. The planting took a great deal of what little money we had, but I hoped that the investment and the experience gained would more than make up for it. Only time would tell.

My contact in town, the old man who gave me the few tips I had about farming going into this new life, left me with some words of encouragement. 'That's farming for ya!' he told me, but somehow I am not entirely confident in my achievements so far. I will have to be vigilant, and harvest these little crops as soon as they are ready, which I fear will be the hardest challenge yet.

I still wonder if these new crops will require some sort of maintenance that I have not yet been made aware of. I cannot tell if these tools I have available can help me to water the crops, protect them from weeds or insects, or other seemingly obvious challenges that could present themselves. The old man in town simply told me to harvest the crops before they wither, which struck me as rather obvious, frankly. What little I knew about farms covered the simple concept of plant, wait, harvest, without any wizened 'expert' to help me. Do I simply wait, standing here on my new land, my deep, blue eyes staring unblinking at the horizon, until that moment comes that I can spring to action and harvest these crops that my entire family is depending on? Is there nothing I can do to occupy my fretting mind in the meanwhile? This will truly be a difficult time.
