fields.title: District Alpha: Chapter 6
fields.text:
I've been pleased as punch with the response to the first excerpt from my new novel, District Alpha: Government Mandate Zone. I was so encouraged by all the positive feedback, in fact, that I have decided to release the next chapter for your consideration! Even though everybody seems to love it, for some reason I still haven't been sent an offer for the movie rights. Reminder: the movie rights are still available!

District Alpha: Government Mandate Zone

Chapter 6

The reports did not look good. District Epsilon was way over quota. Recounting the numbers was not going to help, just as it had never helped before.

Maximum Chamberman of District District 5 Dorald Yugdab pulled at his chin, hoping that the numbers would add up if he counted them all one last time. It didn’t work. His thoughtful grey eyes looked up from the Commpadd, burning a hole in Director Pagu, the poor soul whose duty it was to deliver this bad news. Yugdab did not have laser vision, but he might as well have had, as far as Pagu was concerned.

“What do these numbers tell me?” The Maximum Chamberman calmly asked. Yugdab spoke with a generic British accent, which obviously made him seem either intellectual, exotic, or aristocratic - it doesn’t matter which.

Director Pagu could not adequately respond purely by sweating, but it didn’t stop his body from trying. His mouth opened and closed as he tried to determine what Yugdab meant.

The Chamberman looked up at Pagu, his eyes narrowing. Pagu was staring intently at the pile of dogs curled up around the base of of the chamberseat upon which Yugdab sat. Like all Maximum Chambermen, Yugdab surrounded himself with comforts. His affinity for dogs was evident by his host of loyal canine pets. The host of beautiful, scantily clad ladies lining the chamber showed his affinity for scantily clad ladies. Nobody can really resist scantily clad ladies, really, and this grand setting featuring a lot of them would have been right at home as an important shot in a movie trailer. Pagu wondered what else Yugdab had an affinity for. He tried to remember if he had heard anything about laser vision. Pagu was a very nervous man who was always afraid that people had laser vision.

“What do these numbers tell me, Director?” Yugdab asked again, saying each word clearly. His voice was level and - to Pagu - terrifyingly relaxed. Pagu hadn’t become a District Director without learning an important lesson about what people sound like when they’re angry. Yugdab had no reason to not be angry, Pagu knew, so it must have meant that he was really, extra, laser vision caliber angry.

“District Epsilon is . . . over quota . . . ?” Pagu answered slowly.

Dorald Yugdab chuckled to himself. Handing the Commpadd to one of the Chamber aides, who were standing in a sweeping arc behind his plinth, Yugdab stood and stepped down to the Chamber floor. Standing level with Pagu, Yugdab still towered over him. History had proven that the tallest people were the best, and so it was no surprise that a man like Dorald Yugdab came to power. Standing exactly six feet eight inches tall, Yugdab cut an extremely imposing figure. He was a thin man, but he had the bearing of a genius, and his rugged good looks made everybody really like him, even if he was kind of a jerk. His red hair, cut short, and his smooth face were the paragon of fashion, and he always wore futuristic suits, which are basically like regular suits except they’re kind of shiny and made of space-fabric. Even though Yugdab was pretty old and wise, one of the advantages of his high status was that genetic tampering and age treatments left him looking much younger, as if he were about in his mid twenties.

“District Epsilon is over quota,” Yugdab mused as he paced across the Chamber floor, looking absently at the host of scantily clad ladies. “That’s what the numbers mean, Director. What do they tell me?” He was still talking with that cold, condescending way that would have really irritated Pagu if it hadn’t terrified him to the point of inventing a new language using sweat.

“I . . . I don’t . . .” began Pagu, turning to Yugdab who was standing in the middle of the Chamber with his back to the poor Director, picking through some fruit which was piled on one of the scantily clad ladies. Yugdab was that cool - he had a scantily clad lady as a fruit bowl.

Yugdab spun on his heel, throwing a long, narrow finger at the Director, screaming, “It means that you haven’t been doing your job, Director Pagu!” Venom and hatred were overflowing from his once neutral face. Pagu was almost relieved to finally be getting the stern talking-to that he was expecting all along. Pagu was also relieved that the sudden outburst hadn’t scared out of him what it almost scared out of him. He silently cursed his uniform standard white pants. He felt as if a thousand scantily clad lady eyes were on him.

“Twenty seven districts I’m in charge of and every single one of them is under quota except for yours!” continued the Chamberman. Pagu flinched at each syllable, still waiting for the lasers to start firing from those deep, grey eyes. The pile of dogs stirred, and some of the dogs raised their heads as their master was getting angry. Suddenly it occurred to Pagu, counting dog heads, that there were quite a bit fewer dogs in that pile than he originally thought. Being torn to shreds by vicious gigantic dogs started to compete in his mind with being charred to a crisp by an angry man’s eye lasers. If he cooks me with his eye lasers, those dogs will eat me, Pagu thought to himself, with a shiver down his spine.

Pagu was not particularly aware of what Yugdab had said, but even if he had, he wouldn’t have known that it wasn’t true. District Epsilon was not the only district to be over-quota. In fact, many of the districts within District District 5 were over quotas or in some crisis or another. Yugdab was the only man who knew the truth about every district. He was a very shrewd politician and leader, sharing nothing with his subordinates. The ability to not tell your underlings that you aren’t doing that great is a sign of a really good leader - something that Yugdab totally was. He slowly walked around Pagu, menacing him.

“You will increase the zombie count in District Epsilon by ten percent,” Yugdab said, talking through clenched teeth to suppress the anger that was welling within him. Pagu was weighing the pros and cons of being eaten alive by giant dogs versus being fried to a crisp by angry lasers. Yugdab’s clear order snapped the Director out of his mental turmoil.

“Sir, that’s not going to be easy . . .” Pagu began. He wanted so desperately to just say “yeah, sure, ok,” but he knew it would be much worse to have to face these dogs and these lasers and who knows what else if he failed what was probably an impossible mission. It was obviously the most tactful solution to let Yugdab know now that what he wanted would be impossible. Pagu prided himself on his ability to tactfully find the path least likely to lead to his being lasered.

“Then you had better get started, Director.” Yugdab responded, returning to his plinth and collapsing back into his chamberseat. The dogs settled into a new pile arrangement.

Pagu’s eyebrows furrowed ever so slightly, and he found himself once again fighting the urge to ruin his white pants. He raced through his mind, trying to run the numbers, visualising the spreadsheet displayed on the very commpadd he had just handed his boss. He hardly had enough idlers left in his district to afford mandating that many more zombies. Then he realized a thing he had thought earlier. Who knows what else is waiting to destroy me besides the dogs and lasers? Pagu thought to himself. He was suddenly aware of the vaulted ceiling above him, and the conspicuously tiled floor below. I bet that ceiling opens up, he thought to himself. The ceiling opens up and, what, these floor tiles are on little catapults? Oh no, he’s going to catapult me out of a 126 story building. He’s going to catapult me and then he’s going to skeet shoot me with his eye lasers and then his dogs are going to have raining breakfast.

Yugdab simply glared at the young Director. The Chamberman knew what was going through Pagu’s head. Not the catapulting stuff - nobody just looking at the guy would know any of that. If someone were there who could read thoughts, they would probably feel extra important with this knowledge that Yugdab didn’t have, just like people who watch movies after reading the book feel superior to those who skip the book. Yugdab was more interested Pagu’s thoughts about the statistical analysis of his District’s zombie counts. Before today, Yugdab had little faith in Pagu, and now he had none. This young Director had proven his inability to understand the nuance of Government Mandate Zones, seeing things purely as numbers on a spreadsheet. Yugdab knew, though, that mandating citizens went far beyond simply running the numbers. Pagu’s district, District Epsilon, was a major source of manufactured goods for the rest of the districts in the District. As a result, the workers in District Epsilon were cocky, thinking they could drink all the delicious Coke and eat all the Taco Bell that they wanted. In all fairness, anybody would feel inclined to do that, because those are both really delicious and satisfying things. However, the Government had to make an example of these workers, to show them - and the neighboring districts - that Government Mandate Zones were not to be trifled with.

Would industry suffer? Marginally, perhaps, but the overall increase in productivity as citizens buckled down in fear of the Mandate would more than make up for it. Besides, zombies could work most machinery just as well as many of the citizens in District Epsilon. These sorts of things went right over Pagu’s head, but Yugdab was such a great thinker that it came naturally to him - and he was so good at expressing himself that someone just looking at his face as he glared there would have picked up all of this cool background information just from his subtle facial expressions.

Pagu bowed his head obediently, giving Yugdab a “yes, sir.” He turned with the efficiency of a bureaucrat and nervously walked the long length of the chamber to the grand exit. With each step he became more sure that the tile beneath him would launch him like a clay pigeon.

Yugdab watched the man walk away. He turned to one of his aides and called him by name, which was “Cranden.”

Cranden obediently responded. Yugdab knew each of his sixty three aides up and down. He knew their strengths and weaknesses, so he would know exactly who would be best suited for each of his myriad tasks. For example, he knew that one of his aides, named Ruddle, was almost completely useless, except for the most basic of tasks, which is why he chose that aide to hold his commpadds for him. Ruddle often even managed to screw that up.

Cranden was an excellent aide, however. He had served the Chamberman for almost six years, and Yugdab knew the time had come for the young man to get the promotion he deserved. With his eyes still fixed on Director Pagu, making his way daintily out of the chamber, he gave the orders that would change two men’s lives forever.

“It will be up to you to see that zombie count is mandated.”

“Yes, sir.”

“And see to it that former Director Pagu is the first one.”

“Yes, sir.”

Yugdab leveled his expressive eyes on the aide. “Congratulations, District Director Cranden,” he said.

The slightest hint of a grin showed on the new Director’s face. His time had finally come. All he could say was, “thank you, sir,” which is why he said exactly that before stepping out of line and heading out of the chamber. It was Cranden’s job, now, to set about giving Pagu a fate worse than death - worse even, perhaps, than being launched, cooked, and eaten by catapult, laser, and dog, respectively. It was common knowledge that it was really annoying to be a zombie.

Maximum Chamberman of District District 5 Dorald Yugdab allowed himself a brief moment to reflect. There was much to do, and he could afford very little time to staring off thoughtfully, but those sorts of things really make a character look like they have a lot going on, so that’s what he did. Only for a moment, though.

Then he stood, briskly making his way to the side door, which led to his personal offices. “Ruddle, come with me,” he said, “the rest of you are dismissed.” He had found that the only way to keep Ruddle from being completely, utterly, sometimes destructively useless was if he kept the dullard at his side at all times. Only under the strictest of supervision could the boy - he was 17 and looked like a poor man’s Michael Cera - get anything done without making a mess of it. Yugdab occasionally found himself checking to make sure he hadn’t recruited a zombie by mistake. As the two of them approached his office, the other aides, the scantily clad ladies, and the pile of dogs all shuffled offscreen.

Yugdab kept the simple lad around because there was something about the glassy look of his eyes, the blank expression on his face, and the perpetually open mouth that made it easy for Yugdab to open up to him. He was able to talk through his plans, as he paced back and forth in front of his giant office window. Yugdab had always found it useful to voice his ideas, and in the process they would somehow fit together and reform as even better ones, like taking ice out of a freezer to melt a little bit and then putting it back in so that it all froze into one giant supercube. The Chamberman’s ideas were like perfectly formed ice cubes, but by sounding them out and fitting them together, he could create the most supercube of ideas.

Really, Yugdab’s technique was not unlike that of a writer, blindly stabbing at mixed metaphors and misplaced symbolism in the hope that eventually some words will happen to fit together into a coherent sentence or two. To Yugdab, Ruddle was like a big whiteboard which Yugdab could throw darts at until he happened to collect enough ingredients for an idea-sandwich.

Long ago, when Yugdab was actually younger, and not just synthetically younger, Yugdab had had a stuffed bear, his cherished possession. He spent hours sharing his secrets and his schemes with that bear, in the privacy of his bedroom. He never knew what happened to his beloved Bobo, but he found a certain similarity in the inanimate stuffing of this Ruddle. One difference was that Ruddle wasn’t quite as good at holding important commpadds as the stuffed bear, but Yugdab had grown to expect that by now.

As they came through the office door, Ruddle managed to stumble over the threshold, as he always did, and drop one of the commpadds he was holding, as if doing so specifically to illustrate his incompetence. Yugdab ignored it. He had given up trying to force some sense into the boy. He was already launching into his train of thought for the afternoon.

“Another district over quota, Ruddle. These citizens are getting harder to keep under mandate. How do they expect us to survive with what we have if they keep insisting on taking more than their share?”

“I don’t know,” replied Ruddle.

Yugdab looked over at the blank face, which was breathing through its mouth as always. “Do you remember what I told you about rhetorical questions, Ruddle?”

“. . . uh . . . no,” replied Ruddle.

Yugdab simply sighed and looked back out the window. The view was quite impressive from the chamber atop the 126-story District District headquarters building, in the heart of District Alpha. Yugdab knew he could see all the way to the edges of his District District, and he glared at the thought of District District 4, and the ever present competition of Maximum Chamberman Auldis Doogon just over the horizon. He went back to the thoughts inside his beautiful little head.

“Twenty-seven districts. Each one with countless citizens, all striving to be the best they can. What gives them all the opportunities to prosper, Ruddle? We do! The Government Mandates keep these districts from falling apart. I do. Just think what a difference I could make if I were selected to be Chamberman of District District 1! Chamberman Zeldo’s health is declining by the day. It’s only a matter of time, now, before someone will be asked to take his place. It should be me! I know I’m the best suited. I know the chamber of elders see me as the obvious choice. If only that damned Doogon weren’t always one step ahead of me. They’re just waiting for one of us to slip up, to give way for the other to take District District 1 and the world. I won’t be the one to make a mistake. I won’t let Auldis Doogon take what’s rightfully mine. What does he know about Government Mandates, anyway? Have you seen the reports of District District 4 Mandate Zones?”

Ruddle was pleased to finally have a question he knew the answer to. “Nope!”

“It’s like he doesn’t even care about quotas! Why, in his wheat processing district, citizens are allowed to shop at Macy’s as much as they want! How can they possibly keep order when they can go to such a wonderful and quite affordable under any budget department store for all of their domestic needs? Where’s the supply for that? How can everyone in an entire district get fashionable accessories? I can’t even imagine! Think of District Sigma, or even Epsilon. Millions of people live in those districts. We don’t have enough of this season’s hottest styles for everyone in one Mandate Zone, let alone a District, or by damn, the entire District District!”

Ruddle thoughtfully made bubbles with his spit. He was getting quite good.

“Don’t you see, Ruddle? Every man, woman, zombie, robot, and child out there is a District, and I won’t rest until each and every last one of them is mandated! I’ll mandate them a hundred times if it means I can stay one step ahead of that blasted Doogon and his free spirited ways!”

Just then, a familiar dingle dongle sounded from the door to the Chamber room. As Yugdab turned, the door opened to reveal one of his aides - a quite tech savvy young man whom Yugdab had stationed in the radio surveillance department. Yugdab expressed his frustration at having his train of thought derailed with a quick, “whatisit?” The toxic chemicals contained within his train cars of thought were spilling all over the innocent villages of thought inside his vast mind.

“Sorry to bother you, sir, but you requested to be notified if a particular set of frequencies was detected.”

Yugdab immediately perked up, then composing himself again - careful to hide his excitement from these aides - he asked, “What of it?”

“Well, sir, we picked it up. It showed up yesterday morning, in the outskirts of District Alpha: Government Mandate Zone, and it took us some time to confirm. It seemed to have come from District Delta, which makes sense, sir. I believe we were unable to pick up the signal before now because it was being masked by interference from the high concentration of robot farms in that district.”

“Ah, I see. You have a report, there?” Yugdab gestured toward the commpadd in the aide’s hand.

“Yes, sir, I prepared a complete report for you.”

The aide began to hand the report to Ruddle, as was customary by now, but Yugdab quickly stepped forward and took the commpadd from the aide himself. He hated having to show the slightest interest in the report, but he just couldn’t bear to see Ruddle drop this one on the floor, for the great possibilities that the report could signify. With as much nonchalance as he could muster, he took the commpadd to his desk.

“Thank you, that will be all.”

The aide left with a nod. Yugdab stared at the report, looking for the specific frequencies indicated. He would have read the data to himself, but this is really important exposition, so he spoke to Ruddle as he processed what he saw.

“There are the frequencies, alright. I had almost forgotten. After all these years . . . Why now? It seems awfully dubious that these frequencies should emerge now, with me so close to being promoted to District District 1. There’s only one thing for it, I’m afraid. I’ll have to get to the bottom of this. I’ll have to choose my best aide to find the source of this signal, and bring it back to me.”

Riddle got excited. “Me sir?” he asked.

“No,” Yugdab replied. He set the pad down and took another moment to reflect. Two moments in one day was certainly a lot of reflection time, but he certainly deserved it after the last several pages. He had a lot of planning to do. He had just sent his best aide to a new assignment, and now he had to pick another one to waste his time on what could very well be a wild goose chase through the streets and alleyways of an entire District. He wondered if this was a ploy by Doogon to sap his resources. One thing was for sure, though. Life was never dull for the Maximum Chamberman in District Alpha: Government Mandate Zone!

fields.title: Ads on DenyConformity.com
fields.text:
For the last few days, there have been no ads on DenyConformity.com. I suppose that isn’t really a surprise. Before about a week ago, there had never been ads on DenyConformity.com. However, this is an annoying and frustrating turn of events. I want to be serious about this website, and so far I’m pretty proud of myself (this is the ninth day of consecutive updates!). However, to be able to take this seriously, I will need to come up with some way to pay for it. I’m afraid I will have to come up with a new solution.

I was using Google AdSense, a pretty simple system to potentially monetize web content. The idea is that you put some code on your website that Google gives you, and then when people go to the site they’ll see ads that are tailored to the content on your site. It uses Google’s fancy algoribbons to pick ads that are related to the stuff on the site (at least for the most part). When visitors click on the ads, you get a very tiny cut. Through my testing process over the last few months, and the first week of the new DenyConformity.com’s life, it worked perfectly.

I have two ad locations. One is on the main timeline, at the top of the page. It’s a leaderboard size ad, which falls back to a smaller banner if the screen is smaller, and a mobile banner if the viewer is on a smartphone (or has a tiny browser window for some reason). On the post page (the page you’re reading this on), a skyscraper floats to the right side of the content. This ensures that the user has one ad on any page that contains content, and they aren’t obnoxious or in the way. With AdSense, I was getting ads for costumes, Chicago businesses, and sci-fi novels, among other things. I felt that those things were pretty accurate for the content I have here.

This is what my ads look like now. How will my readers get access to Cool Runnings costumes (an actual ad I saw here a few days ago)?

Well, I guess it didn’t exactly work perfectly. The problem is that I made an uncomfortable bed for myself with this ridiculously complicated and ambitious design. There are plenty of reasons why the site looks the way it does, but the problem is that it doesn’t really cooperate with Google AdSense. You see, AdSense has some pretty hefty caveats. First, it has to load with the page, so you can’t load ads with Javascript after the page has loaded. Second, their ad code is for one specific size, and one specific size only. Third, their crazy terms specify that their ads can’t exist inside iframes. They stipulate these things for very specific and justified reasons.

How is that a problem for me, though? Well, first, since my site only had one page load, and all the content is pulled using Javascript, I have to be able to load ads dynamically. Second, this site is responsive, which means that the same page will load on any size screen, be it a phone, tablet, netbook, or 30-inch cinema display. I can’t load the same size ads for a smartphone as I load for a 30-inch monitor, so the ads on my site have to also be responsive. Finally, the only way I can overcome those problems is by loading their ad code in an iframe, which I can then reload dynamically depending on window size, device, user navigation, or whatever.

I figured they would have a problem with what I was doing, but since I was just bending their rules to make it work, I hoped that they could work with me and perhaps make an exception. They say the rule of thumb is, “whether you’d feel comfortable explaining what you’ve done to a website that competes with you,” and “ask, ‘Does this help my users?’” Every choice I made was specifically with my users in mind, and I am not ashamed of anything I did on this new design. However, when I started getting impressions and (a tiny amount of) clicks, they simply shut me down. My account is suspended, my ads are disabled, and all of my requests for further information or support have gone unanswered. After perusing the AdSense forums, it is my strong opinion that with what I’ve got going on, I’m not getting AdSense back.

I can’t blame them. This is a world that entire industries have popped up to take advantage of and cheat. We’re talking about a thing where you can put ads on a web page and you get money every time somebody clicks on them. I can think of about fifty different ways somebody could screw with that to get free money just off the top of my head. Basically, after years of dealing with garbage, Google isn’t messing around, and they don’t have time to deal with violators, legitimate or not.

So, fine, I can tell when I’m not wanted. Using Google AdSense was a bit of a shortcut, anyway. It was a cheap way out, and that’s not the DenyConformity way. If there’s anything that defines this website, it’s that we do things the very, very hard - and usually dumb (but at hopefully at least entertaining) way. I just need to figure out the proper DenyConformity.com approach to ads.

To be clear, I’m actually all for advertising in general. I think it serves a valuable purpose, namely to give people access to free stuff. If I can maintain this website, get paid for it, and still let people out there come here and get a laugh or two for free, I don’t see anything wrong with it. The fact is that this would be a much more expensive world - I mean absolutely anything you spend money on - if we didn’t have ads. As long as they aren’t getting in the way or making things more difficult, I'm happy to have them around. That’s why I don’t see it as a “sell out” move to try to get a little ad revenue here.

Still, I don’t want to sit here and defend my motivations for trying to monetize this project, because there’s nothing to justify. I’ve spent more time working on this website than I’ve spent on anything else in my entire life, and I know that I’ve provided a respectable amount of entertainment value to the world. The simple fact is that I deserve to be compensated for what I’ve done, and I need capital to continue working on it as I move forward. End of story.

So how can I raise that capital? Should I have annual pledge drives, like PBS? Should I quietly but regularly ask for donations from my visitors? That relies pretty heavily on my audience being pretty generous (and have plenty of disposable income). Should I get some t-shirts or other swag and sell them at reasonably marked up prices? That worked for Homestar. Should I start selling prints of the photos I’ve posted here? Should I solicit ads myself, personally finding companies to advertise directly to my tens of regular visitors? As the site’s presence grows (and I’m hoping that with my new focus on regular updates it will), that might actually become somewhat viable. Should I start a subscription service, where most of my content is behind a paywall that requires some sort of modest fee? Should I start trying to write commercially, and sell stuff I write to actual big-time publishers and websites?

The fact is, I’m going to start working on looking into all of the above. Stick around and help me try out some of these things that I should have been looking into long before now.

Thanks for your continued support!

fields.title: Michigan Avenue
fields.text:
Not long after I moved to Chicago, I took a trip to Michigan Avenue (the Magnificent Mile) to take some pictures. It was still very exciting to live in Chicago, and it was fun to go to Michigan Avenue as a resident instead of a tourist. This place was always such a exotic location - a place I only went as part of a big special trip. Of course, whenever I came to Chicago, I was obsessed with looking like I belonged here. I didn't want to look like I was excited about anything or like I was seeing things for the first time. I did not want anybody to look at me and say, 'there's total tourist.' If you had told me when I was seventeen that I would live in Chicago, and - in fact - work right on Michigan Avenue (I had a contract in the Tribune Building for the first three months in 2012), I never would have believed you. Yet here I was in August, 2009, resident of Chicago, walking up and down Michigan Avenue. All I wanted to do was gawk and the cool buildings and take pictures - like a total tourist.














Now, if you'll excuse me, I am going to play with these Legos. I got them at the Lego store, on Michigan Avenue.

fields.title: The Parker Jotter
fields.text:
A DenyConformity.com review.

George Safford Parker is a classic example of the American Dream. In 1888, Parker was fed up with having to constantly repair the fountain pens he sold for the John Holland Pen Company, so he did what anybody back then did - he made his own. In 1891, Parker found his first investor, and went on to forge one of the largest pen companies in the world, from a rickety (and presumably ink-stained) shack in Wisconsin.

For decades, Parker was essentially the Mercedes Benz of writing instruments (sort of a Mercedes Penz, if you will). Year after year, Parker continued to innovate and perfect the fountain pen, taking a short break at one point to invent the mechanical pencil. Later, just after his death, Parker (the company) released the Parker 51, “The World’s Most Wanted Pen.” It was in every way revolutionary, technologically advanced, and beautiful.

The most popular fountain pen ever made.

This was a time when perfectly useful pens weren’t sitting around pretty much everywhere. To own a nice, dependable pen was a pretty important thing for a gentleman, like owning a nice car or pocket watch fob or something. If you needed a good pen, you had a “51.”

Even if you were a Nazi.

In 1945, Nazi General Alfred Jodl signed the treaty which ended World War II in Europe. He used, of course, his own trustworthy fountain pen - a Parker 51. Remember, Parker started in Wisconsin. Here we were, in the clutches of war, fighting over who could rule the world, and Parker was a trusted name on both sides.

Also there’s this.

Of course, the American Dream doesn’t end there. Parker (the guy)’s dream of “making a better pen” lived on for decades, until it gave way to the new American Dream, a multinational corporation. In 1993 Parker (the company) was acquired by Gillette, and then in 2000 they were purchased by Newell Rubbermaid, parent company of Sanford, which is now the largest stationery company in the world. Sanford (and Rubbermaid) also owns Sharpie, PaperMate, Liquid Paper, Prismacolor, Waterman, and Uniball. In 2009, Rubbermaid decided to close down Parker’s factory in Janesville, Wisconsin, where Parker (the guy) originally founded the company over 120 years earlier.

Parker (the guy)’s legacy lives on, however, and many excellent pens are still made under the Parker (the name) name. The Sonnet and Duofold continue the legacy of the venerable “51,” and the Jotter, introduced in 1954, is in its 58th year of production. As far as I can tell, that makes the Jotter the longest running cartridge-based ballpoint pen in history. A few weeks ago, I bought my very own.

Its design and construction has changed somewhat since it was first introduced. Today the Jotter primarily comes with a stainless steel cap and button with a plastic or steel barrel and a metal nozzle. Beginning a few years after its introduction, Parker fit the Jotter (in fact all of its pens) with the characteristic Parker Arrow clip. Parker makes a big deal about how the Arrow clip will let everybody you see know that you don’t have just any pen.

That’s one of the most pretentious things I’ve ever heard.

Far more important than the stupid arrow clip is the Jotter’s tungsten carbide writing ball. Introduced in 1957, the “T-Ball” refill was the first of its kind. Pretty much all ballpoints have a similar design today, so the legacy of Parker innovation is right at home.

In the hand the Jotter feels incredibly light, especially compared to similar steel-body retractable pens like the Zebra F-402. That certainly has to do with the fact that the model I have been using features a plastic barrel, but even the all steel model feels just as light. The action of the button is quite heavy compared to other retractable pens (in a good way), and at the risk of sounding pretentious, that satisfying click is the most characteristic feature of the entire pen. It feels louder.

It looks great, too. The smooth curves and brushed steel give the pen some serious elegance. In the world of retractable ballpoints, you really can’t find a classier pen. Faintly etched around the middle seam are the Parker emblem and name, as well as, for some reason, “France.” They’re obviously trying to make the pen seem grander than it is. Let’s face it, Parker was founded in a garage in Wisconsin. It was only in 2009 that Rubbermaid moved the company’s production to France. Aside from the ham-fisted branding, I doubt the French have had much influence over the pen’s classic design.

Take the pen apart, and you get a look at the real Parker legacy, the ink cartridge itself. When the Jotter was introduced, it was the first ballpoint with a serious replaceable cartridge. It originally would last more than five times longer than other ballpoints at the time. Since then, refill cartridges have been standardized and modern industry has perfected their construction, so the “Quinkflow” ballpen refill isn’t as amazing as it once would have been. My pen has the Medium point, but a fine point option is available.

The Jotter’s diminutive size and elegant design do come with a downside, of course. The pen features no rubberized grip or ergonomic finger grooves, and those lovely curves actually mean the spot where you grip the pen is relatively small. It’s nothing you can’t get used to, for sure, but if you’re more familiar with more substantial writing instruments (or you have giant monster hands), you’ll find your fingers cramping up just a bit. I also noticed a few times while using the Jotter that the tip extends from the barrel just a tiny bit less than most other pens. This must sound terribly pedantic, but it is actually a bit disconcerting. Perhaps it’s just me, but there’s something ever so awkward about writing with that tip only half-way out.

These days a ballpoint pen’s ink isn’t terribly startling. A ballpoint’s a ballpoint, certainly as far as most end users should be concerned. The ultimate problem with the Jotter is that it is, in fact, just a ballpoint, and so it is ultimately victim to the problems that beset ballpoint pens. Pretty recently, my Jotter has started doing the thing that most ballpoint pens do at one point or another. Basically, it turns into a sort of embossing pen instead of an ink pen. This is a result of the fact that ballpoints are actually based mainly on luck. The ink will stop flowing over the ball, no matter what kind of carbide it is, and the only marks you get on your paper are the shameful marks of a ballpoint that doesn’t work. In other words, you have a bunch of those “make it write” scribbles in your margins.

It only happens sometimes, but I kind of don’t expect it from something from France.

So since I don’t really have metrics to judge pens, yet, and since this is the first pen I’ve reviewed, it’s hard for me to sum this review up. The Jotter is an excellent pen - perhaps the best ballpoint I’ve used in my entire life. It comes down to a few important questions, though. Sanford has really reduced the ubiquity of Parkers since they bought the company. Maybe it’s a move to make them seem more “prestigious” or maybe they’re just cutting corners. The end result is that it’s supposedly not terribly easy to find Jotters anywhere. I got mine at Office StapleMax or whatever, and there are certainly plenty of Jotters online, so they aren’t actually that difficult to find. The real problem is price. At about $6 per pen, they’re more than twice the cost of a Zebra F-402, which is a pen I used faithfully for years before somebody “borrowed” it a few months ago. Sure, $6 is not terribly much, but is it really worth that much more than the Zebra? I guess I’ll let you know when I review the Zebra.

The other question is one of morality. What has happened to Parker (the legacy)? What was an American - nay, a Worldwide - tradition has become a boutique novelty. Parker (the company) is now a pretentious arm of a faceless conglomerate bent on world domination. Should we disregard the obnoxious “France” rebranding? Should you buy this artificially rare object of groan-inducing pretense, shamelessly abandoning the respectable legacy of an almost forgotten man from American history? Will you buy a Parker Jotter and support this cycle of corporate greed?

Well, no. You’ll buy a Parker Jotter because it’s a really good pen - the stainless steel standard by which all pens shall be judged.

(The Parker ads and the picture of Jodl came to me from Google)

fields.title: How to Ride a Bus
fields.text:
A DenyConformity.com Guide

Welcome to the world of public transportation! So you found yourself wanting to be somewhere, and you came to the conclusion that you had to take the bus. Despair no more! A city bus is a logical place, governed by a strict set of rules. Those rules may seem intimidating to someone who isn’t a professional bus rider. No longer! With this handy pocket guide (if you open it on your smartphone it is, anyway) you can act like one of the bus riding elite.

Fig. 0 - The logo for this guide

Everyone knows that the moment a member of the non-bus-riding community - a Sidewalker, as bus riders call them - sets foot on a bus full of professionals they will be laughed at and mocked with a precision that is unequalled in other areas of professional public interaction. If you have truly exhausted all other methods of traveling to your destination and you cannot think of a way to get there without riding a bus, you cannot step onto the bus looking like you don’t belong. The following steps will not help Sidewalkers turn themselves into professional riders, but they’ll at least be turned into professional fakers.

Step One: Know your Bus
Fig. 1 - The Standard eight-row, two-door Single Decker

A professional bus rider spends years studying the seating layouts, intertia ratings, smell zones, and average speeds of an entire city’s bus armada. Without a lifetime to devote to knowing these minute details, you must do your best to fake this knowledge.

Fig. 2 - The Middle-Hinged Double Single Decker

These diagrams showcase the most standard types of bus employed by cities across the United States. Make yourself familiar with them, to call into your mind as you step onto the bus. When you make your way to a seat with confidence, the scornful eyes of the professionals on the bus will think you’re one of them.

Fig. 3 - Two-door Single Decker Variant: “The Awkward Eye Contact”

Always remember that you can count on a few things being true on every bus you are forced to ride on. First, every bus has wheels. This is something that can be very comforting, because you can know that the wheels on your bus will go round and round all through the town. Unless, of course, the bus breaks down or has a crash. Also, the pigs on the bus go “oink, oink, oink” e-i-e-i-o. Wait, that can’t be right . . .

Fig. 4 - Two-door Single Decker Variant: “The Board of Inquiry”

It is not a guarantee that the bus you are about to enter has the same layout of seats that you might be ready for - or that it has any seats at all. Bus makers get very bored, because making a bus is really boring, so they will change the seating layout for no reason. Because of this, almost every bus you enter will have a completely different seating arrangement.

Fig. 5 - Two-door no-seater Single Decker (“The Cattle Car”)

When standing on a bus - which you will have to do if you find a bus with no seats - remember to hold on to something attatched to the bus, and not the person next to you (see “Do’s and Don’t’s,” below).

Fig. 6 - The McCutcheon Family’s Ford Aerostar

The City picks bus sizes based on the population density of the area they are serving. If you live in a tiny city without many people, you might just have to talk to someone who lives down the street from you and treat their car like the bus. You can have fun making their car filthy, and they can have fun yelling “exact change” at you, and not stopping to pick you up when they see you standing at the corner.

Fig. 7 - The Triple-hinged Tetrabus (nicknamed “The Subway”)

Sometimes a bus isn’t actually a bus. These are called “trains.” They are faster and scarier than a bus, but most of the same rules apply.

Fig. 8 - One-door Magic Single Decker

Many schools employ a bus battalion to ferry students between home and school. Remember that when you see one of these bright yellow affronts to design they will not pick you up. They aren’t there to take you to work even if you have the $2.25 for them - unless you work at school, and you’re 12.

Fig. 9 - The City Omnibus

The word “bus” actually comes from the Olde English “Omnibus” meaning “every smell.” The first bus was built in 1794, as a transportation device for crates of stinky cheese. The actual content of the bus might have changed in the intervening years, but basically everything else is the same - including the smell.

Fig. 10 - The Greyhound

Some forms of bus go long distances, from city to city. Sometimes these are called a Mega Bus, because they beat up smaller vehicles. However, these are not a city bus, and so they are outside the scope of this guide.

Step Two: Behave Like a Pro

You might think that everyone on the bus is drunk. This is only partially true. The reality is that everyone on the bus merely looks drunk. When you first set foot on the bus, you will experience a moment of disorientation, as if your entire world were suddenly racing along at around five miles per hour. That is only the bus, meandering down the street to the next bus stop. Try to maintain your composure as you make you way down the bus aisle, but keep in mind that looking like you’re having trouble keeping your balance is perfectly natural.

Unlike drunk people, however, bus riders follow very strict rules of conduct. If you want to fit in, and keep your trip from being even more worse than it already is, you should stick to these rules, too.

Fig. 11 - Fill as large a space as you can.

This is the most important rule that all Professional Bus Riders follow. You can use your imagination and be creative. Put your feet up, sit diagonally, or bring a giant backpack with you. Bus riders don’t keep score, but if they did, it would be based on how much space you take up. Be the largest person on the bus, and you win!

Fig. 12 - Don’t scoot over unless someone tells you to.

The important distinction here is that you can disregard other passengers who merely ask you to move. The answer is always no.

Fig. 13 - Smell as bad as you can.

It can help if you know you will be having a bus trip in your future, because you can go without bathing or changing your underpants for a few days. What causes the stink is up to you. Some riders keep urine-soaked towels with them so they always have a perfect bus-worthy stench at all times.

Fig. 14 - When someone gets up from a seat in front of you, do not sit in the seat.

By all means, there’s no reason why you should take that empty seat right in front of you, especially if the bus is full of people. If nobody behind you can sit there, why should you?

Fig. 15 - Always get up while the bus is in motion.

It may seem counter-intuitive, but real pros don’t wait until their stop has arrived. Get up from your seat several blocks ahead of your stop, making sure to only move when the bus is moving. This ensures that you cause the biggest disruption as you leave - your other primary goal aside from taking up as much space as possible.

Fig. 16 - When two adjacent seats open up, it’s first come, first served.

Two adjacent empty seats are like a big, delicious Value Meal to bus riders. When someone gets up from a seat, leaving a pair of adjacent seats open, those seats are officially up for grabs. They will become the domain of whoever gets there first, so keep an eye open for these succulent prizes, and grab them before one of those selfish people standing in the aisle get it. Then you can sit on the aisle seat, blocking those whiny Elderly and Infirm from moving in on your domain. Also important: never sit next to someone you are riding the bus with. If you are traveling with a friend, consider sitting a few rows apart, because yelling to each other is much more fun than casually talking to someone sitting next to you.

Fig. 17 - No matter how many people are on the bus, it can always hold more.

First, it goes without saying that if you’re waiting at a bus stop you should make sure you get in front of everybody else waiting at the bus stop, so when the bus stops you get first dibs of any open seats on the bus. When those doors open and you see a solid wall of humanity because the city has cut funding to the bus system so there isn’t enough room for everyone, do not hesitate. Only Sidewalkers do something lame like wait for the next bus. You could be standing there, looking like an idiot, for whole minutes!

Fig. 18 - Maintain the accepted standing zones.

Always stand your ground when you’re standing on a bus. That is, awkwardly stagger your ground, because that is most likely the best you can do with the bus driver constantly slamming on the brakes like they’re trained to do. If more people start to collect in the aisle, you are in no way obligated to make your way farther back, and you especially don’t have to stand in the raised area in the back. Consider it a demilitarized zone.

Fig. 19 - Bring a snack.

Going minutes without eating usually gives most professional bus riders the shakes. Because of this, you should bring a snack along to fit in. As soon as they see you not having withdrawal from McDonald’s, they’ll know you’re not meant to be there. Unshelled sunflower seeds and the smelliest of Italian beef are the best snacks to enjoy on the bus. A good rule of thumb is to ask yourself, “would I eat this thing in the presence of someone else when not on the bus?” If you say no, you’ve found a perfect snack for a crowded bus.

Fig. 20 - Bring the proper entertainment.

Bus Riders don’t read books. A newspaper is good, only because it requires you to keep your arms wide while reading it, helping you take up more space - just remember to leave the newspaper on your seat when you get off the bus. A cellphone is another great option, especially if it has a good speakerphone option. The bus is a great place to make personal phone calls. If you find yourself without anything to do, strike up an argument with the empty seat next to you.

Fig. 21 - Use proper language.

You are on a bus, not an elementary school. If anything, you have an expletive minimum. If you are having a conversation with your friend two rows down, someone on your phone, or the empty seat next to you, feel free to shovel d-, a- and especially f-bombs into your parlance as much as you can. You get extra points if you are sitting next to a child.

Fig. 22 - Disregard the Elderly, the Infirm, and Expectant Mothers

What, are you running a charity? Where do those geezers need to go in such a hurry? Isn’t walking a necessary component of physical rehab, anyway? What, her baby daddy couldn’t borrow his mom’s car for the afternoon? Most Elderly, Infirm, and Expectant Mothers you see on the bus are faking their condition, just so they can cheat and take your seat away from you. Those big walkers and huge bellies? They’re just a ploy so these people can take up as much space as possible. Are you going to let them beat you at what is now your own game? While we’re on the subject, have you noticed the funny symbols on the seats in the front of the bus? That weird picture of a guy with wheels? It’s just there as a joke. Of course you have wheels - you’re on a bus!

Step Three: Do’s and Don’t’s

DO NOT eat anything you find on the bus.

DO NOT stow your bike on the bike rack. Did you smash your bike? What are you doing on the bus?

DO take advantage of the fact that the bus is just really big trash can.

DO assume everybody else on the bus is inferior to you.

DO NOT utilize your lap. Your stuff has as much right to a seat on the bus as you do, and more right than that grumpy-looking person standing in the aisle.

DO always give money to anybody on the bus who asks for it. There’s a strict honor code among Bus Riders, so that guy who needs a couple bucks will definitely get you back.

DO whatever the stinkiest, noisiest person on the bus is doing, because they’re the best at riding a bus, and if you act like them, you’ll get extra respect from the pros.

DO NOT rely on another person for support while the bus is in motion. That person is teetering on the brink of falling over just as much as you are. If you hang on to him, you're just going to make him spill his Salisbury steak.

DO memorize the bus schedules and routes before making any attempt to ride anywhere. You don't want to be 45 minutes into your trip and suddenly realize you're on the number 9 B, which for some reason goes to the opposite side of town from the number 9 A.

DO whatever you can to avoid taking the city bus in the future. They are universally terrible.

Please understand that everything here is a joke and should not be taken seriously. - Shauvon

fields.title: C2E2 2012 A
fields.text:
Just last weekend was the annual Chicago Comics and Entertainment Expo, or C2E2. This is the second year that I've gone, and the first year I went on a Saturday. It's a pretty exciting event, and though it costs $35 ($25 if you buy tickets ahead of time), I think it's worth it. A comic convention is a pretty interesting place. A large number of people are - for this one weekend - free to finally express their nerdy fantasies. It's the only time you can see chubby versions of your favorite movie and comic book characters. I really wish I could have gotten a costume together, because it really is a lot of fun. I did, of course, bring my camera.

C2E2 takes place each year in McCormick Place, just south of downtown. Maybe it was just me, but it seemed much bigger this year. Incidentally, those serious looking guards standing to the right are just dudes in costume - unless C2E2 was being protected by S.H.I.E.L.D. this year.
The first costume we saw, though, was this positively adorable little dude walking into the convention center. Jedi? Nope, Jawa. I looked for him inside, so I could get a picture of his hood up - and buy a new protocol droid - but I couldn't find him.
This guy is great. I enjoyed walking around with Alyson because she could point out all of the Harry Potter references and I could point out all of the Sci-Fi references (like this guy).
The place was absolutely packed. This was my view for most of it. I can't imagine how boring it must be for somebody of normal height. We tried following that Stormtrooper, thinking he would be able to clear a path, but I think it was just a guy in costume.
I was pretty honored that people have already started Cosplaying as District Alpha characters, but Alyson told me they were just Hunger Games people. You still have to give them props for the timeliness of their costumes. So, in the Hunger Games everybody caries an expensive camera?
Even Sith Lords have to stand in line to get an autograph from Anthony Daniels?!
These two dudes spent a lot of time making some Handheld Portable Portal Whatevers, but they don't even have the leg braces. Come on, guys!
This girl and her friends just kept saying 'Abraham Lincoln. Airplane. Raincloud.' Get it!?
Here's a really awesome Gamorrean Guard. He barely made it inside before he was mobbed by photographers, which I guess is to be expected. I later saw him with his mask off, and he was a really sweet looking older guy with a great big bushy beard.
This old costume's still got legs.
You really have to hand it to this guy for the sheer quality of this costume, and his absolute commitment to posing in it. What you have to hand him is, apparently, a cheeseburger.
The cool thing about a general comic convention, as opposed to a Sci-Fi or more specific type of convention, is that all bets are off when it comes to costumes. Any time period, real or imagined, is game.
It's really great that dudes who bought or made Stormtrooper costumes a few years ago are getting bored with them, so they're coming up with fantastic ways to make them fresh.
This picture is great, yes, but what I love is whatever's going on between that chubby dude and the Stormtrooper.
When you wear a costume to a convention, you're going to be in a lot of pictures - that's probably why you do it. The important thing is to really get your pose down. Everybody has their own, and it's fun to watch them strike it over and over as people all around them take pictures from every angle.
This guy was obviously extremely proud of his homemade Tron: Legacy costume. It looked great, and I'm glad his girlfriend humored him and put on that little number to stand by his side. A comic book convention is a drastically different experience for a girl like that.
Some costumes are always popular, like this kind of awkward example of a Joker / Harley Quinn combo. It's kind of awkward because he's a pretty great cartoon-style Joker, and she's a pretty great Video Game style Quinn. They don't really go together. This leads me to a bit of an aside. I was looking through the pictures I took last year. They mostly weren't interesting enough to post here, except for the following one:
A the time I was more interested in those awesome The Monarch Henchmen, but upon looking back at this, I recognized that Joker. Either he found a much hotter girlfriend in the intervening year, or she got (justifiably) sick of wearing that ugly but thematically appropriate Harley Quinn costume. Joker needs to update his style to match. Or they could, you know, find a new costume pair already.
That Ferrigno-era Hulk was pretty sweet. I try to get more candid shots of people in costume, which is tough with my giant camera. I think it's fun to see the Hulk looking at pictures on his friend's camera, or Batman trying to eat a soft pretzel.
This chick had some Hell of great makeup. She's going to be blue for weeks, probably.
This Catwoman was getting tons of attention everywhere she went. She was obviously loving every minute of it, because who wouldn't? When you're in a giant room full of chubby dudes, this is kind of unfair, really.
Dr. Doom was in a big group with the Catwoman, an Ares and a lady Dr. Who. This picture shows the contrast between attention that he was getting compared to his Catwoman friend.
If I were at a comic book convention dressed as Godzilla, I would just walk around knocking stuff over until they kicked me out. How can you not do that?
I got the feeling that these dudes were being paid to wear those beer costumes, but they were still pretty cool.

That's just a taste of the costumes that were on display. One popular costume this year was 'chick with giant hammer.' I'm not sure what that was about, but I saw several seemingly normally dressed girls with big (like three foot wide) hammers walking around.

I have a lot more cool stuff to show from C2E2 this year, though, so stay tuned!

fields.title: C2E2 2012 B
fields.text:
Yesterday we looked at some of the interesting costumes that were to be found at C2E2 this year. That's not the only reason go to a big nerd convention, though. It's also fun to check out all the neat stuff people are trying to sell.

For example, this awesome poster. I was about to dismiss these things as pretty derivative and uninteresting, but then I saw this one, and thought it was pretty great.
This is a common sight at a comic convention, obviously. If you're into comics, tables and tables of old comic books would be pretty exciting. To anybody else, it's pretty boring. It's best to go to an event like this with one specific thing in mind that you want to get. Otherwise you had better go with lots of cash. It can be pretty tempting to buy lots of stuff - if you're into this kind of stuff.
However, everybody is into this stuff. If you ever have occasion to buy some Hi-Chew candy from Japan, do it. They're kind of like Starbursts, except ten times better. I bought $20 worth, because I have been dreaming of them ever since last C2E2.
The problem with nerd conventions is that there are tons of booths like this Toy Cave, but they're all clogged with nerds. You just have to resign yourself to the fact that you can't really walk through and look at everything. I tried to examine the traffic flows to figure out what works and what doesn't - in case I need to make another how-to guide - but there really is no rhyme or reason to it. You just have to move as fast as you can, and try be as small an obstruction as possible if you stop to look at a vintage toy or poster or Catwoman.
The problem is that there are no organized traffic areas. In this picture, which is about as average a sight as you could find, there are people standing in every possible direction - in what should be a flowing traffic area. I get really irked by crowds not making any effort to maintain proper traffic flow patterns. I will resist the urge to get into details about the way crowds should work.
Pepsi seems to have some new version of Pepsi every time I go to a thing like this. This year, they were giving out free samples of Pepsi Next, which I guess is the next Pepsi or something. I wonder what they'll call the next next.
This booth for some motorcycle garage really went nuts with the people dressed up like zombies. I would think that people who work on and ride motorcycles would shy away from things depicting mutilated corpses, but whatever. I also don't think a zombie would have the coordination to walk on stilts like this chick, but also whatever. Edit - I've been told that this was a booth for the dungeon of doom haunted house located in Zion IL. That must be one terrifying haunted house.
This other dude at the same booth was happy to pose for a picture holding that ax to somebody's throat. If you look carefully, you'll catch a glimpse of the booth that shared a wall with these motorcycle zombies. It was for the Bristol Renaissance Faire. It's juxtapositions like that which make these things great fun. Heavy metal was blaring on one side, and ridiculous fake British accents were being shouted on the other.
Yes, this is a thing. We didn't buy anything here.
You really have to just become desensitized to inaccurate depictions of women at these things. This was one of many tables covered in stuff like this.
Sure, a $190 Magic card. It doesn't even seem that good.
Here's Computer Engineer Barbie. She's got some chic glasses, a really cool shiny jacket, and a sweet pink laptop. Yup, that's me in a nutshell. What's she working on, there? Some Java applets? Debugging some MVC application? No, she's looking at a picture of . . . herself. Also she has an iPhone attached to the back of her hand.
This booth had some really sweet video game shirts, but I got pretty annoyed when I saw this one. Nobody uses the Quick Fix! I tried to explain that to Alyson, but for some reason she didn't care. You see, in Team Fortress 2, the Medic has a different version of the Medic Gun which - hey, where are you going?
This is supposed to be a giraffe, I guess. This is kind of the exact opposite of a giraffe, really.
There's always a corset booth. I am not passing judgement. Seriously, though.
When I rounded a corner and saw this, some primal, instinctual part of me panicked for a short moment. It was just a disembodied head, though, which - frankly - makes this kind of a stupidly easy thing to make.
I've seen this master collection Megatron a few times, and boy would I love one. I'll be damned if I'm going to pay that much, though.
This was a child's t-shirt, but I still wanted one.
Oh, no problem, there's a whole column of Adventure Time shirts in this t-shirt tower, right between the Futurama column and the Family Guy column. Last year, I was kind of freaked out by how much Big Bang Theory stuff there was. There was still plenty this year, but thankfully it wasn't so prevalent. Do actual nerds really watch that show, or are the BBT shirts just designed to make fun of outsiders trying to look like one of us?
A couple of women were selling these things really hard. I felt sorry for them because these things are pretty dumb.
There's always a sword booth at these things. If you're looking for a corset, a sword, a pair of steampunk goggles, or a creepy Japanese wig, go to a comic convention.

These pictures can't really do a convention justice, of course. There's a certain . . . quality that you just can't get visually. It's a certain olfactory quality. Let's just call it . . . Eau De Weeb. Thankfully there are enough normal people (in Big Bang Theory t-shirts) who kind of help bring the average BO levels up to a bearable level. Anyway, there's one more set of pictures to go, so come back tomorrow to see more!

fields.title: C2E2 2012 C
fields.text:
There are two good reasons to go to a comic convention. You could go to show off your sweet Batman Villain costume, or you could go to spend a bunch of money to complete your Transformers poster collection. However, if you think that's the only reason to go to a nerd expo, you'll be missing out on one of the most interesting things - people watching.

This was on the way from our car to the convention center. This guy's really doing a great job at being a Joker.
This booth was a real gem for checking out nerds being, well, nerds. Who would have thought that girls desperately seeking attention by dressing (and then undressing) as video game characters would be really popular in a room full of socially deprived video game obsessed dudes? Actually, at this moment, the girls were waving and smiling at some children that were walking by. Feel free to discuss that among yourselves.
Just down the way, a couple of the girls from the Burlesque booth were walking around handing out fliers. You can't see them, because they're behind that wall of dudes.
I remember this R2D2 from last year. He just wanders around the floor checking out the cool stuff, just like anybody else. It's actually a pretty awesome thing, to be looking at some comic books and have this apparently autonomous robot just wander by.
I think he just wanted to get through, but a solid ring of people gathered to watch him.
He noticed my sweet camera, and posed for me. This picture is actually a lot better than you think. Have you figured it out, yet?
Hey, what's that thing? I knew robots weren't real!
Alyson and I were sitting on the floor, sharing a soft pretzel, when I saw an opportunity to get a hot Gamorrean Guard upskirt pic.
The Mountain Dew bottle is a great touch.
There were quite a few Assassin's Creeds at the expo. This one wasn't doing a terribly good job at blending. Nerd joke!
These guys were pretty cool, and this is a good example of one of those poses I talked about in my first set of pictures. I tried taking a few pictures, but the dude on the right had his eyes closed in all of them.
Some Stormtroopers were marching around the place holding random people at blasterpoint and checking for credentials. They were looking for some lanyards people could buy to enter themselves into a special raffle. It seemed like a lot of fun, and it was neat to watch kids getting fake harassed by fake stormtroopers.
This guy was a really big fan of Catwoman, or at least of boobs. This is the same guy you can see in the other picture I posted of this Catwoman taking a picture of her with his phone, while his son looks on awkwardly.
Here's a stormtrooper carrying some of those special lanyards. He wasn't exactly walking with the bearing of a stormtrooper. I think it had been a long day.
Here's Catwoman, again, standing next to her Lady Who friend. That chubby Batman had wandered up and started a fake argument with her. It was kind of funny, but also kind of sad. He was desperately trying to flirt any way he could, and he wasn't doing a very good job. It was all in good fun, though, and exactly the sort of communal experience that these events are great for. Everybody's a friend here.
Batman went to talk to those Asian Mario twins. Catwoman was obviously still attracting attention just to the left.
Only at a comic convention can you get a picture of a My Little Pony girl talking to some nervous nerds while a steampunk dude chats with a guy in full modern combat gear (complete with skull mask) in the background.
Also, whatever the heck these dudes were. They were yelling stuff at Godzilla, who was just standing there, probably as confused as the rest of us. Are those guys the Insane Clown Posse?
This guy was getting a bit of rest off to the side of the place, but when I started taking a picture, he still went into pose mode. These people are really committed to their craft.
These were almost certainly promotional, just from the sheer quality of these costumes, but they were really incredible.
Just outside the convention, this girl had to explain to that guy what exactly she was. I'm still not exactly sure what she's supposed to be, but I bet that guy would have talked about anything just to have the opportunity to talk to a chick in a skintight bodysuit.
I just really like this picture a lot.
Only at a comic convention . . .

fields.title: Building a Web Server
fields.text:
So it's been over two years since I started thinking about getting my very own Web Server, and almost two years since the last time I posted here about it. Needless to say, I haven't just forgotten about it in that time. Turn the way-back machine to two years ago, then...

When last I mentioned this project, I was mired in the difficult process of convincing my Internet Service Provider to get me set up with a static IP address. It started to seem like it wasn't going to work terribly well, but I decided to go ahead with the project, anyway. One glorious day, I got on the bus to head out to the local Microcenter to buy a pile of computer bits.

Microcenter: a magical place.

Microcenter is like Newegg.com, except that you don't have to wait a few days to get anything. They have almost anything you could want in the way of technology or computer bits, and for a lot of stuff their prices are actually better than online. It's a great place to go on a Saturday Morning to spend hundreds and hundreds of dollars. Later that day, I got a bunch of dudes together to play Twilight: Imperium, so I'm pretty sure this was the nerdiest day of my life.

I spent a good while browsing the bits at Microcenter, picking out the perfect components for my new server. I decided not to go crazy and actually build a real server. That would be just too expensive and far more powerful than I needed. These days, a basic budget computer (with plenty of hard drive space) is actually perfectly capable of any average home server task. Armed with this knowledge (it was more of a hope than actual knowledge at the time), I got together parts that I hoped would be super stable, power efficient, and inexpensive.

Efficiency is the name of the game with a server, not just in choosing the components themselves, but also in getting absolutely every unnecessary piece out of the way. Almost all desktop and laptop computers are air-cooled, so all of the components rely on fresh air moving over them to keep them from overheating (which is when things break). When building a computer, you really have to pay attention to airflow, and make sure that air can easily get from one side of the case to the other. Any wires inside the case can get in the way of that airflow, so it's best to get rid of anything you don't need. On my server, then, I wanted to get rid of everything but the bare necessities. I didn't want any removable disk drives, unnecessary power cables, or expansion cards of any sort. I knew this thing would need to be on 24/7, so it would have to be at peak form to run as long as possible without any problems.

I started with the case, which needed to be able to keep the thing cool and quiet through constant operation. I chose this CM Storm Scout. It's a mid-tower, so it isn't ridiculously huge, but it has plenty of fans and vents for airflow. I have a Cooler Master case for my primary PC, and it has worked very well, so I was sure this would be up to the task. Computer case boxes are always really silly. This isn't some sort of stealth bomber, it's a budget-level computer case.
Here's the back of the case box. Again, this isn't even a very top of the line case, so it really isn't that cool at all, even to nerds.
The power supply is perhaps the most important component, because it will need to maintain performance and efficiency while being powered on all the time. I would have loved to go with a high-end Antec or PC Power and Cooling supply, but I saved a bit of money with this Cooler Master unit. 600 Watts would be more than enough, so it won't be struggling with a lot of strain. It's also modular, which means I only have to use the wires that I need. Also, it's eXtreme, so how could it be bad?
The hard drive(s) are perhaps the most important component, because they would need to safely and securely hold lots of important data. The best way to do things is to have the Operating System on one drive, and have another, much larger drive for storage. I had some old Seagate 320 Gigabyte SATA drives laying around, so I wanted to save money by using one of those for the Operating System.
I did not want to cut corners with the storage drive, though, so I bought these Western Digital one terrabyte drives. I've had nothing but the best experiences with Western Digital in the past, so I knew I could trust these. Yes, I bought two of them, so I could put them in a mirrored RAID array.

RAID, or Redundant Array of Independent Drives, takes multiple hard drives and through the power of magic turns them into much more powerful drives. In striped mode, the two drives get turned into one super fast drive with the capacity of both smaller drives put together. It's super fast that way, but also really dangerous because if one drive fails, you lose all your data. In mirrored mode, any data written to the array is identically saved to both drives. It's not any faster than a single drive, and you have to pay for two drives to get the capacity of one, but it's super safe. Modern Hard Drives rely on lots of mechanical do-dads that can go catastrophically wrong at any moment, and if they do, any data on the drive is unceremoniously destroyed. If you mirror the drive, though, one of the drives can fail and the other will still have the data. Getting a mirrored RAID array is the best way to cover my butt in the event of hardware failure.

The motherboard is perhaps the most important component, because it needs to have a lot of the features I need while being super stable. I always go with ASUS components where possible, and every time I've gotten a motherboard by another company I've regretted it. This particular board has built-in video (so I wouldn't need a separate video card), built-in RAID (so I wouldn't need a separate RAID card), and it's one of the first motherboards to have onboard USB 3, which will come in handy in the future, I'm sure. Also, it has xtreme design, so it should go with the power supply I picked out.
I went to Cooler Master, once again, for the CPU heatsink. They make really dependable cooling products, and I really needed something I could depend on for the CPU heatsink, which is probably the most important component of the entire system. The processor needs to run constantly at peak efficiency without overheating, so by using a heatsink that would be perfectly suited to a processor much more powerful than the one I chose, I shouldn't have any problems.
I cut a bit of a corner with the RAM, I'll admit it. I would have loved to use some RAM I had laying around (with those hard drives), but the motherboard and processor I chose needed DDR 3, so I had to get some new stuff. Though I went with a cheap option, I didn't get a cheap-o brand. I got a mid-spec 4GB kit, with two 2GB modules. I figured that if I decided the server needed some more RAM, I could always just get another one (the motherboard supports four modules), and bring the capacity up to 8 GB.
So here's the processor I've told you so much about. Honestly, I wasn't as concerned about the CPU as I was about some of the other bits, so I made my choice based on price and potential heat. I went with a dual-core, figuring that a quad would just be unnecessary for these purposes. Getting a processor that was too powerful would only use more electricity and generate more heat inside the case. I went with AMD because Phenom processors are way cheaper than their Intel counterparts, and by getting a Black Edition I could control the clock speed myself. Usually this means you can overclock the processor to get a bit more power out of it, but I actually wanted to underclock it. That way it would be extra stable, cool, and efficient.

All told, the whole thing cost about $800. Quite a mini-Christmas, indeed. Speccing out the parts on Newegg came out to about the same amount, so I was pretty content with my decision to buy it at Microcenter. The bus ride home wasn't the most comfortable in the world, however.

Computer Porn: Putting the Bits Together
Here's the case out of its silly box. Aesthetics were totally unimportant, because this will probably just live in a closet or something, but this case has a few features I like. Having a window might seem like a really stupid thing, but it's actually really handy for quickly glancing at the inside of the case. You can see if there's a lot of dust on the CPU heatsink (which is really bad for airflow), or quickly see if anything is amiss. I also really like how the handle / style whatever business up top shelters the fan on top of the case. I can set things on top of the case and it won't obstruct air flow to the important top fan.
Here's a closeup of the heatsink on the motherboard chipset. Whatever, ASUS.
Those square things in front of that dumb heatsink structure are solid-state capacitors, which run much more efficiently and with a much lower failure rate than the standard cylindrical type capacitors. They're pretty much standard on ASUS motherboards these days, but it's yet another component increasing the efficiency of this machine.
Another cool feature of the motherboard was these little switches, which let you toggle the CPU overclocking. It's a feature you may never need, but the one moment you do could mean the difference between a computer that works and one that doesn't, so it's good to have. The little button lets you turn the computer on without it even being inside a case, which can be handy for debugging purposes.
This is the CPU, sitting upside-down on its box. When I got it out, I realized with horror that one of the pins was ever so slightly bent. You can just barely see it toward the right side of the array of pins. This could have meant disaster for the build, because I'm pretty sure all those pins are important. The cool thing about buying this stuff in a store was that I could easily return or exchange it if anything was broken, which is a time consuming process with Newegg.
I ever so carefully bent the pin back to vertical with the end of a flathead screwdriver. Back in the day, Processors didn't come with these big aluminum heat spreaders on top, and you could actually see the processor die and some other bits on top. It's much easier to install a heatsink now, though, which is why they do it this way.
To judge the efficiency of a heatsink, you can look at the bottom of it, where it contacts the processor. The more polished the bottom - and if it's made of more conductive copper instead of aluminum - the better it is. This little thing needs to make as perfect a seal with the processor as possible, to transfer as much of the heat away as it can. You should also, of course, use a quality thermal paste.
And then after some stuff happened, the computer was done. I guess I didn't feel like taking pictures of the actual process. I really need to get my standards higher. Anyway, here's the server sitting next to my computer. Don't let the relative size of this thing fool you, it's actually pretty big - it's just that my computer is ridiculously huge. As you can kind of see through the window, there's only really one bundle of wires going through the interior of the case - the 12 volt connector which goes straight to the middle of the motherboard. There's no video card, no CD drive, and only a few tiny SATA connectors going to the hard drives.

So for about $800, I built myself a pretty decent home server. Only time would tell how good it would be at actually doing server tasks, but that's all part of the adventure. Next - probably in about two years - I'll show how the machine is set up on the software side of things, and then we can get into what I've actually used this thing for.
