fields.title: Prepare for your Future with DenyConformity.com!
fields.text:
Hey, students, what’s up?

If that’s got your attention, you might just be perfectly suited to an action packed internship at the office(s) of DenyConformity.com!

What will our intern be responsible for? Why, all sorts of great, exciting, and broadening work around the office. We have lots of organizing to be done here! Sorting stuff out - you’ll be an expert in no time. Collating? Yeah, you’ll do some collating. We need somebody switch out our Futurama DVD’s when we’ve watched all of the episodes on them. Also, come to think of it, you would be responsible for bringing us coffee. I mean, just thinking out loud, really. DenyConformity.com Interns will do all kinds of cool stuff, in addition to the coffee thing which I just thought of on the spot. Coffee is just a part of the job. Everybody keeps talking about coffee - that’s why I bring it up - and we are totally just as much into coffee as every other productive adult. That’s why we need an Intern. Some people have never really had much coffee before, I guess, so they aren’t sure what the big deal is - but not me! I’m all about coffee, yessir.

Oh, please note that we will not be calling our interns “sir.” You will be calling me “sir.” I just want to be clear on that.

We are looking to hire up to one intern for the Fall 2012 semester, to start immediately. We have only one position available, so get your applications in today! While you’re at it, If you stop by to drop off your application in person, you might as well bring me a coffee. I mean, if you’re going to be in the area anyway. Any kind is fine. Obviously, I know what kind of coffee somebody would bring a guy, but I want to see if you know.

Applicant must be a go-getter, because they’ll be go-getting a lot of stuff. Self starters need not apply; it makes me uncomfortable when things start themselves. Forward thinkers are much preferred over those for whom time is not linear. I’ll give perfectionists a try, because it takes balls to lie so blatantly to somebody’s face. If you’re physically weak, that’s pretty great, because one of your duties will be to lose to me at arm wrestling, anyway. Applicant must be capable of laughing at jokes they don’t find funny.

Knowledge of Team Fortress 2 is a plus. Applicant must own his or her own computer capable of playing Team Fortress 2. Applicant should not be obnoxiously good at Team Fortress 2.

We don’t need someone with Ruby or Flash experience. We don’t need someone with teaching experience. We don’t need someone with travel experience. We don’t need someone with driving experience. I can’t have somebody around here making me look bad. If you think you’re here to show how good you are at stuff I don’t know you can just get the Hell out.

An applicant needs enough proficiency with web design paradigms that they can keep up a conversation about it, but still be inexperienced enough to be able to think I’m really cool for being able to do stuff. In fact, a strong proficiency in anything is only going to make you seem like you’re trying too hard. Be good enough to get something hacked together, not so good that people would be like, “jeez, look at that show-off.” This is, of course, unless you’re really good at making coffee.

Bring to your interview between three and five good ideas for stuff to write about on the Internet. It’s probably best if you aren’t too terribly attached to them. Also, we’ll need some references on your coffee making ability, preferably from anybody who really didn’t like coffee until you made it for them.

Please be prepared to answer the following questions at your interview:

1. “What would you say is your strongest?”

2. “How long did you stay in your last position (before you got tired)?”

3. “Why or how did you choose to wear that particular shirt today?”

We will not ask you any of these questions in the Interview, but if you aren’t prepared for them, we will know. Bring a couple copies of your resume, and seven references - Star Wars, not professional.

After extensive negotiations with local Universities, we can now officially provide you with class credit in “please stop contacting us.” You will have to deal with the paperwork yourself, though, because they aren’t returning my calls anymore. I’m not sure how many credit hours we’re talking about, here, but you’ll be doing stuff for me every day. Just in one semester we’re looking at several hundred hours. I mean, every day you’ll at least be working long enough to make some coffee. That’s like - what - two, three hours a day?

Oh yeah, this is an unpaid internship only - sorry. If hired, however, you will be able to dig through one of two sacks of cables and take whatever you want. Actually, if you know anybody who would want a sack or two of cables, let me know.

Either email your applications to internship@denyconformity.com, or send them directly to:

Back window,

1983 Honda Civic parked outside Daley Plaza

Chicago, IL 60602

It’s the one with the “Oh yeah!” bumper sticker

Respond to the following prompts, in as many words as you see fit:

Name:
Email address:
Cut of beef (Flank, ground, etc):
Last 4 digits of a number you made up:
Preferred occupation:
School of attendance:
Perfect Sunday:
One thing you wish you could take back:
One thing you wish you could take forward:
Coffee making proficiency (1 - 5, 5 being “really great”):
Coffee making experience (1 - 5, 5 being “never done it”):
Suggestions for making good Coffee:
Thank you:

Please rate the following sentences based on how much you agree with them (1 is “strongly disagree” and 5 is “strongly agree”):

“I really enjoy coffee.”
“I would rather make coffee for others than drink it myself.”
“I often find myself fantasizing about ways to improve how I make coffee.”

Finally, please sign (and print) your name.

Thank you, students, for taking the time to apply, and good luck!

fields.title: DenyConformity.com Redesign Journal part 4
fields.text:
This is part three (well, technically part four) of an ongoing series about the redesign of this website. Spoiler alert: the new design has been live for three weeks. I originally meant for this ongoing thing to actually go on as I was working on the new site and be sort of a teaser for the new design. Now that the new design is live, though, this will just have to serve as more of an ongoing discussion. Think of it as the audio commentary track for the Internet.

So far in these posts I have talked about the way the site came about, and some of the quirks and problems in the old design. Today I want to discuss some of my thoughts on Web Theory. Just what is the Internet? What is a website? What is DenyConformity.com, and how does it fit into the world?

The old (not the old-old, but the new-old) version of this site.

One major problem with the Internet is its lack of tangibility. We know what a book is and a magazine makes perfect sense, but what is a website? Books, magazines, and other more physical things are limited by the nature of what they are. For example, a book has text on pages, magazines are a certain size, and a TV show has a pretty specific box (figuratively and literaly) that it has to fit in. A website doesn’t really have anything to conform to (hey, that’s like the name of this site!). There’s no limit to the design, content, platform, format, or audience that a website can have. Yes, that’s what makes the Internet great, but that’s beside the point.

The problem is that we need better terms. We can’t just call something a website just like you can’t go around bragging about your classic muscle car by telling people you have a “vehicle.” Think about everything that counts as a website. That old Hanson fan page from 1997 is a website. Homestarrunner.com is a website. Google Docs is a website. Facebook is a website. Engadget is a website. Is there anything that is common between any of those things, aside from some underlying technology and the fact that they all run in a web browser?

We are going to leave this page up, but stop working on it. The run-off of this page is Hanson Heaven! it will be updated as often as possible. Come and visit! (jenilynn.tripod.com)

We have different kinds of websites, then. Google Docs is a web application. Facebook is a social network. Engadget is a technology news blog. We have a whole new vocabulary to describe all this stuff. It just isn’t enough, though. Go to your parents and try to explain to them what Homestar Runner is - or Twitter, or Tumblr - in a way that isn’t essentially just saying “it’s a really interesting website place.”

The Internet is almost by definition a lack of format. Is it even possible, then, to come up with terminology to describe what we do with it? More importantly, does it even matter?

The Internet doesn’t operate like any other medium. It’s not like a library, where you browse through great shelves of content. You don’t just go to Internet and click on Interesting Website Place. It’s like a vast, featureless subdivision, where every house looks the same from the outside, and you can’t walk in any front doors. The only way into a house is by going through another house. You don’t just walk up to a website, you have to be sent there.

How did you get to this page? Did you click a link on Facebook or Twitter? Did you stumble upon this page? Did you come here from the RSS feed or the main timeline? How many of you typed “http://www.denyconformity.com/post/389/Design_Journal_4” into your browser? Certainly very few, if anybody did that. Even the most pure type of traffic - those people who hear about this site and type DenyConformity.com into their address bar - are still only going here because they’ve heard about the site from some other source. No traffic on the Internet is original - it’s all second-hand.

Because of this, the concept of location doesn’t matter on the Internet anymore. Your browser’s address bar is becoming less and less necessary - a vestigial organ which only exists to comfort our need for a physical metaphor. Look at Google Chrome, where the address bar isn’t really an address bar anymore. It’s a search bar, where you can just type “interesting website place” and then you get Google links to anywhere you might want to go.

So who cares what a website is? It doesn’t matter what DenyConformity.com is, because all that matters is the content. The biggest surge of traffic I’ve gotten since the new site went live was last weekend, when somebody posted a picture from my “How to Ride a Bus” guide on their Tumblr page. There was no “check out this interesting website place.” There was just a link, and that link went right to a particular piece of content. People read that content, and then they continued on to some other link to some other piece of content.

The way I see it, there are three types of websites. There are the sites I use (Google Docs, for example), there are the sites I watch (stuff like Facebook or email, which I regularly check for updates), and there are the sites I consume. I’ll read an article here or watch a funny video there. DenyConformity.com is that kind of website - a thing to be consumed. It’s the magazine you pick up while waiting for an appointment. It’s the book you read while you’re on the bus. It’s the art you hang on your wall. DenyConformity.com is here for you to take in. That’s all. Maybe it will enlighten you, or maybe it will make you laugh, but it has only one goal: to be interesting. All I deliver is regular content that I find interesting, and that’s exactly what DenyConformity.com is here for.

Anyway, that’s why I just call DenyConformity.com “a really interesting website place.”

fields.title: A Zebra Three-Way
fields.text:
A(nother) Pen Review.

I believe that everybody should have one good pen. You should keep a dependable ballpoint in your pocket for situations when you need to jot down some notes or sign a receipt. It’s as necessary, I feel, as your wallet and keys. Through most of my college career, for me that pen was a Zebra F-402. They come in a two-pack, which is customary at Zebra. I’m not sure where the first one ended up, lost to the annals of time. The other stuck with me through quite a few adventures, until just a few months ago when I let somebody borrow it. If you take nothing else away from this post, you should at least learn that if you have a pen you like, you should never let somebody borrow it. Needless to say, that old dependable 402 and I will never cross paths again.

Last week, I was out at the grocery store, and I passed one of those office supply stores - I think it was a Paperclipz (the z in their logo is a paperclip!). After using this Parker Jotter for a few weeks, I figured I might as well get some new pens to have something to officially compare it to.

I got a whole herd of Zebras.

I won’t go into a bunch of detail about who Zebra is, because it’s not as interesting as Parker (the company). They’re a division of another company called Zebra, which is probably a division of another company called Zebra. Zebra (one of them, anyway) makes a bunch of different products, like toner and markers. Basically, if it can totally ruin your Mom’s towels, they make it. Zebra has been around since 1982, so they don’t have quite the same legacy as Parker (the legacy), but they were founded as an already wholly owned subsidiary of a corporation, so they at least haven’t lost any legacy, either.

Zebra makes a pen called the F-301, which which has the awkwardly ambiguous nickname, “The Original.” It can’t be the original retractable ballpoint pen, because Parker was making them for decades before Zebra (any of them) existed. It can’t even be Zebra’s original pen, because why would they have called it the 301?

Anyway, Zebra specializes in stainless steel bodied ballpoints and Mechanical Pencils. I’m focusing on their main fleet of ballpoints.

Welcome to Pens-ilvania
Today’s subjects: “The Original” F-301, “The Gel” G-301, and “The Aforesaid” F-402.

The problem with Zebra is that I’m not sure why they have a “fleet” of ballpoints. Ballpoints are workhorses, purely for taking down notes or writing checks. They lack the smooth uninterrupted lines of felt-tips, the fine, even points of rollerballs, and the visceral grace of fountains. Everybody needs a ballpoint, but you only need one. Why, then, does Zebra have an entire line of them? Where is the market for all of these things?

Zebra has the original 301, the nicer 402, and then the unnecessarily expensive 701. I’m skipping the 701, because I’m not part of the 1%, but the others are too similar to both exist. They’re both stainless steel, and they have exactly the same ink and cartridge (so on paper they’re identical). Is the 301 for the ever-so-slightly less wealthy? Do people buying pens think they don’t deserve a 402? It doesn’t make sense to me.

In fact, for numerous reasons, there’s no reason to ever consider an F-301 at all. I won’t waste too much time analyzing it. It’s the bad kind of light, where it just feels cheap. The textured plastic grip is uncomfortable, and the click action is perfectly generic. At the Paperclipz, a pair of 301s was only $1.20 cheaper than a pair of 402s. Just get a medium fries with lunch, and get the 402.

The F-402 isn’t usually this out of focus.

The 402 is a much better pen. It’s heavier than the 301 (or a Jotter), so it feels more substantial. It doesn’t have any subtle curves (or the pretentious arrow clip), and even in spite of that huge rubber grip it’s pretty spartan. It’s a no nonsense writing utensil, and there’s nothing wrong with that. It’s probably because I used one for so long, but it’s more comfortable to me than the Parker. That shouldn’t matter to you, because that’s purely an opinion and there’s no reason for you to be subject to mine. Still, it’s worth noting that when I go to grab a pen in the morning, of these four (including the Parker), I seem to always go for the 402. The 402’s action is somewhere between the chincy click of the 301 and the heavy “cachunk” of the Jotter. It’s not as satisfying as the Jotter, but I feel more comfortable clicking the 402 because I’m not afraid it will wake up my neighbors.

Just imagine it without the “gel” icon, and this picture can also be for the F-301.

The other pen I picked up looks just like the 301. Okay, so it is a 301, but this one has a G instead of an F. I’m not sure what the F stands for, but the G apparently stands for “Gel.” It has an identical body to the 301, and other than the “gel” badge, they’re completely indistinguishable. That’s a mark against the G-301. Everything I said about the F-301 is true about the G-301, except that since the G-301 has slightly different internal mechanisms, its action feels even more chincy. Also, the G-301 was only $4.99 at Paperclipz, which is yet another reason why you should never buy an F-301.

The 10th Circle of Gel

I wanted to pick up a gel pen, not just because somebody recommended the G-301, but because gel is pretty popular and I wanted to do a side-by-side comparison to regular ink. The differences are quite interesting.

Gel ink has a few unique properties. It’s water-based, as opposed to the dye-alcohol paste in standard ballpoints. This means it’s actually more environmentally friendly than standard ink. You would think this would be more common knowledge, since everybody is obsessed with the environment these days. Because of how gel works, you can get a wide range of wacky colors, which is why you can buy hot pink and electric yellow gel pens. Gel ink is more opaque than regular ink, which makes it thicker and darker, and it can supposedly be used on a wider range of mediums - including stuff that isn’t absorbent, like paper or your Mom’s towels. Gel ink will take longer to fade than regular ink, so if you want to sign some official documents or do some other sort of archival thing, you should use gel. Gel will not, however, last as long in a pen, because it is less efficient than standard ink. You might need to buy as many as eight refills to the G-301 to keep up with a single F-301 cartridge. Gel supposedly also will “clump” more and cause breaks in your lines, since the gel doesn’t coat the titular ball as evenly as standard ink will. Finally, gel uses something called a liquid stopper, which can evaporate. When it does, there’s nothing keeping the gel inside anymore, and it will get all over your mom’s towels.

There are some other more technical things about gel, but those are the basics. How does it compare in the real world, though?

The Write Stuff

In the world of pens, ballpoints are the blue collar workers. They can’t be expected to do anything but the most basic of pen on paper action. That’s not to say they aren’t good for anything, just that they’re never going to be held in as high regard as felt for artists or fountains for writers. Because of this, ballpoint pens have some important features that make them special. Generally you can be pretty cruel to the tip of a ballpoint, and it won’t be destroyed as easily as a felt-tip or a fountain nib. They’re perfectly suited to hang out in your pocket, waiting for their time to be useful.

I did a series of tests to compare the strengths of these ballpoint pens, on standard college-ruled paper - I figure it’s a pretty common media for ballpoints. I then scanned the pages for analysis. These tests are by no means scientific, but I hope they will be a reasonable facsimile of real-world anecdotal evidence.

The first test I looked at was a fill test. I wanted to see how well the ink would fill an area, and how it would look afterwards.

Test 1: the Fill Test

Again, the F-301 and the F-402 have the exact same ink, so they should be pretty identical here. Interestingly, the Parker ink seems nicer to my naked and admittedly inexperienced eye. It’s a warmer black, and it has a better sheen to it. Here you can see the higher opacity of the gel ink showing its colors (literally).

In a similar test, I ran the pens over a fill made by another pen.

Test 2: The Overlap Test

The 402 and 301 blend together here, which is to be expected. However, you can see how the warmer Parker ink shows up on top of the Zebra ink. The gel is again a darker and more solid color.

Next was a far more important test - the smear test. As a left-handed writer, smearing is an eternal problem for me. I want a brand of ink that will smear the least as I’m taking notes in my various notepads and journals. I drew a thick swatch and smeared it with my thumb, and then did the same with a single line. Then I drew a line and counted to five before smearing it, to see how quickly the ink dries.

Test 3: the Smear Test

The gel suddenly loses its appeal. Since it’s water-based, it smears much more readily than regular ink. You can see how the gel “globbed” at the end of the last line. A bit more ink was absorbed into the page at the end of the line, where I stopped writing. The other three pens seem pretty similar, but thanks to the power of computers I could get a bit more information.

Smear Test modified in Photoshop

Quite interesting. Here you can see just how thoroughly each line is smeared. The Jotter seems to smear just a tiny bit more than the Zebra ink. The 402 also seems to be a tiny bit more smeared than the 301. This might simply be due to tiny differences in the pressure I used to write them. However, I don’t think it’s unreasonable to assume that the rubber grip gave me a tiny bit more power in the 402.

It’s interesting how the smears are kind of striped. Either the smear streaks are a result of an irregularity in the pens’ balls, or it’s the pattern of my thumbprint. Remember how I said this wouldn’t be scientific?

Another important thing about a pen is how much pressure you need to write. This is where ballpoints have a disadvantage, because you actually need a lot of pressure to get the ball rolling, as it were (and it is). With all ballpoint pens, there’s a sweet spot, where you get a good distribution of ink. Press too softly and you won’t get anything, but press too hard and you’ll have an ugly, broken line.

Test 4: Heavy Writing

If I had any budget at all, I might build some sort of robot that is able to write things at exact pressures. I don’t have a budget, though, so I didn’t do that. Instead, I just wrote a thing with each pen, pressing very hard. This was harder than anybody would ever comfortably write - except maybe the Hulk or something. At this level, all four pens heavily exhibited what I call “Mosesing.”

Let me explain.

This is how a ballpoint pen is supposed to work. Basically.

I threw together a couple diagrams to explain this visually. Above is an example of how a ballpoint pen is supposed to work. Ink (in this case it’s hot pink) flows over the ball and makes a smooth, even mark on the page. However, that’s not how it works all the time.

This is how a ballpoint pen actually works.

Sometimes, especially when you press too hard, the ball is smushed into the page, and ink doesn’t fit underneath it. Then you get a line with an odd stripe in the middle, which you can only really notice if you look closely. I call it “Mosesing” because the ball is like a tiny little Moses parting the ink like a tiny Red (or pink) Sea.

This happens with all ballpoint pens, and it’s why they aren’t great for anything that needs to look nice. Here you can see it happening randomly with all four pens, even when just writing normally.

When people see your uneven lines, they’ll know that you have a Parker.
The F-301 and the F-402 have the same ink, so they’re both equally guilty.
The gel ink has it the worst.

Gel is more viscous than normal ink, so it gets the worst Mosesing. The line drawn by the G-301 is about twice as wide as the line drawn by the F-301, and their tips are the same size. That’s why the gel ink runs out faster, and it’s twice the surface area to be “Mosesed” by the pressure of the ball.

I also wanted to see how the pens handled writing softly. This is an aspect where ballpoints really can’t hold up, because they rely on the friction of the ball on the paper to get it all to work. However, I was pretty surprised by how well they hung on. This is something that would have been more of a challenge for pens back in the days when Tungsten Carbide was just a wild fever dream.

Test 5: Light Writing

There was hardly any Mosesing anymore, but the gel showed a new problem. It could not handle the lack of pressure. In all, I think the Jotter shows the most range of pressure, which translates to a higher chance that you’ll be able to write however you’re comfortable without having to adjust to what the pen needs. I’m sure I’m not alone in picking up a foreign pen for whatever reason only to find that it requires an amount of pressure that I’m just not used to using. That’s a feature you don’t want in your trusty pocket workhorse.

Test 6: Extremely Low Pressure

For the final test, I held a single sheet of paper by one end, bending it slightly to get it to stand out. I then tried my best to write a few lines on the far margin, where the pen would be able to apply very little pressure. This would really test the limits of the pens’ ability to write without much force. The three standard ink pens were able to just get some faint lines. However, the G-301 just wouldn’t work, and mainly just managed to scrape the paper a bit. What lines the gel ink was able to make were much darker than the other pens, of course, but the plain fact is that the gel ink requires a bit more pressure to work - and with pressure comes Moses.

Finally the Finale

The Zebra fleet - minus the pen for rich people.

So just how does the Zebra fleet stand up against the Jotter? First off, just forget the G-301 exists. I hate it. The 402 certainly offers some serious competition, and it might very well be a full-on toss up between it and the Jotter. Parker (the company) does have slightly better ink, and you cannot beat the build quality and elegance of the Jotter. However, the 402 is mighty comfortable, and it’s less than half the cost (per pen) than the Jotter - plus you get an extra 402 to let somebody borrow. Purely on the merit of the pens, though, I think I actually prefer the lighter, smoother, more stylish Jotter - despite my long relationship with the 402.

The outlier is the G-301, with it’s crazy gel ink. Some might really appreciate the dark, thick lines that gel gives you. Others will be put off by the higher pressure required and the fact that gel ink smears much, much more. Even if you love gel ink, though, you’ll still be stuck with the 301 body, which basically made my hand almost fall off I hated it so much. I’m pretty sure I ventured into hyperbole at some point there. The point is that you can get a much better gel pen than the G-301. For example, Parker makes a gel refill for the Jotter.

So ultimately we can disregard most of Zebra’s lineup. The 301 is too cheap, the 701 is too expensive, and their gel ink is in the wrong pen. They have too many pens. Like everybody else, Zebra does not need a fleet of ballpoint pens. They only need one good dependable workhorse. Unfortunately for Zebra, though, they can’t do what the rest of us do. We already have one good pen, and it’s made by Parker.

(Some of the handwriting examples were written by Alyson)

fields.title: A Treatise on Evil
fields.text:
While dealing with the amoral practices of the utility companies, as we all do once a month, I started thinking, as I do every month, about the existence of evil. We have to live under the yolk of the power company (among other amoral authorities), forced to pay any fees and put up with uncaring service because we have no power - literally and figuratively - to stop them. It is easy to feel victimized and violated by these obvious corruptions of authority. We can easily travel down a dark road of cynicism, losing all faith in Humanity or Society. However, something dawned on me today that gave me real hope.

As a living thing - weak, soft, and defenseless - your imperative, ultimately, is to make it to your next dinner. You personally must survive to eat dinner tonight, but you must also see that descendents of your species will live to see dinner tomorrow. What is the purpose of a life? Is there any higher purpose than to merely survive? Humans - at least this modern Society of Humans - are above that type of thinking. Dinner tonight will be provided for us. We can spend the few hours until then watching TV or deciding which tablet to buy. Is our obsession with celebrity and useless technology throwing our purpose away? I present to you that our purpose has already been lost, not because we lost our way in a sea of iPhones and Kardashians, but because we are on the cusp of a new Era of Humanity.

This is high language, I grant you, and you might think that it borders on new-age radical nonsense, but I’m actually quite serious.

Hundreds of thousands of Your Earth Years ago, Humans were still animals. They fought, killed, and huddled together in caves to survive. They were weak, soft, defenseless creatures in a vastly hostile world, simply trying to live to see - and catch - dinner. However, Humans had an advantage: reason. They made tools, clothing, and shelter. They domesticated beasts and conquered agriculture. Early Humans were able to adapt so much more quickly than any other living thing. In what is cosmically a microscopic amount of time, we have grown more powerful than everything around us.

In short, we won. We beat nature. Yes, we’re still victims to disease and famine and natural disasters, but none of those things threaten our survival any more than buying a gallon of milk threatens someone’s bank account. In modern society, we don’t have to fight and struggle to see dinner. We have to find something to watch on TV while we wait for dinner to be delivered. No other species in our experience even comes close to pursuing activities that serve no purpose but to occupy the time of the pursuer. What are the Kardashians if not a complete and total admission - dare I say it, celebration - of our victory over survival?

The problem, though, is that we are still animals. We are the same creatures that huddled in caves thousands of years ago, and we have the same instincts to survive. When given the choice, we will take advantage of others to help ourselves. Can you blame the power company or other corporations for ruining lives to make a profit? Deep down, our CEOs are just weak, soft, defenseless creatures letting a cruel beast eat someone else instead of themselves. This is instinctual; built into our being at a primal level. You are not free of blame. As you sit there, a Human Being just as intelligent and logical as you is starving to death. Is your passive evil - cruelty of inaction - any better than a corrupt CEOs active evil - cruelty of action? Is it all simply the circle of life - survival of the fittest?

Humans have always been brutal, pitiless creatures. Humans have always fought and killed each other to get a better piece of the world for themselves. There is no era of Human History in which some entity or group was not trying to destroy another to take what they had.

Listen - er, Read: until recently, active evil was normal. Humans were content to commit intensely cruel actions against each other as a matter of course. It has only been recently that we have even considered the existence passive evil. Nobody in modern Society two hundred years ago would have felt bad eating a full meal when impoverished third worlds were starving around the globe. Today, active cruelty is still common, but the key is that it isn’t universal anymore. At this rate, tomorrow it may be gone entirely.

Evil is vestigial. Its is an unnecessary organ - an evolutionary leftover - that we are slowly working to remove. Cruelty and greed is rampant in our society, yes, but they are dying. We are beginning to agree with each other on a global scale. We connect to each other through mind-boggling technology and are truly beginning to see ourselves as a unified species. There are parts of the world now which are legitimately, completely, safe. We are redefining what is right and wrong, and more importantly we are doing it based on a common morality, not supposed divine right. We don’t seek the directives of our leaders - we make decisions for ourselves. We are rooting out those aspects of ourselves that are base and evil, and we are slowly smothering them.

Two hundred years ago, Humans fought world wars on the whims of Kings and Emperors. Plagues ran rampant in the streets, completely untreatable. Cruelty went unmatched. News would take weeks, if not months, to travel short distances. Just imagine how far we have progressed as a species in two hundred years. Where will we be two hundred years from now? What glorious achievements of reason and morality will we see?

Imagine how exciting it is to be able to live in this period of history! We are witnessing the death of evil first hand, and these corrupt companies and greedy CEOs are its death knell. My grandchildren might grow up in a world where things like War, Poverty, and even Disease are nothing more than stories. This isn’t the wild dreams of new-age radical nonsense, either. This is really happening.

So what is the purpose of a life now? What will my grandchildren live for? When a species defeats survival, what is left for them to do? That, my friends, is the great question of our age. That is the new era of Humanity that we are on the cusp of discovering.

We Humans have finished our dinner. All we have to do now is find our dessert.

fields.title: Video Games: Commuting Simulators
fields.text:
So you're Dragonborn? Go kill three wolves ten miles away and then come back here. Thanks!

(Note: I didn’t want to dig through a bunch of old games to get screenshots, or deal with Google Image Search to find them, so all of the pictures in this post are artist renderings.)

My friend and colleague Will Hughes maintains an interesting website place, where he often posts commentary on the video game industry. He posted some postings about open world games recently, and that inspired me to collect some of my similar thoughts into some postings of my own. And lo, that is what I have done. Please visit his website place to read his comments on “Escape as Art,” on the illusion of choice in open worlds, and “Off the Script,” on problems inherent in storytelling for open world games. Those are both very important points about this trend we’re being force fed more and more. I agree with Hughes that merely making a game “open world” does not suddenly catapult it into an upper echelon of brilliant gameplay. Really, it just wastes your time.

When I was in High School, I played a lot of video games. I really enjoyed shooting games like Half Life and Unreal, strategy games like Command and Conquer, and role playing games, like Final Fantasy. Then a friend introduced me to a game called Gothic, which was a pretty unique (at least to me at the time) open world role playing game with a fantasy / medieval theme.

And terrible voice acting.

I tried to get back into Gothic a few months ago, after getting the entire Gothic collection (they’re up to Gothic 4) on Steam. It was difficult to get back into. The controls, by today’s standard, are just weird, and though you can get over the graphics (which weren’t great even back then), the voice acting really is hard to get around.

A lot can be said about Gothic, really. It actually had surprisingly similar features to Skyrim, which came out ten years later. I’m not going to tell you that Gothic is better than, or even really as good as Skyrim. I’m also not going to belay the point, because analyzing Gothic is outside the scope of this posting. The point is that Gothic was a lot of fun, and it sucked me into the world of role playing games - a world with gems like Morrowind, Anachronox, Arcanum, Fallout, Diablo, Fable, and The Witcher, among many others.

One day, my Dad saw me playing a role playing game (I don’t really remember what it was, but needless to say it was some sort of open world). In the classic way that all fathers say things to their sons when their sons do something they don’t understand, he said, “I don’t get that game. Whenever I see you playing it you’re just running somewhere.”

He was right. What’s the main thing all the games I listed above have in common? The player spends at least 60% of the game running somewhere.

Sure, you can sprint, but only for thirty seconds at a time for some reason.

Running is the essence of an open world game. You can sprinkle random encounters, crafting ingredients, beautiful vistas, or other marginal player rewards around your world, but in the end when I boot up Skyrim or ArcaniA (the awkwardly capitalized latest sequel to Gothic) I know that it’s going to involve me sitting at my desk watching some dude in various levels of armor running for a long time.

Ultimately video games are a waste of time. That’s what they’re designed to do. Still, there’s wasted time, and there’s wasted time. If I’m going to watch a movie, I’d rather cut straight to the part where the two fugitive cops bust in on the bad guys and have a big shoot fight, instead of watching their entire car trip from New York to Chicago. I’d rather have delightfully interesting people to talk to all around me than ten miles between me and my next objective with nothing but some crafting ingredients and GODDAMN CLIFF RACERS.

The number one reason I’m probably never playing Morrowind again.

Back in the day, roleplaying games were very different. Computers couldn’t render big city centers (they could hardly render anything), so games couldn’t have sequences where you run around talking to people for hours. Look at the original Mechwarrior game (or at least what I remember it looking like):

I tried playing Mechwarrior recently. It’s pretty unplayable.

You didn’t have to go through the tedium of walking from your garage to the place where you get missions. You just clicked a button. For a while, during a time we can call the dark ages of wasting my time, games had no fast travel feature at all. In Gothic or Morrowind, we were supposed to be so enamored with the fact that the world is one big open place that we would put up with walking along the same stupid trail from one guy who tells us what to do to an area where monsters hang out so we can kill them. At that point, if anybody ever watched you play one of these games, all they would ever see you do is run somewhere.

Then we get to the modern age of open world games - the age of fast travel. In Skyrim, you can just click on any village or landmark that you’ve already been to and you’ll instantly be transported right there. I always start the game thinking, “this game is so cool looking, and there’s so much to explore that I’m never going to use the fast travel.” Then about five to ten hours into the game, I fast travel literally everywhere.

Yeah, I’m not walking all that way again.

The problem with exploration in video games is that it’s so artificial. Okay, so video games are all artificial - fair enough - but it really defeats the purpose. Exploration is about discovering neat little secrets, and the thrill you feel for uncovering them. You’re in a world that was entirely put together by a bunch of people, though, so everything was placed there for you to find. You’re meant to find it, and that makes it so much less exciting when you do. Skyrim is cram packed with hundreds of little stories and vignettes to find, but to me most of them had this sense that the designers were basically elbowing me in the side and winking the whole time. They just feel like I’m being let in on an inside joke. They all end with me shrugging, saying “well, there’s that,” looting all the crafting ingredients I could find, and then moving on to the next cave or hut in the woods.

The fact is that once you see that mountaintop, once you explore those ruins, you’re done. Then all you want to do is get to those quest-delivering hotspots as quickly as possible and continue the story. Having to walk to your quest in a video game is just like having to walk to work every morning. Skyrim, then, is not a “sticking swords in monsters” simulator, it’s a “commuting to work” simulator. I hate commuting to work, and I would probably hate it a lot more if I had to keep killing feral wolves all the time.

Or you could be like LA Noire and both make the world completely uninteresting and refuse to let me fast travel anywhere.

The game Mount and Blade is an interesting example. It’s nothing but an open world; there’s no story or objectives to complete. You’re just a dude who can wander around this kingdom recruiting armies and fighting whomever you want. It’s kind of neat how you can make your own substance and come up with a bit of a narrative anyway. I’m not saying it’s some groundbreaking revolution in game design, but I think there’s a lot that could be done with it. I’ll have to save an analysis of it for a different posting, because that’s neither here nor there. What Mount and Blade does that’s relevant is that whenever you enter a town or village, you get a little screen that lets you go straight to the tavern or the shop or whatever.

Yes, “steal cows” is an option when you go to a village in Mount and Blade

It’s just like Mechwarrior. Thirty years later, we’re back where we started. You don’t get any ability to fast travel from city to city (because then there wouldn’t be any game at all), but you don’t have to wander around a poorly designed generic village map trying to find some fish to feed to your dudes. It cuts out a completely superfluous, time wasting section of unnecessary gameplay.

And that’s the point, isn’t it? Good game design should cut out anything that’s unnecessary. What is a game’s point? What are players here to do? What is wasting their time and keeping them from doing that?

I suppose the argument is that we might as well just have a button that says “play for me” and leave it at that. Why not? Why shouldn’t I be able to skip boring, tedious parts? The game designer’s job should be to give us that button but do everything he can to keep us from wanting to push it.

You win!

Make gameplay I want to play, not that I want to skip. If you’re going to have an open world, it needs to be a place that I actually want to live in, where stuff happens that I want to experience. If you’re going to have exploration, you have to make it feel natural. If you’re going to make me walk around everywhere, give me a real companion, with personality and desires - another thing Mount and Blade does really well. Make your game fun all the time, or give me the ability to skip it when it isn’t. Don’t waste my time.

Someday I hope I can say to my son, in that way that all fathers say things to their sons when their sons do something they don’t understand, “I don’t get this game. Why don’t you ever have to run anywhere?”

fields.title: Of Student Bondage
fields.text:
How “crowdsourcing” could save education.

Imagine that you are in your last semester of college. Yes, most of my readers were probably there not terribly long ago, but just bear with me. How do you feel? You probably feel excited or proud. You’re ready to enter the world and make a place for yourself. You feel accomplished. You probably don’t picture yourself trapped under an immovable weight.

You should, though.

To graduate from college today means entering a terrifying and seemingly endless world of debt. Tuition has skyrocketed over the years, and now it seems a student just can’t make it through school without some form of student loan. We have as a society built a system that preys on the youth, telling them that the only way to succeed in life is to go to College. We then hand them a contract that commits them to pay for it for the rest of their lives. Perhaps the story we tell our kids is, indeed, true, but the result is a constant curse from which many graduates will never escape.

You might see that nihilistic sentiment as an exaggeration. “It surely isn’t that bad,” you might say. You obviously aren’t one of my college graduate friends, because if you were you would know that it is. It really is that bad.

Some quick Googling (are we supposed to capitalize that?) raises some startling statistics. College students who graduated in 2010 carried an average of $25,250 in debt. We’re not talking about doctors or lawyers, here. This is the average of all college graduates in the US. With unemployment rates among college graduates shooting up, too, many new grads have little hope of paying their debt off any time soon. Here’s an interesting infographic I stumbled upon about it.

So now imagine that you’re about to graduate, but you have this $25,000 cloud hanging over your head. If you pay $100 every single month, it will take you Twenty-one years to pay that off, and that’s not even including interest. Now how do you feel? You’re about to enter a world with the highest unemployment rate for college graduates ever, and you have to somehow pay every extra penny you make for the next two decades. What if you want to move somewhere? What if you want to start a family? Can you? What will you never accomplish because you can’t afford to try?

Hopefully I’ve scared you enough to stick with me here, because I have an idea that might just save future graduates from a similar fate. It might even save - dare I say it - the world!

The real question that comes up here is not “how could a system like this come about?” The answer to that is obvious. As long as the “free market” economy rules our lives, this type of domination will always happen. I’m not saying there’s anything necessarily wrong with capitalism - that would have to be the subject of another post - I’m just saying that this was inevitable. We built a world designed to target populations that are easily exploited financially, and then convince every single generation of children to get the best education they can, completely ignoring the cost. How is nobody outraged by this yet?

The real question that comes up here is “why hasn’t anyone done anything to stop this?” Sure, we have websites with startling statistics, and we march around complaining about our debt and rising tuition, but awareness doesn’t necessarily solve anything. We live in the future, where for the first time anybody with an Internet connection has as much theoretical power as anybody else. The time has come to come up with an Internet solution to this problem.

So now we get to my idea. I propose a Crowdsourced Education Investment System. Students - both past, present, and future - post their College fees on a secure and tightly regulated website (the tricky part will, of course, be to make sure posted needs are legitimate). This will work like Kickstarter or Ebay, except students are offering up their education expenses. Normal people who have some money they want to invest - people like you or me - can log on to this site and buy stakes in these students’ education. Eventually the students have to pay back these loans, but they go right back to their average Joe investors, not faceless greedy corporations.

For students, it will work just the same way as the system does now. You’ll apply for loans based on your need, someone pays for you to go to school, and then you have to slowly pay it back after you graduate. The difference is that now the person giving you the money is a real human being, investing in your - and by extension their - future. When you do finally get out into the job market and that education pays off, it’s not just paying off for some faceless investment firm like Sallie Mae.

For investors, this system will have the same effect as putting money in a CD or another long-term investment, except that the potential interest rates could be substantially higher. Yes, it will be years before students pay the money back, but with interest rates of up to 10%, you’ll make far more money than you would with your cash just sitting in a bank (earning less than one percent), with far less risk than investing in the Stock Market, and with infinitely more satisfaction than either. Personally, I would much rather invest a few grand in one of these Student Bonds than a complicated and volatile 401k or IRA plan. Let’s face it, even in a worse-case scenario, wouldn’t you rather lose money on a kid’s education than on some stock in a company you hardly know anything about?

So students get money (and an education), people have a tangible and trustworthy investment opportunity, and our society benefits from a new generation of educated, empowered young minds. Everybody wins.

Effectively, it’s a new investment firm, just like Citigroup or Sallie Mae, except that it’s just a union of regular people. With outrage over the “1%” going through the roof (just like these student loans themselves), I’m honestly surprised more people aren’t clamoring to do things just like this.

The real potential of this, though, is the long-term effects it could have on the world. If greedy fat cats aren’t profiting anymore from taking advantage of this “College or die” mentality, we can finally stop hiking tuition and charging for every penny we can get. Maybe once we take the power away from the Few, College will actually be affordable again for the Many.

Ok, so it’s far-fetched and certainly optimistic. A product like this would be incredibly hard to get off the ground. How does it make money? How does it protect itself from inevitable liability issues? That’s even before you consider what those big corporations will try to do if something like this actually gains traction. Still, what if? What if students could graduate from college without that crushing weight on their shoulders? What if we could come together as the community that we could so easily be and just support each other? What if it turned out that we didn’t need “investors” at all?

Kickstarter has proven that in this Internet-enabled world, we can do things on Our own. We can take care of Ourselves. We can and in fact have - dare I say it - changed the world! Imagine what today’s students would be capable of if they could do anything but worry about their debt. Shouldn’t we at least try?

fields.title: In a Dino Jump, Everything is Shaded Blur
fields.text:
Last weekend I went to a birthday party for a few friends. It's part of the reason why I neglected to post anything here for a few days. Please excuse this personal indulgence - I took pictures at the party and I want you to see them. Don't worry, though, they aren't just boring, 'look at how cool I am' pictures. This wasn't a normal 20-something party.

This party had a Dino Jump.

Anyway, that's what Mike called it. I took it as a fun photographic challenge. It's not easy to take pictures when everything (including you) is moving unpredictably and terrifyingly.

The rental place offered a big fan to inflate the thing, but we just used Andrew's super power. He has an unnatural control over gasses.
We have all been raised with the common knowledge that you take your shoes off before going into a Dino Jump. The red sign says 'STOP! Do not enter unless operator is on duty.'
Inside a Dino Jump, everything is shaded blur.
Three things surprised me at the end of the night: no bones were broken inside the Dino Jump, no boobs were exposed inside the Dino Jump, and nobody threw up inside the Dino Jump. I wouldn't have bet against any of those happening.
I didn't really notice it at the time, but upon looking through my pictures I noticed that everyone inside the Dino Jump has a giant smile on. If smiles were operators, we'd all be totally fine.
One thing you don't want to do in a Dino Jump is fall over the side. It's incredibly difficult to get back up. It was always incredibly exciting, though.
I'm pretty sure just a few adults surpasses the weight limit for one of these, but we had at least 10 people inside at one point.
It was constant, chaotic, nearly terrifying fun.
Nobody takes a flattering picture inside a Dino Jump. I quickly gave up trying.
What's more fun than a Dino Jump? Tickling Mike inside a Dino Jump. We are all four years old, you see.
The guy in the blue shirt is Tom. Tom is like a gravity well. He made the Dino Jump sink wherever he was, and everything around him was drawn into his sink-hole. He also constantly farts. He made the Dino Jump stink wherever he was. When he was inside the Dino Jump, everybody was desperately trying to avoid falling into Tom's stink-sink-hole.
A ball is a fun addition to a Dino Jump. Everybody has to sit down for there to be any ability to not be constantly falling over.
Somebody (usually Tom) always ends up getting bored, though, and starts jumping, which sends everybody scattering.
The sheer chaos inside the Dino Jump makes it seem like somebody is going to break a bone (or expose a boob) at any moment.
Falling into a corner was the most terrifying, because not only would it make the whole Dino Jump collapse onto you, but there were also four giant metal spikes holding the thing down, which were just outside each corner, waiting for someone to fall on them.
This picture was taken when it was my turn to jump around. This was the least blurry of the pictures taken at this point.
Tom is a chaotic individual, and he was in a chaotic situation. It could have been a sitcom. Also he constantly farts. That was less fun.
There was also a pinata, but that's outside the scope of this post. Take note of the brown creature head on the left side of the Dino Jump. What the Hell is that thing? it has three horns, a trunk, and a turkey-ish waddle.

fields.title: The Pentel Hybrid Technica
fields.text:
I don’t want to get ahead of myself, here, but I am really having a hard time being in favor of gel. Yes, technically gel is better than paste ink. It’s darker, it’s less vulnerable to fading or washing, it works on more mediums, and it’s better on the environment. I just have a hard time getting behind it - especially for a general purpose pen. On paper it might be better, but on paper, it just doesn’t do it for me.

I feel exactly the same way about the Hybrid Technica, a precision gel pen from Pentel. It’s branded as a pen for artists, though it doesn’t really look like one. It has a very fine point, a smooth line, and a little “05” on the cap. The problem is, though, I’m really not sure what this pen is actually good for.

The Technica comes in 0.3, 0.4, 0.5, and 0.6 millimeter sizes. Mine is the 0.5 mm.

First, there’s the name. I have absolutely no idea what makes this a hybrid. Perhaps they are emphasizing the use of gel in an art pen. My guess is that they’re just trying to make it sound cool. Think about it. The biggest market for sleek looking capped Pentel pens is not artists - it’s offices and students trying to look cool. If you name your pen that you’re trying to brand as an artist’s pen the “Artistic Dingdong” you’ll scare away your only real customer base. “Hybrid Technica” belies the fact that this is not an artist’s pen at heart.

Then, there’s the range of sizes. Certainly artists have plenty of reasons to use both a 0.3 and a 0.4 millimeter pen, but with a ballpoint tip and gel ink, I really can’t believe these are precise enough to make that much of a difference. Unfortunately, I don’t have the other sizes to really see, so I’ll just have to put that aside for now. The point (no pun intended) is that offices and students aren’t going to care how many tenths of a millimeter their cool looking pens are. So Pentel makes these in a range of sizes for all of the ballpoint pen artists out there. Maybe the Technica really is an artist’s pen, then.

Next, there’s the ink. I won’t go into tons of detail or comparisons. Needless to say, it compares pretty evenly with the Zebra gel (though the Technica does, obviously, write a much finer line). Being gel, it’s nice and dark, but it smears like crazy. Should an artist take the Technica over one of the other art focused gel pens out there? What other art focused gel pens? There’s your problem. Other art pens have felt tips, because ballpoints just aren’t good enough. So this isn’t an artist’s pen at heart, after all. This is an office pen trying to play in a field it isn’t qualified for.

Finally, there’s the design. Other than the “05” on the cap, this thing is about as “basic Pentel stick” as you can get. Don’t worry, the guys in the office won’t think you’re trying to show off too much by taking this to the next staff meeting. It certainly isn’t trying to be convenient, either. I tried carrying it as my standard pocket pen for a few days, which was not extremely enjoyable. It fell out of my pocket at one point and it actually cracked when it hit the floor. I almost lost the cap several times. Don’t count on it being well built or convenient (it actually makes the Zebra F-301 feel sturdy). It’s definitely meant to sit on a desk, then, but is it meant to sit on a desk in chemistry class, or sketching class?

I wrote out a few pages of text with the Technica, just to see how it wrote. Aside from the blur issue, which is always present, I felt that it was just a bit too fine for my tastes. Some people might like the fine point for writing, but it was too harsh for me. I would take any of the pens in my last post over the Technica for writing, even the F-301.

It’s supposedly a pen for drawing, though, so I also wanted to see how it handled the sketch pad. You might have seen some of the sketches I made with it. It was nice and smooth. It mostly made a crisp line. It didn’t feel like I was doing art, though. It just felt like I was doodling in the margins of my chemistry homework.

It could have been what I was drawing, though.

It still has all of the failings of any other ballpoint. Sometimes it refused to draw solid, straight lines - or it refused to draw anything at all - which forced me to re-draw my lines, which quickly makes things look sloppy. It also still commits that most heinous of ballpoint sins - Mosesing. It may not be quite as pronounced - because of the much finer point - but it’s still there, compromising any advantage gel is supposed to have.

I’m pretty much the best artist.

In the hands of a real artist, though, it’s a bit better. Alyson (somebody with a real art degree) took it for a spin, and in a few minutes came up with a sketch of me that I feel is actually pretty damn good.

She really captured my freckles - and steam breath.

This scribble-ey style is much more suited to the Technica, but you still can’t erase its shortcomings. It isn’t much of a problem anymore, but the Mosesing and broken lines are still there. The simple fact is that these problems just wouldn’t be there if she was using a Micron.

Imagine turning in your chemistry lab worksheet with this in the margins.

Alyson didn’t hate the Technica. She liked the dark lines it put down, and liked its precision. However, she only used it in the first place because I asked her to, and as soon as I’m done with this review (which is now), she’ll probably go back to felt tips for her line work.

That’s the Hybrid Technica in a nutshell. It’s trying to be an artist’s pen, but it isn’t as good as a felt tip. It’s trying to keep to its taking-notes-in-chemistry-class roots, too, but it’s straying just a bit too far. It isn’t sturdy enough or convenient enough to carry in your pocket. It seems harder and harder to see the Technica filling any role, especially when you consider that it’s more expensive than the same size Micron.

Pentel says the Hybrid Technica has a fine point, I say it has no point at all.

This hybrid succeeds at bridging the gap between art and gel pens. Unfortunately, it only manages to keep all of the disadvantages of both. Artists should stick with felt, and leave gel where it belongs, writing checks and taking notes in chemistry class.

And also . . .

As a side note - in case you need another reason not to use gel for anything but writing checks, I did another quick test of inks - the “back of the hand” test. I wrote a quick note on the back of my hand with the Parker Jotter, the F-402, the G-301, and the Hybrid Technica (in that order).

I’m just happy that a club finally accepted me as a member.

Even though it’s supposed to be better on more surfaces, gel does not work well on skin, and the Technica’s fine point made it almost useless. Both gels almost immediately washed away, too. At the end of the day, as I’m typing this, only one of the inks has been able to outlast the others, and it probably isn’t a huge surprise who it was. You guessed it - Parker (the ink). That’s yet another reason to keep a Jotter handy, in case you’re the sort that likes to - well - jot reminders or phone numbers down on the back of your hand, or if - like me - you’re trying to recruit more members to your new favorite club.
