fields.title: District Alpha: Chapter 7
fields.text:
I've been working on this book for quite a while now, and I'm still very excited about how great it is. However, I'm still waiting on some offers from some movie studios for the film rights. Just let me know when you're ready to make some fat stacks, movie studios.

Anyway, when last we left our really beautiful heroes, they were running for their lives through the streets of District Alpha, trying to get to a safe house where our hero Matt's friends lived. Our other hero, Kate, was just trying to get a handle on being in the big city, since she grew up on a robot farm.

District Alpha: Government Mandate Zone
Chapter 7

“Welcome to Exposition House,” said the old man in the doorway, grinning from ear to ear at the two of them. “It’s so good to meet you, Kate!”

The old man had already given Matt a heartfelt greeting, but it’s much more interesting to start this scene when the old man meets Kate. They were standing, the three of them, in a dark corridor of a large apartment building. The hall was very dark, and graffiti could be seen on the walls. Bright, warm light cascaded from the open door to Matt’s friends’ apartment. It was very inviting.

Kate looked at the man. He was small and only had hair around the back of his head. Kate had never met this kindly old man before, but his warm greeting made her immediately at ease. She had only met one physically old person in her life, many years ago, so she was fascinated by the lines on his face and the shine of his bald head. He stood aside in the entryway, gesturing grandly to the both of them, ushering them inside. Kate followed Matt inside, left speechless by this onslaught of new experiences.

“Kate is from District Delta.” Matt filled the silence left by Kate’s inexperience.

The old man, whom Kate had just learned was called Pete, held his hand out to Kate, somehow smiling even larger than before. She stared at his wrinkled face and followed the line of his beliverspotted arm to his hand, held vertically with his fingers all pointing at her. She stared, confused, for what seemed like minutes before suddenly remembering the gesture that she had seen her father make to other gentlemen on the robot farm many years ago. With a flash of comprehension on her face, she brought her hand to his and wrapped her fingers around it.

Looking over at Matt, the old man said with a chuckle, “she’s a naive one, isn’t she?”

“Pete, take it easy,” Matt said, “she’s been through a lot in the last few days.” Matt reached out to gently pull their hands apart. Kate was happy to know how to shake the old man’s hand, but she had no idea how or when to end such a gesture. She was very grateful for Matt’s tactful interjection, and she smiled softly at his hand on hers. She would have preferred to shake his hand.

“Well, you’re in safe hands, now, my dear!” Pete said to her, his warm friendly face making her smile again. Kate was really displaying a broad range of subtle emotions, but they were all just smiles, so it’s not like it was some really expensive Oscar winning moment or anything.

The old man turned into the apartment with the same grand form with which he treated everything, saying, “come, you’ll have to meet the whole family!”

Kate looked at her surroundings, now, as they stepped into a new corridor. They were now standing in a short hallway, softly lit by an overhead light. The walls were lined with pictures of many things Kate had never seen before, and many people Kate wanted to meet. The people in the pictures were all smiling. Kate marveled at all of the old photographs - some of them were so old that their hologromatic projection was starting to fade - as Matt and Pete chatted. She hardly paid any attention to them. This corridor was a big contrast from the last few corridors they had gone through.

“Oh, your Aunt Kathy and Uncle Tom are going to be so excited to see you,” Pete was saying, putting his thin arm around Matt’s shoulders.

“How is everyone?” Matt asked.

Pete started explaining that times were as rough as ever, but as they reached the end of the corridor they all stopped short at the sound of a high-pitched scream. Kate tensed up.

“Matt! Guy’s, it’s Matt!” A young woman was shouting. The corridor opened up into a cozy kitchen, and just beyond Kate could see several figures inside a living room, all excitedly getting up and hurrying to where Pete and Matt were standing.

Kate could only stand and watch as what seemed like a thousand hugs and warm greetings descended upon her new friend. She felt awkward for the first time, in this new social situation she would never have dreamt of. She couldn’t keep up with everyone speaking all at once, and she was surprised at the myriad ways each person used to say the same thing. If she had a thesaurus with her, she wouldn’t have been able to come up with as many synonyms for “good to see you” as they had.

Some of the strangers’ eyes were turning on her. She felt more awkward at first, but these people were so friendly and their smiles were so inviting that she felt safe and decided to just go with it. These people really were friendly, you see.

Matt looked at her and smiled. He said, “this is Kate. She’s my new friend.”

The entire room looked at her then. She smiled awkwardly back at them and lifted her hand in a little half-wave. Pete was all smiles. He has already met the new girl, so he was way ahead of everybody else.

Matt began the introductions. Kate smiled and touched hands with everyone in the room. Some of them were introduced in pairs because they were married or something, but Kate still touched their hands separately. Kate knew she would never remember all of these new names and faces, but most of these people aren’t major characters so it doesn’t really matter who they are. She was able to tell who was important in the room because they were more attractive and had a few more things to say to her than just “hello.”

Kate met Matt’s uncle Tom and aunt Kathy. Pete mentioned them earlier, so they’ll probably be important to the story later.

Then Kate met a girl named Alice. Alice was about Kate’s age, but she seemed a lot smarter than Kate about stuff that Kate wasn’t so smart about. Kate also really didn’t like the way Alice was looking at Matt, but she also really didn’t know why. Alice was really pretty, but in a different way than Kate. Alice was the Mila Kunis to Kate’s Natalie Portman - but only as an example. Who could afford them?

Then Kate met a really grumpy looking guy. “What’s your problem,” she asked.

“Oh, I’m not very important,” he replied, “so my whole part will probably get cut out of the movie entirely.”

Kate didn’t really understand that, as her furrowed brow implied. At least he got to say something in the book. The guy stepped back to his place and very deliberately milled about, conspicuously being inconspicuous. For example, he chatted with one of the other extra people in the room, but neither of them actually said anything.

Finally Kate met a man named Braiden. He owned the apartment they were all living in, which is only part of the reason she could tell he was a main character. He was also a Steve Buscemi looking guy, and those sorts are always really important. Braiden looked at her with his big, round eyes and welcomed her to his home. Kate was put off at first by Braiden’s blatant un-attractiveness, but you know how Steve Buscemi is actually really endearing, especially when he’s being a nice guy. He wore an olive-colored shirt, buttoned all the way to the collar even though he didn’t have a tie. His olive-colored cargo pants were well worn, and he had lots of stuff in all of his pockets, including the two on the front of his shirt. His quaint little fedora hat was haphazardly placed on his head.

Kate met some other people there but they weren’t important so it doesn’t matter. They were just extra people. Eventually everybody - people with names and all the extras - filed out of the kitchen and went back to what they were doing. Braiden took Matt under his arm and they went into a back room. Kate felt alone for a moment, left to fend for herself.

She looked around at this part of the apartment. The kitchen was very nice, with cooking utensils stored all around the granite countertops. Kate noted that the appliances were all made by GE, and she could really tell that they were very high quality appliances. A long countertop separated the kitchen from the next room, which was a sort of living area. When she looked in that direction, she realized that two little girls were standing by the kitchen island, watching her.

“Hi,” one of the girls said. The other nodded.

“Hello,” Kate replied. “What’s your name?”

“Ashley,” the girl said. The other nodded.

“Oh, okay. I’m Kate.”

“I know!” The girls giggled. They had heard her name said a hundred times already. The two little girls wore pigtails and dresses with flowers on them. One of them was white, and the other was black, but it really doesn’t matter which was which. The important thing is that nobody is surprised when they show up on a movie screen.

“T!”

Kate gasped in shock when the shout rang out to her side. She had forgotten that Pete was still standing there, and he was looking up at her with his customary smile. She had no idea what he meant.

“What?”

“I’ll make some tea!” Pete elaborated. “Don’t tell me you’ve never heard of tea.”

She relaxed. “Oh! Of course I’ve heard of tea. I just didn’t understand why you yelled it in my ear.”

“Oh, you poor naive girl, you have a lot to learn about the city! Here, I’ll put the kettle on and make you a cup of darjey. Tea’s a bit different, but I’m sure you’ll love it if you try it.”

Kate sighed and decided that this old man wasn’t all there. She shrugged and said, “okay.”

Kate looked back at the two girls. They were still smiling and giggling as if they knew something Kate didn’t. Kate might have wondered at that point if her fly was down, if automatic pants hadn’t been invented many years earlier. They weren’t giggling at anything in particular, though, that’s just how kids are.

“Do you like Tv?” the one girl asked Kate. The other nodded.

“Sure. We had a government-issue television on the robot farm. I used to watch it when I was your age.” Kate replied. The gratuitous backstory was lost on the little girls.

“Do you want to watch with us?”

“Okay.” Kate replied. She didn’t have anything better to do.

The girls ran off, giggling, to the living area, where a big comfy couch sat in front of a screen bigger than Kate.

“The TV on my farm wasn’t nearly as big as this one,” Kate said, staring at the giant screen.

One of the girls grabbed a remote and flipped the screen on. They started watching a television show or movie made by whatever production studio buys the movie rights to this book. It’s a perfect cross promotional opportunity. Kate sat on the couch next to the girls.

Shortly Pete walked into the living room carrying a steaming mug. He carefully handed it to Kate, who took a quick sip.

“Here you are, young lady.” Pete said as he sat in the easy chair that was right next to the couch.

“Thank you, Pete.” Kate replied.

“Watching some Tv?” Pete asked.

“Yes. I haven’t seen this show before.” Kate replied.

“Ah, yes, we only watch old shows here. We have a great collection. We don’t watch the Government Tv.” Kate realized that he was putting an emphasis on the T in Tv, which she figured was a city thing. Pete continued, “all the programs are Mandated by the Government, you know. No creativity. No freedom. No Scott Bakula. Not like the good old days.”

They sat there, sipping tea and watching a great collection of content from the early 2010’s for quite a few minutes.

Finally Pete leaned to Kate, and in a sort of mystical, hushed voice said, “so you’re here for the prophecy?”

Kate looked up at the old man. He was smiling gently, comfortingly, with a look that said, “it’s okay, your secret will be safe with me” except that Kate didn’t know what the Hell he was talking about.

A long pause happened then, during which Kate tried really hard to process what the old man had just said. Nothing was working out, though, so all she could say was, “what?”

“The prophecy. You’re the One, aren’t you?” Pete replied with a wink.

That wasn’t really much of an elaboration, and it only raised more questions. She decided to choose the question that was in the forefront of her thoughts, which was, “what?”

“Some say it isn’t true, of course, but now they’ll believe. Now they’ll have someone to put their faith in.”

Another pause. Another attempt for her brain to get a handle on things. Another “what?”

Pete smiled, and a bony old hand reached out to gently touch hers in a comforting manner. “So Matt hasn’t told you yet. Well, there’s no harm in spilling the beans now, I suppose. You’ll learn your destiny sooner or later. I probably don’t need to tell you what everybody thinks of that Matt. He always was, you know.” he said, kind of trailing off there at the end. He smiled to himself, lost in thought.

Kate was starting to freak out a little bit. “What were you saying?” she prompted.

“Oh, well, he’s been with us quite a while, you know. That Braiden, he thinks Matt is -”

“No, not about Matt. What is this prophecy?” She interrupted.

Before Pete could respond, Matt and Braiden came back into the room.

“Okay, Kate, let’s talk about what’s going on,” Braiden said. The two of them stood there staring at her. She sat, mug of tea in hand, staring at Pete.

Finally Pete leaned gently to her, and with a caring pat on her knee, said, “I think they’re waiting for you to follow them.”

Kate slowly stood, eyes wide, careful not to drop her mug of hot tea. She walked over to Matt and Braiden, through a doorway into a room that Kate thought looked like a meeting room.

“This is our meeting room,” said Braiden, as he and Matt followed her inside. It was an old bedroom, repurposed for the repurpose of being a meeting room for this group of whatever Braiden is about to explain that they are. At the far end of the room was a window, but it was covered, giving the whole room a very ominous, shadowy quality. In the middle of the room was a table. Not many table manufacturers seem like the type to underwrite a book or movie so it doesn’t matter what kind of table it was, but if there’s a company out there that would be up for that then it was totally that kind of table. It was a rather large table, seating eight comfortably. The top was made of a hard wood, and was a deep shade of brown. It’s not really important to the plot or anything, it was just a really, really nice table.

Matt pulled out a chair for Kate, and she sat down. Sitting at the other end of the glorious table were the couple introduced to Kate earlier as Uncle Tom and Aunt Kathy. They were holding hands and looking at her with a happy excitement in their eyes, so Kate could tell that she wasn’t in trouble or anything.

“Did Pete make you some tea?” asked Matt as he sat down next to her. Braiden took the seat on the other side of the table. Two adults could sit across from each other at the table without having their knees touch. It was a really, really nice table.

“Yeah,” responded Kate, hesitantly. She was partially unsure how to feel about that old man, but also just really impressed by the quality of craftsmanship of the table.

“What do you think? It’s a bit weird at first, but you’ll --” responded Braiden, but Kate interrupted him.

“It’s a bit weak, really. I’m used to having fresh - not from a tea bag. I don’t want to sound ungrateful or anything, but he should really steep Darjeeling for longer than he did, especially since it’s a bit older.”

“How do you know so much about tea?” asked Matt.

“I grew up on a robot farm,” Kate pointed out, as if saying, “well, duh.”

The others looked at each other. It seemed there was more to Kate than they had expected.

“So,” said Kate, “Pete was telling me something.”

“Oh, was he saying something about a phrophecy?” responded Matt. “Yeah, he does that all the time. Don’t take him too seriously.”

“Yeah,” added Braiden, “he was selected for zombification years ago. For some reason it didn’t take, but ever since then he’s been a bit loopy.”

“Oh,” said Kate, “that’s a relief. I mean, not that he’s like that, but I was starting to wonder.”

“About prophesies and destiny?” asked Braiden. “Those are just old cliches from books and movies. Scientists proved a few years ago that destiny doesn’t actually exist. It’s just mumbo-jumbo that writers use to give their plots a bit of weight. Good writers don’t have to fall back on such hackneyed methods like that. Everybody knows the best way to make a story truly interesting is to add more explosions.”

Just then, the chair Braiden was sitting on exploded. Splinters scattered everywhere, and he fell to the floor, just barely avoiding getting impaled on a jagged piece of wood. A handful of change fell out of Braiden’s pockets and scattered across the hardwood floor. Everybody else in the room stood up in shock.

“Are you okay?” Matt’s Aunt Kathy exclaimed.

“Yes,” replied Braiden, “I’m fine. It’s just this stupid chair. It was bound to happen one of these days.” He stood up and brushed himself off. “I’ve been eating a bit too many of Amanda’s brownies, I guess. Oh, don’t worry, the chair wasn’t made by the same people that made the table.”

He said the last bit to Kate, who was staring at the shattered remains of Braiden’s chair. Reassured, she and the others sat back down. Braiden gathered up the change that was scattered on the floor and took the chair next to the pile of what was once the chair he was sitting on.

And so the four of them - Braiden, Matt, and Matt’s Uncle Tom and Aunt Kathy - began to explain to Kate just what this little group was all about. Kate was pretty sheltered from politics and worldly affairs her whole life, so they had to give her a brief history lesson, too. It’s really unique and interesting.

For a long time - it doesn’t matter how long - the area - it doesn’t matter what area - was under the dominion of the Government. The aforesaid Government has split the aforesaid area over the course of the aforesaid time into Districts, and then they split those Districts into Districts.

“If They had Their way,” explained Braiden, “they would split each and every one of us into our own District.”

Everything wasn’t just happy Districts within Districts, however. It turns out - and this is where things get really original - the Government was actually bad. They keep taxing everybody, and then they impose ridiculous Government Mandate Zones that ration things like sandwiches and Delicious Coke.

“Did you want a Coke?” Matt’s Uncle Tom interjected. “‘Cause we’ve got a guy who knows a guy.”

“No, I’m okay, thanks,” responded Kate.

Matt’s Family - most of them weren’t actually related, incidentally - was part of an underground resistance movement called the Underground Resistance Movement. Their big thing - aside from not coming up with a good name for themselves - was that they wanted to overthrow the Government and bring things back to the Way they were when stuff was great, like the 2010’s.

“That was the Golden Age for Humanity, Kate,” Matt’s Aunt Kathy said. “When Coke flowed like water in the 7 Elevens and the absolute best examples of Human creativity were being showcased in Tv, Movies, and especially on independently operated websites. Those were halcyon days.”

They told Kate about the dangerous Peacecorps, which patrolled the Districts hunting down anyone they deemed a troublemaker. Kate had, of course, already experienced a Peacecorps patrol as she and Matt were making their way to the very house they were now sitting in. Braiden told Kate about the high-power peace enforcement techno blasters that the Peacecorps officers carried and about how dangerous they were. He emphasized this point to really drive home the idea that the Peacecorps officers were really scary. Kate was pretty scared, and she said things like “I am scared of that” and “that’s really scary to me” to clearly indicate her terror to anybody who might have been watching her, just in case her face wasn’t expressive enough to carry the emotion on its own.

The URM were the good guys, you see, and everybody in the Government were bad guys.

“You really couldn’t write a story this good,” Matt very astutely pointed out. “Sure, it would make a really great book, but it would take some sort of genius to come up with a story like this. I mean, the bad guys have guns that can shoot lightning at us. If somebody did write a book about this, it would definitely have plenty of explosions.”

Just then, the chair Braiden was sitting on exploded. This chair spontaneously disassembled itself just like the first one did, and with a loud clatter a handful of change once again fell out of Braiden’s pockets. Everybody in the room stood up in alarm, but once again Braiden was fine.

“The point is,” continued Braiden as he gathered up his loose change, “we have made it our mission to get rid of all of those rich aristocrats up in that Chamber Tower.” He pointed in an arbitrary direction, as if pointing at the Government Headquarters. Kate looked where he pointed, but it was just at the blank wall. He was just making a point, not actually pointing where the tower really was.

Braiden pulled out the last chair on his side of the table and sat down. “We want to make it clear that you can join us if you want, Kate, but if you choose not to you can still stay here with us, where you’ll safe from the dangers of the Mandate Zone. We don’t expect you to put yourself in any danger if you don’t feel comfortable with it.”

Kate thought about it for a moment, letting it all sink in. She looked around at all of the expectant faces looking at her, pleading at her. She thought about the ordeals she had gone through to get there. She thought about almost being captured by that Peacecorps patrol and Officer Traldo. She thought about the zombies roaming the streets. She thought about when she was attacked by bandits and how Matt rushed in to rescue her, and how even though it was really awesome it was also really scary. She was so overwhelmed by all of these new things, most of which were pretty terrifying.

“I’m sorry,” she said, “but I’m just not cut out for being a freedom fighter. You might think we don’t experience much Government Influence in District Delta, but we actually had things just as bad there. My . . .” she paused for a moment, obviously hiding a really deep and interesting backstory, “. . . family definitely met our share of Mandates. It’s not that I don’t agree with your ieas, I just . . .”

The others looked at her sympathetically.

“It’s okay, Kate,” said Matt’s Uncle Tom, “we understand.”

They all looked at each other, clearly let down by her unwillingness to help them.

“I mean,” added Kate, “I could probably help you come up with a better name, if you want.”

Matt looked at Braiden with a worried look. “But how will we . . .”

“We’ll figure something out, Matt.” Braiden responded, “if Kate doesn’t want to put herself in danger just for some people she just met, we can’t blame her.”

Matt’s Aunt Kathy added, “don’t you worry about it, Kate.” She was firmly supporting Kate’s decision. “Nobody will blame you for not wanting to go on some silly dangerous mission like something out of one of those great movies from the good old days. Talking about prophecies and destiny or whatever is all well and good, but let’s not forget that the real key to those stories is that they’re full of unnecessary explosions.”

Just then, everybody looked at Braiden, whose chair remained fully intact. He looked up at Kate and said, “Matt’s Aunt Kathy is right. I would probably make the same choice if I were in your shoes.”

“I guess I can head back out tomorrow,” said Matt, “and try to find someone else who can help us.”

“It’s just such a shame,” Matt’s Uncle Tom was also saying. “She would have been so perfect.” They were really laying it on thick.

“Now, now.” replied Braiden. He leaned back in his chair which responded with a slow creak. Everyone in the room held their breath for a moment. “She made her decision. Let’s not make her feel terrible about it, even if it means that all of our plans might completely fall apart and the bad Government will go on forever.”

The rest of them nodded.

“Well, that’s all there is to it, then,” concluded Braiden. “You might as well go try to get some rest and we’ll figure things out in the morning.” He smiled and stood, and then everybody else stood.

Matt and his Aunt and Uncle filed out of the meeting room, but Braiden stayed behind. “I’m sorry, Braiden,” said Kate as she went to the door. “Seriously, though, if you need some ideas for names . . .”

“It’s quite alright, Kate,” responded Braiden. “You go along and make yourself at home. I have to look over some of these Mandate reports from the neighboring districts.” Kate would have noticed the stack of papers earlier if it weren’t for the sheer quality of the table upon which they sat. It really was a very nice table.

Kate smiled sheepishly at Braiden and stepped out of the room, closing the door behind her. She was too absorbed in her own thoughts to notice the other girl Alice, who was standing in the kitchen glaring at her.

As Kate was walking away, she could hear from inside the meeting room the sound of a loud crash and a handful of change clattering across the floor.

* * * *

Later that night, Kate was watching more Tv with Pete and the little girls. Matt and his Aunt and Uncle had left to take care of their own various things which aren’t important to the plot. A woman entered the living area and addressed the girls. She was very motherly, and must have been either one of the girls’ mother or some sort of caretaker for the group’s children.

“Okay, Ashleys, it’s time for bed,” the woman said. The girls dejectedly flipped off the Tv and followed the woman down the hall and into another room.

Kate looked over at Pete, who was sound asleep in his easy chair. She wasn’t sure what to do, but felt curious about just how big this apartment was. She decided to do a bit of exploring, to figure out where Matt went.

She got up and looked down the hall leading away from the living area. It branched off to a stairway in one direction, and a few doors in the other. Kate headed up the stairs, which led to another living area and some more doors. There was no Tv in this area, and Kate noticed that a big set of curtains covered the wall behind where the Tv was downstairs. Opening the curtain, Kate was able to see the view of the vast cityscape that was visible from this old penthouse. She stared in wonder, never having seen anything like it. Buildings seemed to stretch off forever, an amazing mosaic of sizes, shapes, and colors twinkling in the night sky all the way to the horizon. A Peacecorps patrol plane (or car) slowly drifted along an avenue below, shining its spotlight at the ground beneath it. Further in the distance Kate could see some great, long vehicle - a transit train - zipping along a rail between buildings.

She watched this spectacle for what seemed to her like hours. Eventually she heard a voice behind one of the doors down the hall - Matt’s voice.

She closed the curtain and walked quietly down the hall, careful to overhear what he was saying. He was talking to someone. Kate could hear a muffled voice - a woman’s voice, but not quite human.

Reaching the door, she carefully turned the knob and opened the door just a tiny bit to see inside. What she saw almost made her scream because of how shocking it was.

Are you ready for it?

Inside the dark bedroom, Matt was sitting on a dirty mattress that had no sheets or blankets. In his hand was an opened can, and he was scooping something out of it with a spoon. Just in front of him, standing ominously in the light cast by the single overhead light bulb was a female zombie.

“These should be a bit more fresh,” Matt was saying. “I just got these cans today. How is it?” He lifted the spoon to the zombie.

The beast before him was slowly swaying, staring half at Matt and half at nothing. Its clothes were a tattered mess, but Matt had obviously made some effort recently to look after them. The creature had clearly been a woman before whatever grim fate transformed it into what it was. It had long, once beautiful hair, and its slender frame must have been quite striking. Now its darkened and scarred flesh hung from its bones in a most displeasing way. It responded to him in a mixture of mumbling and grunting, and Kate couldn’t understand what it - or perhaps she - said. It wasn’t taking the spoonful of mush that Matt was offering.

“Come on, you have to eat your brains.” Matt said. Finally he was able to get the zombie to take another spoonful into its mouth. It moaned in response, either approving or disapproving, Kate couldn’t tell which.

The zombie replied with another garbled sentence, but Kate could have sworn she heard the phrase, “looking for a job” Then it began reaching for Matt’s shirt. Kate was worried for a moment, and thought about trying to rush to stop this monster from attacking her new friend.

Matt sighed and calmly held the zombie’s hand. “My shirt is fine,” he said. “I’ll be able to get a job whether I tuck my shirt in or not.” He offered it another spoonful of brain mush.

Kate was very confused by what she was hearing. The zombie responded again, and this time Kate was sure it was asking Matt if he needed any money.

“I’m fine.” Matt responded, choking back a tear. “I’m just fine.”

Kate carefully closed the door again, and stood stunned in the darkness. It had dawned upon her that this wasn’t just a zombie. The way Matt was speaking to it, and the way it was attempting to speak back was suddenly quite clear. Matt was sitting in that sparse, cold room, calmly spoon feeding his zombified mother.

She realized then that this wasn’t just a fight of principal for him, this struggle against the Government. For him, this was personal. He was looking for revenge, and at that moment, Kate felt an incredible appreciation for him and his cause. She had lost both of her parents, too. It was clear to her, then, that she had to offer her help to this justified - albeit poorly named - group of freedom fighters.

She went right down, then, to find Braiden in the meeting room and tell him that she had changed her mind. She had decided that she was going to fight to see those Government aristocrats put to justice. Also, she wanted to get another look at that table. It was a really, really nice table.

“I’m so glad to hear that, Kate,” Braiden responded. “You may very well help us save the whole world, from right here in District Alpha: Government Mandate Zone!”

fields.title: How to be an Asshole: a Webcomic
Alleyways in Wicker Park
fields.text:
About five years ago I posted pictures here of some alleyways and dumpsters in West Lafayette, Indiana. For some reason I am fascinated by the secrets hiding behind the scenes in urban areas. Well-kept storefronts and urban planning can spruce up a city street, but it's an artificial beauty. Garbage piles, abandoned vehicles, and dumpsters - there is no superficiality in these things. On the other hand, there's a whole underground of people who fill these spaces graffiti, just because they can. What we get is a fascinating world filled with garbage and decay that we are programmed to ignore. A city is all slight of hand, distracting us with trees and polished windows to keep us from noticing the unavoidable filth that humanity leaves behind.

For the last year, I've lived in the Wicker Park neighborhood of Chicago. Chicago is a much larger city than West Lafayette, and so it has a great deal more filth to hide away. I've been meaning to capture some of it with my camera, and recently I finally did.

Wicker Park is the area around Milwaukee Avenue, from about Chicago Avenue in the South to about Armitage in the North. Hundreds of stores, from expensive boutique shops that hipsters shop at to the used clothing stores they want us all to think they shop at can be found there.
The intersection of Milwaukee, Damen, and North Avenues is like the center of a big, dumb hipster bike. Stupid hipsters.
The intersection also features quite a few back alleys.
Some alleys are pretty well organized and reasonably clean.
Almost any surface that isn't regularly watched for such things is covered with stickers and labels. Apparently a regular graffiti dude trick is to use stick-on labels to easily tag surfaces. A local graffiti dude called 'Weed Wolf' really loves this trick.
Here's a window right on North Avenue. Its only shelter is the scaffolding which has been set up around it for a while. I wonder what has to happen to make a surface suitable for graffiti.
This dumpster says 'Helter Skelter.' I'm not sure what the point of tagging dumpsters is. Maybe that means he owns the dumpster, in graffiti dude circles, or maybe they're just trying to score as many points as possible. A dumpster certainly isn't worth that many graffiti points.
Often alleys haven't been re-built or resurfaced as much as the streets that surround them. These old bricks have probably been here for a very long time.
This truck probably has, too. I wonder if they put it there specifically to be graffiti'd, or if it has just slowly been consumed by graffiti dudes seeking mad graffiti points.
Here's a closeup of the front of the graffiti truck. Are the graffiti dudes being nice for avoiding the truck's windshield, or are they being wimps for not going for the super mega double graffiti points available there?
Chicago's Blue Line travels along Milwaukee avenue through Wicker Park, and (at least where it's above ground) it's a great place for people to stash their filth.
The graffiti dudes have a lot of work to do. I can spot at least six surfaces that haven't been tagged. Come on, graffiti dudes.
This is an example of the pure utility of alleyways. Nobody put that trash there for any reason, it's just where it ended up.
No care was taken to make this place look nice at all. The backs of buildings are built with the cheapest, ugliest bricks. That garbage is strewn wherever is convenient. Even the graffiti is arguably only making it look worse. Is this place beautiful because of its complete lack of beauty?
I wonder how many times these fire escapes have been used.
Anybody want that broken plastic storage box?
These dumpsters are pretty close to the street, so they have a bit less filth scattered around them. Also, you can see some fliers posted there, trying to advertise to people who like to look closely at dumpsters.
Here's a weird wood box, and an old pinstriped suit jacket.
I think that's a bum's stash there, under the tracks.
Here's some strange aperture in this wall, from one of this building's pas lives. Just beyond you can see where a door used to be, replaced by bricks.
In a few places the CTA tracks are so long and straight that you get really awesome views like this. Nothing is ever built underneath the tracks.
I'm not sure what this building is used for anymore, but it once had a great deal of loading and unloading going on back here.
That dude got some serious graffiti points.
The building seemed to be pretty empty through these back windows. It's just begging to be rebuilt into some sweet apartments.
A bit further along the tracks you can find this painting on a garage door.
Here's another one of those views along the tracks, except with a fence in the way.
And another one, going the other way. It just seems to go on forever.
Years of street art has led to strange collages of bizarre art and torn shreds of paper on a few of the more obscure walls in the area.
Fuck bitches get $.
It's strange to see something like this pile of cleanly cut tree branches in the middle of a totally urban area.
Just up Damen, a vine-covered gate sits in front of this alley.
This is a small park on Damen. There aren't any dumpsters here, but you can still see the unavoidable decay of human influence. Years of people walking exactly the same way across this area has killed the grass growing there.
There's also graffiti. This graffiti dude was apparently stopped mid-tag.
You only see flowers next to a sidewalk. This bush is about as artificial as you can get a plant to be. Its shape, its color, and its very presence has been carefully chosen by human hands.

Is there anything that you can’t get on Amazon.com? I don’t think so. The problem now, though, is that it can be pretty hard to find what you’re looking for, because you have to search through a collection of everything that has ever been sold.

Let me give you an example. I’ve been finding that I run out of spoons all the time, so I figured I would just pop onto Amazon.com to buy some more. All I needed were spoons. That should be super easy to find, right? Apparently not.

Here’s a word-for-word list of my searches on Amazon.com, in order, and the main result they returned. This is all completely real - these are the real results returned by these search terms.

“spoons”

Munchkin Soft-Tip Infant Spoons

“spoons NOT infant”

Philips AVENT BPA Free Toddler Weaning Spoons, 6+Months

“adult spoons”

Egg and Spoon Race

“spoons for eating”

Munchkin Soft-Tip Infant Spoons

“ADULT spoons for eating”

Oneida Paul Revere 3-Piece Child Set

“regular metal spoons”

Norpro Stainless Steel Scoop, 56MM (4 Tablespoon)

“spoon for cereal”

Post Shredded Wheat Original Cereal, Spoon Size, 16.4 Ounce Boxes (Pack of 4)

“I just need some spoons, please”

Clairol Nice ‘n Easy Perfect 10 (Pack of 2)

“pack of spoons”

Munchkin Soft-Tip Infant Spoons

“ADULT pack of METAL spoons”

Thermos Stainless King SK3000MBTRI4 Food Jar, Midnight Blue

“regular plain old metal goddamn adult spoons for eating raisin nut bran”

No results.

“raisin nut bran”

Raisin Nut Bran Cereal, 17.1-Ounce Box (Pack of 6)

“milk”

Organic Valley Organic 1% Lowfat Single Serve Milk, 8-Ounce Aseptic Cartons (Pack of 24)

“how do you ship milk”

Omega J8005 Nutrition Center Single-Gear Commercial Masticating Juicer, Chrome and Black

“milk shipping container”

The 2009-2014 World Outlook for Steel and Aluminum Fluid Milk Shipping and Delivery Containers and Sheet Metal Grain Bins and Vats Excluding Crates, Drying Floors, Fans, and Heaters

“milk bottle”

Dr. Brown’s BPA Free Polypropylene Natural Flow Bottle Newborn Feeding Set

“Amazon stop giving me baby stuff I am not a baby”

No result.

“just show me something that isn’t for infants”

No result.

“I just wanted spoons”

The Adventures of Dj Spoon and Missy- The Bullying Stops: The Bullying Stops

I feel like I’m just getting farther and farther away from them. Also, I think Amazon.com is trying to tell me something - that I am going to need to invest in infant supplies.

I better make a few phone calls.

fields.title: Shauvon Fest
fields.text:
My parents moved to Arcadia, Indiana a few years ago. Every summer, Arcadia has a little festival to kick off the start of summer or whatever. It's no C2E2 - in fact it's kind of the opposite - but it was a chance for me to take a few pictures on a beautiful day.

I call it the Shauvon Festival, because it's on my birthday.

Arcadia is really just a few blocks, about an hour north of Indianapolis. For Shauvonfest, people come out and put up a few booths selling, well, junk.
At one end of town, a few (really) old cars were being shown off. They were actually pretty neat.
There were also some old scooter things.
Inside was an old MG, which by the looks of this picture was white and had an MG badge.
Those old cars had tiny little engines, or at least compared to how big the cars are.
This old car had a jumpseat. I had my 50mm lens, which can be a bit tough to capture shots with in close quarters.
While we were looking at the old cars, a dude hopped into this car (after winding up the engine) and drove off. Right on, dude.
Down the way was a Native American looking dude selling mostly tie dye t-shirts. Also this t-shirt.
Another tent had this bucket of $1.00 swords.
Indiana.
Yet another tent was selling some dime-store rings. The theme for Shauvonfest is 'People in Arcadia love buying whatever random crap you want to sell'
Somebody get this guy some 'O's - and one 'C'
The lady working the food trailer was selling more different items than there were people at Shauvonfest. Also, and I'm not passing any judgement here, she had a pretty serious mustache. I tried to see what kind of Hot Dog roller she had in there, but I couldn't see one. Total amateur hour.
Cornhole is still a thing?
Uncle Gary is serious about his Kettle Corn booth.
The World's Cheapest Carnival Ride was pretty popular.
Eventually a couple rambunctious youths rode by on their bicycles. This particular youth obviously thought two wheels was one too many.
If you like things depicting wolves, you had a few options.
Like this pretty awesome shirt.
There was even a band. I don't know what they were called, but it was probably something like 'Midge and Boys.'
Here you can see a dude who brought a little wagon with him to carry all the sweet junk he was hoping to find at the 'fest.
What leads a man to sell Pimp Hats at little town festivals? I mean, the pot leaf dream catcher is totally awesome, but is there really a market for pimp hats anymore?
This was literally just a junk table.
Alyson was a bit creeped out by a pile of furs and other dead animal parts.
These minerals and jewelry seemed pretty legitimate. The guy behind the table was talking to somebody and I heard him say that he would 'never sell plastic.'
The piece de resistance was this guy with almost an entire block of tables covered in old toys and hundreds of pictures of Marilyn Monroe.
It was almost impressive just how completely D-list his toy collection was.
He was a pretty nice guy, though. Crazy, but nice.
A few houses around town wanted to join in the junk sale fun, so they put some of their own junk out on the lawn for passers by to pick through. I guess somebody just didn't want these old shirts anymore

About DenyConformity.com
fields.text:
Welcome to DenyConformity.com, a really interesting website place!

DenyConformity.com uses a unique site design that - aside from making it ineligible for Google Ads - makes it (hopefully) easy and fast to use. The main page is structured like a timeline, so you can get a quick view of the content that has been posted recently, and so you can see posts dating back to the before-times. Also, the site takes advantage of modern browsers so you can always hit 'back' and 'forward' to navigate just as you would any other site. Posts on DenyConformity.com are categorized by a number of tags, which you can use to see similarly tagged content. Use the tags page (with the link at the top of the site) to see every tag on the site, or click on an individual tag at the bottom of any post to see all the posts with that tag.

DenyConformity.com is currently in Beta, which means that stuff might not work right. If something doesn't work like you think it should, report it to beta@denyconformity.com with a description of what you were trying to do.

A dude called Shauvon McGill started this website 2005 as a place to write about non-conformity. It quickly became a stupid place where he posted the uninteresting rants of an angst-y college student. More recently he has written much more interesting stuff. It's not dumb, now, I promise.

Shauvon is interested in Comedy, Photography, Fiction, Technology, and Ideas. Most of the stuff he posts here will fit into one of those categories. Check back daily (mostly) for content ranging from discussions of computer games to satire to beautiful (mostly) photographs - which are all available for sale, by the way - to original hand-drawn web comics.

The only goal of DenyConformity.com is to be an interesting website place. If you've been able to kill a few minutes of your day looking at cool pictures or reading a dumb thing and you don't think it was a complete waste of your time, DenyConformity.com has succeeded. If there's ever anything you'd like to read about or anything, feel free to make a request by sending an email to requests@denyconformity.com or by making a comment down below.

Your continued support is greatly appreciated. Shauvon doesn't get much out of this other than the satisfaction of being able to entertain people. If you have enjoyed something you saw here, you might consider buying a print of a picture or purchasing an ad on the site. Above all, though, the best thing you can do is share the site with your friends (we'll even take enemies). It's really appreciated.

fields.title: The Color Run pt. 1
fields.text:
There's this thing called the Color Run. It happens in a bunch of cities all over the country, and just this past weekend it happened in Chicago. It also happens that it's one of the coolest things ever.

It's just a regular old 5k, except that at predetermined locations along the route, a team of people toss colored powder at you. Everybody (there are thousands of runners) starts perfectly clean, and ends up completely covered in bright colors. It's truly amazing, and you should go check right now to see if it's coming to a city near you. Seriously, go to the website right now. I'll wait. It will be an experience you will never forget.

So Alyson ran the thing and I brought my camera. I wrapped it up in a garbage bag ahead of time to try to protect it from being color blasted, in case you worry about that.

I made sure I knew where the Yellow station was (it's my favorite color), and it just happened to be nearby the starting line (the route was sort of clothespin-shaped). The buckets full of powder looked pretty exciting.
The website said that they were going to let off groups of 1000 runners every five minutes for an hour. That's a lot of runners.
The website also said to wear as much white as possible. These lightning-bolt people were pretty neat (though you'll soon see that it surely didn't make much difference), but a lot of people thought it would be neat to wear colorful socks or other secondary clothes. That really defeats the purpose.
These Blues Brothers (emphasis on the 'blue') were there to warm up the crowd waiting to kick off at the starting line. The atmosphere at the starting line was really great - like a dance party.
Here's a group setting off. You can see some of the colorful socks there, which I don't think was a good idea. You can also see a few sunglasses, which is probably a really great idea.
It was a few minutes before any runners showed up at the yellow station. The first few people came through really quickly, like they were just there to run or something. Why you would come to this thing just to run, I have no idea.
The people posted at the yellow station had little things like mustard bottles which they used to squirt nice little streams of yellow powder. You can see one just to the left, in this shot.
I think they were told not to aim at the face, but obviously they bent that rule a bit.
There was, of course, collateral damage on the color team. This guy was really enjoying himself. You really can't blame him.
The powder is apparently just cornstarch. The air tasted like cornstarch every time a group of runners came by.
This girl had a sweet X on her face, which was apparently just about to be transformed into an asterisk.
The best runners were obviously enjoying the Hell out of it. It has to be the most fun.
The color blasters were excited, which really excited the runners, and that made the blasters even more excited. It was pretty exciting. Everybody was having an awesome, colorful time.
There was a bit of a breeze, which helped clear out the clouds.
The problem with following the 'no faces' rule is that then you just end up color blasting dudes in the junk. Maybe this girl liked that part, though.
Everybody ends the race looking different, and it really is awesome to see the different blasts of color, and what must have happened to cause them.
How about this dude? The explosion in the background is from the color blasters getting bored with their little spray bottles and just dumping what's left of those buckets full of powder on unsuspecting runners.
There were quite a few kids there, and a few mothers even ran the thing with a toddler in a stroller. I'm not sure how I feel about that, but the babies always seem pretty into it, and nobody was dumb enough to dump a bucket of powder on one.
They handed those number things out sequentially. This girl was the 7,916th person to check in.

That's the first half of my pictures. Next week I'll post the rest. Again, do this thing. If you aren't a runner (like me) just go and hang out. It's one of those things that's unlike anything you'll ever do. Just be sure you're prepared to be covered in corn starch.

fields.title: How to Be an Asshole: A Webcomic
How to Keep Your Apartment Organized
fields.text:
Somehow my email address was signed up for this “Apartment Guide” newsletter, which basically just sends me random garbage about apartments pretty much every day. I totally don’t need that, since I’m already an apartment expert. Apparently it’s totally cool to post articles about how to Apartment better, so it’s time for me to chime in.

Of particular interest is this article “Take Steps to Stay Organized in Your Apartment” which came to me today. I haven’t read that article, but I am sure I can come up with a better guide to keeping your apartment organized. For your consideration, I give you my version of that guide (with some marginally relevant pictures I dug up from my archives).

How to Keep Your Apartment Organized
or, Don’t Put That There
An example of an unorganized apartment. In my defense, most of it was caused by the cat. That little dude never picks up after himself.

It’s your apartment. Ultimately, you can do whatever you want. Let’s just face the facts, though - hot babes do not want to come hang out in a slob’s trash-pile. Cool Dudes are not going to want to chill in an unorganized apartment. If you ever want to run for President - and who doesn’t, come on - they will know that you had an unorganized apartment, and when the media gets a hold of that you’re done for.

There’s a basic instinct in all of us to avoid unorganized situations. Why do you think we started building houses in the first place? We did it to get the Hell out of Nature. Nature is pretty unorganized. In fact, Nature should really read this guide. You should probably print a few copies of this guide out and staple them to some trees outside. It wouldn’t hurt.

How disorganized.

Anyway, the point is that nobody wants to be with you if you aren’t organized. I’m not your Mom or anything, I’m not going to tell you how to live your life. I’m just telling you that people are going to constantly judge you. Here are some tips for you, if you feel like getting off your butt and not putting your garbage just any old place. Unlike some other guides out there, though, this guide will actually help you “turn over a new leaf” (I’m looking at you, Nature) and maintain a more organized apartment - not just for this year, but maybe even into the next.

Don’t put that there.

Seriously, that thing doesn’t go there. Just put it away now, while it’s in your hand. If you put it there, you’ll just have to make more of an effort later because you’ll have to pick it back up and then put it away. Just put it away now, and you’ll be done with it. I mean, unless wherever that thing goes is kind of hard to get to and your favorite show is on TV. You can put it away later.

Some things - lids to hamster cages, for instance - should definitely be put where they belong.

Leave your door open at night.

This might seem counter-intuitive. Sure, initially you’ll have some cleanup to take care of, but you’ll be really surprised how being robbed can make it much easier to organize your place. Okay, so you can try to sell some stuff on Craigslist or something, but that just takes so long and you have to talk to people. Just get yourself robbed and you’ll cut down how much stuff you have really quickly.

These are actual burglar's fingerprints.

Fire.

If you find that you have some areas that just seem to “attract” clutter, just throw a couple lit matches in the pile and watch as your problems take care of themselves. You might stand by with a bucket of water or something just in case the fire spreads to something you don’t want to get rid of, like the walls or the floor. Nothing says “unorganized” like not having a floor.

Guns don’t really work quite as well (nor do tires).

Designate a “garbage room.”

This is why I like to get an apartment with one more bedroom than I need. Now when you see some clutter or disorder, just scoop it up in your arms and toss it into your spare room. It can help to have a friend quickly open and close the door for you, so you don’t get buried in your own organization technique. You don’t want to end up like a cartoon.

Stay in there. I have company coming over.

Lie to yourself / others.

The easiest way to deal with an unorganized apartment is to just redefine the term “unorganized.” Try out the following handy mantras on yourself next time you find yourself questioning your organization:

  • Look, the reason you put things where you put them is because it’s easier. Convenience is the whole point of organization, isn’t it?
  • What do you mean? That’s where that thing goes.
  • Hey, look, Mythbusters is on.
  • Sure, that thing is in the way. We could put it away, or we could play some video games.
  • It’s just that we’re out of matches.

This technique works almost as well on others, too. When your friends come over, or you have some special lady company, just tell them something like:

  • “I know, I kind of hate it, too. It’s just that I’ve been reading these books about ancient Chinese mysticism, and apparently this is best for the energy of the space.”
  • “What do you mean? That’s where that thing goes.”
  • “Oh, like your place is any better.”
  • “I actually just moved in, so I’m still unpacking.”
  • “I’m in a feud with the garbage man right now, so he’s refusing to take any of it. I can either leave it in here or down on the street where identity thieves and raccoons are going to get into it.”
  • “I’m getting ready for a yard sale. You want that? Dollar fifty.”
Those are my roommate’s, I swear.

Stop seeking motivation from the Internet.

Honestly, this place - the Internet - is only for distracting you from your problems. Why are you sitting there reading that instead of just putting stuff away. You aren’t going to magically get an email that cleans your room. That’s why your parents made you do it when you were a kid - so you’d get into the habit. You know what? No more Internet until you finish your chores.

Seriously. We’re done. Clean your room.

Then shovel the sidewalk.

fields.title: What is Univox Corporation?
fields.text:
A while ago, I received this weird letter in the mail. It was from a company called 'Univox Corporation,' and it seemed to be hand typed. I had no idea what to make of it, but I just came across it in one of my desk drawers, and I thought I would post it here to share in the mystery.

I have reproduced it for you, typos and all.

1446 W. Irving Park Road
Chicago, Illinois 60613
(312) 588-2300

Dear valued customer,

It's the financial year-end inventory clearance season here at Univox, and we have our festive liquidation hats on. THAT MEANS SAVINGS! We've been Chicagoland's #1 UNIX Systems Distributor for over 75 years, and we didn't get here hosing you like those thieves at Gary's Tabulators and Adding Machines on 1901 W. Madison.

Our 6300 Series Mainframes come with freeinstallation and no money down! Featuring the latest versions of Solaris, HP-UX, and OpenSUSE, the 6300 can even be used with a monitor when configured to use the cutting edge X Windows System. Our code comes pre-compiled and ready to get the job done. Connect to USENET, BBS, ICQ, and Webs 1.0 and 2.0 with our exclusive ISDN service. When you need a computer that fills the room, the 6300 Series Mainframe from Univox gets it done. No money down and financingrates have never been better, 2.9% APR.

We're the only mainframe distributor that lets you shop at home, wkth free samples in your home, and one of our experienced service technicians, with over 350 years of comined installatuin experience on all types of floors, including carpet, wood, laminate vinyl, and tile. (Even on Pergo and Bellawood, availalbe at UNIVOX Discount Flooring Warehouse, 3319 N. Lincoln Ave.)

So whether you're making a family newsletter you can print on one of our many dot matrix printers, or ironing out the kinks of te interstage on your Teller-Ulam thermonuclear device, you can count on Univox Mainframes and Tele-Terminals. Follow us on Facebook with terminal command 'wget http://192.775.22.09/fb/like.js && ./thumsup.js' and plug your printer into our twitter feed at ///:LPD.192.775.22.09:9100 @univoxcomputrons.

Yours Truly,

Danielle Moinet, CEO

Pretty weird. The address supplied is just some house. It definitely doesn't look like the sort of place that would supply anything called a 'mainframe.' Some time later, a second letter arrived, this time printed like an old-fashioned dot-matrix print.

1446 W. Irving Park Road
Chicago, Illinois 60613
(312) 588-2300

Dear Univox Customer,

We hope you are enjoying your recently installed 6399 Minecraft Mainframe. We hope you have also noticed our brand-new, 100% computerized letterhead, and you may not believe it, but this proportionally spaced text is also produced by one of our state-of-the-art word processors. The time has never been better to fire that secretary and sell the typewriter, especially with this amazing savings event!

All of our word-processing capable computers are on sale! With price reductions of over 50% (Apple II only) it's big savings season here at Univox. Finally, you can correct your typographical errors with a single keystroke! Let potential employers know how computer-savoir-faire you really are with a cyber-tronic cover letter and resume! What was once the science-fiction dreams of rich men and kings can now be yours with one visit to our showroom.

If you act now, we will throw in a free ream! That's right, a whole 500 sheets of Univox Brand Computer Printer Paper! You could write a book, you could find that lost dog you've been looking for, you can advertise your blues-rock trioâ€™s upcoming gig. The possibilities are endless with Univox and paper.

Getcha on over here,

Darla Mannheim, Sales Director

Very weird. The whole thing remained a mystery for a while (I'm a bit iffy on the timing of the whole thing, since it was so long ago). In fact, as memory serves, I basically forgot about the whole Univox mystery. I put the letters in some drawer (where I found them just now), and went about my business.

Then I was headed from Lafayette, Indiana up to Chicago with a couple dudes, and we stopped at John Schuster's house in Valparaiso, Indiana. We were hanging out for a bit, and John went off to do something, so Andrew and I decided to check out his room. Sitting on a desk next to an old fashioned typewriter was a few papers - with the familiar 'Univox Corporation' letterhead. The mystery was solved.

The sad thing is that I actually could use some Mainframe computers. It took a few months, but I got my revenge...

fields.title: The Color Run pt. 2
fields.text:
Hopefully by now you've looked up your nearest and soonest Color Run and signed up for it on the Color Run website. Please find enclosed additional pictures to make you excited for the cool thing you'll be doing.

After a while, the air became pretty thick with yellow dust.
It was actually a bit tough to photograph. Aside from the obvious concerns of dust getting in and on the camera, the thick air made it difficult to properly focus, and substantially reduced the sunlight. Luckily it was a beautiful day, so there was still plenty of light and a cool breeze blew the dust away pretty quickly.
This picture, for example, is unfortunately focused on the arms spraying powder instead of the arms groping blindly through the yellow cloud. I still like this picture, though, for some reason.
I believe the spray bottle developed a clog, and so this color blaster just took the top off and went to town. I'm not sure which way this runner is facing.
Whenever a group of runners approached, the people at the yellow station began shouting things like, 'they aren't colorful enough!' or, 'they have too much green on them!' It was a fun tongue in cheek hostility.
It's kind of gross, but you could easily tell which people were more sweaty than others, and where.
The green station was right before the yellow one. They must have been absolutely crazy, because almost everybody we saw was quite green. It really motivated the yellow blasters to up their game.
In the background you can see someone who is very green. In the foreground you can see the girl who will soon change that.
This guy was really fun. Still.
Something about this girl apparently made everybody only want to color blast her head and shoulders.
I just didn't get the people who seemed completely uninterested in the whole thing. This guy didn't even seem to notice.
Yet more proof of the green team's handiwork.
It was way better when the runners were having fun.
When one big group went by, this girl started just jumping around flinging dust everywhere. It was pretty epic.
It was like watching an action movie to see all of these runners emerge from a billowing explosion of color.
Sometimes you can't help but smile at some people. Then you get a mouthful of cornstarch. It's basically a win-win.
Here are a couple more pictures of this serious chick.
You can see just how completely the world was shrouded in dust.
Those bottles had some pretty good range. Eventually, though, the pathway was completely covered in a solid inch of dust - about half-way through the whole event.

Unfortunately I can only take so many pictures before I run out of space, and I was nervous about taking my camera out of the garbage bag cover I had fashioned, so I just had to call it quits. We met up with Alyson, who was pretty well covered with color, and found our way to the finish line ceremony. Each runner was given a pouch of color. You can probably spot them in some of my pictures. They were all sorts of colors, not just the basic blue, red, green, and yellow of the course. At the finishing line, a huge group of people gathered - probably four hundred by the time we made our way there. Suddenly the call went out, and everybody tore open their pouches and flung the contents in the air. It was an incredible 45 seconds. Afterwords everybody was a tableau of random colors. It was definitely one of the coolest things I've ever been a part of.

fields.title: How to Be an Asshole: A Webcomic
Picture Letters
fields.text:
Maybe you've seen some of these silly 'spell out things with pictures' items you can get from Skymall or whatever. I didn't think much about them when I've seen them before, but it recently occurred to me that I could be making them and selling them for fat stacks.

I spent the better part of today running around downtown Chicago trying to build a library of letter pictures. The idea is that you take pictures of architecture and inanimate objects that look like different letters of the alphabet. Then you can spell out your last name or your favorite word or something and hang it in your game room or office. How hard can it be?

What letter looks like a penis?

It's actually more challenging than you might think. I figured that some letters would be easier to find in the wild than others. Plenty of windows look like an 'E.' Street lamps and plenty of other things look like 'I's.' The thing is, though, that in practice it's kind of hard to get decent versions of those shapes. The real toughies were 'G' 'B' 'J' and 'C.' It turns out that those shapes aren't very common without looking more like other letters instead.

I was worried I wouldn't find a 'G' until I came across this little squiggle.

Ultimately, it was a really fun little project, and I especially enjoyed taking strange closeup pictures of random things and then pulling out my little notebook to make note of which letters I'd captured. Finding a perfect example of a letter is pretty exciting, and finally coming across a letter I had trouble finding is genuinely satisfying. The best way to go is to just keep your eyes peeled for any familiar shapes. Don't just search for one letter at a time. It's definitely much more exciting and faster to just get whatever letters you find.

Q was a fun one to find.

You should give it a shot some time. If you know somebody for whom this sort of thing would make a good gift, spend an afternoon trying to get some pictures together. It will save you the cost of a dumb Skymall item, and it will challenge your creative side.

Or, if you're lazy or don't have the photographic skills to do it or you don't live in Chicago, you could buy one from me! Send an email to photo@denyconformity.com if you're interested. I'm serious. Does anybody know how to start an Etsy store?

Here's one I put together for myself. What do you think?

fields.title: Univox Corporation: The Rebutal
fields.text:
Last week I posted a couple letters I received from some strange company called Univox Corporation (What is Univox Corporation?). Well, I found out that they came from my old friend John. I was the subject of some weird prank trying to get me to go to a random address in Chicago looking for computer mainframes and looking the fool. Revenge was in order. I decided to respond in kind.

While at some consignment / used clothing / junk store, I found an old back-issue of PC Magazine - from the late 90’s. It was full of articles and ads talking about really old computer stuff that’s so obsolete now it’s actually a joke. At least, I hoped it would make for a pretty good joke. I knew it would be the perfect random thing to send to my friends at Univox, so I mailed it to John, along with a letter. In the interest of continuing my series on “I have nothing to write about so I’m just digging up random stuff out of my drawers” I have transcribed the letter below.

Danielle Moinet
Univox Corporation
1446 W. Irving Park Road
Chicago, IL 60613

Subject: NEW TECHNOLOGISTICS

Do you have time and money just laying around to waste on any old thing?

The future sure comes on quickly, and the rest of us must struggle to catch up. All you have to do is blink a few times and you suddenly see a new server terminal interface module or a high-baud network protocol. The world is surely a minefield of microchips and capacitirons, and we're living on the razor's edge between technologistics that catapault us into the profit zone and those that leave you with no enough space for your PCI option ROM. What you need is a rudder to guide you through the silicone sea. We here at FUTECH LOGISTICS are that rudder.

Our expert team of LOGISTICS MAXIMIZERS will analyze every aspect of your educational outreach program and your upward dynamic revenue synergy. Then they determine exactly the perfect machine type for each of your departments. Most companies settle for a single computer mainframe for the entire staff. At FUTECH LOGISTICS, we envision â€“ as I hope you do â€“ a future containing three or even four computers for every man, woman, and child on your EXTREMELY PROFITABLE team.

We have helped many businesses succeed where others have failed. Using our expert knowledge, our clients don't waste their time and money buying just any old thing. I ask again: do you have time and money to waste on any old thing? Don't be like the other guys. Be like the guys of the future. BE FUTECH LOGISTICS GUYS.

To prove that we “know our stuff” (one of our many slogans and catch-phrases), I have attached just one of the many super-modern tech magazines that we often have just laying about the office. Inside you'll find many bizz-words which we use as our bread and butter. Is that stuff intimidating? Don't be! It's our job to help you GET HER FINISHED.

Please consider us in the coming business cycle as you decide on your technologistic needs.

Samantha Standles
Marketing Manager, Futech Logistics

Is this the last we’ll hear of these two technology companies? Will Univox Corporation and Futech Logistics work out a deal? Only time will tell.

fields.title: Opinion: Those Were Totally Gunshots Just Now
fields.text:
Once, when I was a kid, my Dad took me to a gun range. We went with another guy and his kid - their family was sort of friends with my family or whatever. We had an old .22, the other dad had a huge-ass muzzle-loader, and there was some sort of medium-caliber revolver. I don’t remember much about the afternoon, other than that the muzzle-loader was pretty terrifying. I fired the .22 a few times, and I gave the revolver a try, but generally I was a pretty scared kid who didn’t like doing things that could easily murder somebody. I haven’t changed a whole lot, but I kind of want to go back to a shooting range to fire a gun again. Mainly because I don’t remember what they sound like in person.

The point is, I totally just heard a few gunshots outside. Admittedly I am not sure what gunshots sound like, but movies have taught me that they can be pretty varied. All I know is that, just now, outside, there was this pop pop pop sound, like three tiny explosions. It happened all in a row, like one, two, three. I mean, that’s totally gunshots, right?

The problem is that it was kind of nice out today, not like the sweltering heat that we’ve been having. I’ve been worried about the power bill from all this AC action, so I had my window open. That’s how I was able to hear this sound so clearly. I bet somebody had a score to settle, and he wanted to take advantage of this nice weather to come on over and settle said score. That is just the sort of calculating individual who would make sure there are no witnesses. I’m not completely sure, but I might just count as a witness that needs to be silenced. Don’t tell anybody I told you about this, seriously.

I know the Fourth of July just happened. Perhaps they were fireworks, you might posit. Look, you - the Fourth of July was like a week ago. I don’t know much about people who launch fireworks in urban areas, but they totally seem like the sort that would get bored easily, so they’re certainly on to other crazy illegal things that the police won’t do anything about. Not only that, but I know what fireworks sound like. This was not like any firework. There was no fizzle. There was no sizzle. I heard no sparks, nor did I hear any report of a launcher or something like that. Also, there’s the fact that there were three of them, in quick succession. Like, it was just “blam, blam, blam” and then nothing. Who would light three fireworks at once and then do nothing else? I don’t know, but I do know that three bullets would totally be enough to settle a score.

I wasn’t really paying much attention before the sound, because I was busy looking at the Internet and I don’t usually pay much attention to the out-of-doors. However, now that I think about it I think there was actually a scream or shouting or something before the sound. I think I heard a guy shouting, possibly saying something like “take it easy bro, let’s work this out!” I didn’t actually hear anybody say that, and I’m not totally sure what somebody would really say when a guy is all up on them looking to settle a score, but movies teach me it would be something like that. It was one of those things that I normally wouldn’t have thought much about, but then I heard some sounds that were totally gunshots so now I think it must have been a guy yelling. I mean, at the time it sounded like maybe just a car revving, but it could also have been a guy yelling.

I’m not totally sure what’s going on now, because I can’t hear much when I’m crammed in between these coats. Needless to say, when I work up the courage to come out of my closet here and try to check the police blotter for info about a score settling gun crime in my area, I’ll definitely post the whys and wherefores of the whole thing. On the other hand, it’s actually pretty comfortable in here. I have some shoes piled up like a little butt pillow, and these coats aren’t bad to lean against. Maybe I’ll just spend the night in here.

Oh crap, I should probably have closed that window . . .

fields.title: Counterpoint: Maybe We Should Order a Pizza
fields.text:
So a lot of talk has been going around about supposed sounds out back and theories about what those sounds were. Sure, we could knock around ideas all day about what we think about this or that sound, but where would that get us? The fact is that there are sounds all the time, and it just doesn’t make sense to try to categorize and place each and every one of them. I mean, so what if something outside kind of sounds like it might be, oh, I don’t know, gunshots or something, you know? That’s just distracting us from the real issue - namely, do you want to order a pizza or something?

I know a pretty good place, or we could Yelp it if you want to try something new. I’m totally up for whatever. I’m actually pretty hungry - I didn’t have much of a dinner last night and I skipped breakfast. You know how it is, sometimes you get really busy and you just don’t realize where the time went. It’s not really important what I had for dinner last night. Come on, It’s not like I only had some old nip chees that were in a jacket pocket in the closet. That would just be weird, man. It was some captain’s wafers.

That’s neither here nor there, though. Oh, hey, maybe we could play some Xbox. Do you want to order a pizza and play some Xbox? I’ve been playing this one game lately. You play as an undercover cop working in a really dangerous neighborhood. I get pretty into it, but it’s really intense. In the game there are these two gangs that are at war, and sometimes dudes will just start shooting at each other out of nowhere and . . . you know what, let’s not play that game. Man, I haven’t fired up Viva Pinata in a while.

We’re going to have to move the couch really quick, actually. Oh, I was doing some redecorating. I just wanted to see how the room looked if I moved stuff around a bit. I’ve been reading up on feng shui lately. You know, feng shui, where sometimes if you pile up a bunch of furniture in front of the back door and windows it charges the room with positive energy. You don’t feel that energy? Well, we can put it back for now, anyway. I guess the couch is better in front of the TV. I guess they didn’t have TV’s back when they invented feng shui, huh?

Let’s just order a pizza then, yeah? We can do it online. It’s really easy. Just ignore my other browser tabs. I like to check in on the local news sometimes. It’s pretty funny what you read on the old Police blotter’s website occasionally. I check it all the time. My street is actually one of the lowest crime areas in the city. Did you know that? I totally did - it’s why I moved here. Yup, I’m glad I checked the old crime reports a long time ago, before this morning.

Oh yeah, the other thing was that my phone died. Just in case you tried to call me - that’s why I didn’t answer. It’s better now, I plugged it in. You know how these smartphones go these days, they just have no battery life. You can never tell if somebody hasn’t charged their phone or if they just left it in the other room and for whatever reason they’re too scared to go get it. I mean, too scared or lazy. Either one - there’s no reason I said “scared” first.

How about those fireworks stores, though, huh? Did you know they just keep selling cheap fireworks for like ever? The Fourth was like a week ago! They have those “buy one get fifteen free” deals, now. You can get a bunch of those popper things that just go “pop, pop, pop” really quick, like one, two, three. I mean, I’m guessing they have a thing like that. It would be pretty exciting. The police sure don’t seem to care much about if you launch fireworks in the city, huh?

Anyway, yeah, we should get on that pizza train. We could try this one place. I actually have a coupon. I mean, we could Yelp it, or we could use this coupon. Whatever you want to do - I’ve had it a while. I was organizing my closet earlier and I found it. Crazy, huh? Just doing some spring - er, summer cleaning. Oh yeah, I always like to organize my winter coats and sweaters in the middle of summer. Anyway, yeah, I found this coupon and some captain’s wafers and a couple bucks in change. We are set for the night.

Well, I already ate the captain’s wafers...

fields.title: Introducing Fankboner Industries
fields.text:
The last two and a half weeks have been pretty rough. I’ve been contending with a lot of serious work to do, moving to a new city, and the fact that regularly posting something here is just hard. As a result of all these excuses, the last three weeks have seen so little content here that I’m sure we’ve lost our precious tiny audience. This has led to a new development which kind of becomes a sort of good news / bad news situation.

The bad news is that I’m going to be losing a certain amount of creative control. I know what you’re thinking. Without you, where will I get my fix for dumb jokes and ideas? you might be asking. Don’t worry, I’ll still be here. I’ll just be getting a little, let’s just say help.

Since I started this website, in 2005, it has existed as the centerpiece of my online company, DenyConformity Media. What you may not know is that a few years ago, not long before the site’s big April Fool’s Day relaunch, my company was bought out. A large, mysterious corporation moved in and put forward a pretty hefty investment to own this mighty empire. It turns out that I might have made this bed for myself, in fact.

Back in 2006, I wrote an ill-conceived post about a job I had. It was mainly about some interesting names I had found in a Purdue database. The last name I found belonged to one Harland Fankboner, an Purdue graduate from way back in 1901.

He still looks like a Fankboner.

Well it just so happens that this enigmatic corporation which wholly owns yours truly goes by the name of Fankboner Industries.

This is their logo, which I only know from the letterhead on their - frankly quite pushy - letters.

Is it a coincidence? Of course not. As I was told (or at least what I’m allowed to tell you) is that my benefactors wanted to maintain a silent role in ensuring DenyConformity.com maintained a “more intentional drive for integrity” and that it became a “more interesting place.” Until now I had to follow their directives (such as not talking about their namesake anymore) without acknowledging their presence (or even their existence). I had to keep that up until now.

The new DenyConformity.com was a bit of a “last straw” scenario for my benefactors. Either I succeeded in finally making this little arm of Fankboner Industries finally successful, or they were going to step in and take over. Unfortunately for me, though I tried my best at the former, the latter has come to pass. Please welcome Fankboner Industries as they step in to really kick this website into shape.

What can you expect from the new Fankboner Industries Presents DenyConformity.com? We’ll just have to wait and see.
