fields.title: How to Be an Asshole: A Webcomic
Installing a Ceiling Hoist Bike Rack
fields.text:
Or, How Two Dudes Did a Thing Despite Being a Pair of Bumbling Idiots

I enjoy riding a bike. They provide cheap transportation (over short distances), they’re fun to work on and maintain, and they’re pretty good excercise. The problem - especially for me - is that they take up a lot of space. I have a 2009 Specialized Secteur, and it’s huge. I have to buy the largest frame Specialized makes. Where can I keep this thing?

I’ve had two bikes stolen from me, so I’m not interested in leaving my bike outside for any length of time. That means I have to keep it inside my apartment, where space is at a premium. I’ve heard about these kits you can buy which amount to a series of pulleys you attach to your ceiling. You can then hoist your bike into the air like you just don’t care (though if you have any sense of gravity at all you might be a bit concerned). My new apartment happens to have pretty high ceilings, so I figured the time was perfect to give one of these kits a try.

My friend Andrew Monkey stopped by to give me a hand installing it.

This is the kit that arrived from Amazon.com. As shown on the box you can also use this thing to hoist ladders. I bet you could probably hoist all kinds of things (as long as they don’t exceed the 50 pound weight limit). I was going to make a silly list of things you could hoist - things like pants, children, other hoists, and that kind of thing - but I want to keep this post serious. This is important.
This is my bike. I did those handlebars up in yellow and painted the seat post myself. There is more yellow I wish to apply, but that’s neither here nor there. For scale, that lightswitch is a standard light switch height, so you can picture my bike seat being as tall as that.
This is the corner I wanted to put the thing. This way my bike will be up and out of the way and hanging right over the litter box - just so the cat is reminded who’s boss around here.
The kit came with the two ceiling mounts, two pulleys with little armatures (not pictured), a really long rope (not pictured), and a bunch of screws. The instructions show the thing being mounted directly to a ceiling joist. I’m not sure if my ceiling is made of drywall or plaster or what, but I do know that you shouldn’t just screw this thing any old place. It definitely has to go right into a joist. The directions say that you can mount the thing to a board and then attach that board to the joists, and that sounded like a good idea to me. I figured it would be easier to attach a board to the ceiling than these cumbersome things. If you have a garage with exposed joists, you can just screw the pieces up there and call it a day, you lucky dog you.
The only board I could get was eight feet long, so Andrew helped me measure it in half.
The dude knows a good pen when he sees one.
A four foot board would be the perfect length for my bike. We have enough board left over to make another one of these (if I got another kit, anyway).
This is unrelated. If you see my sister, don’t tell her that this is her birthday present, but that she should come see me for some reason. Make something up.
The board was very much not straight. I figured it wouldn’t be a problem, since it was the only board we had, and - you know - whatever.
Andrew brought his circular saw to cut the board with. I recommend having a friend who has lots of tools that you don’t have. You have to put up with them babbling at you about who knows what, but it’s worth it when you need a circular saw.
I very precisely marked out where the two hoist pulleys needed to go. They hang onto the bike (or the bike hangs onto them) at the handlebars and the seat, so I marked those locations on the board.
Woah, this is a picture of me. Not many of those around.
I screwed the pulley assemblies onto the board where I marked for them to be screwed. It seemed like the thing to do.
Now it was time to figure out where the board needed to go. There are two ways to find studs (or joists) in the wall (or ceiling). You can take a drill and make hundreds of little holes until you drill into solid wood, or you can get a stud finder, which uses magic to tell you where the studs are. I had to run to the Sheller Mart down the street to pick up a 9-Volt battery (the magic kind), and I set about finding where the joist was. Stud finders might seem like a hokey thing, but they work great. Explain that one, science!
While I was doing that, Andrew fired up some Obama Type.
Here are some of the bits I didn’t include in the other picture (except the drill, that was in the other picture). The tape measure and drill were not included in the kit but they’re good things to have around. Don’t rely on your babbling friend to have those things for you - you should have them for yourself.
Here I am gloriously modeling the screws I got to attach the board to the ceiling. They were like four inches long and pretty serious. I wanted to be sure they would get through the two-inch thick board and still have plenty of screw left for the joist.
We chose a drill bit to make some pilot holes. We thought were were being really smart by holding it up next to the screws, and we took this picture to document just how smart we were.
Then this happened. The drill bit just hauled off and broke inside the board. Now there is a drill bit permanently included with my ceiling hoist, so there’s that.
So we picked out a new drill bit, and re-drilled the pilot holes. What a couple of bumbling idiots.
I put all of the screws in position, ready to just go right up into the ceiling. I was really optimistic about that happening.
This picture really belies the fact that it was a pain in the ass (and the arm) to hold the board in place. I was standing basically on top of an ancient ladder (thanks for letting me use that, Andrew) and holding that up about as high as I could. The ceiling is very high. I had to line the thing up, and then commence to screwing. That’s no easy feat for an idiot as prone to bumbling as I.
As you can probably imagine - as I can imagine now that I have the magnificent power of hindsight - the screws didn’t go into the ceiling joist basically at all. I live in an extremely old building, from back in the day when they built buildings before they started not making things like they used to. We decided that the ceiling joist also needed some pilot holes, which meant marking where they needed to go. This picture shows me putting the screws in a bit further - or farther, whatever.
With all of the screws poking out like this, all I had to do was hold the board in place and give it a good whack - or thwack, whatever - and I would have a mark for each screw. Again, we decided this plan made us some sort of pair of geniouses. Not being able to spell geniuses belies the fact that I am, in fact, part of a pair of them.
I got back on up there and gave the board the aforesaid whack / thwack.
Then I hauled off and drilled that sucker with the drill bit that survived drilling the other holes. This was a difficult thing, because man that ceiling joist was one tough mother. I could go an inch or two, but then it felt like I just couldn’t drill any further / farther. It was like trying to drill into rock, or like, some sort of heavy metal. Try as I might, I just could not get the screws to go in all the way. The really tough thing was that Andrew was too short to give it a try himself. I was the only person who could make this thing happen.
For some reason, Alyson wasn’t completely confident.
New plan! We attached a pair of spacers to the bottom of the board. These incredibly high tech components would mean that the ridiculously over-sized screws I bought wouldn’t have to go into the joist quite as far, thereby hopefully meaning that I would actually be able to screw them in all the way.
The holes in the spacers are very scientific calibration and load-bearing components, not side-effects of the fact that the spacers were once part of a piece of Ikea furniture.
I don’t know why I thought you would want to see a picture of some holes in a ceiling, but here you go. Feast your eyes.
The spacers did the trick! Using my incredible man-strength, I was able to get all of the monster screws into the ceiling as far as they could go. The people upstairs haven’t complained about screws sticking out of their floor yet.
All I had to do now was run the rope through the various pulleys, starting with this little hole where the rope starts.
Andrew had a grand old time, and we had only strung one of the pulleys up.
Here it is fully assembled. Without a weight like a bike or a child on the little fingers, they don’t both go up and down as you pull the rope. This makes it actually not as fun to play with as when there was only one pulley on it, but this isn’t some sort of toy.
I hooked my bike up to it and gave the rope a tug. It worked! Both armatures rose at the same time, and it was not terribly difficult to pull the rope with my bike attached. It only took a small fraction of my fantastic man-strength. Here you see the look of terror on Alyson’s face as I use the hoist for the first time.
Andrew is a normally sized man, and it was well over his head. I can still bump my head on it - in fact I have - but that’s just because of my freakish height.
Just because the project was finished doesn’t mean that I was done being an idiot. Whatever you do, don’t assume that the rope is plenty long enough and cut the excess while the bike is hanging there. Don’t you realize (I’m talking to myself here) that the excess slack is so you can lower the bike? Luckily (I’m talking to you, again), after doing the stupid thing, the excess rope was actually long enough to work, so after re-doing the whole pulley system, I can actually use the thing.
Even though it was installed by a couple of goomers, the ceiling bike hoist system works pretty great. There was a bit of panic right before I used it for the first time that it was too close to the wall (you can see that the front wheel is turned slightly so it fits better). It just barely has enough room, but this is definitely something you should remember to watch out for if you ever try to do this in a less stupid way than I did.

Do you have some bikes (or other things weighing less than 50 pounds) in your way, but plenty of ceiling space in which to hang them? You should definitely consider buying and assembling one of these contraptions. The ceiling bike hoist is a cool thing that is a bit easier to use than it was to install, but it will definitely pay for itself in the convenience it brings. My bike has been hanging up there for about a week, and it’s still holding strong.

Make sure you bring a friend along to help you with your ceiling bike hoist. Just try not to bumble quite as much as we did when you go to install it.

fields.title: Everything is Okay, an FTL adventure
fields.text:
by Brandon Lionel Kirk

[This is the first in a series of posts narrating a single playthrough of the indie game FTL. It's all made up, but entirely based on things that happen in the game. We open on a aspiring young captain, setting off on a vital mission to save the Federation. . .]

Captain’s log, stardate . . .

Does anybody know what day it is? Oh, screw it, I’ll start over.

How do I stop this thing? No, I just want to erase it and start over. This one? Nope, that just made it louder. This is weird. I can hear myself. Here. Okay, that got it, right? Damn it. Ok, whatever. That’s fine. Everything is okay. I will just start over.

Ok, um, hello, there. Greetings. This is Captain Brandon Kirk (no relation), of the spaceship Brandon Kirk. Now I have proof that everything in my life is not just a series of completely random encounters, because I have achieved the rank of Captain and gotten my own ship which I have named after myself. Finally, nobody will scoff at the name Brandon Kirk, because it is not only the name of a totally real space captain but also a totally great spaceship. The jerks over at the Milky Way Copy Hut (where I had my new business cards printed) will have to eat their words once the name Brandon Kirk is synonymous with either “War Hero” or at least “Functional Spaceship.” I know my therapist, Dr. Wendle, would tell me to stop taking others’ comments so personally, and I am trying to do that. Those guys were jerks, and that’s fine. I am okay with others making comments directed at me. Everything is okay.

The USS Brandon Kirk, in full military deployment.

My new crew checked in today. They’re all male (or at least malien). That’s fine. I am okay with that. I have to revise my Dream Girlfriend Plan, but that will be much easier now that I’m a Space Captain (and have the same name as a Real Spaceship). I’m sure my crew was assigned to my ship based on their aptitude and ability to work together, not just generated at random. Dr. Wendle is always telling me to remember that our lives are the product of our own choices, and not - despite my theories or perhaps delusions otherwise - just a series of randomly generated encounters and events with no real connection or causation involved. I’m sure we will all do just great.

I’m getting to know the new team. I assigned Sem to the helm, because that’s where he was when I came aboard. I needed somebody I could trust at the shield terminal, obviously, so I sent the other human there. It’s not a race thing - he’s white. I don’t know what the Hell kind of name Rafn is, though. That’s fine. I will learn to be okay with having a crew member called Rafn.

We have two aliens aboard. Willow is some sort of crazy electricity monster, so I put him as far from me as possible, in the engine room. Finally, there’s Junpeng. I’m absolutely not afraid of him or his crazy-ass name, and I let him do what he asked to do - man the weapons - because he obviously has a natural proclivity to do that. I’m not afraid of him. I am not afraid of his arms which are basically just four foot long blades, or the fact that the only personal items he brought on board consist of raw meat and the latest issue of Forbes Magazine. That’s fine. I will learn to be okay with living with a creature that personifies my two biggest fears, giant blade monsters and investment banking. As my therapist has pointed out, other people’s financial decisions have no bearing on me, so I need to just relax and try not to dwell on that.

With the crew in place and the power systems allocated, the USS Brandon Kirk and her captain - me, Brandon Kirk - set off on our first big mission, which is important, I think. So, I wasn’t exactly paying attention to the mission briefing. That’s fine. I spent the time working on the name of my new ship, which is how I came up with the great ship name Brandon Kirk. It works on so many levels, you see. I’m sure my therapist would use it as a sign of my supposed “narcissistic tendencies,” but there’s a reason I didn’t bring Dr. “Broken Record” Wendle onto my spaceship. I shouldn’t say that about her. I’m sorry, Dr. Wendle. You probably have good reason to point out my many narcissistic tendencies and crippling negativity. No, I am okay with myself. I am a powerful Space Captain, now. I am a successful person.

So I’m not actually sure what we’re doing out here. That’s fine. I’m okay with that. As Dr. Wendle would say, “don’t focus on what you can’t do - be proud of what you can.” So I can’t figure out what exactly my mission is. I’m sure it wasn’t something vitally important, since I’m kinda new to this whole thing and I just have a pretty basic ship with a completely inexperienced crew. That’s fine. I’m not “saving the galaxy” or anything of that sort. I will just focus on what I can. My ship has four basic lasers - I like to just call them lasers, I don’t see the need to focus on the fact that they’re “basic” lasers - so obviously our main mission is to shoot things with lasers. We will set off to find something that we can shoot lasers at.

The first encounter of the USS Brandon Kirk.

Aha! We took one faster than light jump and came across a poor sap needing help. This light came up on my dashboard indicating that someone was in distress (I call it the distress signal). My therapist told me that when I feel down on myself I should try to focus on helping others, so off we went to the source of the signal. I’m . . . not down on myself. I’m just saying that’s what my therapist told me. I mean, my bed on this ship is more firm than my one at home, and I forgot to requisition any evening primrose oil supplements for the ship so my fatty acid levels have been imbalanced . . . Um, everything is fine, except for this poor sap sending out their distress call. They need help. I am okay, though.

So there it was, this small ship struggling to maneuver through an asteroid belt. I disregarded my first thought which was, “couldn’t you have just gone over the asteroid belt?” As Dr. Wendle would say, that’s just “stinking thinking.” I tried to see if we could just shoot some of the asteroids with our lasers - that being our mission, and all - but the crew assured me it would be impossible for some reason. I ordered Sem to take the ship into the field and escort the poor sap to safety. Obviously what this situation needed was a giant, marginally maneuverable spaceship getting in the way.

Let’s just chalk this one up as a wash.

That’s fine. I am okay with the fact that the ship was embedded into an asteroid and exploded and nobody survived. My therapist told me to stop blaming others for my problems, and so I will try my best to do that even though I’m pretty sure it was Sem’s fault. I do have to give my guys credit for being quick on the draw with those salvage operations, though. We dug ten scrap out of that asteroid before heading on our way. I’m sure Dr. Wendle would tell me to “look on the bright side.” The bright side here is that we got ten pieces of scrap metal.

Well, okay, then. I have to go sit under my UV lamp for a while. The Brandon Kirk is currently a bit too far from any stars, so I’m not getting enough natural sunlight in my cabin. If I don’t get enough UV exposure my vitamin D-6 levels will go down. Then I won’t be able to sleep, and that means the next time we encounter a serious decision like we saw today (one based purely on the skill and quick reaction of myself and my crew, not entirely on random chance, of course) I won’t be able to make the lightning quick decisions that save lives. Well, today’s decision didn’t save any lives, but that’s fine. I am okay with the decisions I made today. Well, I am unhappy that I forgot to pack my white noise machine, but my cabin is close enough to the reactor that I should be okay. Everything is okay.

Everything is okay.

I better schedule an appointment to see Dr. Wendle when we get back.

To be continued . . .

fields.title: Small Victories (an FTL adventure, part 2)
fields.text:
By Brandon Kirk

[This is part two of an ongoing narrative based around a single playthrough I did of the Indie game FTL. It's highly abstracted and fictionalized, but it's entirely based on in-game events and situations. It's a fun game. You should play it.]

Dear Diary. Oh, that sounds so stupid. I really need to figure out how to reset this thing. What if . . . Nope, now it’s just louder, again. Whatever. Dear . . . um, Log. The mission is going so great. Well, okay, I don’t actually know what my mission was, but that’s fine. I have accepted that, and decided to just let my mission find me. As my therapist, Dr. Wendle would say, I’m going to just focus on the little victories.

Business as usual here on the USS Brandon Kirk.

Life is just fine aboard the Brandon Kirk. Well, okay, there are a few things that I will need to remember in the future. For example, when I am leaving the medbay through the port-most doors, I have to remember to turn right instead of left. Turning right will take me to the Air Circulation control room. Turning left will take me into the unsurvivable vacuum of space. It’s just little things. Thankfully, the ship has systems in place to prevent anyone from being sucked into space if someone opens one of those external doors. Still, it gets very cold. It also gets very hard to breathe.

Today we continued to venture forth through space, jumping from system to system in search of things to shoot with lasers. Arriving at one system, we happened to run into an automated scout ship protecting some sort of storage cache inside a nebula.

The USS Brandon Kirk’s first hostile encounter.

The dangerous nature of the nebula diminished the capacity of our reactor, so a few of our systems couldn’t get power. Fortunately, we had plenty of power for our lasers. “Blast it out of the sky!” I commanded. Well, no, I didn’t sound that heroic. Actually I said something like, “fire the lasers at it!” My therapist told me to start telling the truth more about things I have done, so I will do that. I need to be more honest with others, and I will then be more honest with myself.

Okay, fine, I didn’t say “fire the lasers” either. I’m sorry. What I actually said was, “Oh God! Kill it! Kill that thing! What is it! Kill it!”

The automated scout with disabled weapons.

Junpeng was somehow able to control the lasers even though his arms are just swords. We disabled the enemy weapon system, so it was unable to shoot any lasers back at us. That was a really great thing, because I prefer lasers to be heading away from me, not at me.

Destruction of the automated scout.

With a few more shots, we put an end to the craft. Using my vast intellect, I outsmarted this hostile foe. Well, okay, it was just an automated defense robot, and it didn’t have any shields and was actually really easy to kill. That’s fine. I will take this victory with any others because it is a far better action to remember than almost killing myself by going through the wrong door.

We salvaged what we could from the storage cache, which was a bit of fuel, a couple missiles, and 15 scrap. It was, therefore, about as fruitful as watching those poor saps collide with an asteroid yesterday. I’m not sure if I’m supposed to take a lesson away from that, or what that lesson might be.

This nebula we had found was simply full of things to shoot with our lasers. Well, some of those things were just bits of rock and other debris, but that didn’t mean they were any less susceptible to our lasers. That’s fine.

Another hostile encounter.

Eventually we came across another drone. This one was a bit more tough than the first, but we were out of the dangerous energy fields of the nebula, and could therefore utilise the full potential of the Brandon Kirk’s systems. I quickly ordered that we enable the shields. Well, actually I ordered that we run away, but Sem let me know that we couldn’t get away from the drone until the FTL drives were charged. That is fine, though. I was not afraid of being shot at by an automated assault robot.

The Brandon Kirk finds yet another success.

And why should we have been afraid? Truly, nothing could withstand the power of our mighty (basic) lasers. Well, to be fair we had yet to face anything with a sentient brain, but whatever. Sure we took a couple hits, but we barely had a scratch. We destroyed the thing before our FTL drives were even charged.

Not that I was watching the FTL status the entire battle, or anything.

A poor, naive pirate tries to hustle the mighty Brandon Kirk.

Soon enough we left the comfortable protection of the nebula and we came across some joker trying to collect a “toll” at an FTL beacon. Sure, friend, we’ll just pay your silly scrap toll to head through this empty system. I mean, 17 scrap is a pretty paltry sum. All we have to do is crash a ship into an asteroid and we’ll get that. We will just ignore that skull and cross-bones (or for whatever reason, octopus and cross-bones), and hand over our hard earned scrap. Or, you know, we could SHOOT YOU WITH LASERS!

Battle with the hostile space pirate begins.

The Brandon Kirk is definitely a very formidable warship. Of course, this filthy space pirate (are space pirates filthy?) did have a drone with them, which was a new experience for me. It had a tiny little beam weapon which couldn’t even penetrate our shields. What a pathetic, filthy space pirate this was (it’s just seems that there isn’t that much in space to make a pirate filthy). I knew this was going to be a cakewalk.

The Brandon Kirk sustains damage, with shields down.

Well, actually, the space pirate did have a space missile launcher. Missiles will just go right through the shields like they weren’t there at all - like the shields weren’t there, not the missile. So if they launch a missile at our shield generator, then our shields will go down, and then their stupid drone can begin shooting us. Also the missiles can set the ship on fire, so that’s also a problem. Anyway, exactly that happened. Our shields went down, and also our engines caught on fire. Thankfully Willow had equipment to put out the fire, and Rafn set about fixing the shields.

More damage is suffered on the Brandon Kirk.

Then they shot a missile at our sensors, which meant I couldn’t see anything on the ship (except for rooms that had a crew member in them). That’s fine. I didn’t need to see anything in those rooms, anyway. There’s nothing interesting happening anywhere except the room where the laser controls are.

. . . and more damage.

So then they shot at the room where the laser controls are. That’s fine. One of the lasers was put offline, but we still had three. Junpeng got to work fixing things, as Willow set about fixing the engines and Rafn made sure the shields were back up. Oh, also the cockpit was damaged, so Sem had to fix that before we could maneuver at all. This meant that our only way of not being hit by missiles - that is, flying out of the way of them - was gone. All in all, things were not going too great for the Brandon Kirk. That’s fine, though. I am okay with challenge. As Dr. Wendle would say, that which doesn’t kill you makes you stronger. It’s just that missiles could very easily kill us.

Brandon Kirk turns the tide of the battle.

However, the best defense is a good offense, or something like that, right? We still had three working lasers. Alone, a laser couldn’t penetrate a ship’s shield, but three of them can overwhelm shields and punch right through to the gooey, delicious center. I had Junpeng put them to work disabling the enemy shields, and then we shot them in their stupid missile launcher that I had really begun to hate.

A hard fought victory for the Brandon Kirk.

And by the skin of our teeth, we (the Brandon Kirk and her captain, me, Brandon Kirk) vanquished that dumb filthy space pirate (they are filthy in the “I hate them and their stupid missile launcher” sense) and collected their scrap in our, well, whatever we keep all this scrap in. Is it a scrap tank? Is it some sort of pouch? I don’t know. Our scrap pouch was now nice and full.

Yes, the Brandon Kirk has made short work of not just automated drones, but also backwater, two-bit space thugs trying to bully small ships for milk money. Well, fine, so we kind of had a hard time with that last one, but we learned some valuable lessons. Mainly we learned about how much I hate missiles (a lot).

Yet another victory for the Brandon Kirk.

So when we came across another filthy space pirate (their ships do look pretty filthy), this time dangerously close to a star, we knew just how to take them down. So we did take them down. We barely took any damage doing it, so we obviously had things under control, now.

Now the Brandon Kirk is on fire (again).

Well, okay, there was the matter of the ship being on fire. That’s fine, though. We were too close to the star, so solar flares were setting things on fire. The FTL drive was still charging, so we couldn’t just go somewhere else. These fires had to be put out before they spread to important systems, like the room where the laser controls are. I was going to send Willow in there with his trusty fire extinguisher, but then I remembered something I had learned - something involving doors . . . and space!

Brandon Kirk’s cunning has saved Brandon Kirk.

Aha! I am a hero. By venting the room on fire into space, the fire had no oxygen left to breath, so it all went out. I have to remember to tell my therapist about this, because it will totally shut her up about telling me to be less selfish.

The fire is put out.

Here is a situation where I could have easily sent somebody into a raging inferno, but instead I did something that made them not have to do that. I might have saved Willow’s life, there. Well, actually, I was the one who decided to fly this close to the sun in the first place, but it’s hard to see this navigation control, and I couldn’t really tell that would happen. It’s fine. Small victories, right?

To be continued . . .

fields.title: Presidential Pens
fields.text:
It’s hard not to see or hear people talking about the upcoming Presidential Election everywhere you go. Though it does get a bit annoying, it’s refreshing to not hear people talking about Kardashians or Kate Middleton’s wedding for a change. If you were hoping that DenyConformity.com would be a place where you could get away from the Presidential Debate coverage, I’m sorry to disappoint you. However, I think I might be taking an analytical angle that you won’t find anywhere else. It occurred to me while watching the last debate, the one in Florida.

What kinds of pens are the candidates using?

I am interested in pens, of course. I like to collect them and compare them. Examining exactly what pens Obama and Romney chose to bring to take notes during the debate made watching the debate slightly less boring, and also might give a bit of insight into the candidates themselves, if you’re so undecided that you’ll take absolutely any piece of differentiating information to make a decision.

First, let’s throw a bit of Presidential trivia out there. When a president signs a big bill or other document, it’s tradition to actually use a bunch of pens to make the signature. I guess they just carefully make bits of each letter with each pen. Once it’s done, the President has a bunch of unique souvenirs they can hand out to important people related to the document. Lyndon Johnson apparently used over 75 pens to sign the Civil Rights act in 1964, and gave one of the first ones to Martin Luther King Jr.

Bush deviated from this tradition, of course, because he signed all of his bills with crayon.

The President will obviously use special pens for these occasions, not just some off-the-shelf clicky-top. They’re high-class capped numbers, with the President’s signature engraved on the side. It turns out that Obama’s pens are somewhat unique, aside from the fact that they have his name on them. The engraved signature is right-side-up only when the pen is held in the left hand. Obama is left handed, just like all of the coolest people.

Let’s move on to the debates, though. It happens that the third Presidential Debate is the best one to take a look at. The first debate placed the candidates at big podiums, which made it impossible to see what they were using, and the second, “town hall” debate had the candidates standing and walking about, not sitting down carefully taking notes. For the last debate, the candidates were sitting at the same table, with nothing but their notepads and pens in front of them. Finally, there will be no secrets about the candidates’ preferred writing utensils.

While the candidates prattle on about their continuing rhetoric, we can see what pens they like to use.

Let’s start with Mitt Romney. He’s a businessman, and according to his debate rhetoric, he’s looking to make the government more simple and cut out anything unnecessary or expensive. We don’t have to go into the facts and figures of what he said at the debate or elsewhere. The point is that he’s rooted in business, and - being a very rich man - check writing.

These principles are actually kind of reflected in his pen choice.

This is a closeup of the pen Romney was using at the last debate.

Romney was using a Uni-ball 207 RT with blue ink. It’s a very straight forward, simple pen. It also happens to be fantastic (I found one on a chair in college and I still have it and enjoy using it). It’s part of Uni-ball’s Signo line, which means it has archival, “helps prevent check fraud” gel ink. It’s not quite as smearable as the Zebra gel I tested a while back, and the pen itself has a really smooth, dependable quality. That being said, there’s no pretense about it - it’s all very light plastic. It has a clear body to see the level of ink in the replaceable cartridge, and the only design embellishment is on the clip, which features the Uni-ball and Signo logos. All in all, it’s a very good choice of pen for a pragmatic, down to earth businessman.

Another look at Romney’s pen, with some of the archival scribbles it produced.

Uni-ball does produce four point sizes for the 207, and also makes a 0.7mm “needle point” version as well. I’m guessing Mitt was using the standard 0.7mm medium point. Now, there are blue and light-blue versions, but it looks like Mitt has the regular, conservative blue.

This is the Uni-ball 207 RT, for reference.

So how about Barack Obama, then? Obama is pretty much what you could cite as the classic politician. He went to law school, and practiced as a lawyer for many years before moving into politics. He has worked for his position, moving through first state and then national elected offices. He’s very well spoken, and pretty verbose, at that. He’s earned a reputation as being a very attractive and picturesque man. His image is important.

Here is Obama holding his debate pen.

It wasn’t as easy to recognize as Romney’s choice, but after examining some pictures I have determined that Obama was actually also using a Uni-ball in the debate. Unlike Romney, however, Obama had a Uni-ball Vision Elite, a pretty classy capped rollerball. The Vision Elite is not one of Uni-ball’s Signo gel pens, but it does have archival quality, pigment-based, water resistant ink. That sounds like gel to me, but who am I to say? I would say that a nice, comfortable rollerball pen would certainly be a logical choice for somebody known to be verbose. Also, for a career politician who is careful to maintain a classy mystique, nothing beats a sleek, black, capped pen. The claim that the Vision Elite won’t leak on an airplane is certainly not a bad thing for Obama, either.

Here is the best view we get of Obama’s pen, but we can clearly see the characteristic, circular “uni-ball Vision ELITE” branding and clear butt.

I’ve used a Vision Elite before, but I don’t have any here to refresh my memory. It will definitely go on my list to check out, then. It is a rollerball, though, which means it’s very smooth and designed for writing. It’s more substantial than the 207, and has a heavier, more imposing (for a pen, anyway) presence. The Vision Elite is also, for what it’s worth, a tad bit more expensive than the 207.

It’s surprisingly hard to find a picture of this thing with the cap on, instead of stuck on the back end, but here it is.

Pictures of the second, “town hall style” debate show that the candidates had the same pen choices there, which implies that these really were chosen by the candidates, or perhaps even their own personal pens. I doubt we’ll ever really know, but it does seem like these were more than just a last minute, “oh, here, better take a pen and paper with you on stage” situation.

There’s Obama’s Vision Elite, while the candidates were discussing five point plans and binders full of things.

Further, It’s interesting (or incredibly boring, I suppose, if you aren’t a weirdo like I am) that in the last debate, the moderator, Bob Schieffer, was also apparently using a Uni-ball.

It’s tough to find a good picture of his pen, but there are plenty of his stern moderator face.

Schieffer’s pen has a very characteristic cap (it was, like Obama’s, a capped rollerball), and at first I thought it was a Pentel Hybrid Technica. However, Schieffer’s pen was blue, and the Technica only comes in black. Looking through Uni-ball’s selection, however, it seems that Schieffer had a blue Uni-ball Gel Grip, another in the Signo family of gel pens. I don’t know what this pen says about Bob Schieffer, and I don’t care to explore it too much since he isn’t running for President. However, one interesting fact about this pen is that I can’t seem to find it in packs of less than 12 or so. I guess Schieffer likes a pen that comes in bulk, then.

Good thing, since they’re apparently delicious.

Perhaps all these Uni-balls are part of some grand pen-related conspiracy, or a complex product placement. Considering nobody else is talking about it, it probably isn’t. Uni-ball, for the record, is part of the same huge corporation that owns Sharpie, Papermate, and Parker. If the candidates were wanting to reassure us that they weren’t going to support corporate interests, their pens don’t really help their case. Who knows, maybe Sanford helped underwrite the Commision on Presidential Debates. Maybe it was just a coincidence. Whatever the case, perhaps the most interesting thing of all is that these two men who seem to disagree on so many things have at least this one thing in common.

What about the Vice Presidential Debate, you ask? Well, I looked into that, as well. I won’t analyse them, since it’s already very late, but here they are, anyway.

Paul Ryan makes a point while flanked by two simple pens.

Paul Ryan used a pair of blue Papermate Flairs (I’m pretty sure that’s what they are, anyway). Perhaps the blue thing was a campaign choice. The Flair is a simple felt tip pen. They’re unique in the debates in that respect, and though they aren’t from Uni-ball, they’re still under the Sanford umbrella, so it’s all in the family.

Joe Biden is the white to Obama’s black. I’m talking about pens, here, of course.

Joe Biden actually has the same pen as Obama, in white instead of black. I suppose that’s awkwardly appropriate, isn’t it? It’s a very clean, articulate pen, indeed.

Anyway, I find all this more interesting that most of the actual debate talk. Maybe you can go out and pick up your favorite candidate's pen, and feel like you're part of the team. Whatever the case, I hope you found this any bit as interesting as I did. Also, you're welcome for not making any 'uni-ball' jokes.

I guess I should specify that all of these pictures were from Google Image search, since I have no real journalistic integrity to uphold.

fields.title: Some Old Arcade Games
fields.text:
Hello. A many years ago I got a huge collection of MAME roms off the electronic Internet. MAME stands for Multiple Arcade Machine Emulator. So these are old (and slightly less old) arcade games from a many many years ago. I’m bored tonight, so I’m going to select a few random ones and tell you about them. Let’s begin.

Psychic 5
1987, by Jaleco

“Select Esper” is what I’m prompted upon hitting start on this side- and vertical- scrolling platformer. I didn’t see any Espers on the screen, but not knowing what one is I wouldn’t have known if one was there. I didn’t have much time to figure it out, though, because the game started.

Select Esper

I’m apparently a small boy lost in some sort of old Japanese Haunted House (maybe that’s racist - it’s of an asian persuasion). I can jump with one button and smash things with apparently a hammer, because all boys have hammers, right?

I smashed what must have been a priceless antique pot and there was a smiley face inside. I picked that up, like you do, and traveled onward to seek more of these things.

There’s a witch randomly flying by, and what appears to be an angry clock puking smaller, less angry clocks at me. My hammer makes short work of the smaller clocks, and I can use my “because this is a video game” ridiculously high jumping ability to make it up to the platform with the larger one. I don’t want to go near that monstrosity, but if I were puking clocks (or for that matter anything), I’d want a boy to put me out of misery with his hammer, too.

I’m a hero, I guess.

Okay, so my hammer just dazed the thing for a second, and he pretty quickly woke up and turned me into an angel. There’s a lesson in there somewhere.

Of course I have another life, so this time I give the clock monster a wider berth. I find a few more priceless antique pots, but they contain what looks like jewels and other valuables. Why the first one had a smiley face in it I have no idea. Stupid clock monster cornered me and made me another ghost. I’m not very good at platformers, as it happens.

Life number three begins with great promise. I got past my timekeeping nemesis and ignored the witch thing because she apparently doesn’t actually do anything. The highlight of the game was finding another smiley face. I then proceeded to spend a solid 90 seconds trying to jump on a moving platform.

I’m really not good at platformers.

Perhaps the story would make more sense if I had played Psychics 1 through 4. I bet they explain what Esper is and how one selects it. This game seems to mainly be about seeking smiles while you avoid the inevitability of time. Hits too close to home for me. Next.


Ms. Pac Man
1980 / 81 - Midway MFG CO

I’m tempted to skip this random selection because showing a game people have heard of defeats the purpose of making fun of obscure old arcade games. Then I realized “who cares” and just played it anyway.

In this game you play as a lemon meringue pie with a fetching red bow and lipstick. You have to make your way around a maze eating tiny white dots and avoiding four differently colored ghosts. You can eat one of four larger white dots to make all the ghosts the same color and susceptible to your gaping, yellow maw. When eaten, the ghosts’ eyes travel back to their paddock in the center of the level and they come back to life - er, death. They’re ghosts, so I don’t know why you thought you could kill them by hitting them with a pie.

A female pie, in fact.

Also there are cherries, so I guess she aspires to be a cherry pie instead of lemon. I’m not sure how the ghosts fit into the pie metaphor.

This isn’t my first time around the maze with old Ms. Pie Man, so I know what I’m doing (also it isn’t a platformer, so I don’t have to waste any time trying to jump onto anything). We all know your only escape from this glowing red, ghost-infested hell (I guess that’s just regular Hell, actually) is by collecting all those tiny dots. So I do that.

Which of course prompts the game to reset and it all starts over again. So ultimately, a young pie’s attempts to feel good about herself and actually accomplish anything meaningful are completely futile. Again, too close to real life for me. Also that incessant “wakka wakka” sound is pretty excruciating after like five seconds. Let’s move on.


Ginga NinkyouDen
Unknown year (it’s in Japanese or something) - Jaleco

Now we’re talking. Here’s some weird Japanese arcade game about who knows what. Let’s do this, Ginga NinkyouDen.

So within about five seconds of pressing start I see what is apparently the Macguffin for this game (some floating garbage or something) fly away and then some asshole hits me in the face with a pie. Literally, all this happens before I can even move.

It’s actually an endless stream of these pie-armed vixens.

Trying to run away from them, into what is obviously a room behind this dude, is apparently impossible.

I just realized that building is a face.

With the police station apparently closed, this horrible town has just fallen into chaos. Why must all arcade games be about pie? Finally I get my bearings and jump over one of the obnoxious pie vixens. Then I run . . . into . . .

wat

Now I’m fighting some red thing and also there are Godzillas falling down a hole behind it. Ginga NinkyouDen, you really are full of surprises. I timidly step toward the thing and wail on the button that makes the little dude that I am swing his fist a dangerously small distance in front of his giant head. The red thing surrenders like a chump, and I am ready for my next challenge. Godzilla parade.

Another one of those red dudes pops up, scratching menacingly at the pavement in front of him. I wouldn’t be afraid of the little badger thing if it weren’t for all those Godzillas.

An endless stream of Godzillas.

I strike out with my single fist attack (my only attack, unless you count a “because this is a video game” ridiculously high jump as an attack). It turns out the Godzillas are just as susceptible to my fury as the red thing, and a couple of them fall to my cunning strategy. I even avoid the one that inexplicably attacks me from the left side of the screen. Then I accidentally fall into the hole (platformer), and get killed by some sort of Jason-looking dude with a plasma gun that’s also a chainsaw.

That escalated quickly.

With my next of the obligatory three lives I was able to dive right into the hole and charge down the hall toward those Jason-looking dudes. When no Jason-looking dudes showed up I was a little thrown, but then they did so it all worked out. Then they pulled that “showing up on the left side” trick that the Godzillas pulled earlier, which was a bit more successful because these Jason-looking things can shoot at me. Not fair, Ginga NinkyouDen.

Life number three went much further. I defeated a few Jason-looking dudes, punched some random guys in their underwear (I don’t know how we got from plasma gun and chainsaw to boxer shorts), beat up a few more Godzillas, and then Rambo shot me with a rocket. Seriously.

Bonus: Motorcycle Ninjas

Ginga NinkyouDen knows what I’m looking for. That is to say, I have no idea what is going on, but I like that. Video games let you do things you wouldn’t normally do, and today I punched a Godzilla and got chainsawed by a Jason-looking dude while an angry man in his underwear watched. The music isn’t half-bad either - fast paced and innocuous enough to not be obnoxious. Overall, an excellent experience.

Plus it features this babe in some capacity.

That's enough for now. I'll probably do this again some time.

fields.title: Some More Arcade Games
fields.text:
Hello. A few days ago I posted a thing about some arcade games I played. Well, I was pretty bored that night, so I actually played a few more games than I had room to write about in a single post. Here are my thoughts about a couple more as they were pulled randomly from my library of obscure and old arcade games.

Tazz-Mania
1982 - Stern Electronics Inc.

Back in the day before people really figured out what video games really were, people were free to experiment with all sorts of horrible and almost unplayable gameplay styles. I fear this is one of those experiments. From the early 80’s graphics to the “PULL STICK FOR INSTRUCTIONS” message, I’m not getting a good feeling about this one.

I figure I had better pull the stick to see what’s up with this, and it shows me a laundry-list of different scores I can apparently get, followed by a screen explaining how the game works. The explanation proceeds to explode before I can read it. No matter, I’m a long-time video game player and I basically have infinite quarters, so let’s do this, Tazz Mania.

wat

Okay, so I’m some green thing, and there are a bunch of red . . . things, and there are some . . . yellow . . . face . . . things . . .

And the yellow things touched me and we both exploded. Okay, lesson one: don’t touch the yellow face things. What does any of this have to do with Tazmania? With my second ‘up’ I discovered that I have some sort of gun! A gun that only shoots when I push a button and move in a direction, so I have to move toward the thing I’m trying to shoot. Great. Also apparently this is “The Face Room.” Time to hunt me some faces.

I take out a few of the things before they finally get me. The walls are slowly closing in, but I’ll be damned if those yellow face things take me alive. I’ll spit hellfire from my gun or whatever at those damned monsters until they pry this little yellow line from my cold, green hands. Tell my green wife-thing or whatever and presumably smaller green children if I have them that I love them. I die like I lived - not really understanding what the Hell. Next.


Bells & Wistles
or, apparently, “Detana!! Twin Bee”
1991 - Konami

This is one of many of my arcade roms that comes in multiple versions - in this case an American version and a Japanese one. Obviously I’m going to choose the version with all the exclamation marks. Without a clear shtick for how I’m going to make fun of this game, I’ll just type out my thoughts as I have them.

I think this is one of those “bullet hell” games where you fly around with everything shooting at you and try not to die. It also apparently - from the attractor loop (you know, the gameplay that plays while waiting for some kid to plop in some quarters) - features shooting at a bell for some reason, so like 90% of the sounds spewing out of my speakers right now are this constant horrible lo-fi ringing bell sound. Let’s get this over with.

Dear God, just putting in quarters elicits an excruciating sound effect. I don’t know why Konami would want to so immediately and severely punish someone for giving them money.

Now there’s some chick saying Japanese at me. I’m starting to regret picking the Japanese version of this game.

This is some epic music, though.

We’re like 45 seconds in and she’s still yapping away. That’s a crazy long time for an arcade game to go without even an explosion.

This chick isn’t even showing any skin.

Okay, the chick disappeared and now I’m some sort of floating bubble-man with clouds around me. For a “bullet hell” game there sure aren’t many bullets.

I can fix that pretty quick, since I can be a source of bullets.

I shot at a cloud and a bell popped out. Sure. I can keep shooting the bell and it travels along with me. Then some strawberries flew by in formation, followed by some turnips, and corn, and then a different kind of corn. Those are carrots, I guess? What the hell is going on?

Then a raspberry appeared, summoning its juicy pods or whatever from the very sky around us. Flashing once, it shot at me, killing both me and the bell I had been taking with me this whole time.

I’ve lost the will to carry on. I’m not sure if I had any to begin with.

I know I complained about games being too much like real life, but this is perhaps a bit too “out there.” Maybe if the sound effects and music weren’t conspiring together to make me want to rip my own ears off and feed them to the designers of this game, I could stand it a bit longer.

I think I'll go lay down for a bit, now.

fields.title: Another Arcade Game
fields.text:
Hello. For a few years I've had this collection of old arcade roms, computerized versions of arcade games from the 80's and early 90's. The other night I was just super bored so I decided to play a few and write down my thoughts about them. You might remember that from when I already made two posts about it, or maybe this is the first one you've read because it's pretty great. Anyway, here's another game I played and then wrote about.

Mutation Nation
1992 - SNK CORP OF AMERICA

In 1990, SNK released the Neo Geo, a cartridge-based console you could buy for your home or put inside an arcade machine. I’ve never seen one of the consoles anywhere, but the arcades are still in use. Generally speaking, Neo Geo arcade games are the best arcade games. I’m just informing you of that so you join me in my high expectations for this particular one. The chrome lettering and ominous skyline on the title screen should add to your high expectations.

One standard on Neo Geo games is that they’re all controlled with a stick and four buttons. Since it’s a console it has to have pretty standardized controls. Most games didn’t use all four buttons. I think it was required for games to have a sort “how to play” sequence where you see a magic floating finger push each button to show you what it does. That’s a bit more handy than Tazz-mania, but it’s not terribly necessary since this game has one button for jumping and another for kicking.

And oh boy is there kicking! According to the attractor loop, there’s going to be some pretty awesome feats of feets in my future.

There’s apparently also something called a “Torneado attack.”

Mutant Nation is an example of some genre they don’t make much anymore, where you’re a Bad Dude and you’re beating up other Dudes of questionable Badness. In this game you play as a real Dude so Bad he has a pair of fists permanently hoisted in combat mode. While this probably makes a lot of things difficult - getting dressed, for instance - it surely leaves him uniquely suited to beating up, well, a nation of mutants I guess.

Upon starting Stage 1, this building behind me immediate exploded. That really set a high bar for the rest of the Stage. Well, it set a high bar for excitement, but a pretty low bar for what’s expected of me, effort-wise, if buildings are going to just explode around me from the sheer Badness of my Dude. I think the Neo Geo also had an explosion requirement in its games, so Mutant Nation was doing reasonably well so far.

The first Dudes on the express train to Badville are some identically dressed triplets that fell from the sky all around me. SNK was trying to ease me into the whole mutant nation, I guess. In usual “beat-em-up’ fashion, all three of the dudes casually walked off screen where I couldn’t see them. Maybe if I knew how to do that Torneado attack I’d have been able to bring them back over to me for some kicking.

Or maybe they were just three Dudes trying to make their way in this nation of mutants and some jerk with a leather jacket and blue jeans had just blown up their apartment building. The only context Mutant Nation gives is that you are a Dude in some sort of Mutant Nation (titular, in fact), and since I was apparently a normal looking (albeit Bad) Dude, I have to assume that I was the invader. I’m not sure how I feel about that.

Soon my first taste of a “real” mutant arrived. He had like a fish head with tentacles coming out of it. I punched him until he was flung off the screen from the force of my fist (fistforce). Was he just walking to work? Why was he wearing kneepads? These are questions I don’t think this game has answers to. All I knew is that I simply had to collect that glowing “B” on the ground.

Soon more of those fish dudes showed up. They looked hungry, so I gave them a taste of my knuckle sandwich. I was promised some serious kicking and so far I’d primarily only seen punching. I was really starting to root for those mutants. The few fish dudes that didn’t get knocked off the screen entirely fall to the ground and dissolve into a pool of some sort of green sludge. I was murdering these people for no reason.

Then this pointy dude showed up. I’m not sure what his role was in this mutant society, but he had some sort of strange joint condition and the most awkwardly pointy shoes I’ve ever seen. My strategy was to keep punching him until he exploded. That strategy panned out. Still, this pointy dude seemed pretty important. He obviously had a lot going on, and I’m now worried there’s some weird-looking lady out there with a collection of strangely pointy children who won’t get to see their father anymore.

I eventually figured out that you can charge up your power somehow and unleash it in a burst of energy. Maybe I was a mutant after all! I wasn’t some racist jerk invading a country to beat up innocent locals, I was just a serial murderer targeting his own kind.

At least, I hoped so. Alas, though, I was a regular Bad Dude. That glowing “B” I found is what gave me that power. Now I was using their own weapons against them.

My fists continued their quest to crack some mutant bones, finding a few more of those triplets, some dudes that transformed into some sort of weasel things, and some guys that transformed into giant beetles only to charge directly offscreen never to be seen again. Life is diverse and fascinating in Mutant Nation, and I was determined to bring that diversity down by the fistfull.

The second boss was a guy with like tentacle arms I guess and a pack of green dogs. They all got the punching of their lives - specifically the end of their lives.

I’ve noticed that many of the buildings seen in the background are in various levels of decay or halted construction. Had the Mutant Nation economy been crippled by the invasion of Bad Dudes murdering them? If only a recession could be defeated by punching it. I’d put an end to that really quickly. I marched into one of the buildings because these mutants couldn’t cower in their puny slums forever.

I’d wandered into an old art museum. Most of the paintings were of Dali-esque still lifes or landscapes. This nation of mutants was desperate to find an escape in fantasies as bizarre and twisted as they were. The party was over, though. There was to be no art appreciation while this Bad Dude had anything to say about it.

The next room was full of multiple copies of the same statue of some perfectly sculpted specimen of man. Poor mutant children must walk through this room, a look of shameful confusion on their tentacle-laden fish-faces, wondering why these statues look so different from them and all their friends (except I guess their friends who are all apparently just copies of that one guy). There was no time for all that, though, because I had to punch this huge dude a whole bunch of times. Punch him hard. Maybe he was the art curator, or perhaps he was just a really big guy trying to enjoy his day off.

His mutant power was apparently “being Odin.”

This guy sure was big, but that just left me right at crotch-punching level, so I took advantage of that - many times. He jumped at me and the entire floor buckled underneath us. Some curator he was, destroying his own museum. Still, you have to admire his fashion sense. Where other mutants are content with t-shirts and knee pads (the knee pad industry was apparently doing quite well in Mutant Nation), this guy was going full skull-armor.

I kept punching him until his armor grew a head and starts trying to bite me. This fight was getting weird (even for a nation of mutants), so I stopped screwing around and started punching him extra hard. By that, of course, I mean “used several continues” because I am, after all, not the best at video games. Good thing my mom gave me lots of quarters.

Sated with mutant killing in this Area, the Bad Dude cracked his knuckles and pointed defiantly offscreen. What was he pointing at? This game only raises questions, never answers. I had lost my taste for mutant blood, and found I had a hard time venturing onward without more impetus than a flashing icon shouting “GO” at me. Perhaps someday we will find peace with the inhabitants of Mutant Nation, but as long as there Dudes eager to prove how Bad they are, I fear there will always be senseless violence and destruction. I encourage you all to contact your local senators and representatives to raise awareness of this awful state of affairs.

Sound design and music were perfectly adequate.

fields.title: Stupid Office Pranks
fields.text:
I've been working in an office of some fashion for several years, now. In that time, I've learned that things can get pretty boring, especially in those couple summer months when everybody just wants to go outside. If you also work in an office with an indeterminate number of coworkers, there's one sure-fire way around the doldrums. Pranks. Here are some suggestions, in order of when I thought of them.

  1. Cut the power lines to somebody's office. No, I don't mean flip the breaker or something - I'm talking that scene from early in Die Hard when the big German dude saws all the phone lines clean through.
  2. Cubicle walls are hollow. Fill somebody's cubicle panels with milk. It takes a few days to pay off, but oh boy is it great.
  3. Hide in a cabinet in the break room. Every time somebody sets a fork or spoon out and opens the fridge, quietly grab the spoon or fork and hide it.
  4. Follow someone home and take pictures of them in private moments, then set those pictures as their desktop background while they're in the bathroom.
  5. Get an honest afternoon's work in - but give somebody else credit. Your boss will be expecting that much work from then on, so that guy's just screwed.
  6. Dress up like your boss and go around telling everybody they can take off early.
  7. Clog every toilet in the building. When everybody goes to see what the fuck, set all their desktop backgrounds as pictures of you clogging every toilet.
  8. Rename just totally every file in somebody's computer.
  9. Take something off a dude's desk, and then send them a picture of it in front of the building. When they go to get it, set their desktop background as a picture of, I don't know, your junk or something.
  10. Unleash a handful of rats on the floor. If you don't know how to get your hands full of rats, you're on your own.
  11. Work from home? No problem. Just get yourself a cat, and it's like somebody's constantly playing pranks on you - usually involving poop.
  12. With a small pin or needle, poke a hole in the bottom of somebody's diet coke cans, so when they grab their afternoon 'pick-me-up' they're all empty.
  13. Pour honey or syrup into somebody's keyboard, then release a horde of ants on their desk.
  14. Keep replacing something in the break room with laxatives. Give cryptic clues about what.
  15. Set somebody's desktop background to a picture of you setting their desktop background. When they're changing it back, take a picture of it and set that as YOUR desktop background. That will really throw them off.
  16. Remove the hydraulic fluid from someone's office chair. Do office chairs have hydraulic fluid? If not, just remove all of the bolts from someone's office chair, or saw like 9/10ths of the way through one of the legs or something. When the company charges him for breaking company property, scan the bill and set it as his desktop background.
  17. Straight up set fire to everything.
