fields.title: Lego: a (re-)introduction
fields.text:
Lego is awesome. Really I could probably just say that and be done with it. I don't think anybody would have any arguments to the contrary, and if they did they suck and I hate them anyway. There's something so unique, so perfect, about those little pieces - and something so genius about their designers. If you do the math, with just two standard 4x2 bricks (probably the piece you are thinking of when you visualize the quintessential Lego piece), you can combine them in 24 different ways - that's just two pieces. Take six of those bricks, and you get almost one billion unique arrangements, give or take a few if you happen lose one in the couch or something. Now consider that  in 2012 and 2013, the Lego Group produced about 3,600 unique pieces (according to the database on Rebrickable). Now further consider that any of those 3,600 pieces will be able to interact and interconnect with any of the 17,477 unique pieces that have been produced dating all the way back to the 50's. To put it plainly: pieces you could go out and buy today (or, for example, any of the thousands of pieces I have scattered around me as I write this) are fully compatible - perhaps even identical - to any pieces made over the last fifty years (including all the pieces that have been lost in the couch or the vacuum). Between the Lego Group’s extensive attention to detail and dedication to their product’s original thesis, the world of Lego offers countless adventures without restriction or limit, and what was once just a child's toy has evolved into the perfect hobby for adults.

I have always loved Lego. The majority of my childhood was spent building, playing with, organizing, thinking about, or losing Lego bricks. I can't fathom just how much time I spent flipping through Lego catalogues when I was a kid, memorizing any sets I had the slightest chance of getting some day, and trying to ignore the ones I knew I'd never be able to afford - but obsessing over them anyway. If I had spent as much time studying, I don't know, physics or something as much as I studied the top of the line Lego sets from the mid 90's, I'd have had a PhD by the time I was 14. Lego pieces were everything - literally - and though I strayed from time to time to things like Transformers or G.I.Joe, I always came back. I certainly wasn't alone, either. I doubt any child made it through the 90's without at least once shaking a wrapped Christmas present to listen for the unmistakable rattle that meant you had struck gold. That sound will always bring me back to that exciting worry-free time when a tiny little square of plastic could be anything. At the time it was certain that the Lego Group was forever, and those days would never end.

Then the 2000's hit. It was a period of turmoil, both in my relationship with those little plastic bits, and for the bits themselves. The most casual research of Lego will turn up lots of information about what is considered the 'dark age' of the toy, around the early 2000's (probably as little as just opening Netflix might bring you to that Inside Lego documentary which details the struggles and eventual triumph of the Lego Group through the period). It's hard not to feel just a little responsible, really, considering the company was close to going under right around the same time that I had moved on in my life, to pointless and futile grownup pursuits (like computer games or girls). I wasn't a kid anymore, and so I just couldn't justify spending money on toys. It's a sentiment apparently reflected by most of Lego's major audience in the early 2000's, apparently driving the company to the verge of failure - except that they didn't fail, and no matter how much I tried to deny it, I was still in love. That enchanting rattle, that satisfying way in which those pieces fit, those years spent playing and collecting and dreaming and finding pieces in the vacuum will never leave me.

After years (even decades) of denial, I came crawling back. The last several months has seen me spending quite a bit of time and money feeding my passion once again. Perhaps my resurgence has been fueled by the fantastic The Lego Movie (and its tie-in sets), or the fact that over the years Lego has only gotten exponentially more awesome. Perhaps I'm just being guided naturally by the fact that no video games are really capturing my attention like they used to, or I'm getting over my twinge of shame I have always felt at just wanting to play with a dumb toy all the time. The fact is that though other hobbies and interests have come and gone through my life, Lego has always been the constant - that secret guilty pleasure, maybe my only source of real happiness, that I'm done trying to justify. Frankly it is high time we all stopped fighting our guilty pleasures. Why deny yourself the pleasure if you can just as easily simply deny yourself the guilt? There's nothing wrong with an adult enjoying a hobby.

The problem any adult with a hobby faces, though, is figuring out just what direction to take that hobby. I have too much disposable income these days to limit my impulse purchases to a few sets at a time, and I'm not quite rich enough to go ahead and buy everything. I love seeing the brand new stuff the Lego Group comes out with every few months, but I also feel like I owe it to Young Me to get my hands on some of those sets from the 90's that I looked at for hours in those old catalogues - or even the ones from the 80's that I don't even really know much about. I want to have my own massive basement world just like in The Lego Movie (honestly, who doesn't?), but I have no basement - massive or otherwise - in which to build it. My tastes are too varied and open to limit myself to just Pirates, or just Star Wars, or just any one kind of set. I'm a sort who needs to feel like he's going somewhere with his toy purchases. I need a plan.

Plenty of 'perfectly normal adults' collect Lego, as it happens. Some of those people are collectors who - like with any vintage toy, presumably - buy and sell unopened original sets from history. Today you can find Lego sets on EBay or elsewhere dating from all the way back to the  50's when Lego was first a thing. Vintage collectors spend literally thousands of dollars on what amounts to old cardboard boxes that rattle when you shake them. These people are obviously wackos (although I will admit that they probably have an excellent track record of not losing pieces in the couch). Another type of collector is after minifigures, the little dudes that come with each set. You can find plenty of sets online for huge discounts - because someone bought them simply to add the dudes to their collection and ignore the rest. To me, Lego is about building stuff (and the emotional roller coaster that is searching for lost pieces). For me it isn't about ticking off checkboxes, so I don't think minifigure hunting is for me either. I am happy to take those figure-less sets off your hands, though.

Lego doesn't have to just be about 'pure' collecting (not that there’s anything wrong with it if that's your thing). Some Adult Fans of Lego (abbreviated AFOL by the online communities) could be called 'displayers' - people who buy all of the sets (or certain ones that pique their interests) so they can put it together once and put it out on a shelf to admire and appreciate. There are also builders, people who post ridiculously complicated custom builds on the Internet that make the rest of us feel inadequate and say 'how do you even have that many pieces?' Ultimately, it seems as if there are as many motivations for collecting Lego bricks as there are Lego bricks. You might find these pieces in classrooms, board rooms, dorm rooms, bed rooms, work rooms, or probably a lot of other places that don't have the word 'room' in their names. It's so versatile no matter what kind of hobby you're looking for, chances are you'll find something to enjoy.

It is this versatility that really excites me about Lego, I think. When I was a kid, I had adventures with cursed mummies in Egypt, explored space, fought over deep-sea crystals or whatever, developed a Space Shuttle program, managed a busy commercial harbor, learned about engineering and mechanics, attacked (and defended) the Death Star, held numerous races, of both Formula One and Pod formats, build detailed working models of things, besieged castles, fought pirates, decorated my entire room (and sometimes house), fought robots, built robots, and planned entire cities - all with the same toy. Okay, okay, so technically those are all different iterations of the same toy system. When you get down to it, though, they all have the same parts, and as I said up at the beginning of all this rambling, all those parts are the same parts as the parts kids are playing with today. Sure, The Lego Group does introduce new ones all the time - as well as retire older ones. A lot of times, these are just new or old colors to support different themes. They're still the same basic pieces, and even if they aren’t, they fit right in with everything that has come before. The instructions, too, are as open and universal as possible. Literally every single set of instructions from ever is available online for free (most of them through the Lego Group directly, others through a third party). Once you have the instructions, websites exist where you can find basically any Lego set ever made (or any individual pieces) being sold used (or even new) by collectors and retailers all over the planet.

All that means the Lego System is extremely easy to get into, and it's even easier to get deeper once you're in. I was looking through the online Lego databases at some of those old sets I used to pine away for (old habits die hard - even after almost two decades). Lego is Lego, so all those old sets have (pretty much) all of the same parts as these that I have scattered around me right now, and the instructions for them are literally a click away. I started thinking about dudes who, over the course of years, slowly assemble hand-made hot-rods or motorcycles in their garage. The pieces fit together so well. How many other sets or bulk pieces would you have to buy to be able to make any given set? How many sets could I make right now with what I have?

So the point of all this rambling is that I do finally have the answer. I now not only have a clear and specific mission to pursue, but I even have a perfectly viable justification for pursuing it, as well as parallels to established 'adult' hobbies that should shut up even the most harsh critic (for example my own nagging requirements for a sense of purpose). It's cleaner (probably cheaper, too) than building a hot rod in my garage - and it doesn't even require a garage (or Tim Allen). It allows me to explore the history of my favorite and longest standing passion in life. It gives me a guideline to direct my otherwise random and impulsive usage of disposable income. All I have to do is pick a set, download the instructions, and get to work. Perhaps I had better get going.

So in conclusion, whether you're a collector, a designer, an engineer, or you just like to play, you have a home in Lego. In fact, even if you aren't one of those (you boring person, you), you can still probably find a reason to enjoy a Lego brick or two. I've been playing with the things for twenty five years or something, and I'm still discovering new ways to enjoy them. I can't wait to dive into the archives to start building some old-, and really old-school designs. I also can't wait to see next year's sets, and to pick up some of the Guardians of the Galaxy stuff (I have a certain thing for Groot). After all this rambling, though, there's still a certain indefinable quality about Lego bricks. How can you describe the satisfaction of connecting two tiny interlocking plastic bits or the pure, blissful anticipation of something as simple as shaking a rattling box? Lego is just, well, awesome. What more can I say?

Keep building, my friends - just make sure you check the couch and vacuum.
fields.summary: Lego is awesome. Really I could probably just say that and be done with it. I don't think anybody would have any arguments to the contrary, and if they did they suck and I hate them anyway. There's something so unique, so perfect, about those little pieces - and something so...

fields.title: Lego: Getting Started
fields.text:
In case you didn't read my last post about Lego (don't worry, this one has pictures!), I'm starting a new long-term project involving one of my absolute favoritest things (spoiler alert, it's Lego): Lego. My plan is to reach deep into the annals of time (why are you giggling?) and pick one of the old-school sets from my childhood that I've always wanted to build. I'm then going to slowly, perhaps over the course of years, put that set together. The first step in the process, of course, is picking which set I'm going to be building.

For me, picking a classic set was quick and there's no point belaboring it any further (but perhaps you'll allow me a bit of dramatic embellishment). Thinking back on all those catalogues I used to look at from the 90's, there was no theme I coveted more than Model Team. If you aren't familiar, basically once a year through the 90's, the Lego Group came out with a no-holds-barred, super detailed vehicle with no arbitrary scale or price constraints. They varied wildly in price, since there was apparently no specific guideline on how big they should be. Historically the price points for various themes and set sizes are pretty set-in-stone specific - you can be pretty sure that for any given theme you'll have a small set or two, a couple mediums, and generally one biggon' that would basically be all you got for Christmas that year. You couldn't really be certain about Model Team, though - they ranged from $40 all the way up to $140.

The Model Team Logo in the 90's.

These were the cream of the crop. Back when a few bricks clumped around some wheels settled (albeit acceptably) for 'car' these were beautifully detailed, sophisticated, and expertly crafted models consisting of hundreds of pieces. No one 90's product line stands out more than Model Team, and no Model Team set comes close to the one that dominated the back page of the 1996 Lego Shop at Home Catalog. This set marked the climax for Model Team in both number of pieces and price, and it definitely marked a high point in Lego history. Some might even call it the most unabashedly serious Lego set of all time.

I'm talking, of course, about 5571: Giant Truck. Even the name was right to the point. With 1742 very specific parts, it's probably going to take me quite a while to get it finished, the perfect choice for my hot-rod-in-the-garage project. Other sets might have come out that were bigger, more complicated, or more detailed. Other sets might have better, more sophisticated construction or have more features. Other sets might even be built using nothing but parts I already own. However, no other set comes close to Giant Truck in my heart.

So cool.

Giant Truck (also called 'The Black Cat') was introduced by The Lego Group (TLG) in 1996. I'm pretty sure it was their attempt to see just what they could come up with given no restraint whatsoever. In the same year, TLG introduced some of the sets I most fondly remember playing with for years afterword - sets like 6335: Indy Transport, a set that saw countless hours of my attention, 6248: Volcano Island, a set that I'm literally looking at on my desk as I type this, 6331: Patriot Jet, 1821: Rally Racers, 8230: Coastal Copy Buggy, and 1728: Crystal Crawler, one of the best Aquazone sets. 1996 also saw the Exploriens, the key Lego space sub-theme from my childhood - 6982: Explorien Starship, 6899: Nebula Outpost, and 6856: Planetary Decoder saw a lot of adventures in my house. Also released in 1996, of course, was Star Trek: First Contact, Super Mario 64, Duke Nukem 3D, and Richard D. James Album. The point is, it was a good year full of a lot of things I have spent a lot of hours with. However, I still stared at that catalog, dreaming of the one thing I knew I would never get.

This is from the German catalog, but you get the point.

So first things first. The Lego group claims to host instructions for over 3300 Lego models dating back to 2002. That definitely doesn't include Giant Truck by about six years, but I searched for it anyway.

Oh, Lego, I love you.

Come on, though, they have to have Giant Truck. It's probably a matter of national pride in Denmark. I'm pretty sure it's on their flag.

I don't really remember what the Danish flag looks like, but that looks right.

Anyway, before I really dive in, we might as well humor the possibility of just buying this thing. There are several places where you can buy old Lego sets. The first, probably most obvious, option is Ebay. I pulled up a quick search and immediately saw a brand new, never opened Giant Truck for - brace yourself - $1,325. In case you're wondering what sort of investment an unopened Lego model can be, that's a 946% return on the $140 investment that set would have been if you bought it new. There's another brand new Giant Truck auction ending today with a current high bid of $890 - a relative steal! Obviously I'm not going to be buying one of those.

Presumably those 14 watchers are all like I was with that catalog back in '96.

Another source for old Lego stuff is called BrickLink. It even sports a design from the 90's! Don't let the general shady appearance of the place fool you - it's a fantastic resource. I can confirm that to some extent. I have made exactly one purchase from somebody on BrickLink (that's a bit of a spoiler for later on). Some trepidation for BrickLink wouldn't be unjustified, I think, but considering just how long it's been around (since 2000) and how many buyers and sellers they have (312,353 registered users), I'm guessing there are more good experiences than bad. You can certainly find any Lego or Lego accessory you might be looking for there, being sold by one or more of the (as noted on the site) 8,563 different stores. It works like Ebay, sort of, acting simply as a broker between Lego sellers and Lego buyers. As a result, I imagine, the quality is more in the court of the specific people you deal with rather than BrickLink itself. There are extensive rating and problem handling tools, though, so like Ebay your reputation is on the line if you try to be a knucklehead. Everybody there is united in a common love of all things Lego, though, so there's already a heightened sense of community.

I can basically guarantee you'll find any set you might want there.

The cheapest Giant Truck right now is $341. That's if you want one used, without a box, and shipped from the United Kingdom, which probably won't be cheap (if you're a dumb American like me). The cheapest one in the US is $600. Basically we're still looking at a prohibitive expense.

The last real source for used or old Lego would require that you happen to be lucky enough to have an independent used toy store in your neck of the woods - preferably one that deals specifically in Lego. I just so happen to be lucky enough to have had that happen. Out in the rich-people part of town is a store called Bricks & Minifigs. It's a great store, and it would be the greatest thing ever if the Internet didn't exist. Their prices are, if you're careful, decent (though you'd only really buy new sets there if you're either insane or insanely rich), and they have an ever-changing assortment of used sets from various eras in their display case. It seems to be, for whatever reason, the place to go if you need one of several specific Star Wars sets that they always seem to have several of. It's not the place to go if you're looking for a very specific and extremely high-priced set from the 90's. They do have at least one brand new 10197: Fire Brigade, one of the highest user-rated sets out there, which was discontinued a while ago. It's pretty expensive, as you might imagine. They don't, however, have Giant Truck, so don't even ask.

I'm very lucky to have this resource nearby. I'm sorry that I took this with my phone.

Bricks and Minifigs does - in addition to making grammar awkward - have three huge bins of random parts that you can buy by the bucket- or bag-full. This might come in handy later if I need any specific, but not terribly rare, parts. I think it's safe to say I will be needing some parts at some point in this project.

And stickers, I guess. I'm just going to not worry about that right now.

So then the question becomes one of logistics. What ground rules, if any, should I set down for how I acquire those parts that I don't yet have? I could be strict about where they come from - specifying that they have to be from a certain vintage or that I have to get them all out of actual sets. However, I don't think I'm going to be that hard on myself. Just a cursory bit of checking parts lists online shows that Giant Truck needs like twenty of several parts that only appear at most in quantities of four in other sets. I'm not about to buy five copies of a Lego set from the 90's for a hundred bucks a pop just to have enough of, for example, these guys:

Officially: 609126 Brick 1 x 2 x 11/3 with Curved Top (Black)

It's clear then that Giant Truck is not even close to the ideal set for showcasing how easily you could make a particular set using parts out of a bunch of other ones. What Giant Truck might be perfect for, however, is trying out as many sources for parts as I can. Perhaps that will be the central thesis of this whole thing (other than 'Giant Truck is awesome'). What method for sourcing particular pieces is the most fun, or the easiest, or the cheapest? I'll look for parts in my own collection, by buying both used and new sets, in those bulk bins at that store I'm super lucky to have in my town, ordering them online, or even digging through the vacuum - I'll leave no stone unturned in my quest for all 1,742 pieces of the Black Cat.

In my next article / post / essay / whatever this is, I'll actually show some Lego pieces being put together. In the meantime, keep on building - and if you happen to find any of those curved brick dudes shown above in your vacuum, maybe drop me a line.

fields.title: Giant Truck: Getting Actually Started
fields.text:
To recap, I'm working on a new long-term project featuring one of my all time most favorite things, Lego. I have gone back to my childhood and picked out an epic, monumental Lego set that I've always wanted to build - 1996's 5571: Giant Truck. I'm going to slowly, perhaps over the course of years, put that set together. I found instructions for the set and ruled out the possibility of buying it (since it's crazy expensive in the used toy market). Now it's time to crack open those instructions and actually get started. Well, the instructions are a digital PDF on my computer, so we'll be doing whatever the digital version of cracking is - double clicking, I guess.

They just don't make instructions like they did back in 1996. That's purely a statement of fact, you can make your own assumptions about which is 'better.' The PDF containing Giant Truck's instructions is 107 pages long. Only 60 of those cover the construction of Giant Truck. The other 47 pages cover the alternate model, some sort of Also-Giant-But-Not-As-Giant Truck. Compare that to a modern 'spare no expense' set, 71006: The Simpsons' House, which has about 800 more pieces than Giant Truck. The Simpsons' House has 237 pages of instructions spanning three booklets (and no alternate model). That's five times the instructions for a set that has only 1.4 times the parts.

I purchased this set right after I had some wisdom teeth removed. I mean right after - on the ride home. Oddly enough, I don't exactly remember doing that.

Obviously you should take that statistic with a grain of salt (and keep your weird salt-eating habits away from me, weirdo). The Simpsons' House is a very different kind of set than Giant Truck, so they maybe shouldn't be compared to each other. I'm no mathemagician, so I don't know how to make numbers prove my points, but I'm pretty sure comparing two things that are only casually related is not the best argument. It's undeniable, though, that times have changed. The average number of parts in an instruction step has gone way down. If I were some sort of mathman I would be able to quantify this in a meaningful way, but you'll just have to rely on my crazy old man 'I swear it sure seems like it' claims. Perhaps you'll get an idea of what I'm talking about as we move forward.

Compare this random (but average) page from the Simpsons' House to some of the steps we'll encounter for Giant Truck.

As I said in the last post, I'm not going to plan ahead and try to gather resources before getting started. I'm going to save time by just diving in and seeing how far I can get with what I already have in the Ol' Archive. Obviously this is paying off, as I am now over two entire posts into this project and nothing has been built yet. All that is about to change, however. Let's go for it!

Step 1

This is the first page of Giant Truck's instructions, including the first three steps, and the customary axle sizing guide.

Actually, I am going to have just one more quick digression before going for it. I want to point out that little thumbnail that always shows up at the start of any Lego instructions of the set you're building (you can see it on the page posted just above). They do this because sometimes the instructions break out and build certain separate components and this shows exactly what we're doing right now. They still have those thumbnails in instructions today (for example, in The Simpsons' House there's a set of instructions for the Simpsons' famous pink car, the garage, and then various sections of the house, and each of those sections has a little thumbnail preceding them). I wonder if they should do this for other things. Maybe if they put little pictures of you as a healthy, happy adult on packages of vegetables, kids would be more into them. A picture at the start of high school of me showing my report card to my parents and having them not be mad at me probably would have motivated me a bit more in class. I mean, it wouldn't hurt. Anyway, it just feels a little bit silly for Giant Truck.

Instructions for Giant Truck: Chapter One: Giant Truck. In this set of instructions we will be building Giant Truck. Good to know.

Anyway, the first step requires four pieces. The two 1x8 and one 2x6 black plates are no problem. The 1x10 Technic Plate with Toothed Ends, however . . .

Great, it's the first step and I'm already stuck.

Digging through the Ol' Archive, I found that I have (at least) eight 1x6 versions of that technic plate, and at least one 1x8. Cue the first actual picture of Lego pieces that I took (finally):

In Grey and Black. I don't know what that 1x8 plate is doing in this picture.

According to Rebrickable, part 2719: Technic Plate 1x10 with Toothed Ends was in 23 sets in grey including Giant Truck (it's also in one set in black, and another set in light bluish gray). I have exactly none of those sets in the Ol' Archive. This shall be the first piece I have to hunt for, I guess. In the meantime, I have a couple of part 2711: 1x5 Technic Plate with Toothed Ends, 2 Studs and Center Axle Hole (it just rolls off the tongue), which can be put side-by-side to make the plate I need. They're black instead of grey, but they'll at least make do until I can find the proper piece.

I always like when the first step of these old-school sets was basically just 'take these pieces and put them generally near each other.'

Step one complete!
How much did I have? 75%
How much did I improvise? 25%
Does it look like a truck yet? Heavens no.

Step 2

Here it is again, in case you forgot.

Each step of the Giant Truck instructions includes a handy little box showing exactly what parts the step requires. This information is incredibly useful, and (pretty much) all Lego instructions today have these boxes on each step. However, this wasn't always the case. Giant Truck, being obviously the King of Lego was given the honor of these info boxes; other 'expert' sets over the years that weren't specifically labeled with the Technic badge were also bestowed the honor. Regular sets in the 90's, however, were not deemed worthy. This often (for me, at least) led to moments where you would notice pieces in the instructions and realize that they were supposed to be added several pages ago - or you would end up with pieces at the end of it all with no idea where or when they were supposed to go.

Page 14 of 1999's 5976: River Expedition, containing steps 19 and 20. Can you spot all the differences between these pictures?

Modern sets owe those part info panels to the Technic line. Instructions for Technic sets included the panels all the way back to the 70's when Technic was first a thing. They slowly trickled down to all of the instructions around 2000 (aught-aught) and 2001 (aught-one), at which point most of the 'regular' set instructions have them. Quickly perusing instructions online, I found sets lacking the info panels even into 2010 (aught-ten), but I'm pretty sure those are the exception. Even the cheapest sets today have them. It only makes sense to have that info across the board, and I'm definitely glad the Lego Group listened to 10 year-old me when I was the first person to have that idea.

Here's Step 6 (the entirety of page 10) for 60018: Cement Mixer, from 2013 (a fantastic little set). Here you see just how comically basic the instructions can be these days.

So Giant Truck Step 2 requires one 1x4 red brick and two 1x3 red bricks. That isn't a problem at all. I even have the right colors and I think they're vintage pieces, so that's a bonus. Hot rod dudes are always looking for the same model year parts, right?

So far the improvised piece is working great.

Step two complete!
How much did I have? 100%!
Does it look like a truck yet? Still definitely no.

Step 3

It looks like Giant Truck is going to rely heavily on those grey technic half pin pieces (or as Brickset more awesome-ly calls them, 'Connector Peg with Knob') to attach details to later on.

Now the fun begins. I was worried about these super long Technic beams, since they aren't at all as common anymore as they used to be. However, digging into the Ol' Archives revealed that I have several. Additionally, what Lego piece collection is complete without about ten thousand of those 'Peg with Knob' pieces? My collection has plenty of them at any rate - they will not be a problem.

Here are the parts for step 3. So far I have learned that I need a better way to photograph Lego pieces besides just putting them on my filthy, poorly-lit desk.

So 1x16 Technic Brick with Holes - check. 1x6 plate - no problem. Peg knobs, I've got plenty of those. I'm rocking and rolling now (well, I'm not rolling, the wheels don't get added for quite some time.)

According to Rebrickable, the 1x16 Technic brick with holes has 584 instances in 150 sets, going all the way back to 1980. Mine probably came from 1998's 3038: Super Challenge. That set is noteworthy for being an indicator (perhaps harbinger) of the future of Technic, since it relies heavily on the studless beams that have (pretty much) completely replaced their studded counterparts in the aught-aughts and aught-aughteens. Thankfully Super Challenge had a couple 1x16's of the studded variety for me to utilize on Giant Truck 16 years later.

The improvised beam is causing a potential problem, now. These stand-ins are missing a stud, so this will reduce the structural strength of the truck ever-so-slightly. We'll see if this proves to be a problem.
Three steps in and there's no serious problem yet.

Step three complete!
How much did I have? 100%
Does it look like a truck yet? No, but it is one piece at least.

Step 4

This caption is about as boring as step 4 is.

We finish up today with what is basically a rehash of step 3. No 1x6 plate this time around, however. In the end, step 4 is a predictable romp with the same old plot points and no surprises. I predict a poor showing at the box office this fall. Wait, what were we talking about?

Yeah, I had the front assembly a bit too far forward in the last step. I've fixed it, so don't worry.

Step four complete!
How much did I have? 100%
Does it look like a truck? Yes - er, wait - no.

I'll leave it there for now. The Giant Truck is 7.7% complete. After four steps we are left with something that is neither giant nor truck, but it's . . . well, it clearly has a long way to go, but progress is, as they say, progress (does anybody say that?). Perhaps it's just nostalgia, but building something from digital instructions loses something from the more tangible counterpart. There's a certain magic about turning the page and seeing what's to come, and judging how cool a set is by how thick the book is (which could explain why the instructions are so much longer lately). Indeed, Lego instructions, digital or not, have come a long way in the last twenty-aught years or so. Are we, though, as Lego fans living in the future, any better or worse off than they, the Lego fans living in the past, were in ninety-whatever? It's difficult to determine without some more sophisticated maths (and without letting those pesky opinions cloud the issue). One thing is easy to quantify, though: 3,755 sets have come out since the nineties that those poor shlubs never had. I'd say that makes us the winners, better instructions or not. So until next time, you lucky Lego fans of the future, keep on building.

Feel free to let me know if you have any thoughts or suggestions, too. For the sake of full disclosure: stats, part names, set lists, and other data points were taken from Brickset and / or Rebrickable. Images of instructions were taken from official Lego instruction PDF's (or in the case of super old stuff, the scans available on Peeron), and they're the property of the Lego Group (obviously). Hopefully they don't sue me for loving them too much.

fields.title: Giant Truck: The Champion Part
fields.text:
To recap, I have embarked on a new long-term project involving something very awesome to me, Lego. I have gone back to my childhood and picked out an epic, monumental Lego set that I've always wanted to build - 1996's 5571: Giant Truck. I'm going to slowly, perhaps over the course of years, put that set together. I dove right into the instructions (after a lot of rambling) and was able to get the first four steps completed with what I had laying around in the Ol' Archives, only having to improvise once to fashion a piece I didn't have out of two smaller ones I did. With any luck, Giant Truck will mostly require more common parts - that is, ones that I actually have. Of all the 1,742 parts in Giant Truck, which is the most common, I wonder? What about in all of the Lego world? What is the Champion Part?

This isn't it, but a crown seemed appropriate or something.

Finding the most common Lego piece kind of depends on how you want to judge it (and what numbers you can trust). Basically there are two ranking systems. You can rank pieces by how many times they've been used in total, in which case multiple instances in a single set will improve a piece's ranking, or you can rank them purely by how many sets they've appeared in, quantities notwithstanding. Both stats have their merits, but I tend to think of the second one as being a bit more universal. Some sets might take advantage of a whole bunch of one piece or another, but in my opinion the Champion Part is the one that has been used in the most sets. I think that shows more usefulness or versatility - or maybe just the part that's the simplest. Rebrickable shows both ranks, and I think their numbers are reasonably trustworthy, so I'll blatantly copy and paste both stats here to make it look like I actually did research.

Let's get back to the Giant Truck, already in progress.

Step 5

The parts count for each step is starting to go up.

I want to be able to know the origin of every piece I put into Giant Truck, but for some it seems a little un-possible. This step contains some super common parts that could have come from anywhere. A lot of these parts have been around since the Beginning, or at least as near as makes no difference. They've appeared in hundreds - in fact thousands, of sets over the last fifty-or-whatever years. Let's just take each piece in this step one by one.

First up: this one.

The 2x4 Plate, or Part 3020 as his friends call him, is definitely one of those super common parts. This is one of THE Lego pieces - one of the ones everybody has, even if they don't collect Lego sets. It appears almost 20,000 times in over 3,400 different sets and 40 different colors. That makes it the 11th most common part overall, and the second most common part included in a set. It's safe to say that I own at least one of the 1,048 sets that had a 2x4 Plate in black (element ID 302026). This particular one I'm using could have been from quite a few of those. I would list the ones I have, but it's too numerous for how lazy I feel right now.

It should be a bit easier, however, to track down where my 2x6 Plate (Part ID 3795) might be from. I was somewhat surprised to see that the 2x6 plate is actually pretty common, at 28th overall and ninth by set use, appearing almost 10,000 times in just over 2,400 different sets in 36 colors since its introduction in 1978. The color I need (specifically 'Light Gray', Element ID 379502) was one of the original colors for the 2x6 plates and has appeared 511 times in 240 sets since 1978 - more than I expected.

Specifically these sets.

The odds are actually semi-decent that mine came from 1821: Rally Racers, from 1996, which would make this one of those sweet, sweet same-model-year parts. Rally Racers is a fitting set to get parts from because it contains a pair of trucks, so these parts already have some truck experience. For the record, Rally Racers also includes a black 2x4 Plate. That's quite a useful little set, there.

Keep racing, fellas, at least until I dismantle you for all your plates.

The 1x3 Brick (Part ID 3622, in black 362226) is a bit more uncommon. Like the 2x6 plate this piece was first seen in 1978, but in fewer colors. Today it ranks in at 20 overall and 31 by set use. Of course, that's out of like 17,000 parts, so it's still quite common. In Black the piece has appeared so far in 365 sets (you could build one a day for an entire year!), so that actually makes that particular color more common than the 2x6 Plate in Gray that I just dug up. Also, since black is a color the Lego Group still produces, this is a part that has appeared in sets all the way into 2014 and (probably) beyond (for example there are a modest 32 of them in 10237: Tower of Orthanc from 2013). I could very well have pried this one out of 6048: Majisto's Magical Workshop, a beautiful little set from 1993. I think Majisto's Workshop was my sister's when we were kids and as a result I wasn't allowed to touch, look at, play with, or think about it, but I have it now so who gets the last laugh?

Look eight-year-old me, I totally won! Take that, twelve-year-old my sister!

So what's the most common piece to appear in a set? This is apropos trivia, since the part is in fact included in this step of Giant Truck. It's the Inverted 2x4 Double Slope. Just kidding - it's the 1x2 Plate, which has appeared no fewer than 45,500 times in almost 4,000 sets. It's the second most common part overall, because there is one other part that appears in higher quantities, but at least according to Rebrickable (or at least according to my interpretation of the numbers on Rebrickable that don't really have any explanation), no part has appeared in more sets than the good old 1x2. I need a yellow one in this step, which is one of the less common colors, appearing in 629 sets (the black 1x2 has appeared in 1,315). This one could have come from 8828: Front End Loader, a set I somehow had two of as a kid. A yellow 1x2 plate is also in 6335: Indy Transport ('96 - same model year), but since my one of those is still at Mom and Dad's house, I don't think this one came from there. This piece totally tore it up in 2014, actually, appearing in almost 40 different sets (just in yellow), so it's still super easy to get your hands on.

The most common Lego piece to appear in a set.

What about the part that's number one overall? This is less apropos, because none of them appear in this particular step (but they will come up in Giant Truck eventually, I'm sure). Interestingly, it seems to be the 1x2 brick, which has been made in 52 colors since 1959. It just edges out the plate version by appearing 62,633 times (give or take), but falls short of both the 1x2 plate and the 2x4 plate by only appearing in 3,338 sets. Apparently the 1x2 shape is the most useful of all the Lego piece sizes. If this step had called for one of these 1x2 bricks, this could possibly be the easiest step of Giant Truck. Since it isn't in this step, though, I can't really justify bringing it up right now, so just forget I did.

Not really relevant to what we're doing.

This step also calls for a couple 1x2 Tiles, which is also a pretty common part. These studless wonders have appeared over 15,000 times in almost 2,000 sets, ranking it 15th overall and 17th by set. The use of this piece is boosted, of course, by the number of different printed versions that exist. This versatile part has been used for keyboards, equipment panels, bus tickets, license plates (for example 'OUTATIME'), other random text, dashboards, cash, envelopes, the word 'POLICE,' and tons of other things. I need a couple blue ones for Giant Truck, and I was able to find them pretty easily.

The 1x2 tile has come in 50 different colors, including Blue, Medium Blue, Sky Blue, Dark Blue, Maersk Blue, Sand Blue, Trans-Dark Blue, and Trans-Light Blue. I'm pretty sure the ones I dug up are the regular blue that I require. It looks like the Blue 1x2 Tile first appeared in 1992 with 6038: Wolfpack Renegades. I don't have that set, but I do have 7553: City Advent Calendar (2011), which had one, 71006: The Simpsons' House (2014), which has eight, 5988: The Temple of Anubis (1998), which has one, and 6331: Patriot Jet (1996), which has nine. One of these that I'm using might be from the Advent Calendar (I bet you never thought about Advent Calendars as a source for parts!), but I can be pretty sure at least one of these is from the same-model-year Patriot Jet (the Simpsons' house is stored in a separate container, and the Temple of Anubis is two hours away at my Mom and Dad's house, so it can't be from those). I'll look into colors more in a future post.

A very difficult piece to visualize.

To be extra, pedantically clear, this 1x2 Tile is specifically 3069b: Tile 1x2 with Groove, which first appeared in 1974. There's a tiny, well, groove around the bottom of all of the tile pieces, which gives you just a bit of purchase for pulling them apart (or for wedging that remover tool in there), since there aren't any studs up top to use for leverage. Indeed, without that simple tiny groove, these would be sucky to remove (but easier to write rhyming couplets about). There was a Tile 1x2 Without Groove (3069a), which appeared in the 60's and 70's, while also appearing for some reason in a few sets in the early aught-tens. For the record, the non-grooved 1x2 tile is ranked 309 overall and 868 by set, which isn't too shabby for a piece that (for the most part) hasn't been produced in 35 years. Giant Truck will not be using any Tile 1x2 Without Groove, so you can forget I mentioned that one, too.

Unlike the other pieces in this step, the black Inverted 45 degree 2x4 Double Slope took a bit of digging, but I do have one. By my reckoning, this one also came from 6331 Patriot Jet, which is proving to be another pretty good source for parts along with those racin' trucks. The double slope (part number 4871, if you're curious) has been used 652 times in 352 sets since being introduced in 1985. It comes in 14 colors, but first appeared in Light Gray in 6377: Delivery Center. The black one (which started its career in '87 as a spaceship part) is in 76 sets, including at least one Advent Calendar (not the one I have) and a couple sets that came out this year (2014). It's one of those old standbys that's always been around (to me that's literal, since it was first produced the year before I was born).

So anyway, all this is to say that I have all of the parts for this step.

Sheesh, why didn't I just say that?

The little rear assembly in this step is, perhaps, the first visual embellishment of the Truck so far. We'll be able to see how that sloped piece will look as more Giant Truck gets built around it, but it might be our first glimpse of the Giant attention to detail in this set. It's also interesting that the 1x2 piece inside there is yellow, considering we may never see it in the final product. I always wonder if designers put bright colors in places you'll never see them like that just for the heck of it, or if they were trying to meet certain color quotas. Perhaps we'll never know.

The truck is starting to take shape. It still isn't a truck shape, but it's some sort of shape.

Step five complete:
How many parts were needed? 8!
How much did I have? 100%
Does it look like a truck yet? Nope.

Boy, if I can continue to ramble on this much I ought to be able to eek this project out for the rest of my life. The only problem with doing that, aside from the fact that nobody in their right minds would read that much inane information, is that all of the statistics I'm posting in these earlier posts will probably be completely obsolete and incorrect by the time this is all said and done. The Lego world is an ever changing one, and with new sets introduced basically every couple weeks, there are new sources for parts, both common and rare. Who knows, maybe in a few months we'll have a new set with a whole bunch of some part that drives it up to the top of the charts, or we'll see some huge paradigm shift that will dethrone the current 1x2 champ. One of the things I love about this world is that like the very creations we can build with them, the parts themselves are ever changing. However, sets that will come out next year will still contain parts I could use in this set from 1996. That 1x2 plate is the champ because it's the same piece (at least as far as we need to concern ourselves) that they've been making for 50 years. This world, then, is as dynamic and fluid as you want it to be. That's pretty awesome. What's your champion part - that part you find most useful or important? What piece do you have the most of in your collection? Whether you're going to go count out your pieces or not, keep on building, my friends. I'll see you all next time.

It's worth noting (again) that all of the statistics shown here were taken from Rebrickable and are accurate only inasmuch as that site is accurate. The numbers are almost constantly going up (as new sets are released or catalogued on Rebrickable's database), so the numbers listed here will not be accurate for long. Still, it's a reasonable representation of part rankings and history.

Also, remember to let me know if you like these posts or if there's anything you'd like me to elaborate on in the future (as if I'm not already elaborating far too much).

fields.title: A Parade of Cranes
fields.text:
In case you haven't seen my website in a while - or you haven't spoken to me at all - I've been working on a new project involving one of my favoritest things, Lego. I'm working on building a particular Lego set that I thought was super cool when I was a kid. The 1,742 piece epic that is Lego Model 5571: Giant Truck, from 1996, was always my favorite page of the Lego Shop at Home Catalog, and now I'm going to build my very own. I found the instructions online, and through the power of having a lot of Lego bricks laying around, I am hopeful that I can make it happen. Only time will tell how far I will be able to get before I hit the inevitable roadblock of 'I just don't have one of those.' As the steps have worn on and I have been tasked with less common parts, time has begun to tell.

Watch this video for my latest update, or read below if you prefer reading to watching. Yes, I realize that it took me way too long to post this. While getting Giant truck together, I am also working on getting my life together.

Anyway, my last post completed step six, so now I'm ready for step 7, and I'm nervously awaiting the time when I hit an Inevitable Roadblock.

Step 7

I have hit an Inevitable Roadblock. Now I need two more of those 8x1 Technic plate with toothed end mounts. I definitely knew that this was coming when the first one of these came up back in step three or whatever, because these Technic plates never travel alone. I have the other parts for this step, but not those Technic plates. This will be the first case where I'll just have to halt progress until I get them.

So how do I do that?

As I said in the earlier post about step three or whatever, these parts are featured in 23 sets, so I could look around for one of those. Let's hit up Bricklink.

The coolest set (aside from Giant Truck, obviously) that these parts are in would probably be 8868: Air Tech Claw Rig, from 1992 (four years before Giant Truck). It's a super sweet truck with a big crane on the back - or some sort of weird car with a grabber thing on the front (or a lot of other things I guess, if you're good at building things with Lego). It originally went for $139.

8868: Air Tech Claw Rig. It's even fun to say.

Lego is pretty serious about cranes as it turns out; 8868 was neither the first nor the last. In fact, just in '012 they made what is basically a remake of the Airtech Claw Rig, 9397: Logging Truck, which had a retail price of - look at that - $139 (the newer one has more pieces, too). Those of you saying Lego has gotten more expensive can go ahead and eat your hats now, or whatever. The modern 9397 is Hell of more awesome in a literal sense (8868 is arguably more awesome in a uselessly nostalgic 'back in my day' sense).

One of many logging trucks made by the Lego Group. Just why do they hate trees so much?

Claw Rig is going for a minimum of $105 on Bricklink. At this point in my life (which was several months ago, since these posts take so long for me to make), I had never bought anything on Bricklink before. I wasn't sure how shipping worked, and the cheapest options were all in Europe. I was pretty worried about that. Through the power of hindsight, I now know that it's prohibitively expensive to ship any Lego sets from overseas. Anyway, Claw Rig has five - count 'em - five of those 8x1 plates-with-whatevers I'll need, giving me a pretty inefficient surplus of two. However, there's a good chance I'll be able to use quite a few other parts from Claw Rig in Giant Truck. Also - I should point out - if I buy a Claw Rig I'll also then have a super sweet Claw Rig that I can play with.

I'm 29, why do you ask?

There's another truck-with-crane option, 8854: Power Crane. This one's from 1989 and it's just a little too funny looking for me. This does show just how awesome those pneumatic functions were, considering this set from '89 has very similar pumps and actuators to the ones you can find on sets today. Power Crane is priced in the 70's on BrickLink (from the Netherlands). It has exactly three of the little plates I need, so there's no unnecessary redundancy. However, the extensive red-ness of Power Crane leaves little room, I think, for other parts I could use, and I wouldn't have that super sweet Claw Rig, so I think I'll pass on this one.

8854: Power Crane, with a face only a mother could love. A mother crane.

Yet another crane option (there isn't really anything more Lego than a crane, I guess - except for maybe a ferry) is 8438: Pneumatic Crane Truck, from 2003. It's a re-release of 8431 (from 2002), which was a re-release of 8460 (from 1995). The early 2000's were a really weird time for Lego. Still, since this wasn't actually made in the early 2000's, it's a cool set. It's a bit less truck than Air Tech Claw Rig, but a bit more crane. Like Claw Rig and Power Crane, Pneumatic Crane Truck takes advantage of the titular Pneumatic functionality to operate, just like a real crane! Since it's smaller than Claw Rig, it's a bit cheaper. It was originally $85, and you can find them on BrickLink for - as of whenever I looked it up - $73 (from the Netherlands, so that isn't really a number that applies to me at all). I really like the look of Pneumatic Crane Truck, and when I put myself into the shoes of younger me (or current-age me, for that matter), it's a tough choice between it and Claw Rig.

8438: Pneumatic Crane Truck - surprisingly hard to say.

The real vintage choice is 8054: Universal Motor Set, from 1989. I guess this is the same amount of vintage as Power Crane, but this one feels more vintage to me. They don't make these 'here are some bits, and some things you can do with aforesaid bits' sets anymore in the Technic label, and I think that's a shame. A lot of things can be learned about Engineering tinkering with one of these, but God forbid we give kids a chance to not know what they're doing, they might make a mistake. Anyway, Universal Motor Set has a crane and a car and another car and a helicopter, plus whatever else you feel like making with a motor in it. This also has a super old-school motor kit which some collectors might be all 'oh baby' over. I'm not super keen on the motor, though, since it isn't in Giant Truck. Universal Motor Set is going for as little as $39 ($45 from somebody in the US).

8054: Universal motor set. It's universal as long as you are building a crane.

Another, much cheaper, option is 8829: Dune Blaster. I had a very similar vehicle to Dune Blaster (8320: Coastal Cop Buggy, from two years later) - but mine doesn't have the parts I need. Dune Blaster is a pretty straightforward buggy that also makes a motorcycle. It has suspension and a moving engine, which is kind of neat I guess. Dune Blaster is going for as little as $17 (from the US) on BrickLink, which is also kind of neat.

8829: Dune Blaster: because dunes don't blast themselves!

If you're a cheapotron, though, the best choice might be 5279: Steering Elements, Plates and Gear Racks. This was just a little sack of bits that you could get to make your Legos able to steer, I guess. Like I said before, the rack and pinion setup was Hell of common in sets back in 'the day' so I really don't know why you would want to get one of these, since these parts were everywhere at the time. Well, I guess maybe you're trying to build Giant Truck and need one of those sweet, sweet 8x1 jobs. It just happens that this sack of bits comes with three of them, so that's handy. It's $5 (from Germany) on BrickLink, so that's pretty handy, too - unless shipping ends up being more than the sack itself. For the money, SE, PaGR offers the smallest barrier to having the parts I need.

5279: Steering Elements, Plates and Gear Racks. 1993's nominee for COOLEST NAME EVER.

If you're an Omega Cheapotron you might say 'just buy three of those parts, dummy.' Well, BrickLink does have a massive (perhaps even Giant) repository of parts for sale from all over the world. I can get those 8x1 plates for as little as $0.07 a piece (that's seven cents). Most places have a minimum total you have to meet with your order, but I'm sure I could get there just by flipping a few pages ahead in Giant Truck's instructions to find a few more parts I need.

Something just feels a little cheap (-otron) about just buying parts, though. It is staying true to the 'building a hot rod in my garage' aesthetic that I'm going for I guess. I can just order all the parts I'll need and get this thing done and then I'll have that Giant Truck I always wanted. However, this endeavor will lose the 'look at how universal Legos are' aesthetic that I was hoping to show off, too. There's something really fascinating about building this big (perhaps even Giant) truck purely from parts scavenged from other sets. Also this whole project may or may not just be an excuse to buy all of the old sets I lusted after but could never get because I was just a Poor Child. Now that I'm a Rich Child I can do all the things I always wanted to do (which is pretty much exclusively buying Legos). On the other hand, is buying some old sets any different than buying old parts, when you get down to it, other than how much more expensive it will ultimately be?

I guess it comes down to what my goal here really is. If this truly is a hot-rod-in-the-garage project, I'd just order the parts I need and get her done, as it were. However, that is a super sweet claw rig.

Spoiler alert: I ordered the Claw Rig.

fields.title: Nonsense, and other nonsense
fields.text:
My name is Shauvon McGill and I will be your guide through the land of nonsense. Now, I understand that calling it nonsense probably doesn’t set it (or me, for that matter) up as a terribly respectable or in fact useful subject. However, just bear with me here, because in my professional opinion, the whole concept of nonsense does not get the respect it deserves. “That’s nonsense!” You might say to me. “Yes, exactly,” I reply. Then you will probably walk away because that’s not a great way for me to retain an audience. I promise that over the next weeks, months, and perhaps years if Kate will keep me around that long, I will show you a thing or two that just might - dare I say it - change the world! I’ll also occasionally tell some jokes, so you might at least have a good time.

Nonsense, malarky, “hoo-haw” - whatever you call it, you can’t deny that it’s actually kind of everywhere. Let’s face it, elevator pitches and business proposals are at least 80% claptrap. Turn on your TV right now - I’d bet good money the majority of your stations are going to be playing commercials at this very second (or some sort of news program). That’s two hundred channels of hogwash (especially those news programs - am I right?). I have sat through many a business conference whose agenda could easily be rewritten as drivel, prattle, a break for lunch, and finally light babble followed by a session of poppycock. To put it simply: Business is Baloney. You may be denying it right now, but search your feelings - on some level you know it to be true.

Here’s the important thing, though: there’s nothing wrong with that. That’s just how people operate, whether it’s business or anything else. Society is baloney. You can have a great idea, an unbeatable passion, or a brilliant mind, but if you don’t have the bunk to back it up, you’re going nowhere. Nonsense is important because it gives our thoughts structure. It transforms thoughts from mysterious unspoken things into real, tangible ideas. Think about this for a minute: you can think up a completely random thought in your brain and somehow transmit that thought in perfect high definition to someone else’s brain using nothing but words. You just mind controlled somebody using pure, homegrown balderdash.

Don’t fight that. Unlock it. Shape it. Manipulate it. Be the Emperor of Nonsense. Once you realize everything anybody has ever said has just been words somebody thought up, you have the greatest power of all: the power of nonsense. Once you learn that power, you’ll be unstoppable.

I’m getting ahead of myself, though (literally). I started this by introducing myself, and I ended up glossing right over that part and going straight to the nitty gritty without establishing just who I actually am. I got carried away with all of my mumbo jumbo. Let me take a step back, then, and establish some of my credentials.

I may be a young whippersnapper, but I am pretty proud of where my career has taken me so far. I graduated from Purdue University with a degree doing computery things back in 2009, at the height of the Great Job Crisis that Christian Bale and Steve Carell created (at least I think so, I haven’t seen that movie yet). That job crisis didn’t affect computery jobs, as it turns out, so off I went to Chicago to earn fame and fortune making apps and websites and working for high profile marketing and technology companies. I was successful, too. Well, maybe not fame so much, but I was really quite successful as a computery, programmery sort of person. I have worked for small start-ups, gigantic corporations, and many things in-between. I became pretty well versed in the language and methodology of business and of corporate America. To put it another way, I have developed a keen grasp of nonsense.

All this was merely a day job, though, as I pursued my real passion, which began for me all the way back when I was a kid: goofiness - I mean, comedy. Goofiness is just something I was born with, like my left-handedness or my ridiculous height (though those both probably contribute to the goofiness, now that I think about it). Comedy, though, is a type of nonsense that is particularly special to me. Who doesn’t love a good joke? Well, the Germans, I guess, but this isn’t Germany. I learned early on how powerful a well-placed punch line can be, and chasing that power led me to study Improv.

I spent four years as a member of an Improv Comedy group at Purdue, and continued to pursue it in Chicago, studying at the prestigious Second City Training Center (people call it the Harvard of Comedy - seriously). I have studied movement, stage combat, Shakespeare, comedy, clowning, and mime (yes, even mime). By day I wore the tie of business and the pants of working in cubicles, and by night I switched the tie with the tie of comedy (they look very similar, but the comedy one is easier to wear on your head). I have discovered that these parallel lives I have been living are not, in fact, so different. Reacting quickly to change, thinking outside the box, solving problems - these are all major parts of Improv, as well as the world of ties and cubicles.

Now it’s time for those worlds to collide. I want to share what I’ve learned about the strengths of Improv, and how these ideas and methods can - dare I say it - change the world! Join me, and by extension The Speaker’s Studio, in this new frontier.

. . . or maybe that’s all just a bunch of nonsense - you be the judge.

fields.title: The Rules of Improv
fields.text:
Imagine floating in space, free from gravity, direction, or orientation (you have a space suit with oxygen, though, so don’t freak out). This is pure, undiluted freedom. Where do you go from there? Where can you go, without any force to direct you or frame of reference to orient you? As humans I think we all need rules of some sort to govern the things we do. It’s comforting to have a structure to work within. We want to know that someone has spent time establishing a framework to keep us going in the right direction, or to keep us safe, or to keep everyone on the same page. This is one of the paradoxes of Improv: to experience freedom, we have to embrace our necessary structures. You can’t think outside the box without knowing what the box is in the first place. Pure freedom is useless without some sort of structure or guidance. Improv, therefore, needs some structure to work around. Improv, despite being an exploration of creative freedom, still needs rules.

I have been doing Improv for over ten years now. To be fair, I guess, since basically everything is made up, I’ve been doing improv for much longer than that. I’m talking about official, laugh at me on stage, capital ‘i’ Improv, not just “making stuff up.” I’m talking about Improv as a performance style. I’m talking about Improv as an art form. It really is, too. If you don’t believe me, I suppose I should be glad I held back from the argument that it’s almost a religion. It’s an incredibly deep and complicated system of beliefs and techniques, with millions of hours of study being conducted as we speak and thousands of different exercises, theories, games, lessons, and platforms being consumed, shared, and preached throughout the world.

Let me just take a moment to establish that you might not agree with me in any way on any of this Nonsense I throw out. That is okay. My goal is to establish the Things that I have observed in the world, and collate them into a set of concepts that work for me. What works for me might not work for you. However, I would ask that you open your mind and take a moment to see things my way, and experiment with my observations. Either you will discover new truths that do, indeed, work for you, or you will discover disgusting lies that will not - either discovery is important and valuable. Discovering a thing that does not work can be as important as discovering something that does. It will get you closer to your own truth either way.

Anyway, I’m going to assume that anybody reading this is already meeting me halfway on the whole “art form” thing, or you’re at least willing to grant me the olive branch of “okay, sure whatever” to see just what I have to say about it. I don’t want to waste a bunch of time trying to make the very basic foundational argument, I want to move on to the implications of that argument. If Improv is an art form, or even a way of life in itself, what do we do with it?

At the basic level, though, let’s just go ahead and define “Improv” so that we have that foundation upon which to build this system. Let us, at least for the sake of the next several paragraphs of text, define Improv as, “empowering the nature of the Human Mind to drive creativity and success in a given field.” Improv lives, of course, in the human mind, and it relies on the natural wiring and functionality of that mind to work. Most, if not all, techniques in Improv are designed to exploit (or perhaps simply direct) the way our minds work. Society conditions us to think in a very specific way, and Improv allows us to unlock that restriction and allow ourselves to think in any way we want. This unlocked mind can then be used to help us do anything, really, from comedy, to general creativity, psychotherapy, emotional awareness, personal development, leadership, public speaking, you name it. Simply put, capital ‘i’ Improv makes us capital ‘a’ Awesome. Of course, it isn’t enough to simply tell someone that she can do anything, though.

Improv is a very personal thing. It taps deep into that core, animal brain, deep in the sensitive, chewy nougat of one’s psyche. This is the strength of Improv, but it also means that everyone who studies it has to develop their own rules. I therefore cannot in good conscience stand before you (or sit behind my keyboard) and declare the definitive, Buzzfeed worthy list of Ten Improv Rules That will Change Your Life. For one thing, it’s still a relatively new art form that has not had time to chisel a series of commandments into any kind of stone tablets. For another, I don’t know if there will ever be a definitive, ultimate list of rules. It’s just too variable from person to person.

What I can share with you are my own personal rules, collected, adapted and organized from my discoveries and experiences. At least, I can share with you how my list looks right at this moment. It, like me, is still an evolving, living organism, and will probably continue to evolve and adapt for the foreseeable future. Feel free to take notes, consider how these rules might apply to your life (or your own Improv work), and adapt them for your own use. I claim no ownership over the nature of the human mind, and I therefore cannot claim to be responsible for any rules governing it. These are simply observations.

We start with the Prime Directive of Improv (don’t worry, there will be a Star Wars reference later), which is the rather ambiguous phrase, “yes, and.” This is the most common rule in Improv, and so I will give it the least attention. You can find entire books (not to mention t-shirts) on the subject of “yes, and” so there is little I can say on the subject that someone else hasn’t already said and been paid a lot of money to say. The core concept is that you should always be accepting of ideas, and constructive. “Yes, and” forms a foundation, where saying “no” or “yes, but” do not. In Improv - I would argue in all of life - all ideas are good ideas, and those offered freely and openly should always be built upon. If an idea doesn’t sound “good enough” for you, you can simply continue building on it until it does. Rejection gets us nowhere.

“Yes, and” is the most common (I won’t say important, but you can feel free to) rule in Improv because it really is the foundation for creativity. The fascinating thing is that all action is really reaction. Even the most creative, unique things in the world are still a reaction to something. Improv, too, though a world of freedom and possibility, is almost entirely reactive, not spontaneous. “Yes, and” is, at its core, a directive simply to react. Listen, pay attention, and respond.

You can practice saying “yes, and” at home. Find a friend, or a colleague, or that guy at work that everybody finds annoying. Strike up a conversation with them. For everything they say, respond with, “yes, and…” and then build on their idea. Tell them to do the same (probably a good idea because you might get in trouble if they catch onto the fact you’re saying “yes” to everything they say). It doesn’t have to be about anything specific, just start brainstorming something. You can quickly get into some pretty interesting territory, where you might not have found yourself otherwise.

I’m afraid that’s all the time we have for today. I know, I promised you a list and gave you only one thing. Why explain in a single post what I can eek out for several, though? I’ll be back very soon with the next rule. Until then, what do you think? Do you agree or disagree with anything I have said so far? How has the concept of “yes, and” come up in your life? How do you think embracing it could help you? Consider those questions as rhetorical or unrhetorical as you wish, taking into consideration the comment box below.

For more stuff like this, check out The Speaker's Studio, or stay tuned for more posts here.

fields.title: Brickworld 2015
fields.text:
Brickworld, the annual (and awesome) Lego event, is coming up in Indianapolis in about a week. You know what that means - it's time to finally get around to posting the pictures I took there last year! Brace yourselves - there are a lot of pictures here.
You might be surprised at how much custom Lego stuff there is. Not just shirts and posters or whatever, but custom minifigures and Lego pieces. Mainly it's stuff to get around Lego's (admittedly tenuous) 'no violence' policy, which makes me a little uncomfortable. There are a lot of tiny firearms you can buy.
There are also lots of minifigures from various licenses that Lego will almost certainly never officially do. Also, there's my Dad.
Anyway, most of Brickworld is tables people have set up with all manor of awesome displays, purely out of their love for Lego.
They aren't trying to sell you anything, or advertise anything, and most of the displays aren't even built specifically for the event, they are just people's personal collections.
Anyway, I'll get out of your way and just let you explore.
That little orange ball thing at the top of this wizard tower was spinning, I believe.
There were plenty of tables selling Lego, too. This one had bins set up to just pick out bulk bricks. I was able to get a small handful of Giant Truck parts. That bin of gray parts was new and old gray mixed together - those pillocks!
This is a replica of some historic firehouse somewhere, I guess. If you look closely, you can see the bagpipe minifigure in the middle there. The kid manning this table went on and on about how valuable he was.
This was about when the official Minecraft sets were coming out, so the big Minecraft area was not using any of the official stuff, so it was completely original.
The fairground mixer was motorized.
I'm not the only one who lost Legos in the vacuum, then.
This is one of the Lego gun makers. I just find it a little sad that we have to arm our minifigures (even though Lego has their own guns, now).
Making battlemech things is a whole sub-genre of MOC (My Own Creation) people. As a huge fan of battlemechs, I have nothing against this. These are super sweet. I'm not sure how to reconcile thinking these are cool but thinking guns are dumb, but here I am.
Vintage space stuff is definitely cool.
Dinosaurs are definitely cool.
This cool droid factory had a lot of moving components, lights, and other special effects. It was a really great, dynamic display.
Brickworld had many great examples of town Layouts. Every Lego town has to have trains, and all of the modular buildings (obviously).
There was a HUGE M-Tron table. it was at least fifty feet long, with tons of super cool stuff. Too bad I didn't get any pictures of it . . . just kidding, let's look.
At the bottom you can see a list of all the collectable minifigures to be found in this display. A few of the tables had those, and it gives you a fun little game to play at each display.
These crazy starships are amazing, but stuff like this is a little hard to look at, really. Okay, dude, I'll just go home and keep working on this blank wall I'm trying to build.
There isn't enough wild west stuff in Lego. I suppose there are legitimate reasons why.
This is a robotic chess set, based on a bunch of Lego Mindstorms units.
Here we see this dude digging through minifigures looking for the Bagpipe Dude. That kid earlier told us just how valuable Bagpipe Dude is, and so we had to see if we could buy one. We could, and I did. It was like $10.
Now we get to this amazing series of kinetic sculptures. This giant square was made up of a ton of individual components, each built by a different person (or team). The idea was that each component moves these tiny balls from one side to the other, using whatever means they can come up with. There were so many awesome ideas, like catapults, gears, wheels, ramps, conveyor belts, and other crazy things.
This one has a counter showing how many balls made it through here. That's a lot of balls.
This was one of my favorites. Those three blurry things are little robotic arms that were picking balls up from the lower platform and putting them on the upper one super fast.
I was excited to see an unopened 5561: Big Foot 4x4 for sale at one of the booths. I bought it - my first actual model team set!

You finally made it through the pictures from 2015, just in time for me to get to Brickworld 2016 and get a couple hundred more! What did you think? What was your favorite thing? Do you have any requests for things I should look for this year? What should I buy?
